title: Dual-Population Evolution-Based Collaborative Optimization for Coordinated UAVs Mission Patrol Under Mountainous Environments_supp1-3645567.pdf
authors: Qingda Chen
publish: N/A
abstract: Uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) play a crucial role in visiting task points to support sector surveillance and maintain environmental and operational stability in mountainous mission patrols. Completing UAV patrol missions requires determining an optimal sequence for visiting task points and planning feasible paths to ensure the UAV safety in the presence of diverse peaks, valleys, and infeasible regions in mountainous environments. To address these issues, we propose a dual-population evolution-based collaborative optimization algorithm (DECOA) for coordinated UAV mission patrol, encompassing both UAV task assignment and path planning, in mountainous environments. First, we design a comprehensive model to represent mountainous environments accurately. Then, DECOA is proposed to address the UAV mission patrol optimization problem using a population-evolution framework applied to the constructed model. In DECOA, two distinct particle encoding schemes are introduced to efficiently convert task assignment and path planning solutions in UAV mission patrol models into representations suitable for optimization processing. Additionally, a dynamic dual-population search strategy is devised to balance exploration and exploitation capabilities. To enhance the global search capability of DECOA in promising regions, an adaptive collaboration mechanism is proposed. Furthermore, to evaluate the performance of DECOA, various scenarios are designed to conduct extensive experiments, focusing on UAV task assignment, path planning, and coordinated mission patrol. The experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed algorithm and validate the effectiveness of the designed test scenarios.

title: Analysis of the Maximum Thermal Sensation in the Veracruz-Boca Del Río Conurbation Zone of the Thermoperivallon from 1981 to 2021
authors: Roberto Díaz-Marchetti
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The analysis of the variable Maximum Thermal Sensation (STA <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$_{\text {max }}$</tex>), during the Thermoperivallon (May 1 to October 31) from 1981 to 2021, was analyzed by regression analysis, ANOVA, Tukey's test and statistical models. The comparison of the results of these analyses with those obtained graphically and which are of daily use by human beings, could provide a clearer approach to the historical behavior of STA <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\text {max }}$</tex> at the local level in the Veracruz-Boca del Río Conurbation Zone (ZCVB) and the trend that this variable would present in the future, being of demand for the well-being of the living beings of this ecosystem. Thus, a scientific analysis is shown based on values plotted and compared with mathematical and statistical results that helped to predict the behavior of the same. This analysis shows that the behavioral pattern of the STA max variable presents a positive trend, whose values constantly exceed 37° C starting in 1989 and continues with this trend until the end of the period (2021). A similar trend to that observed could show high values, which would exceed the limits recommended by the WHO for the safety of people and other living organisms. The regression analysis allowed us to find a forecast with similar characteristics and a positive trend of the slope. Therefore, it can be corroborated that the graphical analysis and the mathematical and statistical analysis of the STAmax variable are scientifically valid to verify the behavior of this variable according to its constant and continuous increase in the ZCVB.

title: CatBoost Optimized with Adapted Reptile Search Algorithm for Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Dusan Cvetkovic, Miodrag Zivkovic, Tamara Zivkovic, Nebojsa Bacanin, Snezana Anetic, Branislav Radomirovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to analyze the potential solutions offered by machine learning and artificial intelligence for intrusion detection systems when applied to problems such as the Metaverse and IoT. The exponential growth of such systems has created a need for better and more efficient detection solutions. The purpose of the research is to quantify and verify the improvement in the results of the classification of traffic provided in the dataset. The methodology of the research is an experimental application of the CatBoost machine learning model, which has been further optimized with the use of a proposed modified reptile search metaheuristic optimization algorithm. The models were developed and validated using data drawn from a real operational environment. Results indicate that by carefully balancing advanced threat detection capabilities with computational efficiency, the proposed framework offers a practical and powerful solution for strengthening security within IoT ecosystems.

title: Forced Oscillation Source Location and Source type Classification
authors: Naga Lakshmi Thotakura, Yi Zhao, Yilu Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: FOs pose significant challenges to power system stability, particularly when their frequencies align with natural system modes, leading to resonance and wide-area impacts. Identifying the precise source location and controlloop origin of such oscillations is critical for timely mitigation. This paper presents a robust spectral energyflow algorithm for FO source localization and type classification at the equipment sub-controller level. The proposed method utilizes a cycle-based sliding window approach to compute cross-spectral energy terms between active/reactive power and frequency/voltage signals, including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{P} \boldsymbol{\omega}}, \mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{P v}}, \mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{Q} \boldsymbol{\omega}}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S}_{\mathbf{Q v}}$</tex>. A composite index is formulated to identify the FO source location, while relative energy dominance among the spectral terms is used to classify the FO as either P-type (active power driven) or Qtype (reactive power driven). The algorithm is evaluated on a synthetic 2000-bus ERCOT test system under various local and inter-area resonance conditions. Results demonstrate accurate localization and reliable source type identification across all test scenarios, including challenging resonance cases. The proposed method offers a practical and computationally efficient solution for real-time oscillation monitoring and diagnosis in large-scale power systems.

title: MetaFSelect: No-Code Metaheuristic Feature Selection for Machine Learning
authors: Muhammed Kotan, Sunusi Bala Abdullahi
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Feature selection (FS) enhances model performance and interpretability but remains challenging due to algorithmic and hyperparameter sensitivity. We introduce MetaFSelect, a stochastic, no-code framework integrating MEALPY, MAFESE, and machine learning models for reproducible metaheuristicdriven FS. Evaluated on six benchmark datasets, MetaFSelect achieved 93.5% feature reduction with only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-21 {\%}$</tex> accuracy deviation, statistically insignificant in four cases (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p>0.05$</tex>), while reducing setup time to under five minutes. The framework unifies automation and statistical rigor for transparent, scalable FS.

title: Super-Resolution of Noisy Images Using L-Estimate Compressive Sensing Filter and Cnn Approach
authors: Andrej Cvijetić, Djordje Stanković, Andjela Draganić, Irena Orović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper proposes an approach for super-resolution of images corrupted by impulse noise by integrating iterative image reconstruction with convolutional neural networks (CNNs). While CNNs are widely used for image super-resolution, they often fail to perform when the input is severely degraded by noise. To address this, pixels with extreme values are first identified as outliers and set to zero, applying an L-estimation based compressive sensing filter to treat them as missing. By doing so, the task is shifted from a traditional denoising problem to a signal recovery problem. A convex optimization-based gradient-descent algorithm is considered to recover the image, providing higher quality input for further processing within the CNN and enabling more effective network performance. The experimental results verify theoretical considerations, showing high performance of the proposed method with PSNR values ranging from 30.90 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$34.88 \mathbf{~ d B}$</tex> and SSIM values between 0.89 and 0.91 on images corrupted with 20 % salt-and-pepper noise.

title: Hybrid Metaheuristic: An Natural Language Processing Application in Log Anomaly Detection
authors: Jovana Arsic, Luka Jovanovic, Snezana Anetic, Csaba Varsandán, Miodrag Zivkovic, Nebojsa Bacanin
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Cloud computing underpins modern information systems, offering scalable and flexible resource management. The massive volume of system logs renders manual monitoring impractical, and real-time error resolution often requires costly human intervention. Proactive anomaly detection offers a scalable solution by leveraging natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning techniques. This study investigates the use of BERT embeddings to represent cloud log data for automated error detection, with AdaBoost classifiers serving as the predictive model. Hyperparameter tuning is performed using metaheuristic optimization, with a modified self-adaptive algorithm (AB-ISASCHO) based on the sinh-cosh algorithm (SCHA) is introduced. Experimental evaluation on real-world cloud log datasets demonstrates that AB-ISASCHO outperforms standard SCHA and other metaheuristics, achieving near-perfect classification metrics and stable objective function scores. The results indicate that integrating BERT embeddings with adaptive metaheuristic tuning substantially enhances both accuracy and reliability, providing an effective methodology for large-scale, automated anomaly detection in cloud computing environments.

title: Fixed Versus Backtracking Step Sizes in Gradient Descent and Nesterov Acceleration
authors: Ana Pletvarec, Ana Sofronievska, Katerina Saneva, Zoran Hadzi-Velkov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Optimization methods are fundamental to machine learning, with Gradient Descent (GD) being one of the most widely used first-order algorithm. However, GD's convergence can be slow for ill-conditioned problems. Two common strategies to accelerate it are: (1) Nesterov's Accelerated Gradient (NAG), which uses a momentum term to achieve an optimal rate of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{O}\left(1 / k^{2}\right)$</tex> for convex functions, and (2) backtracking line-search, which dynamically adapts the step size to enable faster periteration progress. The paper presents a comparative analysis of GD and NAG under both fixed and backtracking step-size strategies. Using a controlled linear regression model, we systematically investigate their performance across different condition numbers and degrees of strong convexity. Our key finding reveals a performance trade-off: in the strongly convex regime, GD with backtracking converges faster than both NAG variants. Conversely, for merely convex problems, NAG maintains its theoretical superiority. These results provide practical guidance for selecting an optimization algorithm based on problem convexity.

title: Advanced Nonlinear State Estimation of Degrading Battery Systems via Unscented Kalman Filtering
authors: Kazi Abdullah Al Imon, Bappaditta Saha Chowdhury, Md Sharif Robbani, Md Asfaqur Rahman, Nahiyan Ahmed, Hasanur Zaman Anonto
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As global reliance on renewable energy sources and electric vehicles increases, the need for advanced BMS becomes ever more critical. Accurate SOC and capacity estimations are essential for optimizing battery performance and longevity. Traditional methods often fall short in addressing the nonlinear dynamics and capacity degradation inherent in modern battery systems. This study investigates the implementation and comparative performance of the UKF alongside the traditional KF within an event-based framework for SOC and capacity estimation. Utilizing a sophisticated simulated battery model that reflects real-world conditions including thermal effects and charge-discharge cycles, the study demonstrates that the integration of UKF and KF significantly outperforms existing methods. The UKF, in tandem with KF, achieves an SOC estimation accuracy within 0.6% of actual values and enhances capacity estimation accuracy by approximately 10% compared to conventional approaches. The findings highlight the potential of employing both UKF and KF to substantially improve the accuracy, efficiency, and reliability of battery management systems. ensuring better energy utilization and extending the operational lifespan of battery-dependent applications.

title: Power Expansion Planning Considering Source-Load Side Influence of Heat Waves and Cold Waves
authors: Kunkan Jin, Dawei Wang, Lili Hao, Mohamed A. H. Elsayed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Frequent occurrences of extreme temperature events, such as heat waves and cold waves, can significantly reduce the output of renewable energy power sources while simultaneously increasing load demand. This exacerbates the imbalance between supply and demand within urban power grids. To address this issue, this paper investigates the influence mechanisms of heat waves and cold waves on the generation, and load sides of urban power grids. By comprehensively considering both conventional scenarios and extreme temperature events, a collaborative expansion planning model for distributed renewable energy sources and pumped storage power stations is proposed. The optimal planning capacity is determined through an iterative solution of a bi-level model, and the effectiveness and economic feasibility of the proposed planning scheme are validated through case studies.

title: Comparing the Performance of 64-Bit Linux File Systems on the Proxmox Virtual Environment
authors: Berk Yildirim, Borislav Đorđević, Nikola Zogović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The goal of this paper is to identify the most efficient guest file system for hypervisor-based Linux environments. To achieve this, we selected Filebench benchmark software to test all file systems in equal conditions. Filebench is a benchmarking tool that simulates different file system workloads to measure performance, providing a controlled environment to ensure fair and consistent results across diverse hardware and OS configurations. We used Proxmox as the hypervisor and Oracle Linux 9.4 as the guest operating system. Performances are measured by testing different type workloads. For instance, Filebench can simulate a file system as if it is a web server or a file server. The results are compared by the outcome of testing each file system with various workloads.

title: Implementation of Quantum PUF in Future Network
authors: Kumar Nilesh, Marc Geitz, Ronny Döring, Christian Deppe, Holger Boche
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Quantum Physically Unclonable Functions (QPUFs) are emerging hardware primitives that harness inherent quantum principle to produce device-specific challenge–response behavior. By embedding quantum-mechanical "fingerprints" into devices, QPUFs can derive unique cryptographic keys and identities, yielding robust hardware roots of trust. This paper systematically reviews QPUF principles, architectures, and security properties, and explores their integration into next-generation networking paradigms with industrial demonstrations. We detail how QPUFs can enable secure device authentication, key generation across quantum communication links, 6G wireless, IoT/edge deployments emphasizing practical implementation strategies and system integration in future networks along with technical challenges. Through this comprehensive analysis, we highlight the transformative potential of QPUFs in delivering hardware-rooted, information-theoretic security for interconnected networks, and outline directions for further research.

title: IT and OT Traffic Separation in Refiners and Petrochemical Industries
authors: Vanlin Sathya, Steve Toteda, Rajeev Shah
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The integration of Information Technology (IT) and Operational Technology (OT) in industrial environments such as refineries and petrochemical plants offers the potential for improved security, performance, and operational intelligence. However, conventional network infrastructures often fall short of meeting the demanding connectivity requirements of such converged environments. This paper explores the capabilities of Industrial 5G (I5G) networks to overcome these challenges by evaluating current IT/OT connectivity solutions—including WirelessHART, LoRa, and Mobile Network Operator (MNO) deployments. We propose I5G-based micro-slicing technology that facilitate robust IT/OT separation segmentation. Additionally, we provide a comparative latency analysis for IT and OT devices under realistic traffic conditions, with and without the use of slicing (MicroSlicing), offering practical insights for effective I5G implementation in industrial settings.

title: Bio-Inspired Optimization Algorithms for Enhancing CRISPR-Cas9 Target Site Prediction Accuracy
authors: Wai Yie Leong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The CRISPR-Cas9 genome editing system has revolutionized precision medicine and synthetic biology through its programmable targeting mechanism. However, the accurate prediction of target sites and off-target effects remains a critical computational challenge due to the complexity of genomic sequences, variability in protospacer-adjacent motifs (PAMs), and the context-dependent nature of DNA-protein interactions. This study proposes a novel framework integrating bio-inspired optimization algorithms-including Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Genetic Algorithms (GA), and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO)-to refine target site prediction models for CRISPR-Cas9. These algorithms are applied to optimize key hyperparameters and feature selection in a hybrid deep learning model combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks. The proposed system is trained and evaluated on high-quality datasets from CRISPRBench and GUIDE-seq, incorporating sequence features, epigenetic markers, and chromatin accessibility data. Results demonstrate a significant improvement in target prediction accuracy, sensitivity, and specificity compared to baseline machine learning models. Furthermore, the bio-inspired optimization framework shows enhanced convergence speed and robustness across varying genome contexts. This work provides a scalable and interpretable approach for improving CRISPR-Cas9 efficacy, with implications for therapeutic genome editing and functional genomics.

title: Quality Control of Products Using Template Press with PLC System
authors: Jeerapath Jommongkol, Kunanon Chuwichit, Parichart Pongsawang, Patiphon Sawaisophon, Sornsiri Thangdee, Kitsada Doungjitjaroen, Kongkarn Vachirapanang, Natthaporn Srichaikham, Tomoki Harano, Manabu Kato, Zacharie Mbaitiga
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: In manufacturing factories requiring mass production, the reliance on labor for product quality inspection poses significant challenges, including excessive time consumption and high rates of human error. These issues may hinder the factory’s ability to scale up to larger production industries. This project addresses these issues by developing an automated quality control system using Reed switches controlled by a Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). The system enhances inspection accuracy, reduces processing time, and improves overall product quality. This system operates by utilizing a reed switch to detect the characteristics of products. If a product conforms to the predefined template, the Reed switch is activated. Conversely, if the product exhibits any protrusions or deformities, the reed switch remains inactive. When a product fails to meet the specified quality standards, the PLC processes the inspection data and transmits a signal to the automated sorting mechanism to promptly remove the non-compliant item from the production line. A test conducted with a total of $\mathbf{1 5 0}$ randomly selected products, consisting of both good items and defective items with defect sizes of $1 \mathrm{~mm}, 2 \mathrm{~mm}$, and 3 mm. The average inspection cycle is 10.53 seconds with a 33% failure rate merely on 1 mm due to mechanical problems of excessive pneumatic pressure. The implementation of this automated system enhances manufacturing efficiency, reduces labor costs, and minimizes human errors

title: Joint Optimization of TAS Scheduling and Synchronization Periodicity in Time Sensitive Networks
authors: Aviroop Ghosh, Saleh Yousefi, Thomas Kunz
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Industry 4.0 applications require deterministic, low-latency and low-jitter communication. Ethernet, when augmented with Time Sensitive Networking standards like Time Aware Shaper (TAS), meets these requirements. For TAS to function accurately, precise network-wide time synchronization is required. However, due to clock drift of network devices, there can still be timing misalignment between devices, disrupting the TAS mechanism and compromising determinism. In our previous work, we proposed adjustment-based scheduling mechanisms that adjust TAS time slots to ensure deterministic latency and zero jitter. Despite their advantages, the approaches can be bandwidth inefficient compared to other forms of scheduling mechanisms. However, their efficiency can be improved by varying the synchronization periodicity.In this paper, we present a novel method to compute the optimal synchronization periodicity in a given network by balancing the synchronization overhead and the time-sensitive bandwidth requirement. This trade-off enables improvement of the overall network bandwidth efficiency without compromising determinism. Further it reveals the existence of an optimal operating region, a range of synchronization periodicity intervals where the network overhead cost remains low and stable. We validate the effectiveness of our approach through simulation-based case studies in realistic network scenarios. Compared to using the default synchronization periodicity value defined by IEEE standards, the proposed method reduces the overall network capacity overhead by up to 72% and 55% for the two scheduling method variants examined in this study.

title: Nyquist Pulse Family for Pulse Shaping in OTFS for 6G Wireless Systems
authors: Shradha Kouloorkar, Renikunta Mallaiah, Abhinav Kumar, Rie Shigetomi Yamaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Orthogonal Time-Frequency Space (OTFS) modulation is a promising technique for wireless communication in high-mobility environments, especially for future 6G wireless systems. Unlike Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM), which sends data in the time-frequency domain, OTFS works in the delay-Doppler domain, where the channel appears more stable and easier to handle. For OTFS to work well, pulse shaping in the time domain is crucial as it affects the communication system’s capability to manage interference and effectively utilize the available bandwidth. Conventional pulse shapes like rectangular, raised cosine, and Gaussian are easy to implement but often lead to Inter-carrier Interference (ICI) and Out of Band (OoB) power leakage, which lowers the communication system’s performance. In this paper, we propose new time-limited Nyquist pulse shapes generated by convolving existing time-domain Nyquist pulses, such as the Double Jump (DJ1) pulse with Better Than Raised Cosine (BTRC) and Gaussian pulse. These new pulses aim to reduce ICI and improve the system performance. Through exhaustive numerical results, we show that for an OTFS communication systems, the proposed pulses outperform the traditional ones in terms of Bit Error Rate (BER) and Peak-to -Average Ratio (PAPR).

title: Double-Inverter Fed Independent Direct Torque Control of Slip-Ring Induction Machine
authors: Lalitendu Sekhar Barik, Himanshu Misra
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: In this article, both the stator and rotor sides of the slip-ring induction motor (SRIM) are controlled using two distinct direct torque control (DTC) strategies, resulting in a dual DTC (DDTC) architecture. The SRIM is treated as a combination of two independent virtual induction machines (IMs), where each IM is operated individually through the stator and rotor terminals, respectively. In this work, a current model-based approach is employed to estimate the stator and rotor fluxes, which eliminates the need for conventional integration-based flux estimation and enabling more efficient digital implementation. Moreover, a flux sharing strategy based on the minimization of total copper losses is proposed to enhance the flux control performance. Further, field-weakening (FW)-based control is investigated under the DDTC scheme, wherein the motor is operated up to 2.2 per unit (pu) speed, with a base speed of 2 pu, in a doubly fed configuration. A flux-sharing mechanism based on airgap and leakage fluxes is considered to determine the appropriate magnitudes of the stator and rotor fluxes. The proposed DDTC approach is experimentally validated using a 2.2 kW SRIM test setup.

title: Novel Random Access Protocol for Resource Efficient mMTC Access in Cell-Free Massive MIMO System
authors: Srinivasan Selvaganapathy, Sharvari Ravindran, Jyotsna Bapat, Debabrata Das
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Extreme device connectivity and high energy efficiency are top requirements for massive machine type communication (mMTC), which can be satisfied by cell free Massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) proposed in 6G. Grant-Free Random Access (GFRA) is an attractive access scheme for MTC traffic characterized by random short data transmissions. In CF-mMIMO systems configured with limited number of pilots chances of pilot collisions increase rapidly with increase in the number of MTC devices resulting in degradation of communication performance. In this paper we propose modified GFRA protocol with collision resolution for CF-mMIMO (GFRA-CR- CFM). The proposed protocol consists of two solution components; dominant AP-based pilot assignment and introduction of a new control signal for collision resolution to separate resources between colliding and non-colliding users of the same AP. The simulation results show that GFRA-CR-CFM achieves more than 20% improvement for mean per-user throughput performance compared to GFRA. The 95th percentile likelihood per user throughput performance of GFRA-CR-CFM is significantly improved by more than 4X times compared to GFRA.

title: Angularly-Resolved 3D Foliage Modeling and Measurements at 60 and 80 GHz: From Stochastic Geometry to Deterministic Channel Characterization
authors: Jiri Blumenstein, Radek Zavorka, Josef Vychodil, Tomas Mikulasek, Jarosław Wojtuń, Jan M. Kelner, Cezary Ziółkowski, Rajeev Shukla, Markus Hofer, Thomas Zemen, Christoph F Mecklenbrauker, Aniruddha Chandra, Ales Prokes
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we show a stochastic approach to generate a 3D model of a foliage, which is then used for deterministic ray-tracing channel modeling. This approach is verified by a measurement campaign at 60 and 80 GHz with 2 GHz bandwidth. The wireless channel is characterized by path-loss and RMS delay spread and we show the angular dependency of those parameters when the receiver is placed on a half-circle around the tree. Besides electromagnetic material properties, the 3D model is characterized by several interpretable parameters, including tree volume, leaf size, leaf density, and the tree crown shape parameter.

title: SAT–Terrestrial Coexistence With Adaptive Beam and Power Control: An SDR-Based Emulation
authors: Sreeram Mandava, Rifat Bin Rashid, Donglin Gao, Vidhitkumar Malaviya, Prasanthi Maddala, Chung-Tse Michael Wu, Ivan Seskar, Narayan B. Mandayam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: With increasing demand for spectrum, the 12 GHz band is ideal for future 5G deployments, due to its abundant bandwidth and favorable propagation characteristics. Despite these benefits, aspiring 5G terrestrial networks pose critical interference and coexistence challenges for incumbent, in-band, and susceptible satellite (SAT) Digital Broadcasting Stations (DVB-S2). This paper leverages directional beam control and power adaptation through a spectrum sharing framework, minimizing interference on terrestrial SAT receivers. Opposing traditionally rigid spectrum sharing regulations, our framework implements an efficient and reproducible Joint Q-Learning algorithm through a Software-Defined Radio (SDR) emulation on the COSMOS testbed. Evaluating this model against realistic 5G transmission parameters and ETSI Rural Macro case study, a notable highlight of our method is demonstrated through the DVB-S2 Receiver Packet Error Rate (PER), restoring up to 98% of the DVB-S2 link’s ideal performance through coordinated Radio Resource Management (RRM). Furthermore, our model sustains a maximum of 48% standalone 5G network capacity in the presence of SAT downlink, showcasing acceptable coexistence despite simultaneous band usage.

title: Integration of a Battery System Into a Hydrogen-Based Energy Storage System and Impact Analysis of Different System Designs and Operating Strategies
authors: Mohamad Hazem Aref, Thorsten Zenner, Gernot Schullerus
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Germany's transition to greenhouse gas neutrality by 2045 requires a significant expansion of renewable energy sources and advanced energy storage solutions. Projections show substantial growth in both energy generation and consumption, along with rising solar and wind capacity. However, because solar and wind are weather-dependent and intermittent, storage systems are needed to smooth out supply fluctuations and match generation to demand. Focusing on a hydrogen-based energy storage system, this study investigates potential optimizations by integrating batteries to improve system efficiency, stability, and cost effectiveness. Simulations are used to analyze the impact of different system configurations and operational strategies on design, performance, and economics, providing insights to guide the development of efficient and resilient storage solutions for smoother integration of renewable energy sources into future energy systems.

title: Rethinking LED Usage in IoT-Based Smart Parking: A Minimalist Approach to Energy Efficiency
authors: Ahcene Bounceur, Foudil Mir, Adel Oulefki, Huseyin Seker, Sebti Foufou, Abbes Amira, Yassine Himeur
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Smart parking systems typically use red and green LEDs to show space occupancy, but this constant operation leads to continuous power consumption. A minimalist LED framework has been proposed, where only green LEDs signal available spaces, eliminating indications for occupied spots. Simulations with 5-watt LED modules show over 40% energy savings during high occupancy. For a 500 -space parking lot, this approach conserves about 8,800 kWh annually, surpassing 7,225 kWh. Scaling this to 100,000 spaces in a smart city can save over 1.7 million kWh each year, equivalent to more than $144,000. This strategy significantly reduces reliance on electricity from fossil fuels, improving sustainability. The minimalist LED control model is both cost-effective and environmentally friendly, with the potential to scale from local to global levels.

title: Energy-Efficient Modulation Analysis: HQAM over Nakagami-m Fading Channels
authors: Sukhsagar, Shubham Bisen, Vimal Bhatia, Nagendra Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Future communication technologies are anticipated to facilitate applications necessitating extremely high data speeds while maintaining energy efficiency. In this regard, hexagonal quadrature amplitude modulation (HQAM) is an attractive technique to achieve high-rate transmission without increasing the bandwidth, due to its dense arrangement of symbols on the two-dimensional plane. Nonetheless, due to its hexagonal lattice structure, accurately assessing the error probability is challenging, if not unfeasible. This paper presents a detailed analysis of the average symbol error probability (ASEP) for HQAM over generalized Nakagami-m fading channels. The study considers both integer and non-integer values of the fading parameter m, which models various multipath fading conditions. HQAM is evaluated for its error performance and spectral efficiency relative to conventional QAM formats. Analytical approximations and numerical methods are employed to derive ASEP expressions under diverse fading scenarios. The results indicate that HQAM maintains lower ASEP across a wide signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) range, even in severe fading. This demonstrates its robustness and suitability for deployment in practical wireless systems. The analysis confirms HQAM as a viable alternative for efficient communication over Nakagami-m fading channels.

title: Enhancing Power Quality of RES Integrated Smart Distribution System Using Hybrid Energy Storage
authors: Jitendra G. Jamnani, Tanvi Upadhyay
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The adoption of renewable energy sources (RES) is increasing rapidly due to their negligible carbon emissions and environmental sustainability. With rising population and continuous technological advancements, the global demand for electricity is also escalating significantly. The integration of RES into conventional power systems offers a promising approach to meet this demand. However, despite their environmental benefits, RES integration introduces several technical challenges, including power quality issues, fault ride-through (FRT) capability, power balance control, and protection concerns. This paper presents a simulation-based study on the impacts of photovoltaic (PV) and wind energy systems on power quality parameters in a radial distribution network. The analysis focuses on key issues such as voltage and power fluctuations, voltage profile deviations, and harmonic distortions. To address these challenges, a hybrid energy storage system (HESS) comprising a battery and a supercapacitor is employed to enhance power quality. The performance of the proposed HESS is further compared with that of a conventional distributed static synchronous compensator (D-STATCOM). All simulations are conducted in the MATLAB/Simulink environment.

title: Severe Alcoholic Hepatitis in a Young Adult Survivor of Childhood Leukemia : Synergistic Impact of Moderate Alcohol Intake and Metabolic Dysfunciton
authors: Yevgeniy Sazhnyev, Michael Wang, Gary Chu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Severe alcoholic hepatitis (AH) is classically a disease of middle-aged adults with years of heavy alcohol use, but in this case we demonstrate that even a young, relatively healthy 23 -year-old can develop life-threatening AH after a short period of moderate alcohol consumption, particularly in the context of metabolic risk factors. This report details the clinical course, management, and recovery of a 23 -year-old male survivor of childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with obesity, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), and prediabetes, who developed severe AH after only two years of social drinking. The case is contextualized within the current epidemiology, pathophysiology, and guideline recommendations, highlighting the synergistic hepatotoxicity of metabolic dysfunction and alcohol, and underscoring the need for vigilance and preventive counseling in at-risk young adults. This case underscores the need for targeted surveillance and preventive counseling in cancer survivors, who represent a growing population at risk for alcohol-related liver disease due to improved long-term survival. By identifying these individuals early and integrating multidisciplinary care, there is potential to prevent severe outcomes and reduce healthcare burden. Current ACG and AASLD guidelines provide limited direction for atypical populations such as young cancer survivors. Our case suggests an urgent need to expand guideline frameworks to include this emerging high-risk subgroup. ()

title: Wavelet-Enhanced GNN with Sparse Residual Inference for Topology Detection in Distribution Systems
authors: Himani Mattoo, Muneeb Mushtaq Sheikh, J.G Sreenath, Praveen Tripathy
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Detecting topology changes in power distribution networks is essential for reliable system operation but is complicated by incomplete sensor data, noisy measurements, and unmonitored switching actions. This work presents a novel hybrid approach that integrates Wavelet-Enhanced Graph Neural Network with Sparse Residual Inference (WEGNNSRI) for effective topology identification. The wavelet-enhanced graph neural network utilizes graph wavelet-based filtering to produce spatially localized state estimates, capturing subtle variations in network conditions despite measurement imperfections. Sparse residual techniques then extract topology-related disturbances by treating line flow changes as sparse signals amidst noise. The proposed method demonstrates superior accuracy and resilience compared to traditional approaches when tested on realistic distribution system scenarios.

title: Recommendations for Technical Standards for Synchronous Machines Co-Located with Inverter Based Resources
authors: Himanshi Sagar, Jitendra Sharma, Anil Kumar Meena, V Thiagarajan, Manju Gupta, Ashok Pal
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Integrated renewable energy projects comprising of co-located synchronous machines and inverter-based resources (IBRs) such as a mix of wind, solar and/or energy storage are being developed to provide firm and dispatchable renewable power. New generators or bulk loads interconnecting to inter-state transmission system in India submit grid interconnection requests to Central Transmission Utility which assesses the compliance of the new resource to the prescribed standards through various simulation studies. The paper would present the dynamic performance of one such Integrated Renewable Energy Project and the challenges faced during the technical compliance validation process of this project. The project under this study comprises of solar photovoltaic (PV) inverters, wind turbine generators (WTGs) and fixed speed pumped storage (PSP) synchronous machines. The paper would illustrate the dynamic analysis of the project for low voltage ride through capability, high voltage ride through capability and primary frequency response capability with the help of simulation studies conducted on the Root Mean Square (RMS) dynamic simulation model and present the technical limitations of such plants observed in the study. Based on the responses observed from the simulations, the paper would provide recommendations for specifying the separate technical standards for integrated projects where synchronous machines are co-located with IBRs.

title: ML-based Predictive Models for Power Consumption in Virtualised O-RANs
authors: Rishu Raj, Genevieve Akude, Urooj Tariq, Daniel Kilper
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As communication networks adopt virtualized and disaggregated architectures, achieving energy efficiency has become increasingly important for both economic and environmental reasons. Traditional methods for power modeling are inadequate in these dynamic software-defined environments due to their inability to model complex and nonlinear factors affecting energy use. We investigate the use of feature extraction and regressor-based machine learning methods for predicting power consumption in virtualized open radio access networks (O-RANs), utilizing datasets from a hardware-instrumented testbed. We test three variants of deep neural networks (DNNs), namely, a standard DNN, a regularized DNN, and a hybrid model combining DNN-based feature extraction with an XGBoost regressor. We evaluate the performance of these models for various system parameters such as transmission gain, modulation/coding schemes, and airtime. We show that the hybrid model consistently outperformed others, achieving a mean relative error below 0.5%. Results suggest hybrid models like DNN-XGBoost offer superior accuracy and could be integrated into O-RAN management tools to enable more energy-efficient network orchestration in future networks.

title: An Overview of Legal Artificial Intelligence Assistants Landscape
authors: Marjan Gusev, Ana Madevska Bogdanova, Nevena Ackovska, Magdalena Kostoska, Dimitar Mileski, Alen Kostov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This survey presents the current landscape of AI legal tools, serving both legal professionals and the general public. It compares existing solutions, while also addressing technological and business challenges that shape their development and use. The findings contribute to a clearer understanding of the role and potential of AI assistants in the legal domain, offering insights relevant to both practitioners and researchers.

title: Ceemdan-Based Multiscale Cnn for Wind Turbine Gearbox Fault Detection
authors: Nejad Alagha, Anis Salwa Mohd Khairuddin, Obada Al-Khatib, Abigail Copiaco
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Wind turbines play a critical role in the shift toward sustainable energy generation. Their operation relies on multiple interconnected components, and a failure in any of these can compromise the entire system's functionality. Detecting faults accurately is challenging due to the intricate, non-linear, and non-stationary nature of vibration signals, influenced by dynamic loading, environmental variations, and mechanical interactions. As such, effective signal processing techniques are essential for extracting meaningful features to enhance diagnostic accuracy. This study presents a hybrid approach for fault detection in wind turbine gearboxes, combining Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) and a Multiscale Convolutional Neural Network (MSCNN). CEEMDAN is employed to decompose vibration signals into intrinsic mode functions, isolating critical features at different time-frequency scales. These are then input into the MSCNN, which performs deep hierarchical feature extraction and classification. The proposed method achieves an F1 Score of 98.95 %, evaluated on real-world datasets, and demonstrates superior performance in both detection accuracy and computational speed compared to existing approaches. This framework offers a balanced solution for reliable and efficient fault diagnosis in wind turbine systems.

title: YEGI: Web Systems Based on Large Language Models to Generate Summaries
authors: Yavé Emmanuel Vargas Márquez, Giovanna Inosuli Campos Flores, Mayra Alejandra Torres Hernández, Roberto Oswaldo Cruz Leija, Jezreel Mejía, Mario, Cesar Ordoñez Gutiérrez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The exponential expansion of scientific articles has generated information overload, making it difficult for researchers and practitioners to identify and analyze relevant information. In this regard, long-form language models (LLMs) hold great promise for the automatic generation of summaries from scientific articles, but they suffer from redundancy, inconsistencies, and limited accuracy. This work presents YEGI, a customization of LLaMA 3.2 small language model (SLM) designed for the automatic summarization of scientific articles. The system integrates REST-like APIs and a web interface that allows for PDF document uploads, processes them, and returns tuned summaries with the help of tunable hyperparameters (temperature, top_p, repeat penalty, repeat_last_n, and num_predict). The methodology employs the CRISP-ML(Q) model, ranging from scope delimitation to testing with standard metrics such as ROUGE. Experimental results demonstrate that YEGI achieves competitive performance compared to both commercial and open-source LLMs (Gemini, ChatGPT, ChatPDF, and Deepseek). In particular, Gemini outperformed YEGI by more than 50%, ChatGPT by less than 30%, ChatPDF achieved comparable results, and YEGI surpassed Deepseek by over 5%. Even when operating in a local environment with limited resources and SLM, YEGI maintains robust performance, highlighting its efficiency and adaptability.

title: Accelerating Reflect Array Design: Leveraging Machine Learning for Design Process Optimization
authors: Golla Srinikhil, Kowsik Nandagopan D, Anand M
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Reflect arrays have emerged as a viable alternative to traditional parabolic reflector antennas, offering high directivity in a compact, planar structure. Passive anomalous reflect arrays, in particular, enable precise control of electromagnetic waves without active components, making them energy-efficient and well-suited for applications in wireless communications, radar systems, and smart radio environments. However, their design process remains complex and computationally intensive, requiring iterative optimization and extensive parameter tuning. This study introduces an automated approach leveraging Machine Learning (ML) to determine the optimal unit cell dimensions of the reflect array for the desired reflection phase shift and to automate the Printed Circuit Board (PCB) layout. By integrating computational design techniques, the proposed method streamlines and optimizes the design process, minimizes human intervention, and enhances efficiency, facilitating more effective Reflect array applications in future wireless communication systems.

title: Transferable Adversarial Camouflage Attacks with Multi-layer Topology Tuning for Intelligent Vehicles
authors: Huan Jiang, Hua Han, Mengchu Zhou, Li Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Deep learning has been widely used in intelligent vehicle perception systems, but its vulnerability to adversarial attacks poses a serious threat to system security. Especially in the physical world, existing adversarial camouflage attacks often face problems such as poor cross-model transferability and visual unnaturalness, which limits their practical feasibility and concealment. To this end, this paper proposes a transferable adversarial camouflage generation method based on multi-layer topology adjustment. Based on the three-dimensional model of the vehicle, this method constructs a multi-layer attention graph and uses depth-first search (DFS) to generate a connectivity graph of the attention region. By adjusting the topological structure of the graph, the perturbation is guided to be reasonably distributed in different attention layers, thereby improving the interference effect on multiple detection models. At the same time, smoothness loss and unprintability loss are introduced to enhance the naturalness and feasibility of camouflage in physical scenes. Extensive experiments in digital and physical test environments show that this method significantly improves the cross-model transfer performance while maintaining the effectiveness of the attack. In the physical attack task, compared with the existing methods, the attack success rates on Faster R-CNN, Mask R-CNN and Deformable DETR reached 56.3%, 48.5% and 93.4% respectively, all achieving the best performance.

title: Fast Lithium-ion Battery Broadband Impedance Identification with Enhanced Mid-to-low Frequency
authors: Wenchao Liu, Guangyang Chen, Zhipeng Yang, Jinhao Meng, Zhengxiang Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Pseudorandom sequence (PRS) offers a rapid impedance measurement solution for lithium-ion batteries. However, PRS suffers from limited accuracy in the mid-to-low frequency range due to the low power content and sparse distribution of harmonics. Motivated by this, a parallel quadratic residue ternary signal with an almost theoretical minimum measurement time is proposed. By enhancing the power in mid-to-low frequency band, the first few low-frequency impedance points can be accurately obtained without any additional filters. Moreover, a two-stage filter with an iterative procedure is introduced, which eliminates outliers using a predefined threshold and obtains the filtered impedance through Fourier series fitting. Experimental validation proves that the proposed method achieves a max normalized root means square error of 0.59% and max absolute residual of 0.48% under various states of charge, states of health and temperatures, confirming its effectiveness for impedance measurement.
