title: Discrete-Time Sliding Mode Based Controller of DC-DC Buck Converter
authors: I. Kovač, S. Huseinbegović, Boban Veselic, Čedomir Milosavljević
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the control of DC-DC buck converter. The control strategy is based on the theory of discrete-time sliding mode control to ensure robustness against parameter variations and external disturbances. The output voltage regulation is achieved using a digital controller that combines discrete-time first-order sliding mode control with a discrete-time realization of the super-twisting algorithm, commonly used in second-order sliding mode control. The design of the proposed controller is performed using a discrete-time model of the DC-DC buck converter. Extensive simulations were conducted in Matlab/Simulink to validate the performance of the control algorithm under varying load conditions and input voltage fluctuations. A comparative study between conventional PI controller and the proposed discrete-sliding mode based controller in tracking of various voltage references under action of disturbances is given.

title: LVQ Dynamic Weighted Network for Long-tailed Hashing
authors: Shenghan Shao, Huailin Zhao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Deep hashing uses binary code to represent images with fast computation speed and efficient storage. Due to the increasing prevalence of long-tailed data in real life, traditional hashing methods are no longer applicable because their training is biased toward head-class samples and ignores tail-class samples. Recently, several long-tailed hashing methods have been proposed. However, current long-tailed hashing methods do not fully explore the extra-class and inter-class relationships within long-tailed data when learning class centers.However, current long-tailed hashing methods use an equal-weighted cross-entropy form in their loss functions and do not adjust the class weights to account for the long-tailed distribution. Due to the small number of samples in the tail classes, the head classes still dominate the gradient updates, and these methods do not fully explore the extra-class and interclass relationships within long-tailed data when learning class centers. To this end, we propose a novel Implicitly Enhanced Long-tailed Hashing with LVQ Dynamic Weighted network (LDWN) for long-tailed hashing. Specifically, we propose using the LVQ (Learning Vector Quantization) algorithm to learn class centers. The centers generated by LVQ utilize the information between each sample of lang-tailed data and the same of different classes, improving the representation ability of tail categories. At the same time, we propose a dynamic weighted network that dynamically learns the weights of each category and improves the weights of tail categories during model training. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms numerous deep hashing models and recent long-tailed hashing methods.

title: Material Parameter Identification for PCB Based on Modal Testing and Multi-Parameter Optimization
authors: Ni Xiuhua, Chen Zinian
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study investigates the vibration reliability of pressure scanner valve PCB laminates. An equivalent model was established through free modal testing and multi-parameter optimization. Vibration data acquisition employed an impact hammer and ICP accelerometers. The Eigensystem Realization Algorithm (ERA) identified the first six natural frequencies and mode shapes, which were validated using the Modal Assurance Criterion (MAC) matrix. A parametric ANSYS model compared to compare three parameter identification methods: (1) least squares optimization of an isotropic model; (2) RSM optimization of an isotropic model; and (3) RSM optimization of an orthotropic model incorporating parameter sensitivity analysis with Kriging modeling. Results demonstrate that the orthotropic model achieved a 2.19% average frequency error, significantly outperforming optimized isotropic models. It also exhibited superior correlation with the experimental mode shapes. This approach accurately captures PCB laminate dynamic characteristics, providing a basis for the dynamic design of pressure scanner valve PCBs.

title: Design of a Tendon Sheath Inflammation Massage Glove Based on an STM32 Microcontroller
authors: Zhao Yu, Wenping Jiang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Tendon sheath inflammation is a common occupational disease of the hand, usually caused by repetitive movements or prolonged static postures, and often accompanied by discomfort and pain. According to traditional Chinese medicine theory, appropriate stimulation of specific acupoints on the hand can promote blood circulation, relieve inflammation, and reduce muscle fatigue. In this study, we designed and implemented an STM32 microcontroller -controlled massage glove for tendon sheath inflammation therapy. The glove employs a gear - rack transmission mechanism to drive massage heads for precise acupoint pressure, enabling multi level force adjustment and multiple automatic massage modes. The system consists of a hardware actuation module, sensor feedback unit, main control chip, driver circuit, and human - machine interface, and incorporates graded pressure control and a time-based safety protection mechanism to ensure safe and comfortable operation. Experimental results demonstrate that the device is compact, easy to wear, and offers adjustable massage effects, indicating its potential for home healthcare and rehabilitation assistance.

title: Characterizations of Isoberlina Fiber Reinforced Recycled Low-Density Polyethylene Composites
authors: Uwaisu Yusuf, Nasiru A. Sani, Joseph Jacob, Nasir Sharif, Tushar Janardan Pawar, José Luis Olivares-Romero, Javier Vallejo-Montesinos, J. Oscar. Jimenez-Halla, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Recently, environmental pollution caused inadequate plastic waste management have highlighted the need for sustainable solutions that can transform waste into high-value materials for structural applications. In this study, we present recycled low-density polyethylene (rLDPE) composites reinforced with natural Isoberlina fiber, which enhances mechanical performance and industrial viability. The rLDPE compounds reinforced with Isoberlina fiber were produced following standard compounding and molding procedures in accordance with ASTM/ISO standards. We characterized these compounds using dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) to assess their temperature resistance. Additionally, we evaluated various properties of the materials, including density, water absorption, tensile strength, elasticity, flexural strength, Shore hardness, and creep behavior. inadequate plastic waste management has necessitated sustainable solutions that transform waste into materials with high added value for structural applications. Composites with 50 % fiber by weight exhibited the best performance, characterized by a tensile strength of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> approximately 71 MPa, a stiffness modulus of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> approximately 3.89 GPa, a flexural strength of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> roughly 77.1 MPa, and a hardness of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> approximately 68.6 Shore. In DMA, the storage modulus reached <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathbf{4. 0 ~ G P a}$</tex> for the compound with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 0 \%}$</tex> fiber, compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx \mathbf{0. 4}$</tex> GPa for the unreinforced rLDPE, reflecting a marked increase in elastic load-bearing capacity. The loss modulus decreased with increasing temperature and frequency, suggesting lower viscous dissipation and better matrix-fiber load transfer. In creep tests, the reinforced composite exhibited a longer equilibrium time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx$</tex> approximately 37.6 min) and a lower deformation rate than the unreinforced rLDPE. The use of Isoberlina natural fiber improves LDPE waste, resulting in high-performance composites with enhanced mechanical, dynamic, and service properties. This approach provides a technical and scalable method for transforming plastic waste into lightweight structural components, supporting circular economy strategies and replacing conventional materials in non-critical applications.

title: Collaborative Learning and Motivation in Virtual Environments: A Comprehensive Proposal for Online Education
authors: Roxana Villanueva, Karina Mariela Figueroa Mora, Christian Erik Casillas Farfán
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The education system offers a vast number of virtual courses covering diverse topics. The main challenge with these courses is maintaining student engagement and preventing dropouts. This task is not simple, as it requires incorporating elements that help students avoid feelings of isolation, promote interaction among peers, and, above all, provide access to platforms that enable instructors to foster meaningful engagement. This article presents the design and implementation of a game that promotes collaborative learning, particularly suited for online courses. Various types of online courses can benefit from this approach, including those focused on science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM); language learning; social sciences; and professional development programs-especially those that rely on teamwork and problem-solving. Additionally, the article reports the results obtained from applying the USU usability test and a user experience survey, which provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and reception of the proposed game within online learning environments. The presented case study offers encouraging feedback, supporting the continued use of this strategy in virtual courses.

title: Demand Side Management System for Buildings to Optimise Peak Demand
authors: Rajeev Kumar Chauhan, Kalpana Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Due to the shortage of peak demand, many residential consumers especially at rural locations, have poor grid connections (i.e. grid is available for a slot of few hours or multiple slots of a few hours in a day). The residential consumer has to live without electricity or must arrange their own power back up (i.e. battery or fuel generator) to supply building load during grid outage. This paper presents a demand side management scheme for a poorly grid connected residential building to switch ON/OFF the appliances in grid connected and isolated modes. The model is developed in the MATALB. The DSM response regulates the scheduling of appliances in a predictive and efficient way and kept the peak power within a predetermined limit. The results show that the DSM scheme reduces the building demand during peak hours of grid. Moreover, it also keeps the building demand curve more flatter during grid outage mode. The results show that DSM reduced the size of the battery and their capital cost as well as helping to grid during peak hours by reducing their load. Moreover, it increases the electricity reliability at low cost.

title: A Review of Multimodal Dynamic Facial Expression Recognition Based on Unimodal Pretrained Models Transfer
authors: Xiangshuai Kong, Wanjun Yu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: With the rapid development of affective computing, dynamic facial expression recognition (DFER) has gradually become a key technology in applications such as human-computer interaction, intelligent surveillance, and virtual assistants. However, multimodal dynamic facial expression recognition in wild environments faces numerous challenges, including insufficient data diversity, modality inconsistency, and environmental complexity. To improve recognition accuracy and reduce reliance on large amounts of labeled data, transfer learning methods based on unimodal pretrained models have gained widespread attention in multimodal DFER. This approach leverages models pretrained on unimodal tasks, combining transfer learning techniques to apply them to multimodal tasks, effectively addressing the heterogeneity between different modalities and the lack of labeled data. Based on this idea, this paper systematically reviews the multimodal dynamic facial expression recognition methods based on unimodal pretrained model transfer, focusing on the key issues faced during transfer and analyzing and comparing different strategies for solving these problems. The discussion provides new directions and practical references for future research in the field of facial expression recognition, particularly in the application of transfer learning and modality alignment, aiming to promote the implementation of more accurate and robust expression recognition systems.

title: Task Parsing and Verification for Laboratory Automation via Large Language Models
authors: Wen Zheng, Xiaohu Yuan, Libowen Wu, Jing Wang, Shuli Lou, Zhanguo Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Traditional chemical automation systems typically rely on specialized scripting languages or fixed execution formats, which severely constrain user experience and the flexibility of experimental control. To address the limitations inherent in conventional experimental planning and execution workflows, we propose an interactive experiment automation framework driven by large language models. This framework is capable of comprehending natural language instructions through multi-turn dialogues and converting them into structured experimental plans, which are subsequently validated and executed by robotic systems. We conducted experiments to evaluate the system’s accuracy, generalizability, and robustness across diverse scenarios. The results demonstrate that our approach significantly enhances the intelligence and usability of laboratory automation.

title: Quality Of Experience Aware Digital Twin Enabled Heterogeneous Community Network
authors: Dhivvya J P, Akhila Sreenivas K, Maneesha Vinodhini Ramesh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Poor last-mile connectivity and the high Quality of Service (QoS) demand of applications like video conferencing can significantly degrade the Quality of Experience (QoE) of users. This study addresses the digital inclusion challenges of underserved areas by proposing a five-layered Digital Twin-enabled Heterogeneous Community Network (DT-HCN). The Physical layer consists of backhaul and fronthaul connectivity enabled through a Software-Defined Wireless Network. Data Acquisition layer gathers QoS metrics through a Software Defined Network (SDN) controller. Digital twin layer incorporates access, usage and outcome data models that incorporate Artificial Intelligence Techniques. The Application layer focuses on Digital literacy, IoT-enabled services, QoS-driven resource management and QoE aware internet applications. Visualization layer provides relevant dashboards for various stakeholders. Proof-of-concept results demonstrate improved video conferencing stability through adaptive bandwidth allocation and reinforcement learning based QoE optimization. This approach highlights the potential of digital twin systems in effectively automating the community networks in rural areas.

title: Phase-Filtered Neural Network Based Digital Predistortion for PA Linearization in 5G Systems
authors: Girish Chandra Tripathi, Anindya Saha, Shrinivas Bhat, Ratnesh Kumar Gaur, Ramesh S
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel and hardware efficient digital predistortion architecture aimed at improving the linearity of wideband power amplifiers (PAs) in 5G New Radio (NR) systems. To address the challenges posed by high peak-to-average power ratios and wideband nonlinear distortions, the proposed solution combines a time delay feedforward neural network with a zero-phase digital filtering module for phase-consistent signal preprocessing. This phase compensated approach enhances the neural networks ability to learn PA memory effects and nonlinear characteristics from in-phase and quadrature (I/Q) inputs. The use of the h-Swish activation function further improves gradient stability and training efficiency while minimizing computational complexity. Experimental validation is conducted using a 100 MHz 5G NR test signal at 3.5 GHz transmitted through a wideband Doherty PA. The Results demonstrates a significant improvement, achieving an adjacent channel leakage ratio of - 52.81 dBc, an error vector magnitude of 2.49%, and a normalized mean square error of -38.13 dB. These findings highlight the systems potential for real time deployment in 5G and beyond, offering a scalable and practical solution that balances high performance with hardware feasibility.

title: Neural Network-Based Computation of Robot Manipulator Configurations from Cartesian Coordinates
authors: Luis Roberto Cruz-Caos, Julio Antonio Caballero-Mora, Luis F. Marín-Urias, Rogelio de J. Portillo-Vélez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work proposes a neural network characterized by low computational cost, compared to traditional methods, for computing a robotic manipulator's joint positions from desired Cartesian coordinates. The benchmarked methods include Inverse Kinematics (IK) via iterative Newton-Raphson method, Kinematic Control (KC) evaluated using both Euler and RungeKutta numerical integration, as well as a Recurrent Neural Network (RNN); all of them with and without angular constraints on the End-Effector (EE). The performance metrics considered are: the Cartesian error, the computation time, and the efficiency. The results show that point-by-point KC using Euler integration achieves the lowest Cartesian error in the shortest computational time, offering high-precision convergence. However, the RNN demonstrates only a slightly higher Cartesian error compared to KC, while significantly reducing the overall computational time when evaluating large datasets, due to its ability to perform simultaneous inferences on the entire input set.

title: Performance Benchmarking of Edge Devices for Real-Time Facial Recognition Systems
authors: Oscar Fernando Lozada Herrejón, Rogelio Ferreira Escutia, Adrián Núñez Vieyra, Juan Carlos Olivares Rojas, Miguelangel Fraga Aguilar, Marco Vinicio Chávez Baez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Currently, within the field of Computer Vision in Robotics, algorithms that work in real time are required, so they must be processed as quickly as possible and locally on Edge Devices. Therefore, it is necessary to analyze which algorithms are better and on which devices they can run faster. This article presents a performance comparison of three algorithms for realtime facial recognition, Histogram of Oriented Gradients (HOG), Haar Cascades and Multi-Task Cascaded Convolutional Networks (MTCNN) implemented on embedded systems (Raspberry Pi 5 and Jetson Orin Nano) and a reference laptop. We evaluate the models across multiple metrics including accuracy, frames per second (FPS), CPU/GPU utilization, and memory consumption. Our experimental includes a sequential benchmarking system that automatically collects and visualizes performance data. Results demonstrate significant differences in resource efficiency and detection accuracy between the models, providing practical insights for real-world embedded vision applications.

title: Hilbert-Huang Transform-Based Time-Frequency Analysis for Bearing Fault Diagnosis in Rotating Machinery
authors: Ngoc Quy Hoang, David I. Ibarra-Zarate, Jose Manuel Nieto-Jalil, Juan Manuel Martinez Huerta, Adrián Isrrael Tec Chim, Jorge Alvarez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Bearing faults are a leading cause of failures in industrial rotating machinery, making their early and reliable detection essential to reduce downtime and maintenance costs. A Hilbert-Huang Transform (HHT) based methodology is proposed for early bearing fault detection. The Empirical Mode Decomposition (EMD) isolates fault-related Intrinsic Mode Functions (IMFs), which are selected automatically using the Kurtosis-RMS (KR) criterion. Envelope Spectrum analysis is then applied to the reconstructed signal for diagnosis. The proposed method achieved 94% accurate IMF selection and over 85% fault identification accuracy across 18 signals from the CWRU, TianYau Wu, and MFPT databases. Compared with conventional FFT and Envelope Spectrum techniques, the approach improves early fault detection under noise and variable load conditions while reducing manual analysis time.

title: An AI-Powered Multi-Agent Ecosystem for Cost-Effective Planning and Expansion of Telecommunication Access Network
authors: Nermin Goran, Semir Ibrahimović, Elma Avdagić-Golub
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The expansion of telecommunication access networks is constrained by static planning methods unable to process diverse, dynamic data. To address this, we propose a novel Multi-Agent System (MAS) where autonomous, domain-specialized AI agents collaboratively evaluate criteria for network expansion. The framework uniquely integrates structured and geospatial data with insights from unstructured documents via a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) component and synthesizes the agents' collective findings using the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP) to transparently weigh decision factors. This work provides a scalable, explainable, and methodologically robust framework for dynamic network planning.

title: Multimodal Large Language Model Framework for Safe and Interpretable Grid-Integrated EVs
authors: Jean D Carvalho, Hugo T Kenji, Ahmad Mohammad Saber, Glaucia Melo, Max Mauro Dias Santos, Deepa Kundur
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The integration of electric vehicles (EVs) into smart grids presents unique opportunities to enhance both transportation systems and energy networks. However, ensuring safe and interpretable interactions between drivers, vehicles, and the surrounding environment remains a critical challenge. This paper presents a multi-modal large language model (LLM)-based framework to process multimodal sensor data-such as object detection, semantic segmentation, and vehicular telemetry-and generate natural-language alerts for drivers. The framework is validated using real-world data collected from instrumented vehicles driving on urban roads, ensuring its applicability to real-world scenarios. By combining visual perception (YOLOv8), geocoded positioning, and CAN bus telemetry, the framework bridges raw sensor data and driver comprehension, enabling safer and more informed decision-making in urban driving scenarios. Case studies using real data demonstrate the framework's effectiveness in generating context-aware alerts for critical situations, such as proximity to pedestrians, cyclists, and other vehicles. This paper highlights the potential of LLMs as assistive tools in e-mobility, benefiting both transportation systems and electric networks by enabling scalable fleet coordination, EV load forecasting, and traffic-aware energy planning.

title: Design of Pulse-Shaping Circuits for Electrostatic Discharge Generator
authors: Anja Kovacevic, Dragan Olcan, Antonije Djordjevic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We present a design of pulse-shaping circuits for an electrostatic discharge (ESD) generator. The circuit model is derived by approximating the transfer function for the discharge current waveform defined in the IEC 61000-4-2:2008 standard. Two different printed circuit boards of the same schematic were designed using 3D electromagnetic modeling. The performances of the designed and prototyped pulse-shaping circuits were tested by measuring the discharge current. The measurement results are compared with the results obtained from circuit and full-wave electromagnetic simulations. The results show that placement of elements and their parasitics have significant influence on the output current pulse.

title: Channel Estimation for STAR-RIS-Enabled UAV Communications
authors: Saumya Chaturvedi, Vivek Ashok Bohara
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of channel state information (CSI) estimation in communication systems facilitated by simultaneously transmitting and reflecting (STAR) reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) integrated with unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). While STAR-RIS technology, featuring simultaneous transmission and reflection capabilities, promises significant improvements in coverage and performance, its implementation suffers from CSI uncertainties. To overcome this, we propose a three-step channel estimation protocol specifically designed for STAR-RIS systems. Our approach optimally leverages UAV positioning and STAR-RIS capabilities to minimize normalized mean square error (NMSE). Simulation results highlight the proposed scheme’s superiority over benchmark methods under diverse configurations, including variations in path loss, UAV height, and trajectory adjustments. The findings highlight the scheme’s potential to enhance channel estimation accuracy and overall system reliability in next-generation wireless networks.

title: Orthogonal Chirp Division Multiplexing-aided NOMA System with Imperfect SIC Errors
authors: Rahul Makkar, Divyang Rawal, Sandhya Soni, Rohit Rana, Vijay Kumar Chakka, Pei Xiao
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Next-generation 6G communication systems are envisaged to support ultra-reliability and massive connectivity with sensing capabilities. Orthogonal chirp division multiplexing (OCDM) offers intrinsic benefits such as schemes that endorse pulse compression and spread spectrum in radar and communication systems. On the other hand, non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) is a substantial scheme serving multiple users in the code-, time-, or frequency-domain. This paper proposes the integration of OCDM with downlink power-domain NOMA to leverage their complementary strengths—achieving enhanced reliability and connectivity. Using the Fresnel transform for OCDM, the average bit error rate (BER) results for the OCDMNOMA system are presented with imperfect successive interference cancellation (SIC) errors. The proposed systems’ BER performance is notably presented for downlink two-user NOMA systems with imperfect SIC errors. Monte-Carlo simulations of BER are shown for the aforesaid system over transmit SNR and power fraction coefficient variation.

title: Leakage Rate Analysis for Untrusted RIS with Imperfect CSI
authors: Volkan Özduran
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates the leakage rate performance of an untrusted reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-assisted system under imperfect channel state information (CSI), resulting from channel estimation error (CEE) and feedback delay (FD). The study investigates a scenario in which a single mobile terminal communicating with a base station through an untrusted RIS operating in either passive or absorptive mode. To mitigate information leakage, a limited number of friendly jammers are deployed to interfere with the untrusted RIS. Outage probability is used as the performance metric to evaluate the system's leakage rate. Analytical and Monte Carlo simulation results reveal that CEE introduces coding gain losses in the low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) regime, but its impact becomes negligible at high SNR. In contrast, F-D has no notable effect at low SNR but causes performance degradation in the high SNR regime. In both cases, friendly jammers contribute additional coding gain losses at high SNR. However, increasing the number of RIS reflecting elements significantly reduces these adverse effects. Finally, the results demonstrate that the untrusted RIS in passive mode outperforms the absorptive mode, primarily due to differences in the energy reflection coefficient.

title: Hybrid Dual-Heterogeneous Knowledge Distillation Network for Anomaly Detection in Retinal OCT Images
authors: Muhao Xu, Hua Wei, Zihan Nie, Xueying Zhou, Baochen Fu, Hongmei Yan, Yi Wan, Weiye Song
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Unsupervised medical anomaly detection aims to identify abnormal images by training exclusively on normal samples, thereby enabling the detection of disease related irregularities without the need for large-scale labeled datasets. Current knowledge distillation-based methods typically detect anomalies by comparing feature discrepancies between teacher and student networks. However, because these methods employ an optimization strategy where the teacher and student architectures are highly similar, the student network's features tend to closely mirror those of the teacher, leading to an identity mapping issue. Moreover, the diversity of lesion types in retinal Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) images further complicates anomaly detection. In this paper, we propose a novel hybrid dual-heterogeneous knowledge distillation network to overcome these challenges. Our approach consists of a teacher network with an encoder-only architecture and a student network that integrates an encoder with dual decoders. This heterogeneous design effectively mitigates the identity mapping problem, enhancing sensitivity to both structural and logical anomalies. Specifically, our Multi Feature Model leverages convolutional and depthwise convolutional blocks to extract and integrate local features for structural anomaly detection, while the Mamba UpNet employs self-supervised learning to capture long-range dependencies and global anomaly patterns. Extensive experiments on two retinal OCT anomaly detection datasets demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance, effectively handling diverse anomaly types. The source code is available at https://github.com/Xmh L/HDHKD.

title: Coverage Analysis of Aerial Users in Intelligent Reflecting Surface-Aided Cellular Networks
authors: Hongtao Zhang, Di Yi, Nan Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Due to the down-tilt of BS antennas to serve ground users in existing networks, aerial user equipments (AUEs) are only supported through the side lobes, which leads to insufficient aerial coverage. Fortunately, intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) possess the remarkable ability to offer extra signal power to enhance AUEs’ coverage. However, to fully realize the potential of the IRS, its deployment is contingent upon the radiation pattern of the BS which substantially modifies the network topology. This paper proposes a novel IRS-based network model to serve AUEs by constructing the virtual LoS air-to-ground links to provide targeted signal for AUEs, where IRSs are practically distributed in the BS main lobe to effectively utilize the BS radiation power. Specifically, the distribution of IRSs is modeled by a variant of the Matérn cluster process (MCP), based on which the correlated interference from BSs and IRSs introduced by their location correlation is theoretically characterized. Furthermore, based on a concise two-lobe model for BS antenna gain, the effective distribution area of IRSs is derived as a ring concentric with the cell, which exhibits tunability in accordance with the beamwidth and the tilt angle of the BS antenna. In addition, the framework is characterized for analyzing the correlated interference from BSs and IRSs through the accurate integration of the power correlation associated with both direct paths and IRS-reflected paths. Leveraging stochastic geometry, theoretical expressions of network metrics are derived on the IRS-assisted AUE networks. Numerical results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme, as manifested by the significant elevation in the coverage probability of AUEs by 67% when the number of elements per IRS hits N = 2000.

title: Safety-Critical Disturbance Rejection Control for Capsizing Prevention of an Unmanned Sailboat
authors: Bo Peng, Zhengru Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The capsizing of unmanned sailboats primarily results from strong winds, high waves, and improper maneuvering. However, most existing unmanned sailboat control approaches do not explicitly address roll dynamics or capsizing prevention. This paper investigates the capsizing prevention of an unmanned sailboat in the presence of the model uncertainties and unknown environmental disturbances. A safety-critical disturbance rejection control method is proposed to ensure the safe maneuvering of unmanned sailboat. Specifically, an extended state observer is presented to not only filter the velocity measurements, but also estimate the total disturbance composed by the model uncertainties and unknown environmental disturbances. By using the backstepping technology, the virtual guidance and control law is then derived. Both the control barrier function (CBF) and the input-to-state safe CBF are introduced to construct the safety condition. Based on the safety constraint, a quadratic programming problem is formulated to obtain an optimal safety-critical control law. Furthermore, the input-to-state stability of the closed-loop system is proven by Lyapunov theory, while its input-to-state safety is guaranteed. Comparative simulations under different disturbance scenarios using the developed high-fidelity unmanned sailboat model demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed control method in capsizing prevention.

title: A framework for characterizing 3D structures of crevasses and rifts across Antarctic ice shelves
authors: Ao Pang, Qi Liang, Christina Hulbe, Tian Yang, Quan Zhou, Martin Forbes, Xiao Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Brittle failure by crevasses and rifts formation is the most directly observable expression of stress state in glacier ice. Both satellite imagery and satellite altimetry are effective tools for characterizing them. However, the ice shelf surface exhibits non-fracture-related features that can appear similar to crevasses and rifts in images or elevation profiles, making it challenging to distinguish them using a single observational perspective. Here we combine satellite altimetry and satellite imagery to map these fracture features and provide their three-dimensional structure. During this process, we develop a novel algorithm for detecting and characterizing depressions on the ice surface using Ice, Cloud, and Land Elevation Satellite-2 (ICESat-2) L2A Global Geolocated Photon Data, Version 6 data set (ATL03). The strengths of the algorithm include estimation of surface elevation in 10 m along-track segments, broad applicability to different crevasse types, and robustness against surface irregularities. We apply this workflow to the Thwaites Eastern Ice Shelf (TEIS) as a case study and estimate the general depth and width of various crevasse types. Integrating altimetry with imagery, we find that V-shaped depressions, occurring at the early-stage of fracturing, could serve as an indicator of development of large-scale surface crevasses. Within the shear zone upstream of the pinning points, apart from shear failure, the ice surface also deforms due to strong compression, creating peaks a few meters high. This study highlights that including three-dimensional morphology in the detection and analysis of ice shelf crevasses and rifts improves the ability to distinguish between crevasse types and provides insights into ice shelf deformation.

title: Detection of Lymph Node Invasion Using Digital Holographic Images and Machine Learning
authors: Violeta Liuba Calin, Nicolae Tarba, Mona Mihailescu, Adrian Vasile Dumitru, Ana Lucia Asmarandei, Andrei Marian Niculae, Tudor Savopol, Mihaela Georgeta Moisescu
publish: IEEE Photonics Journal
abstract: An accurate detection of the spread of colorectal cancer to lymph nodes is a critical factor in determining the patient prognosis and treatment. Standard histological evaluation faces significant challenges that start from the intrinsic fragility of lymph node tissues, making them difficult to process and prepare for analysis, and from the subsequent manual review of slides, demanding extensive reading time from pathologists. There is a need of computer assisted diagnostic companion of the pathologist that provide objectivity and workflow efficacy. To address this, our study introduces an innovative approach that combines label-free imaging with machine learning (ML) for detection of metastatic invasions into lymph nodes. We utilized a Digital Holographic Microscope to obtain quantitative phase images (QPIs) of unstained samples. QPIs were cropped in superpixels that were classified with two supervised machine learning models (coarse and fine models) based on phase-shift parameters extracted from each superpixel. The ML-based procedure classified pixels with 97.91% Sensitivity and 98.62% Specificity into normal and invasion classes, and delineated invasion and areas with high suspicion grade from normal areas in segmented images. Our tool supports the clinicians in identifying malignant areas and focusing their expertise on the tumor boundaries, representing a step forward in computer-assisted cancer diagnosis.

title: Data-Driven Collaborative Traffic Steering Based on A1 Policy in O-RAN
authors: Tae-Yeong Kim, Young-Ik Park, Jonghyeon Won, Dong-Wook Suh, Jang-Won Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we study data-driven collaborative traffic steering (TS) in the open radio access network (O-RAN) with two types of RAN intelligent controllers (RICs): non-real-time RIC (Non-RT RIC) and near-real-time RIC (Near-RT RIC). These RICs collaborate for TS through a standardized A1 policy, known as the traffic steering preference (TSP), which enables the use of long- and short-term data that represent traffic, user equipment (UE), and cell characteristics. This collaboration facilitates adaptive TS that responds to dynamic network conditions when beneficial, while avoiding unnecessary adaptations that may degrade long-term performance. We develop a deep neural network (DNN)-based data-driven algorithm capable of capturing intricate relationships among heterogeneous features representing traffic, UE, and cell characteristics. In our algorithm, Non-RT RIC utilizes a DNN model with long-term data to generate the TSP, which is then delivered to Near-RT RIC. Near-RT RIC, in turn, jointly utilizes the received TSP with short-term data to adjust handover (HO) parameters. Through simulations, we show that our algorithm effectively performs adaptive TS by leveraging both long- and short-term data.

title: Directional Modulation Design for Three Signals Using Crossed-Tripole Array
authors: Srinivasarao Chintagunta, Diya Sandeep
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper proposes a directional modulation (DM) technique for transmitting three signals of the same frequency simultaneously in the intended direction while scrambling them in all other directions. The method exploits a uniform linear array of tripoles and orthogonal polarization states to achieve this, thereby enabling security at the physical layer. Simulation results are presented using quadrature phase shift keying symbols for each of the three signals. As a result, the combined signal is equivalent to a 64-order quadrature amplitude modulation, which increases the system capacity.

title: Probabilistic Forecasting Accuracy Assessment for GW-Scale Solar PV Plants: Leveraging CRPS and Ensemble Methods for Grid Resilience
authors: Vikas Pratap Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As solar photovoltaic (PV) installations scale to gigawatt (GW) capacities, accurate power forecasting becomes critical for grid stability, economic dispatch, and renewable integration. Probabilistic forecasts, which capture uncertainty, are increasingly vital for GW-scale plants due to their large spatial footprints and weather-driven variability. This article evaluates error metrics for assessing solar PV power forecasting accuracy, with a focus on the Continuous Ranked Probability Score (CRPS) and its integration with ensemble forecasting methods. We analyze the suitability of CRPS, Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and normalized variants for GW-scale applications, emphasizing their operational and economic implications. Through a case study of a 1 GW PV plant, we demonstrate CRPS's effectiveness in evaluating probabilistic forecasts derived from ensemble methods, such as Numerical Weather Prediction (NWP) ensembles. The study provides actionable insights for grid operators and researchers, advocating for CRPS as a cornerstone metric for large-scale solar forecasting. Our findings underscore the need for standardized error metrics to enhance grid resilience and support the global transition to sustainable energy

title: Message Passing Neural Networks for Sound Source Localization
authors: Matija Marijan, Miloš Bjelić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Sound source localization (SSL) is a fundamental problem in audio signal processing. Traditional SSL approaches often degrade in challenging acoustic conditions, while more recent deep learning-based methods struggle to generalize to unseen microphone arrays or to fully exploit the relationships between microphones in an array. We propose Graph-RelNet, a graph-based neural network that extends relation networks with residual graph convolutional layers to regress the direction of arrival (DoA) from generalized cross-correlation with phase transform (GCC-PHAT) features. Experiments on the TIMIT speech corpus demonstrate that Graph-RelNet consistently outperforms a regression-based adaptation of GNN-SSL, while also surpassing conventional steered response power (SRP) with delay-and-sum (D&S) beamforming at medium and high signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs), especially in scenarios with few microphones. At 5 microphones and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SNR}=30 \text{dB}$</tex>, Graph-RelNet reduces mean absolute DoA error by up to 45%. The model also shows strong generalization to unseen microphone arrays and remains competitive under low-SNR conditions.

title: Deep Learning Approaches for Image-Based Malaria Detection
authors: Emre Bayraktar, Faruk Gökdeli, Emir Ahmet Şişman, Nur Banu Hancı, Oğuzhan Erdem, Nermin Şakru
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The deadly malaria parasite, transmitted by female Anopheles mosquitoes, causes approximately 200 million infections and 400,000 deaths annually. Diagnosis through microscopic examination of blood samples by microbiologists is time-consuming and faces significant challenges in some regions due to economic constraints, lack of equipment, and the need for specialized laboratories and trained personnel. Artificial intelligence (AI) models play a critical role in early and accurate detection of malaria parasites, which is essential for effective treatment. In this study, Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Vision Transformer (ViT)-based models are proposed for the detection of Plasmodium falciparum, one of the five species causing malaria in humans. Additionally, a VGG-16 model with weight fine-tuning (Wft) was implemented using transfer learning, and its performance was compared with the proposed models. The accuracy performances of the developed models were tested on three different datasets. In the first dataset consisting of Giemsa stained microscopic images, the VGG-16 Wft model achieved the highest accuracy of 97.06%, while in the second dataset, CNN, CNN-ViT and VGG-16 models achieved the best accuracy of 98.18%. Finally, in the third dataset extended with gametocyte and trophozoite cell images, the VGG-16 Wft model showed the highest accuracy of 96.85%. These models aim to reduce the workload of healthcare professionals and offer a more accurate and cost-effective alternative to traditional diagnostic methods.

title: Shading Loss Mitigation in Advanced Bifacial Photovoltaic Systems for Improved Capacity Factor
authors: Kashaf Abdullah, Khadijah Khan, Hayder Ali, Muhammad Khalid, Hassan Abbas Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Solar resources are inherently intermittent and can affect power system stability if the photovoltaic (PV) production reduces during critical (peak) hours. Shading on PV modules increases power losses, underscoring the need for effective PV system design to mitigate shading effects and enhance performance ratio and capacity factor. This paper evaluates the advanced bifacial module technologies and inverters with multiple Maximum Power Point Trackers (MPPTs) on shading performance, focusing on improving capacity factor and, in turn, resource resilience. Shading losses are categorized into module-specific and mismatch losses and a 12.29 kWp on-grid PV system is simulated for practical settings to evaluate system performance. The analysis compares state-of-the-art half-cut bifacial crystalline silicon (c-Si) and full-cell modules using single and dual MPPT inverter systems. The results show that half-cut cell technology with dual MPPT inverter has an overall shading loss of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 8 9 \%}$</tex> compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 0. 6 9 \%}$</tex> for conventional single-MPPT full-cell modules. Based on the technology available and site constraints in various regions, the findings from this work will inform PV technology selection for achieving improved energy yield, capacity factor, and resource reliability in domestic power systems.

title: Graph-Based TDOA Localization of Partial Discharges in Branched Power Cable Networks
authors: Hassan Ali, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Christian Staubach, Muhammed Zubair
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Partial discharges (PDs) are localized insulation failures that can precede major faults in power cables. Traditional localization methods require synchronization or assume simple linear topologies, limiting their effectiveness in complex networks. This paper proposes a graph-based TDOA localization framework that works with asynchronous sensors and arbitrary topologies. The cable system is modeled as a weighted graph, and PD source location is inferred from TDOA measurements. Two algorithms are presented—one for node-based and one for edge-based PD occurrences. Simulations on synthetic branched networks show high accuracy and robustness under noise. The method is scalable, cost-effective, and suitable for smart grid and industrial applications.

title: A Survey and Evaluation of Wireless Sensor Networks Security
authors: Kristina Živanović, Dimitrije Kolašinac, Zaharije Radivojević
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this paper, a systematic review of real-world attacks on Wireless Sensor Networks (WSNs) is presented along with the countermeasures proposed in the observed literature to address those attacks. Additionally, an evaluation of recent defense mechanisms and their effectiveness across different WSN types - such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAV), underwater, industrial, and smart grid networks - is provided to highlight current trends and research directions in securing resource-constrained sensor environments.

title: 6G Network O-RAN Energy Efficiency Performance Evaluation
authors: Ivan Petrov, Kurt Horvath, Stojan Kitanov, Dragi Kimovski, Fisnik Doko, Toni Janevski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) paradigm introduces disaggregated and virtualized RAN elements connected through open interfaces, enabling AI-driven optimization across the RAN. It allows flexible energy management strategies by leveraging intelligent RIC (RAN Intelligent Controller), and computing continuum (Dew-Edge-Cloud) resources. The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) provides vendor-neutral, disaggregated RAN components and AI-driven control, making it a strong candidate for future networks. On the other hand, the transition to 6 G networks requires more open, adaptable, and intelligent RAN architecture. Open RAN is envisioned as a key enabler for 6G, offering agility, cost efficiency, energy savings, and resilience. This paper assesses O-RAN's performance in 6G mobile networks in terms of energy efficiency.

title: Chatbot as Informative Support: Case Study in the Faculty of Accounting and Administration, Universidad Veracruzana
authors: Mayra Minerva - Méndez Anota, Felipe Mauricio - Méndez Luna, Alma Delia - Otero Escobar
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of an artificial intelligence-based chatbot as an informative support tool for students at the Faculty of Accounting and Administration of Universidad Veracruzana. The aim was to address the growing demand for timely and accessible information related to academic procedures, services, and events. A mixedmethod research design was applied, including an online survey (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n =113)$</tex>, semi-structured interviews (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=7$</tex>), and usability testing with 46 students using the Chatbot Usability Questionnaire (CUQ). The chatbot, implemented through Manychat and integrated with ChatGPT and voice recognition on Instagram, achieved a CUQ score of 63 out of 100, surpassing the minimum threshold defined in the research hypothesis. Results showed high student acceptance, with 93% of participants rating the system as useful and effective. Strengths included the chatbot's perceived utility and ease of navigation, while areas for improvement involved error handling and response personalization. The findings demonstrate the feasibility of deploying accessible chatbots in higher education institutions as a cost-effective solution to reduce administrative workload and enhance student experience, while also emphasizing the need for continuous refinement in inclusivity and knowledge base expansion.

title: Resilience Curves to Quantify the Impact of Severe Weather Events on Electricity Distribution Networks in the United Kingdom
authors: Saif Al Omairi, Daniel L. Donaldson
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven strategy for quantifying the impact of severe weather events on electricity distribution networks in the United Kingdom using customer resilience curves. These curves are developed from historical utility outage data and aligned with severe weather events to provide insights into the system impacts and restoration process. This analytical method facilitates the comparison of essential resilience metrics, including outage rate, restoration rate, degradation rate, recovery rate, and peak customer interruptions, and provides an interpretable means to quantify the effects of severe weather events on network performance. The approach is demonstrated using historical outage data from multiple distribution network operators in the United Kingdom for named storms including Desmond (2015), Arwen (2021), and Isha (2024). The results highlight the value of customer resilience curves as a benchmarking tool to inform storm response strategy, direct resilience investment choices, and improve resilience for future high-impact, severe weather events. While the analysis is conducted for distribution network operators in the UK, similar analyses would be valuable for network operators worldwide.

title: Cube the Sun: A Space-Saving Design for Next-Gen Solar Power
authors: Musaed Alkhurayef, Marina Guindi, Muhammad Ikram
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: With the world heading toward technological advancement, there is a need for a cleaner source of energy. This research suggests a more innovative design to an already existing solar power technology, making it a better solution for future technological advancement. The created design, a cubed arranged solar panels design as a system (CSS), aims to maximize the wattage production using the same space area for a single generic solar panel, which gives a high solar capture concentration in a minimal footprint. To counter and ensure that all the panels are well exposed to solar rays, a system of auto-adjusting mirrors, controlled by microcontrollers that will track sunlight and reflect them on the adjacent panel to give maximum exposure is implemented. In addition, to counteract the higher temperatures of the panels, a cooling mechanism is proposed to make sure that the panels operate at efficient temperatures and not be damaged over long periods of time. This research shed light on the uses of such technology using a logical theoretical approach and calculations while taking into account the solar irradiance, efficiency of the panels, and the change in outputs under different conditions. Researching such challenges as light dispersal and cooling systems, the Cubed Solar System (CSS) aims to improve solar technology to accommodate regions with high temperatures and irradiance such as Kuwait.

title: Reflection Coefficient Analysis of Open-Ended Coaxial Probes Based on Geometrical Parameters
authors: Melike Miray Tasci, Muhammed Ismail Pence, Gulsah Yildiz, Cemanur Aydinalp
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Dielectric spectroscopy is a widely used technique for investigating the frequency-dependent electrical properties of materials. In this study, the influence of probe geometry on the reflection coefficient at the tip of an open-ended coaxial probe (OECP) was systematically examined. Full-wave simulations were conducted in Ansys HFSS over the 0.5-20 GHz frequency range, with methanol serving as the test medium. The probe length (13, 23, and 26 mm), diameter values halved and doubled, and immersion depth (0,3, and 6 mm) were varied across different configurations (a total of nine simulations across four different scenarios). The results showed that immersion depth variations led to changes of approximately 16-18% in the reflection coefficient, probe length extensions caused deviations exceeding 260%, and larger probe diameters introduced differences of up to 135%. These findings highlight the strong dependence of OECP performance on geometric parameters and optimization in probebased measurement systems.

title: Performance Comparison of Channel Estimation Methods for XL-MIMO Systems
authors: Goran Josifovski, Zoran Hadzi-Velkov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Extra-Large MIMO (XL-MIMO) systems enable high spatial resolution through massive antenna arrays but make channel estimation challenging due to near-field effects and computational demands. This paper compares three estimation techniques: Least Squares (LS), Minimum Mean Square Error (MMSE), and Reduced Subspace Least Squares (RS-LS). Monte Carlo simulations across various SNR levels show that MMSE performs best at low SNR but is computationally expensive. LS is simple but highly noise-sensitive. RS-LS offers a favorable trade-off, achieving near-MMSE accuracy at significantly lower complexity, making it a practical solution for large-scale XL-MIMO deployments.

title: Analysis of Wear Behavior of AISI 316L Stainless Steel Using the Finite Element Method
authors: Ramiro De Jesús García-Mesa, Andrés López-Velázquez, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado, Ernesto A. Elvira-Hernández, Noé LópezPerrusquia, Marco Antonio Doñu-Ruiz, Ervin Jesús Alvarez-Sánchez, Fernando Aldana-Franco, Agustín L. Herrera-May
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The wear performance on stainless steel surfaces under direct contact and dynamic loads can be measured through tribological tests. However, tribological instruments such as tribometers or profilometers are expensive and require specialized maintenance. In order to address this challenge, we propose a twodimensional simulation model to predict the wear behavior of 316L stainless steel using the finite element method. This model can simulate the ball-on-flat contact on stainless steel without requiring the UMESHMOTION subroutine of Abaqus Software. In addition, Archard's wear law is implemented via interaction properties-contact type, friction, and wear coefficientsreported experimentally in the literature. The proposed model contains shell elements to reduce node count, determining wear scars depth within 2.68 % average deviation from experimental results at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 ~\mathrm{N}, 10 ~\mathrm{N}$</tex>, and 20 N. The 2D simulation models of the wear resistance on steel surfaces can allow the prediction of their wear characteristics without high computational cost, reducing the cost and use of tribological tests for the industrial sector.

title: Brain-in-the-Loop Learning for Intelligent Vehicle Decision-Making_supp1-3641715.mp4
authors: Hong Wang
publish: N/A
abstract: The inflexible human-autonomy relationship within autonomous driving scenarios still has not realized synergetic intelligence, therefore unable to provide adaptive and context-sensitive decision-making and sometimes leading to violation of human pReferences or even hazards. In this paper, we utilize functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) signals as real-time human risk-perception feedback to establish a brain-in-the-loop (BiTL) trained artificial intelligence algorithm for decision-making. The proposed algorithm uses the result of driving risk reasoning as one input of reinforcement learning combining fNIRS-based risk and driving safety field model-based risk, realizing integrating human brain activity into the reinforcement learning scheme, then overcoming the disadvantage of machine-oriented intelligence that could violate human intentions. To achieve policy learning within limited BiTL training periods, we add two modification features to the proposed algorithm based on TD3. The experiment involving twenty participants has been conducted, and the results show that in continuously high-risk driving scenarios, compared to traditional reinforcement learning algorithms without human participation, the proposed algorithm can maintain a cautious driving policy and avoid potential collisions, validated with both proximal surrogate indicators and success rates.

title: Deep Learning-based Human Gesture Channel Modeling for Integrated Sensing and Communication Scenarios
authors: Zhengyu Zhang, Neeraj Varshney, Jelena Senic, Raied Caromi, Samuel Berweger, Camillo Gentile, Enrico M. Vitucci, Ruisi He, Vittorio Degli-Esposti
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: With the development of Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) for Sixth-Generation (6G) wireless systems, contactless human recognition has emerged as one of the key application scenarios. Since human gesture motion induces subtle and random variations in wireless multipath propagation, how to accurately model human gesture channels has become a crucial issue for the design and validation of ISAC systems. To this end, this paper proposes a deep learning-based human gesture channel modeling framework for ISAC scenarios, in which the human body is decomposed into multiple body parts, and the mapping between human gestures and their corresponding multipath characteristics is learned from real-world measurements. Specifically, a Poisson neural network is employed to predict the number of Multi-Path Components (MPCs) for each human body part, while Conditional Variational Auto-Encoders (C-VAEs) are reused to generate the scattering points, which are further used to reconstruct continuous channel impulse responses and micro-Doppler signatures. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high accuracy and generalization across different gestures and subjects, providing an interpretable approach for data augmentation and the evaluation of gesture-based ISAC systems.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp7-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.
