title: CASM-UFLD: An Improved UFLD Lane Detection Algorithm Based on Curvature-Aware Sequence Modeling
authors: Yunxiang Liu, Rongxing Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The CASM-UFLD algorithm proposes an improved approach based on curvature aware sequence modeling to address the issues of poor detection continuity and insufficient accuracy caused by the independent prediction mechanism of row anchor points in Ultra Fast Lane Detection (UFLD) in complex curved scenes. This algorithm retains the real-time advantage of UFLD at 300+ FPS, and achieves accurate modeling of curved lanes by inserting a curvature aware sequence modeling module (CASM) and optimizing the loss function. The CASM module is embedded between the UFLD feature extraction layer and the classification head, using bidirectional GRU to capture the vertical dependency relationship of row anchor sequences, and combining curvature gating mechanism to adaptively fuse the original features and sequence features, enhancing the continuity representation of the curve region; At the same time, a feature curvature regularization loss is added to achieve “feature position” dual supervision by constraining the second-order differential smoothness of the feature sequence, thereby improving the efficiency of curve feature learning. The experimental verification shows that the accuracy of CASM-UFLD in Tusimple dataset is 96.7% (0.83% higher than the original UFLD), and the accuracy in the complex curve scene of CULane is 3.3% higher. It provides a lightweight solution for lane detection that gives consideration to both real-time and accuracy, and significantly improves the safety of the auto drive system in complex road environments.

title: Filling and Sorting Automation System for Three Golf Balls in a Cylindrical Box
authors: Thitipong Wachirakhuankhun, Ronnakorn Lilitkarntakul, Tanatat Kamonwong, Tharathep Kingkum, Poochida Pookaroon, Kitsada Doungjitjaroen, Natthaporn Srichaikham, Kongkarn Vachirapanang, Tomoki Harano, Manabu Kato, Zacharie Mbaitiga, Sornnarong Ongklueap
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This project is centered on developing an automated Golf Ball Filling and Sorting Conveyor designed to streamline the packaging and organization of used golf balls. The system automates the process of filling cylindrical boxes with exactly three golf balls per box, ensuring consistent output, reducing manual labor, and enhancing packaging efficiency. The automation process employs three pneumatic actuators to manage tasks such as catching cylindrical boxes, ejecting golf balls, and separating boxes. Additionally, a dual infrared photoelectric detection system is integrated to confirm the presence of cylindrical boxes and accurately count the golf balls. Once filled, the system organizes the boxes containing three golf balls each into a $2 \times 2$ arrangement, optimizing sorting and handling for downstream packaging. A Programmable Logic Controller (PLC) is employed to oversee the automation processes, receiving detection data from computers and controlling operations like rejections and other machine functions. The integration of a Human-Machine Interface (HMI) with the PLC enables users to easily monitor and manage key information. Testing has demonstrated that the machine operates efficiently, achieving a $100 \%$ success rate at a commendable speed. However, certain weaknesses were identified in areas such as system stability, pneumatic catcher performance, and overall durability due to constraints in skills, time, and budget. These limitations may result in operational errors, making the system less suitable for long-term investment.

title: A Decentralized and Privacy-Preserving Spatial Crowdsourcing Framework for V2X
authors: Wenhao Zhu, Qingshui Xue
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The rise of intelligent systems and mobile computing has driven spatial crowdsourcing to become an important tool for resource coordination. Among them, intelligent vehicles, as the main entities in intelligent transportation systems and Internet of Vehicles scenarios, have also become an important component of spatial crowdsourcing with the development of communication protocols such as C-V2X and the wide popularization of communication media such as MES, OBU, and RSU. Mobile space crowdsourcing tasks often have high complexity. Some tasks require workers with specific professional skills, and at the same time, they may have different focuses on requirements such as time and quality. Most existing space crowdsourcing frameworks rely on centralized servers. However, these solutions may be affected by single points of failure, privacy leaks and misbehaving platforms. In addition, in space crowdsourcing, the rationality of task allocation, high platform service fees, and privacy protection strategies also need to be taken into account simultaneously. To overcome these limitations and address the dual challenges of fine-grained privacy protection and reasonable and stable task allocation in the complex multi-skill task environment of the Internet of Vehicles, this paper proposes a decentralized personalized privacy-protecting space crowdsourcing framework. By constructing the acceptable list and preference list of tasks and workers, and using the gale-shapely algorithm for matching, the reasonable and stable task allocation is ensured. Meanwhile, finegrained authorization is achieved through attribute encryption based on ciphertext policy. Workers submit travel expenses instead of location information, which strengthens the privacy protection of tasks and workers. In addition, the trust value management method based on Bayesian reasoning conducts dynamic reputation assessment of workers to prevent malicious workers from committing evil deeds. These functions are implemented through smart contracts, while ensuring the transparency of the system and overcoming the main limitations of centralized solutions. Performance evaluation indicates that the scheme achieves two-way location privacy protection while taking into account both computational efficiency and system scalability.

title: Effects of Kilohertz-Frequency Priming Stimulus on Cortical Neural Excitability in Mouse Brain Slices
authors: Utano Suzuki, Daito Kato, Santa Fukuda, Tomoki Sugiura, Yuki Hayashida
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Recently, kilohertz-frequency pulse-train stimulation has attracted attention as a novel neuromodulation method, as an alternative to conventional electrical pulses delivered at repetition rates below 200 Hz. In this study, we propose a new stimulation paradigm in which kilohertz-frequency stimulation is applied not as the main stimulus that directly induces neuronal excitation, but as a priming stimulus applied prior to the main stimulus. Using physiological experiments and numerical simulations, we demonstrated that the cortical response to the main stimulus was partially suppressed by the priming stimulus. These findings suggest the potential of kilohertz-frequency stimulation as a new strategy for precise activation of neural circuits in cortical prostheses.

title: Circular-Optical Intelligent Reflecting Surface Assisted Underwater Wireless Communication System
authors: Rehana Salam, Vivek Ashok Bohara, Khagendra Joshi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This study explores a novel dimension in underwater wireless optical communication (UWOC) by investigating the impact of optical intelligent reflecting surfaces (OIRS) element shape on system performance. While prior research has focused on the deployment and control of OIRS, this work uniquely examines how the geometry of OIRS elements, specifically circular OIRS (C-OIRS) versus square OIRS (S-OIRS), influences non-line-of-sight (NLOS) UWOC transmission. A submerged OIRS is employed to optimize signal reflection and enhance overall transmission efficiency. Through comparative analysis, we demonstrate that C-OIRS offers superior signal enhancement and system efficiency, especially as the number of elements increases. The results underscore the critical role of OIRS shape in improving UWOC performance and present C-OIRS as a promising design for reliable and efficient underwater data transmission.

title: 3GPP Based LDPC Encoder For 5G-NR Over FPGA
authors: Puspendra K Upadhyay, Pallav Maheshwari, Gaurav Jajoo
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: 5G New Radio (NR) offers significantly higher throughput and lower latency compared to its predecessors in communication standards. In 5G, Low Density Parity Check (LDPC) encoding serves as the channel coding scheme for data transmission via shared channels. This work focuses on the Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA)-based implementation of an LDPC encoder compliant with the 5G-NR Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) standards. This paper details the design, development, and evaluation of a generalized LDPC encoder capable of generating codewords for all code rates and payload sizes. The generated Intellectual Property (IP) selects the base graph, calculates the parity matrix, and encodes the data in accordance with T S 38.212. Implementation was carried out using the Xilinx MPSoC ZCU-102 board. The developed IP is tested and verified using the reference output generated by the MATLAB 5G-NR built-in library. Our results demonstrate the efficiency of the LDPC encoder implementation in terms of latency and resource utilization on the evaluation board making it suitable for practical applications.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs for Identifying Determinants of Postprandial Glucose in Type 1 Diabetes
authors: Rocío Contreras-Jiménez, Juan C. Olivares-Rojas, Adriana C. Téllez-Anguiano, José A. Gutiérrez-Gnecchi, J. Eduardo Alcaráz-Chávez, Enrique Reyes-Archundia
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) requires precise glucose management to prevent complications. A significant challenge is determining the optimal insulin bolus dose, as errors can lead to hypo- or hyperglycemia. This paper presents an application of Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) to model causal relationships that influence postprandial glucose levels using the HUPA-UCM dataset (25 T1DM patients with glucose, insulin, activity, and dietary data). Three DAG models were generated: knowledge-based (DAG1), data-driven (DAG2), and adjusted (DAG3). Causal inference was performed using DoWhy, revealing a statistically significant effect of insulin bolus on postprandial glucose. Each additional bolus unit reduced glucose between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 1. 3 0}$</tex> mg/dL (DAG1) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-0.78 \text{mg} / \text{dL}$</tex> (DAG2/DAG3). Robust tests confirmed stability (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p} \boldsymbol{>} \mathbf{0. 9 0}$</tex>). Results demonstrate that DAGs can reliably identify determinants of glycemic response and represent a promising tool for interpretable, personalized insulin dosing systems. These results could support the design of intelligent insulin dosing systems capable of explaining their recommendations to clinicians and patients.

title: LP Gas Leak Detection Prototype for Rural Areas With Aes-256 Encryption via LoRa and 3G Network Transmission
authors: Soto-Ortiz S. I, Salazar-Pérez P. J, Homero De Jesús Portillo Calva
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In Mexico, the widespread use of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) in rural areas poses significant safety risks, accounting for 35.86% of domestic incidents reported by CENAPRED (20102020) [1]. This paper introduces “SafeGas,” an Internet of Things (IoT) prototype designed for early LPG leak detection, integrating gas (MQ-6), pressure, and temperature sensors (MAX6675 with Type K thermocouple) alongside secure wireless communication via LoRa (Long Range) with AES-256 encryption and 3G (third-generation mobile networks). The prototype aims to monitor conditions in real time and trigger alerts through a dual-verification system (pressure + gas concentration), addressing key limitations of conventional leak detection methods. The development follows the IoT Development Lifecycle (IDL), structured into six phases: (1)Requirements: Defining objectives. (2)Design: System architecture. (3)Implementation: Hardware, firmware, and encryption. (4)Testing: LoRa range validation, false-positive rate assessment. (5)Deployment: Field installation in rural settings. (6)Maintenance: Firmware updates and performance optimization [24]

title: Analysis of a Variable Capacitance Sensor Used to Monitor Volumetric Changes in Droplets
authors: Jorge Alberto Uc-Martín, Asur Guadarrama-Santana, Augusto García-Valenzuela
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: We present a simple analysis of a prototype variable capacitance sensor to characterize and monitor the evaporation process of microliter volume droplet, following its volumetric change. The experimental relationship between the differential capacitance signal of the sensor and the volumetric change of the droplet, observed in previous work, it is substantiated. First, we describe a practical sensor, simplifying its analysis by assuming that it is well represented as a capacitor of parallel plates with a uniform substrate and liquid layer between the electrodes. This first consideration enabled us to estimate the conditions and the approximate maximum volume of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{L}$</tex> to be used in practice, ensuring that the sensor response is proportional to the volumetric change of the droplet during evaporation. Next, we present a calculation of the equivalent differential capacitance and resistance of the device, both with and without droplet, as a function of the operating frequency. In this analysis, we assume an equivalent circuit composed of a series capacitor with a resistor. Our calculations indicate a precise optimal frequency for operating the device, which primarily depends on the conductivity of the liquid sample. For water samples, from drinking water to seawater, the optimal frequency is between approximately 300 kHz and the GHz range.

title: Current Status of Cluster Analysis Application in Software Construction Activities: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Álvaro Barradas-Fernández, Ángel J. Sánchez-García, Oscar Alonso-Ramírez, Xavier Limón
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a Systematic Literature Review (SLR) on the application of Cluster Analysis (CA) in software construction activities. Following the guidelines of Kitchenham and Quasigold-standard, we identified and analyzed 28 primary studies published between 2019 and 2025. The review revealed nine CA algorithms applied in this context, with K-means being the most frequently adopted for its simplicity and efficiency, followed by Hierarchical Clustering, Fuzzy C-means, and DBSCAN. The findings show that CA has been used to group code fragments, support refactoring, classify developer profiles, automate code generation, organize APIs, and detect dependencies among modules. These applications contribute to improving software quality, scalability, and maintainability. However, challenges remain in selecting the optimal number of clusters, interpreting results reliably, and generalizing across heterogeneous software systems. Overall, CA demonstrates significant potential as a complementary approach to enhance efficiency and quality in software construction, providing practical benefits for software engineers while highlighting the need for methodological guidance and further research.

title: Two-Stage Optimization for Bess Sizing and Placement in Medium-Voltage Distribution Networks
authors: Sajan K. Sadanandan, Suresh Maganti, Gagandeep Singh Dua, Tareg Ghaoud, Shoaib Ijaz, Asma Saeed, Sayed Abdel Aziz Mohamed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a two-stage optimization approach for the optimal sizing and placement of Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) in 11 kV distribution feeders. In the first stage, an analytical approach determines the optimal BESS capacity by incorporating feeder-specific operating constraints, including reverse power flow limits, node strength, and loss thresholds. In the second stage, a heuristicbased method identifies the most effective feeder locations for deployment. The proposed methodology is validated using two real distribution networks in Dubai. For a single-feeder system (Net-1), the approach achieves a reduction in feeder losses from 32 kW in the base case to 4 kW with three BESS units, while also improving the voltage profile. For a multi-feeder system (Net-2), coordinated deployment reduces total network losses by 81.8% and improves reliability, with taking up to 30% of feeder demand supported through BESS integration. The results confirm that strategic and modular BESS allocation provides significant improvements in voltage stability, loss minimization, and operational flexibility, whereas nonoptimal siting yields only marginal benefits. In general, the proposed two-stage approach offers a practical and scalable solution that identifies heuristic-optimal BESS siting and sizing within real distribution networks under technical and spatial constraints.

title: Queueing-Based Optimization of EV Battery Swapping Stations: Balancing Availability, Costs, and Degradation
authors: Muhammad Osama Tarar, Naveed UL Hassan, Ijaz Haider Naqvi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Battery-swapping stations (BSSs) let electric vehicles trade a depleted pack for a charged one in minutes, but operators must balance spare-battery capital against service reliability and fast-charge wear. We model a single BSS as either an Erlang-B loss system (no wait) or Erlang-C queue (wait), derive closed-form blocking, waiting and utilisation formulas, and embed them in a cost function that sums battery CAPEX, degradation and customer delay/loss penalties. Discrete-event simulation confirms analytic accuracy. Results show that higher charging rates cut required inventory yet raise degradation cost, while allowing short queues can minimise total cost when waiting penalties are modest. The framework yields explicit, closed-form sizing rules for reliable and cost-efficient BSS operation under stochastic EV demand.

title: Enhancing Trigeneration System Efficiency Through Optimized Control of a SOFC
authors: Yaser Qudaih, Bezawit Tinsae, Nuhamin Denbel, Japi Gezachew, Elham Jibril, Ahmed Abdullahi, Mohanad Alata
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper details a biomass-to-trigeneration system for the HCT Dubai campus that uses food waste and animal manure to produce biogas. This biogas fuels a Solid Oxide Fuel Cell (SOFC) to generate electricity, heat, and cooling. To manage varying electrical loads, a custom Python-based mathematical model was developed to dynamically control the SOFC's voltage and fuel usage, an alternative to the MATLAB Simulink model from existing literature. The Python model, which adds temperature as a control parameter, was compared to an uncontrolled SOFC and the MATLAB-controlled system using an exergy analysis. The results showed the Python-controlled system achieved a 19.45 % improvement in energy efficiency and a 36.51 % improvement in exergy efficiency over the baseline. The generated electricity will power campus streetlights, providing a decentralized renewable energy solution.

title: Reduced-Complexity Successive Cancelation Decoding of $\mathbb{Z}_{4}$ Splitting Codes
authors: Aleksandar Minja
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel suboptimal softinput decoding algorithm for linear codes over the ring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbb{Z}_{4}$</tex> (the ring of integers modulo 4), based on the lifting decoder technique. The proposed method operates directly on the parity-check matrix, unlike our previous successive cancellation decoder (SCD), which relies on the generator matrix. This results in a reduced number of arithmetic operations and lower computational complexity. The algorithm is demonstrated for a range of Kerdock codes and compared with both the maximum a posteriori (MAP) decoder and the classical SCD. Simulation results show that the proposed decoder achieves comparable error-rate performance to the MAP and classical SCD algorithms, while maintaining the same asymptotic complexity of the classical SCD algorithm, which in the case of Kerdock codes is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$O\left(N \log _{2} N\right)$</tex>.

title: Performance Analysis of Double Auction Implementations for Peer-to-Peer Energy Trading on Resource Constrained Blockchain Platforms
authors: Maaz Muhammad Khan, Zain Imran, Naveed Ul Hassan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading is gaining momentum as a decentralized alternative to conventional energy systems. Blockchain offers transparency integrity and trust for such markets. However executing blockchain logic on embedded platforms such as Raspberry Pi (RPi) raises concerns about gas cost communication overhead and long-term storage. Despite growing interest in blockchain-based energy trading there is limited performance evaluation on resource-constrained devices. We present a comprehensive analysis of two double auction (DA) implementations using full Quorum nodes running on RPi devices. One performs sorting and order matching fully on-chain while the other shifts these operations off-chain with verifiable results. We analyze gas cost, communication overhead and blockchain growth across different community sizes. Our results show that off-chain implementation offers improved gas efficiency as the number of participants increases. On-chain execution also remains a viable alternative especially for smaller and moderate communities. Both implementations maintain manageable communication and storage requirements under realistic trading activity. These findings demonstrate that full blockchain nodes can operate effectively on RPi devices, enabling the practical and scalable deployment of P2P energy trading systems.

title: Resource-Efficient Transfer Learning by Evaluating Model Robustness to Aggressive Video Metadata Modification
authors: Nebojsa Simic, Ana Gavrovska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Transfer learning from large-scale pretrained models has become essential for achieving strong performance in specialized domains, yet the process remains resource-intensive in terms of storage, computation, and processing time. This paper investigates whether aggressive video dataset compression can maintain effective transfer learning performance for action recognition tasks. Several varying parameters, such as frame rate, spatial resolution and Constant Rate Factor (CRF), are used to analyze the effect of reduced data on the model fine-tuning outcomes. For this purpose, the R(2+1)D architecture on the UCF101 dataset is used. The obtained results demonstrate that significant computational and storage savings are achievable in transfer learning without proportional accuracy costs, and the possibility of providing an automated platform to facilitate compression experimentation is shown to be valuable for resource-constrained scenarios.

title: Identification of Flexible Residential Loads by Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Ahmed Albarakati, Saud Alnahidh, Khalid Alrefaei, Abdullelah Alsolami, Kazi N. Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Residential energy consumption continues to rise, placing significant strain on electricity grids and increasing costs for consumers. This study investigates the use of machine learning techniques to classify household electrical appliances as shiftable or non-shiftable loads, enabling effective load-shifting strategies to reduce peak demand and optimize energy costs. Five machine learning techniques, Logistic Regression (LR), Support Vector Machine (SVM), Neural Networks (NN), Kernel Nearest Neighbour (KNN), and Boosted Trees (BT), were evaluated for load disaggregation, with SMOTE (Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique) optimization applied to address class imbalance. The Boosted Trees and SVM models demonstrated superior performance, achieving high accuracy and generalization. This research highlights the potential of machine learning to drive energy efficiency and sustainability.

title: Optical Flow-Based Visual Estimation of Translational Displacement Using a Raspberry Pi® Embedded Computer
authors: B. J. Mota López, G. Delgado Reyes, M. A. Hernández Pérez, F. A. Carpio Santamaría, S. Marquez Domínguez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study presents the implementation of an optical flow-based algorithm for estimating translational displacement in an Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV), using both a personal computer (PC) and a Raspberry Pi 4®. The algorithm was tested under five configurations, including Gaussian filtering and the Global Positioning System (GPS). The Raspberry Pi <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{(R)}$</tex> with Gaussian smoothing yielded the best results. Quantitative evaluation showed superior accuracy compared to inertial sensors in indoor environments. The approach highlights the potential of onboard optical flow algorithms in low-power platforms for navigation, offering portability and autonomy in GPS-denied or infrastructurelimited scenarios.

title: Distributed Deep Learning Model for Credit Card Fraud Detection: A Cloud-Based Scalability Study
authors: Alireza Izaddoost, Amlan Chatterjee
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Financial security is a primary concern for institutions, companies, and individuals, with credit card fraud representing a major and persistent threat. Deep learning has proven effective in identifying fraudulent transactions, but training such models on large-scale, highly imbalanced datasets is computationally intensive. Cloud computing provides the necessary scalability by enabling distributed processing across multiple resources. In this research, we develop and evaluate a distributed deep learning model for credit card fraud detection deployed on Google Cloud Platform (GCP) using Apache Spark and PyTorch Distributed Data Parallel (DDP). The model addresses data imbalance with SMOTE and distributes key tasks, including data preprocessing and model training, across multiple worker nodes. Experiments with two and three worker nodes demonstrate that distributing resources significantly reduces training time while maintaining high recall in fraud detection. The scalability analysis highlights the trade-offs between speed, resource allocation, and predictive performance, showing that additional distributed resources accelerate training without degrading detection capability.

title: Voltage Conversion in Power Distribution Networks: Transition from 6.6kV to 11kV
authors: Abdul Haleem Medattil Ibrahim, P Aliya, Tareg Ghaoud, Sgouris Sgouridis, Hassan Al Hammadi, Ahmed Mohamed Alsahi Alzaabi, Mohamed Ahmed Mohamed Alhammadi, Abdulrahman Zaki Alsharif, Hend Adnan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This study evaluates the transition of a real-world power distribution network from a 6.6kV to an 11kV system to optimize voltage conversion and reduce overall system losses and operational costs. A comparative analysis is conducted between a traditional three-stage transformation configuration (132/33/6.6/0.4kV) and two alternative setups, including a streamlined two-stage option (132/11/0.4kV). The results demonstrate that the two-stage configuration offers significant reductions in losses and operational expenses, particularly in the context of a steadily expanding utility network. The study also assesses the feasibility of retrofitting existing infrastructure to accommodate the optimized configuration, projecting notable long-term economic benefits and improved efficiency for future network development.

title: Semantic-Aware Interoperability for Digital Twins: A Case Study on Hydrogen Power Plants
authors: Razeen Hashmi, Huai Liu, Ali Yavari
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As digital twins (DTs) become increasingly adopted in hydrogen power plants, a key challenge is enabling them to communicate with and learn from one another smoothly. Without interoperability, DTs remain isolated and cannot share validated knowledge or build upon each other's operational experience. Semantic interoperability is therefore essential for supporting communication, parameter adaptation, and collaborative improvement across multiple DTs. This paper presents a layered framework that achieves semantic interoperability by leveraging W3C-aligned standards, together with shapes constraint language validation and rule-based reasoning. It integrates a semantic gateway, a knowledge graph, and a rule engine to support consistent data integration, semantic representation, and decision support. It also incorporates a DT interface that exposes validated observations and action logs to external DTs under a shared data contract, thereby enabling cross-twin communications. The framework's effectiveness is demonstrated using simulated electrolyzer stack temperature and pressure observations, which confirm correct ingestion, validation, and semantic representation of plant data. A twin-to-twin communication scenario further illustrates how hydrogen DTs can exchange validated knowledge, adapt operational parameters, and support collective learning. Results show that the framework reduces integration complexity and provides diagnostics for non-conforming data, thereby supporting reliable and semantically interoperable DT operations.

title: A Lightweight Reinforcement Learning Baseline for 3D LiDAR Control Under Memory Constraints
authors: Jelena Elez, Predrag Tadić, Jelena Popovic Bozovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents a memory-aware implementation of a SAC (Soft Actor-Critic) agent for RL (Reinforcement Learning) in vehicle control with 3D LiDAR (Three-Dimensional Light Detection and Ranging) sensor data, where minimalist point-cloud processing combined with SAC enables stable learning on a constrained GPU (4 GB VRAM). The SAC agent is implemented in Python version 3.7, and the final solution is validated in the CARLA simulator, version 0.9.15, on the large urban map Town03. Results are evaluated using performance metrics plotted as Policy Loss, Q Loss, Noise Standard Deviation, and Average Reward. They show a steady decrease in losses and an increase in reward during training, indicating stable agent learning. The paper emphasizes the practical value of a simple, replicable MLP (Multi-Layer Perceptron) plus SAC baseline under memory constraints and establishes a foundation for future transition to point-cloud specific architectures when hardware resources permit.

title: Development and Evaluation of an AI Chatbot for Educational Support Utilizing Lecture Materials
authors: Mizuki Takushima, Tetsuro Kakeshita
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: In modern university education, managing diverse student inquiries poses a significant burden on instructors, highlighting the increasing importance of personalized support. To address this challenge, we developed an AI chatbot capable of providing responses tailored to specific course content, utilizing lecture materials and lecture video transcripts. The system is built upon OpenAI API (GPT-5), and integrates RetrievalAugmented Generation (RAG) technology. The developed chatbot is deployed in two courses, “Requirements Engineering” and “Career Design for IT Engineers,” and evaluated with 80 university students. Evaluation results indicate that approximately 80% of the students positively rated the chatbot’s responses as “helpful”, confirming its high utility in aspects such as organizing and re-presenting lecture content, suggesting future actions, and offering diverse perspectives. Furthermore, the utilization of past student comments and instructor responses as learning data proved highly valuable as a supplementary learning tool for enhancing student understanding. This research shows AI chatbots are practical tools for personalized support and reducing instructor workload. Future work aims to build a more personalized and effective learning support environment by incorporating features such as tracking individual student learning progress and enabling instructors to analyze conversation logs.

title: An Enhanced YOLOv11-OBB Model for Biological Sample
authors: Zhengfu Wang, Xuedong Jing
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To address localization deviations, missed detections, and the large parameter size of models in robotic arm-based biological sample sorting, this paper proposes an improved YOLOv11n-based detection method. First, we introduce the C3k2-StarNet module [1], enhancing the C3k2 module using the lightweight StarNet to improve basic feature extraction [2]. While YOLOv11 employs an FPN+PAN structure for multi-scale feature fusion, it struggles with insufficient spatial noise suppression in complex backgrounds and small-target localization errors. Traditional channel attention fails to model positional information explicitly, while spatial attention (e.g., CBAM) overlooks channel correlations. Thus, we integrate a Coordinate Attention-Enhanced CAA module into the neck network to reduce missed and false detections [3]. The improved model achieves 99.7% precision, 100% recall, 99.5% mAP@50, and 84.6% mAP@50:95. Compared to the original model, it reduces parameters by 0. 5 0 2 M, increases mAP@50 by 10.5%, improves mAP@50:95 by 5.1%, lowers GFLOPs by 1.3 G, and boosts precision by 0.115% and recall by 13.8%. Additionally, parameter count and model size decrease by 13.5% and 12.4%, respectively. The enhanced model significantly improves biological sample detection, mitigating low accuracy, missed detections, and localization errors.

title: Optimizing Federated Learning for UAV-Based Crop Health Monitoring
authors: Li Qiong Chen, Tao Li, Huaiying Sun, Kaiwen Zhi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: In recent years, the aerial-ground federated learning architecture, which combines unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) with federated learning, has shown great potential for crop health monitoring in smart agriculture. However, optimizing federated learning for these UAV-based systems in precision agriculture scenarios faces multiple challenges, such as reducing latency, improving accuracy, and ensuring coverage, necessitating a balance between comprehensiveness and efficiency during model training. Existing strategies mainly focus on reducing training time but often overlook the fairness of model training, which can lead to insufficient classification accuracy or incomplete coverage for certain crop diseases, thereby affecting the accuracy of pest control decisions. To address this issue, this study proposes a federated learning optimization scheme for precision agriculture, introducing a novel fairness metric and multi-criteria client selection mechanism based on the upper confidence bound. Simulation results show that the proposed MCCS method achieves superior performance compared to existing DCS and GCS baselines. Specifically, MCCS reduces the total training latency by 20% and 27% respectively while improving the model accuracy by 6.9% and 12%.

title: Scalable ETSI-Compliant SDN-Enabled QKD Network Architecture Using Microservices
authors: Samuel Leyikun Birhanu, Sakineh Ghaderi, Riccardo Bassoli, Frank H. P. Fitzek
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: 6G networks promise advanced applications such as immersive extended reality, autonomous systems, and massive machine-type communications, all of which demand highly secure communication. Yet, the rise of quantum computing technologies poses significant challenges to classical cryptographic methods, creating an urgent need for security designs resistant to quantum attacks. Quantum key distribution (QKD) is a promising solution; however, its deployment is currently constrained by expensive point-to-point connections that require dedicated devices at both endpoints. These constraints, combined with a restricted operational range, have limited the use of QKD to niche applications. To address this, our study introduces a scalable microservice framework for SDN-enabled QKD networks, leveraging the SDN Controller and its support for diverse communication protocols, including REST APIs. Our findings demonstrate that integrating QKD within an SDN-enabled microservice architecture can enhance network performance and flexibility by improving scalability, reducing latency, and extending achievable secret key rates over longer distances.

title: Machine Learning based Mobility Robustness Optimization For Next Generation Cellular Network
authors: Kaustuv Saha, Ayaz Ahmed, Aritra Chatterjee
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The primary need of any cellular wireless network is to support user device mobility with no discernable service impact. There exists in literature several schemes to optimize performance of mobility procedures by tuning configuration parameters. In this work, a machine learning based Mobility Robustness Optimization (MRO) framework is presented. A novel supervised feed-forward neural network model is developed for deploying at the network edge nodes so as to maintain optimal operating configurations to achieve superior mobility performance. As compared to existing schemes which mostly focuses on one specific handover performance indicator, the developed neural network model is designed to cater to a multi-objective optimization scheme, thereby providing a holistic performance improvement. The developed model is trained and tested with data obtained from an operational network deployment, thus providing a realistic estimate of the solution.

title: Smart Truck Platooning System with V2V Communication and Route Optimization
authors: Achu Jayan, K T Chengappa, A Ithamraju, Sreeja K, Navin Kumar, Satya Kumar Vankayala, Seungil Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Truck platooning route optimization, which must ensure safe and stable convoy operation over many destinations is challenging. In logistics, routing truck platoons from one city to another and multi-destination within the city remains central to reducing the transit time, fuel consumption and, the operational costs involved. In this work, method is developed which combines adaptive truck platooning controls with a traveling salesman problem (TSP) algorithm, set on the path of deriving an optimal route from city to city. Using a distance matrix and iterating over possible routes, it sets out to pick on the optimum path that would minimize total travel distance. The most optimal route demonstrated a 38.9% fuel efficiency improvement over the second-best route. This study will assist logistics companies, autonomous vehicle developers, and transportation managers in providing safe, fuel-efficient solutions for platooning of complex multi-city transportation routes.

title: High-frequency magnetic response measurement of test mass with a fluxgate magnetometer for gravitational wave detection
authors: Yuanyang Yu, Butian Zhang, Shengxin Lin, Jianping Liang, Yancong Huo, Wei Su, Donghua Pan, Shun Wang, Ze-Bing Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: For space-borne gravitational wave detectors, such as LISA and TianQin, the disturbance caused by the coupling of test masses and the external magnetic fields is one of the main sources of the residual acceleration noise. Although the detection frequency band is from 0.1 mHz to 1 Hz, magnetic fields with frequencies higher than 1 Hz can still contribute to the noise through down conversion effect. Therefore, it is necessary to measure the AC magnetic susceptibility or magnetic response of the test mass at higher frequency for the evaluation of the magnetic noise. In this work, we propose a magnetic field response measurement method by directly probing the induced magnetic field of the test mass placed in a spatially uniform magnetic field. The frequency can be measured up to 1500 Hz, satisfying the requirement of space-borne gravitational wave detection.

title: UQA-RAG: Enhancing Urdu Question-Answer Retrieval with Semantic Similarity and LLMs
authors: Talha Farooq Khan, Muhammad Arslan, Fahad Alturise, Ahmed H. Almutairi, Muhammad Tariq Raza
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Urdu Question Answering (QA) systems struggle with limited annotated resources and linguistic complexities. These are significant hurdles for traditional Large Language Models (LLMs) that rely on static, pre-trained knowledge. This paper introduces UQA-RAG, a new framework to enhance Urdu QA by using Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) over the multi-domain UNQA dataset. Our core methodological contribution is a Hybrid Retrieval Strategy. This approach overcomes the individual weaknesses of pure semantic or lexical search by combining their strengths. It fuses results from OpenAI’s text-embedding-3-small vectors (Semantic) with BM25 (Lexical) using the Reciprocal Rank Fusion (RRF) algorithm. This method maximizes both context relevance and diversity. We conducted an extensive ablation study to evaluate UQA-RAG’s performance with different LLM backbones, including GPT-4o, Llama-3.2, and Deepseek-r1. The optimal setup, pairing Hybrid Retrieval with GPT-4o, achieved a BERTScore F1 of 93.15%. This was a 16.55 percentage point improvement over our fine-tuned mBERT baseline. The system also reached a high RAGAS Context Precision of 95.20%. These results confirm that our hybrid approach is essential for generating accurate, contextually grounded responses, making UQA-RAG an effective solution for advancing high-quality QA in Urdu.

title: Decentralized Access and Roaming Management in Fixed, Mobile, and Satellite Convergence Networks Using Smart Contracts
authors: Rohit Hunashikatti, Radhika M. Hirannaiah, Prasad Honnavalli B.
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Fixed, Mobile, and Satellite Convergence (FMSC) networks aim to enable seamless communication across diverse infrastructure domains. Traditional access and roaming control mechanisms are centralized, inflexible, and unsuitable for heterogeneous environments. This research proposes a decentralized framework based on blockchain smart contracts to manage roaming agreements and dynamic access authorization across FMSC domains. The architecture introduces two core innovations: (1) a Roaming Agreement Smart Contract (RASC) for autonomous SLA negotiation between operators, and (2) an Access Authorization Contract (AAC) that issues time-bound tokens using decentralized identities (DIDs). By leveraging permissioned blockchains, the system achieves rapid token issuance while eliminating single points of failure inherent in conventional HSS/UDM architectures. The solution ensures secure, auditable interoperability through cryptographic identity binding and immutable policy enforcement, addressing critical gaps in multi-domain trust management. Key advancements include programmable QoS-aware access tokens, integration of intent-based FMSC orchestration systems, and a revocation mechanism for dynamic policy updates. The framework’s modular design aligns with 3GPP and ITU-T standards while enabling new business models for cross-domain service delivery in 5G/6G and satellite networks.

title: More Capacity from Less Spectrum: Tapping into Optical-Layer Intelligence in Optical Computing-Communication Integrated Network
authors: Dao Thanh Hai, Shuo Li, Isaac Woungang
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Optical fiber communications and networks constituting the backbone of Internet infrastructure have been continuing evolving technologically and architecturally to meet the explosive traffic growth. On the technological front, recent key advancements including spectrally and spatially flexible transmission, and wide-band optical transmission hold the promise of order-of-magnitude capacity gain. Concurrently, architectural innovations seek to capitalize on this expanded capacity to enable more scalable, cost-effective, and energy-efficient data transport. A prominent example is the optical-bypass architecture, which has now become widely deployed since the 2000s due to its substantial operational and capital cost savings over the predecessor optical-electrical-optical (O-E-O) mode. Driven by massive investments and consequently significant progresses in optical computing and all-optical signal processing technologies lately, this paper presents a new architectural paradigm for next-generation optical transport network, entitled optical computing-communication integrated network, which is capable of providing dual services at the optical layer, namely, computing and communication. This approach seeks to exploit the potential for performing optical computing operations among lightpaths that traverse the same intermediate node. Optical-Layer intelligence concept is thus introduced as the capability to perform computing / processing at the lightpath scale to achieve greater spectral and/or computing efficiency. A case study focusing on optical aggregation operation is introduced, highlighting the key differences between optical computing-communication integrated network and its current counterpart, optical-bypass ones. A mathematical formulation for optimal designs of optical-aggregation-enabled network is then provided and performance comparison with traditional optical-bypass model is drawn on the realistic NSFNET topology.

title: Post-Disaster Restoration Based on Path Stability in Elastic Optical Networks under Cascading Failures
authors: Eonassis O. Santos, Leila F. Ferreira, Juliana de Santi, Rujia Zou, Sabidur Rahman, Suresh Subramaniam, Gustavo B. Figueiredo
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Large-scale disasters often trigger cascading failures in Elastic Optical Networks (EONs), severely compromising communication networks. This paper introduces a restoration model based on Time-Varying Graphs (TVGs), which captures the temporal evolution of network degradation. The core insight of our approach lies in the observation that all snapshots in the TVG originate from a single initial graph G0 through monotonic topology changes, in which only node and link removals occur over time. the cost-based order of shortest paths computed in G0 is preserved in any degraded snapshot Gi, allowing restoration to be performed by scanning a precomputed candidate path set without global recomputation. Leveraging this property, we design the TVG-DR algorithm, which restores disrupted services efficiently by dynamically selecting the most failure-resilient path from a reusable pool. Simulation results confirm that TVG-DR improves restorability, reduces the number of connections experiencing recurrent disruptions during cascading, and increases availability when compared to conventional strategies.

title: Hybrid Quantum-Classical Computers: A Critical Analysis to Quantum Computational Models
authors: Azita Hajizade, Riccardo Bassoli, Frank H. P. Fitzek
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Quantum computers can often be used in a hybrid setting, where classical computers still play an important role in the operation and use of the quantum computer. A hybrid architecture can serve as a foundational paradigm for realizing the early potential of quantum technologies, allowing us to combine the advantages of classical systems with the emerging capabilities of quantum processors to enable useful computations despite hardware limitations. Keeping the Turing machine for the classical part, this paper provides 5 types of quantum computational models and investigates the key effects and challenges of each from a theoretical point of view. In addition, it gives an overview of the key properties and recent advances to integrate the most efficient and feasible hybrid scheme based on the application in our Quantum Network.

title: Water Demand Model for the Valley of Mexico Using the Logistic Equation of Population Growth
authors: Mario Jiménez Hernández
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The growth of a human population is related to the availability of its resources for its development, the most important being water, therefore, the amount limit of available water determines the maximum value of population growth in a given geographic area. This paper models population growth for the Valley of Mexico using the logistic equation. The values reported by the INEGI population censuses are considered. The population growth threshold is based on the average available water quantity per inhabitant for the Valley of Mexico using statistics from CONAGUA and SEMARNAT. The results present model predictions for population growth under different initial conditions.

title: The Analysis of Harmonic Currents of Residential Heat Pump During Characteristic Operating Modes
authors: Lidija M. Korunović, Dragan Vučković, Goran Vučković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper addresses harmonic currents injected by a heat pump into the low-voltage network. A typical residential heat pump operating in different operating modes is considered. The changes in power and harmonic currents are analysed. Harmonics are compared with international standard limits and the possible effects of the mass deployment of heat pumps on the network are indicated.

title: Agentic GenAI-Driven Network Management: Outage Probability of Relay Signal Transmission Using DF Technique Under BX Fading Case Study
authors: Nenad Petrović, Suad Suljović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper explores the application of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) to network design and management in order to achieve automated maintenance in modern telecommunications. Leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs), Vision-Language Models (VLMs), and Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), the proposed framework enables intelligent reasoning, modeling, and automation of network operations, including both the designand run-time aspects. As a case study, the framework is applied to outage probability estimation in a dual-hop Decode-and-Forward (DF) relay system under Beaulieu-Xie (BX) fading. The results confirm that GenAI-assisted workflows can significantly reduce effort and time while maintaining accuracy, demonstrating their potential to enhance automation, reliability, and efficiency in next-generation 5G/6G network management.

title: Optimal Charging Patterns of EV Prosumers to Maintain Grid Stability
authors: Zhou Song, Madia Safdar, Rabbaya Akhtar, G. Amjad Hussain, Wathiq Mansoor, Farhan H. Malik
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: With the global energy transition and sustainable development, the electric vehicle (EV) market is expanding rapidly. Charging many EVs poses challenges to grid stability, such as load surges. EV prosumers, acting as both energy producers and consumers, can help optimize energy usage, trade surplus electricity, and enhance grid stability. This work involves development of an optimization problem to plan the charging of EVs to support minimizing the peak power of the power grid which eventually helps to improve the stability of the power grid. The energy trading system for EVs based on blockchain ensures the transparency and security of energy transactions. The results of this work show the reduction in the peak load on the grid by 10% though the proposed framework. The proposed idea paves the way for a sustainable and efficient energy ecosystem tailored to the growing demands of EV integration.

title: Kinesthetic Chemistry Learning with the Multimolecular Structural Sphere (MMSS)
authors: Jorge Lozano-Aponte, Julián Alejandro Yunes-Rojas, Rosmarbel Morales-Nava, José Manuel Nieto-Jalil, Andrea Escobar-Bazaldúa
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The study of chemistry, particularly at the molecular level, presents considerable challenges for students due to the highly abstract nature of molecular structures. Three-dimensional representations are essential for comprehending molecular geometry, bonding, and polarity. This study introduces the Multimolecular Structural Sphere (MMSS), a 3D-printed, didactic tool designed to enhance conceptual understanding of molecular geometry through tangible, student-centered learning. The project was implemented in the course Foundation of the Structure and Transformation of Matter at Tecnológico de Monterrey, campus Puebla, México (August-November 2024). Two groups were compared: a traditional instruction group (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}$</tex> = 52) and a treatment group using MMSS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n=64)$</tex>. Although no statistically significant difference in average grades was found (6.9 vs. 7.0), the MMSS group demonstrated greater dispersion of scores, with a subset of students scoring below the mean, influencing the overall result. Exploratory and Confirmatory Factor Analyses (EFA and CFA) of the knowledge survey provided evidence of construct validity, supporting a refined 15-item instrument structured around three thematic dimensions of molecular geometry. Student perception results were notably positive, 83% found MMSS highly beneficial for learning and 86% reported increased motivation to study chemistry <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(n=62)$</tex>. The MMSS proved to be cost-effective, durable, and easily reproducible through 3D printing, offering broad potential for adoption in educational contexts. Entering the second phase of this project-focused on refining the model, enhancing the survey, and strengthening its pedagogical integration, the findings suggest that the MMSS can transform the teaching of complex chemistry concepts, making them more intuitive, engaging, and accessible for students.

authors: M.Á. Pérez-Jiménez, A. L. Herrera-May, A. Baez-Rodríguez, U. G. Zapata-Rodríguez, E. I. Caldelas-González, G. Mendoza-Barron, R. Rodríguez-Huerta, J. Martínez-Castillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Organic field-effect transistors (OFETs) offer several advantages, including lightness, flexibility, low power consumption, low-temperature manufacturing, and high sensitivity. In addition, OFETs can operate as switches, amplifiers, transducers, controllers, smart cards, sensors, and artificial skin. The design of OFETs with low operating voltages is key to enabling their applications in the portable electronics industry. Recent advances in OFET designs have utilized SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and polymers. However, these materials have low dielectric constants and operate at high voltages, which is not suitable for portable low-power transistors. To address these challenges, we propose a compact simulation model of an OFET based on Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> with a high dielectric constant. This model is developed through Silvaco Atlas Software, considering variations in the thickness of pentacene and dielectric layers and selecting gold electrodes. For the lower gate/lower contact transistor configuration and a 60 nm pentacene layer, the simulation model predicts the higher drain currents. With the proposed simulation model, current-voltage electrical characteristics of OFETs can be compared with those of others manufactured in the laboratory. Our simulation model of OFETs can be used to estimate their charge transport properties for applications in portable electronics.

title: Educational Laboratory Course on UWB Technology
authors: Natalia Skliar, Roman Pavlovich, Roman Kostin, Ali Alizadeh, Aleksandr Khelvas, Aleksandr Gilya-Zetinov, Mikhail Marinovich, Ruslan Pashkov, Dmitry Severov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This article presents an original laboratory course on Ultra-Wideband (UWB) technologies developed for technical university students. The course enables students to acquire practical skills in conducting experimental work using electronic equipment. Statistical methods and trajectory filtering techniques are used to process the experimental results.

title: Emulation of Slowloris Attack
authors: Ilija Bašičević, Milan Žeželj, Miloš Jovanović, Filip Parag, Miroslav Popović, Mirko Sužnjević
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this paper we present a laboratory prototype and results of emulation of the Slowloris attack. In this type of attack, the attacker overwhelms the target server with opening and maintaining long lived HTTP connections. Although some defense techniques exist, the attack is still present in the Internet environment. SPHERE testbed has been used for emulation, and publicly available Slowloris tool was used to create the attack. Results indicate that the presented setup can easily emulate Slowloris attack. Numerical parameters of server performance under attacks with different intensity are given.

title: Real-Time Kinematics Positioning GNSS Landslide Monitoring System – Hardware Components
authors: Asja Muharemović, Dejan Jokić, Jasmin Kevrić, Marko Simeunović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Monitoring landslide activity demands positioning systems that can operate continuously in difficult terrain while maintaining high accuracy. Traditional geodetic GNSS receivers provide excellent precision but are often too costly and delicate for large-scale deployments. Recent developments in affordable GNSS hardware have opened new opportunities for building dense monitoring networks at a fraction of the expense. This paper reviews the hardware components most critical to such systems, including receiver types, antennas, power solutions, and communication links. Low-cost single-frequency devices, such as u-blox modules, demonstrate promising results under favorable conditions, though they require longer convergence times. Dual-frequency receivers, such as the ZED-F9P, deliver faster initialization and more reliable precision, albeit with higher cost. Antenna configuration further influences performance, with geodetic-grade options ensuring stability and calibrated patch antennas offering practical compromises. Field deployments typically integrate solar panels with battery storage and rely on cellular or radio communication for real-time data transfer. With overall system costs ranging from €500 to €1500 per station, properly configured low-cost units have proven capable of tracking ground displacements with sufficient accuracy for landslide monitoring. The evidence suggests that careful hardware integration, balancing receiver choice, antenna performance, autonomous power supply, and connectivity is key to designing effective and resilient GNSS monitoring networks.

title: Brain Age Prediction from Morphometric MRI Data Using Machine Learning: Feature Engineering and Atlas-Based Comparisons
authors: Maria Waligórska, Tomasz Wolak
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study investigates brain age prediction using morphometric data extracted from 4352 MRI images, not previously analyzed in any study. Various machine learning algorithms were implemented and different feature subsets were evaluated. Our models achieved results comparable to previous research while also exploring different preprocessing strategies, including dimensionality reduction with Principal Component Analysis, and compare model performances across different anatomical brain atlases. We demonstrate that combining carefully selected features from multiple atlases leads to improved model performance, surpassing models trained on one atlas sets and PCA-transformed data. Additionally, we assess the impact of manual verification on prediction accuracy and investigate brain structures that have the greatest impact on age prediction. Unlike many studies that focus on markers of dementia, this work highlights brain structures that change in a stable and most consistent manner throughout life, rather than those that atrophy most rapidly in old age. We present an analysis using two model explainability methods: Permutation Importance and SHAP.

title: Study on the Verification of Braking Performance of Servie Robots using a Motion Analysis System
authors: Jong Hyun Kim, Chang Gi Lee, Hyun Chul Tae, Jun Sang Park
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study presents an evaluation method and results for quantitatively verifying the braking performance of a disinfection service robot-a critical factor for ensuring operational safety in real-world environments. A motion analysis system (Vicon Inc., U.K.) was used to assess the robot’s braking performance in automated operation modes, including interactions with non-fixed obstacles. Braking distance and braking time were analyzed before and after improvements to the control algorithm. After the improvement, the average braking distance was shortened to 20.5 mm across all conditions. This study provides empirical data supporting performance enhancement and safety certification of service robots.

title: A Novel Lightweight Consensus Mechanism for Mobile Nodes in Decentralized Networks
authors: Zhuo Zhang, Yang Lin, Jie Liu, Weifu Meng, Yannian Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper proposes an innovative blockchain consensus participation mechanism designed to enable mobile nodes to directly engage in the blockchain network’s consensus process. By introducing a hierarchical validation architecture, this mechanism significantly lowers the technical and resource barriers to consensus participation, thereby effectively enhancing network decentralization. The study elaborates on the design principles, system model, consensus protocol, and its security analysis, also discussing its performance and robustness in practical applications. Operational results demonstrate that this mechanism can effectively leverage the computational resources of mobile devices, providing a new theoretical foundation and practical solution for building a more open, inclusive, and decentralized blockchain ecosystem.

title: Phase Optimization for RIS-MIMO Detection via Condition Number Minimization for Correlated Channels
authors: Rubeena Aafreen, Mohammed Zafar Ali Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) have gained popularity for application in the next-generation of communication systems, owing to their ability to dynamically manipulate the propagation environment via controllable phase shifts. Efficient utilization of these phase shifts is critical for optimizing system performance across diverse applications. This paper proposes a unique eigenvalue-based phase optimization framework for RIS-assisted multiple-input, multiple-output (MIMO) systems, aimed at reducing the condition number of the Gram matrix and enhancing the performance of the minimum mean square error (MMSE) detector. A maximizing minimum eigenvalue approach is used to dynamically modify the phase of the RIS, followed by MMSE detection at the base station (BS). Simulation results demonstrate a 50% reduction in condition number, which translates into a BER improvement of more than 5 dB at 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sup>error rate compared to conventional RIS-MIMO schemes with random phase assignments. Also, since the proposed approach is dedicated to improving channel conditioning, it also indicates the convergence of iterative methods for the MMSE detection schemes in a highly correlated environment, thus leading to a further reduction in complexity at the BS.

title: Channel-Aware Distributed Transmission Control and Video Streaming in UAV Networks
authors: Masoud Ghazikor, Keenan Roach, Kenny Cheung, Morteza Hashemi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: In this paper, we study the problem of distributed transmission control and video streaming optimization for unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) operating in unlicensed spectrum bands. We develop a rigorous cross-layer analysis framework that jointly considers three inter-dependent factors: (i) in-band interference introduced by ground-aerial nodes at the physical (PHY) layer, (ii) limited-size queues with delay-constrained packet arrival at the medium access control (MAC) layer, and (iii) video encoding rate at the application layer. First, we formulate an optimization problem to maximize the average throughput by optimizing the fading threshold (transmission policy). To this end, we jointly analyze the queue-related packet loss probabilities (i.e., buffer overflow and time threshold event) as well as the outage probability due to the low signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR). We introduce the Distributed Transmission Control (DTC) algorithm that maximizes the average throughput by adjusting transmission policies to balance the trade-offs between packet drop from queues vs. transmission errors due to low SINRs. Second, we incorporate the video distortion model to develop distributed peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) optimization for video streaming. The formulated optimization incorporates two cross-layer parameters, specifically the fading threshold and video encoding rate. To tackle this problem, we develop the Joint Distributed Video Transmission and Encoder Control (JDVT-EC) algorithm that enhances the average PSNR for all nodes by fine-tuning transmission policies and video encoding rates to balance the trade-offs between packet loss and lossy video compression distortions. Through extensive numerical analysis, we thoroughly examine the proposed algorithms and demonstrate that they are able to find the optimal transmission policies and video encoding rates under various scenarios. Notably, our approach improves the average throughput by 1.7% to 51.65% compared to various baselines, including the selfish and random policies. Additionally, we demonstrate an average PSNR increase of 0.24 dB and 1.7 dB compared to separately optimizing the fading threshold and video encoding rate, respectively.

title: RFDA Frequency Offset Synthesis Given Specified Range Resolution of the Spot-Like Beampattern
authors: Keyhan Hosseini, Mohammad Fathi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Random frequency diverse arrays (RFDAs) yield spot-like beampatterns in both angle and range dimensions. As a result of random frequency offsets, direct estimation of range and angle extension is not feasible. In this communication, the half power beamlength (HPBL) of the fundamental harmonic of the radiation pattern is utilized to design appropriate random frequency offsets to ensure that the RFDA exhibits a specified range resolution. For symmetric probability density functions (PDFs) of the frequency offsets, the problem is cast into a convex quadratic optimization program with linear constraints. In contrast, for general PDFs, the problem is primarily non-convex which is transformed into an iterative quadratic problem with linear constraints exploiting a Lagrange multiplier. Finally, a PDF-weighted random number generator is used to generate several RFDAs with the desired HPBLs. The proposed PDFs generate radiation patterns with desired range resolutions for arbitrary frequency offset coefficients, while enjoying acceptable side lobe levels.
