title: Publicly verifiable information sharing solution in edge computing scenarios
authors: Weixin Liu, Qingshui Xue
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Edge computing has received more and more attention in recent years. Since its terminal devices only have information collection and information generation functions, their own computing power is limited and they need the assistance of edge computing nodes to complete computing tasks. In this process, edge computing nodes are considered unreliable. They not only intend to obtain private information, but also have a certain probability of forging computing results. In response to the above problems, this paper designs a solution based on the three-layer architecture of edge network. First, this paper adopts the improved entanglement polynomial coding technology, which can effectively prevent the leakage of terminal device privacy information and reduce the number of edge nodes required to participate in the calculation; secondly, with the help of the preset auxiliary server, the calculation results finally aggregated by the edge nodes on the central server are verified to prevent some edge nodes from maliciously calculating wrong calculation results and eventually causing the failure of the computing task; finally, the whole scheme realizes the malicious security of edge nodes and ensures high efficiency while achieving high-level malicious security. In the final verification process, the central server will publicly publish the proof evidence, and each participant can verify the correctness of the entire calculation result. Finally, we conduct security and performance analysis on the scheme in this paper. The experimental results show that this scheme is superior to previous schemes in terms of preprocessing overhead and communication overhead.

title: Evaluation of Wearable Sensors for Mental Fatigue Level Estimation under Physical Fatigue
authors: Ahmad Fauzi, Ayumi Ohnishi, Tsutomu Terada, Masahiko Tsukamoto
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Estimating mental fatigue levels during physical exertion is essential for ensuring safety and optimizing performance in sports and other high-demand environments. However, it remains challenging due to the overlapping physiological signals involved. This study examines the effectiveness of various wearable sensors, including ECG, PPG, and EEG, as well as eye trackers, in estimating mental fatigue levels under conditions of physical fatigue. Multimodal sensor data collected during controlled experiments that combined cognitive tasks with physical exercise were analyzed, with a focus on machine learning models for estimating mental fatigue levels. The results show that although EEG is the most accurate single sensor for estimating mental fatigue levels under physical fatigue, a combination of ECG and eye-tracking shows better accuracy (79.16%) with minimal error (MAE $=0.52$). This combination offers a balance between performance and wearability for practical applications.

title: Middleware-Based Customizable Plush Toy Controller for Game Accessibility Enhancement
authors: Yuto Fuse, Hiroshi Ikeoka
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Providing equitable gaming experiences for diverse players, including elderly and those with physical disabilities who cannot manipulate conventional gamepads, mice, keyboards or physical sensor controllers, is an important challenge in human-computer interaction. We have also been developing a middleware-based plush toy controller system for video games. This system utilizes AI technology to estimate plush toy poses, enabling game players to control gameplay through natural and intuitive manipulation of the plush toy’s position and joint positions. However, the system’s lack of flexible input customization limited its versatility across different games and plush toys. In this work, we report on the development of a middleware that bridges plush toy controller inputs to in-game actions through flexible input customization via a graphical user interface (GUI), making this controller system compatible with various games and significantly expanding the controller’s adaptability. The main contribution of the middleware is enabling intuitive binding of various plush toy movements, such as moving the body, tilting, or raising arms, to in-game actions. Questionnaire surveys indicated that the controller system was perceived as highly usable and responsive, achieving high scores on enjoyment metrics. This work demonstrates that our proposed alternative input method can achieve near-comparable performance to conventional devices while significantly improving game accessibility for individuals unable to use conventional input devices.

title: OAM-LiFiNet: Orientation Aware Multi-AP Li-Fi Network with User Mobility
authors: Saswati Paramita, Abhinav Rawat, Vivek Ashok Bohara
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Li-Fi networks provide high indoor throughput but face challenges due to their reliance on line-of-sight (LoS) and limited coverage. User mobility can degrade throughput as movement beyond a single access point (AP) reduces signal quality, while deploying multiple APs introduces interference and signal fluctuations. This paper uses the random waypoint mobility model to analyze how device orientation impacts signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) and throughput in dynamic indoor environments. Results show that orienting user devices toward a Li-Fi AP enhances SINR in high-interference areas, while a non-oriented state improves throughput in low-interference regions by preserving LoS. The proposed strategy dynamically adjusts device orientation based on real-time SINR and channel conditions, balancing interference reduction and LoS preservation. This adaptive approach optimizes network performance under varying mobility and interference scenarios, improving throughput and reliability in Li-Fi networks.

title: Live Testing of Cloud Services: A Framework and Lessons Learned
authors: Oussama Jebbar, Ferhat Khendek
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Cloud services enable cloud-native architectures for 5G networks. They enable rapid and scalable deployment of cloud- native network functions and services. These cloud services need to be tested thoroughly in the development environment as well as in the production environment because of the differences between these environments. Current practices focus on executing the test cases in the production environment without disturbing the system usage. However, these practices have limitations as they only apply to specific types of components or features. We propose a solution for live testing cloud services in the production environment. Our solution consists of a framework based on an architecture and a set of methods. The goal of such architecture is to automate testing activities in the production environment, and enable testing services in the production environment while avoiding test interferences. While giving an overall picture of our solution on live testing we also draw a set of lessons that may be relevant and useful for other software engineering activities that are usually conducted in the production environment.

title: Enhanced Power Savings by Conjunction of PDCCH Skipping with BWP Switching, SCell Dormancy and CDRX
authors: Sathish P, Rahul Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Energy efficiency is a key performance indicator in 5G New Radio (NR) networks, crucial for both user equipment (UE) and base station sides. On the UE side, battery life significantly impacts user experience. Improving UE performance without affecting battery life is challenging due to varying traffic patterns within an active data session. To support power-saving mechanisms, 3GPP proposed PDCCH skipping. PDCCH is used for transmitting control information, and its usage directly affects UE power consumption. By implementing PDCCH skipping, UEs can save power by not monitoring PDCCH during certain periods. Furthermore, when PDCCH skipping is combined with other power-saving features such as CDRX, Scell dormancy, and BWP inactivity timer, even more significant power savings can be achieved. This multi-faceted approach to power saving enables 5G NR networks to enhance UE battery life and overall energy efficiency, providing a better user experience.

title: AI-Driven Dynamic Line Rating to Enhance Power Grid Resilience to Extreme Weather Events
authors: Moamar Sayed-Mouchaweh
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Power grids are increasingly vulnerable to outages due to the rising frequency and severity of extreme weather events, particularly heatwaves. Enhancing the climate resilience of power systems is therefore essential to ensure reliable electricity delivery and minimize the impact of such disruptions. This paper presents an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven approach for real-time monitoring of the thermal capacity of transmission lines. The proposed approach enables early detection of line overheating during heatwave conditions and provides timely alerts to grid operators, allowing for corrective actions that safeguard the integrity and reliability of the transmission network.

title: A Hybrid Approach to Efficient Adaptive Multimedia Streaming
authors: Radenko Banovic, Dragan Kukolj, Ilija Basicevic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Video streaming represents the dominant type of traffic on the Internet today, with MPEG Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP (DASH) being the leading standard for adaptive video delivery. The main goal of streaming services is to provide the best possible Quality of Experience (QoE) to the user, and one of the most critical components in achieving this is the adaptation algorithm, which selects the most appropriate video representation under the variable network conditions. Numerous adaptive bitrate (ABR) algorithms aiming to improve the QoE have been proposed, mainly following two approaches: based on measured throughput values (traditional approach), and those relying on the prediction of throughput for the next segment download. This paper presents a novel hybrid DASH adaptation algorithm approach that combines the traditional measurement-based approach with throughput prediction to improve users QoE. An ablation study was conducted to identify the Takagi-Sugeno-Kang (TSK) model that provides the most accurate prediction of network throughput. Four key QoE metrics were considered in the experimental evaluation: average bitrate, the number of bitrate transitions, the magnitude of bitrate changes, and the duration of buffer underruns (the time during which multimedia playback is stalled). The proposed algorithm outperformed all evaluated algorithms across all QoE metrics.

title: Optimization of Wind Turbine Power Generation Using Carbon Fiber Single Blade
authors: Pelumi Peter Aluko-Olokun, Muhammad Akmal, Haris M. Khalid, Ghulam Amjad Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The proposed research examines the effectiveness of a single-blade carbon-fiber wind turbine. A finite element analysis (FEA) is performed to evaluate the enhanced stiffness and vibration characteristics of the orthotropic carbon fiber. Moreover, the airflow patterns around the turbine blade at various angles of attack are also explored through comprehensive computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations. Although there are advantages, such as reduced weight, the carbon fiber single blade still faces challenges related to practical performance, manufacturing development, environmental impacts, and cost-effectiveness.

title: Industry Revolutions and Business Intelligence Resources for Designing an Automation Roadmap
authors: Josué Aarón López-Leyva, Miguel Ángel Ponce Camacho, Gerson Caleb Lopez-Servin de la Mora, Víctor Manuel Ramos García
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper examines the evolution of industrial revolutions, from Industry 1.0 to Industry 6.0, and their relationship with Business Intelligence (BI) as a strategic tool for business automation. It highlights the contributions of BI to improving organizational competitiveness through the analysis and exploitation of tangible (technological infrastructure) and intangible (processes, methodologies, and analytical tools) resources. Using Porter's value chain model, it identifies critical areas where BI can add value by optimizing both primary and support activities. It also proposes a roadmap for business automation based on competitive analysis, identification of improvement opportunities, cost-benefit assessment, and implementation of technology solutions. Finally, it presents some data mining tools, which are essential for transforming data into strategic knowledge and facilitating informed decision-making.

title: Robustness of Structured Data Extraction from Perspectively Distorted Documents
authors: Hyakka Nakada, Yoshiyasu Tanaka
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for data extraction from documents is essential to intelligent informatics, such as digitizing medical records and recognizing road signs. Multi-modal Large Language Models (LLMs) can solve this task and have shown remarkable performance. Recently, it has been noticed that the accuracy of data extraction by multi-modal LLMs can be affected when in-plane rotations are present in the documents. However, real-world document images are usually not only in-plane rotated but also perspectively distorted. This study investigates the impacts of such perturbations on the data extraction accuracy for the state-of-the-art model, Gemini-1.5-pro. Because perspective distortions have a high degree of freedom, designing experiments in the same manner as single-parametric rotations is difficult. We observed typical distortions of document images and showed that most of them approximately follow an isosceles-trapezoidal transformation, which allows us to evaluate distortions with a small number of parameters. We were able to reduce the number of independent parameters from eight to two, i.e. rotation angle and distortion ratio. Then, specific entities were extracted from synthetically generated sample documents with varying these parameters. As the performance of LLMs, we evaluated not only a character-recognition accuracy but also a structure-recognition accuracy. Whereas the former represents the classical indicators for optical character recognition, the latter is related to the correctness of reading order. In particular, the structure-recognition accuracy was found to be significantly degraded by document distortion. In addition, we found that this accuracy can be improved by a simple rotational correction. This insight will contribute to the practical use of multi-modal LLMs for OCR tasks.

title: 5G Regulatory and Policy Framework in Emerging Economies
authors: Laurence Banda, Fisseha Mekuria, Mjumo Mzyece
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The rollout of 5G networks presents a major opportunity for digital transformation in emerging economies, yet regulatory and policy challenges threaten to delay progress. This paper analyzes the current 5G regulatory landscape in emerging economies, focusing on spectrum allocation, licensing, institutional capacity, and regional policy coordination. Using qualitative policy analysis and case studies from South Africa, Nigeria, and Kenya, the study highlights disparities in readiness and identifies critical gaps. Key findings underscore the need for cohesive strategies to address infrastructure, governance, and inclusion. The paper offers policy recommendations, including spectrum reform, regional harmonization, and inclusive regulation, to support an enabling environment for 5G development in emerging economies.

title: Simulation of Entanglement-Based Competition Resolution in Distributed Systems
authors: Roaa Jasim Algayyim, Sándor Imre
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Resource access is a fundamental challenge in distributed systems where multiple uncoordinated nodes contend for a limited medium. Classical random-access protocols, such as Slotted-ALOHA, achieve modest efficiency because of frequent collisions and retransmissions. An entanglement-based procedure for collision-free slot allocation is investigated in this paper. The performance is evaluated through simulation under ideal classical and quantum channels. A system of N competing nodes is modeled, and three operations are implemented: JOIN, LEAVE, and TRANSFER. These operations rebalance amplitude probabilities and reflect node priorities while preserving normalization. The entanglementbased approach compares the obtained throughput and collision metrics with those of Slotted-ALOHA. It is shown through simulation results that higher throughput is achieved and collisions are completely eliminated across all tested <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex> and iteration settings. According to the theoretical model presented in [9], this study is focused on developing a practical simulation framework and exploring priority-aware scenarios. The results demonstrate the feasibility of distributed entanglement establishment and provide a practical interpretation of JOIN, LEAVE, and TRANSFER operations under normalized probability constraints.

title: A Case Study on the Impact of Noise on Maximum Likelihood Quantum Amplitude Estimation
authors: Doaa Subhi, Laszlo Bacsardi
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The recent quantum age has allowed quantum algorithms to perform in the real world. However, they have significant performance errors in noisy environments. To investigate this issue, we conduct an analysis and simulation to evaluate maximum likelihood quantum amplitude estimation (MLQAE) circuit depths under various conditions: (1) ideal, (2) theoretical noise model, and (3) real noise model. These show variant performance errors, especially in a high-qubit circuit with high error rates, even when using a low-noise model.

authors: Usman Ahmed Siddiqui, Avesha Khurram, Raja Masood Larik, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Yassine Himeur, Zeeshan Ahmad Arfeen, Zeeshan Rashid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As the demand for renewable energy grows, maximizing the efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) systems has become crucial. Solar tracking technologies, particularly single-axis and dual-axis systems, play a key role in enhancing energy yield. This study presents a comparative analysis of these two systems in terms of energy efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and real-world applicability. Dual-axis trackers offer higher energy gains by following the sun's movement in both azimuth and elevation, but come with increased costs and complexity. Single-axis trackers, while less efficient, provide a simpler and more economical solution suitable for larger-scale or budget-conscious installations. The analysis considers factors such as installation and maintenance costs, return on investment, and suitability across different environments. The findings suggest that although dual-axis systems outperform in terms of energy capture, single-axis systems may offer a better trade-off between performance and affordability for many practical scenarios.

title: Interpretable Network Intrusion Detection Framework using Hybrid DL and ML Models
authors: Madhu R Koravanavar, Sanika S Mithare, Rajendra Hegadi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Network Intrusion Detection Systems (NIDS) play a critical role in safeguarding digital infrastructures against rapidly evolving cyberthreats. Traditional NIDS often struggle to maintain high detection accuracy while providing transparency and adaptability, particularly when faced with sophisticated or zero-day attacks. To address these challenges, the proposed work presents a hybrid deep learning and explainability-driven architecture for intrusion detection. The approach integrates a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network for capturing sequential attack patterns with a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for local feature extraction, enabling both temporal and spatial learning. To enhance interpretability, the proposed work employs Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) and SMOTE sampling to quantify feature contributions, providing actionable insights to security analysts. Additionally, Isolation Forest-based anomaly detection identifies unusual and zero-day attacks that lie outside the labeled training distribution. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed CNN, LSTM, Autoencoder and Isolation Forest pipeline achieves superior detection accuracy while maintaining transparency. By combining deep learning with explainable AI, this framework offers a robust, trustworthy, and adaptable NIDS capable of responding effectively to evolving cyberthreat landscapes.

title: Low-Complex LLR Computation for 5G-NR
authors: Arjun Menon K, Samudrala Soujanya, Prem Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a novel, low-complex algorithm for log-likelihood ratio (LLR) computation tailored for higher-order quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) modulation schemes in fifth-generation new radio (5G-NR) systems. Unlike conventional approaches that require distinct, complex calculations for each modulation order, the proposed method uses a recursive framework that models LLR calculation as a scaled and shifted quadrature phase shift keying (QPSK) problem, enabling scalability and uniformity across modulation schemes. The proposed algorithm significantly reduces computational complexity and execution time by utilizing only linear operations and avoiding computationally intensive operations, making it highly suitable for hardware implementation. These reductions are achieved by the proposed scheme with almost no compromise in block error rate (BLER) performance, as demonstrated by simulation results. Its recursive and scalable design makes it a promising solution for efficient LLR computation in higher-order modulation schemes used in 5G-NR systems.

title: A 2-W Ka-Band Power Amplifier Design in the 0.15 μm GaAs pHEMT Technology
authors: Mehmet Batuhan Dinç, Mustafa Berke Yelten
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents a three-stage 2-W Ka-band power amplifier (PA) operating from 24 to 28 GHz. The PA is designed using a commercially available <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.15 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> GaAs pHEMT technology. It employs various matching network types, including cluster, bus-bar, and T-type networks. Under a 4 V supply voltage, the simulated PA exhibits a large-signal gain of more than 16 dB and achieves a saturated output power exceeding 2 W, with a power-added efficiency (PAE) exceeding 24% at the 3 -dB compression point. The small-signal gain has a flat response with less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1$</tex> ripple. The input and output return losses are lower than −6 dB and −12 dB, respectively. The occupied chip area is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.3 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Rapid Prototyping Techniques of Industrial Environment
authors: Faruk Hota, Dejan Jokić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper explores the integration of control and monitoring systems within a graphical environment where factory (production line) simulations can be conducted. Gamification of simulators enables realistic testing of proposed solutions, allowing errors to be identified and resolved before equipment is installed in real factories. In this way, the 1-10-100 rule can be applied, where quality issues and costs grow rapidly depending on the stage at which they are detected. The most effective approach is to use simulators to verify design of factories before purchasing and installing components. For this reason, the new generation of gamified simulators can significantly reduce both costs and development time for new factories. When including components from different manufacturers and various types of equipment such as PLCs, robots, and CNC machines, gamified simulators can support rapid prototyping of industrial environments. The Simulator Factory I/O, in combination with TIA Portal, is recognized as an adequate environment for verifying the proposed design of an entire factory or a specific part of a production line

title: Parallelized Movie Recommendation System for Efficient User Personalization
authors: Darko Petrushevski, Vladimir Zdraveski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In today's data-rich environment, recommendation systems must process vast user-item interactions efficiently. We present a parallel movie recommendation pipeline using Apache Spark's MLlib, accelerating training and prediction with distributed scheduling. Partitioning the rating matrix yields nearlinear speedups. On the MovieLens 32 M dataset [1], our ALS model runs 99% faster than a sequential baseline on 10 cores, with an RMSE of 0.82. We also analyze performance factors such as cores, shuffle, block size and caching.

title: Overview of Interpretable and Explainable Artificial Intelligence for Atrial Fibrillation
authors: Stojancho Tudjarski, Ana Angjelevska, Marjan Gusev, Ana Madevska Bogdanova
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Accurate and interpretable detection of irregular work of the heart, such as atrial fibrillation, from electrocardiogram (ECG) signals is crucial for timely diagnosis and effective patient management. While machine learning (ML) models, particularly deep learning architectures, have achieved state-of-the-art performance in ECG arrhythmia classification, their black-box nature limits clinical adoption. This paper explores explainable artificial intelligence (XAI) techniques applicable to ML models trained on ECG data, highlighting both global and local interpretability approaches. We provide an overview of posthoc methods, including SHAP, LIME, PFI, and LIG, among others, treating various types of ECG recordings. As a practical case study, we present our findings analyzing the results of PFI and LIG methods applied to a transformer-based model fine-tuned for atrial fibrillation detection and explain its decision process. Our findings underscore the value of integrating XAI into ECG analysis pipelines to enhance transparency, foster clinician trust, and support more informed decision-making in cardiovascular diagnostics.

title: Public 5G-Aided Robust Smartphone GNSS Localization in Challenging Environments
authors: Cung Lian Sang, Marco Drawe, Timo Siekmann, Marc Hesse, Ulrich Rückert
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we present a robust smartphone GNSS localization method aided by publicly accessible 5G signal metrics from existing infrastructure (i.e., public 5G networks). The approach requires only a typical smartphone and needs no external hardware, or operator-supplied information. It is implemented using standard Android APIs, and the signal extraction process is described in detail. We evaluated the method in a real-world test environment at a train station, which included indoor areas, train platforms, and an underground tunnel where GNSS signals were weak or obstructed. The proposed system demonstrates significant improvements in position estimation accuracy in such challenging environments. Notably, the approach is agnostic to mobile network operator, smartphone model, and 5G deployment mode (ie., non-standalone (NSA) and standalone (SA)), underscoring its broad applicability.

title: Feature Importance Analysis of Smart Meter Time Series for Electricity Theft Detection
authors: Cvetanka Bilbiloska, Elena Todorova, Ema Mishevska, Marija Markovska, Dimitar Taskovski, Branislav Gerazov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Electricity theft, a major source of NonTechnical Losses (NTL) in power distribution, poses an imbalanced and rare-event classification challenge. This paper proposes a data-driven framework for detecting anomalous consumption patterns using engineered statistical and dynamic features instead of raw time-series inputs. A diverse set of descriptors-capturing variability, entropy, autocorrelation, and seasonality-is ranked through information-based and model-agnostic importance measures. Two ensemble classifiers, Random Forest (RF) and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), are evaluated under a unified training protocol using precision-recall metrics, with PRAUC as the main indicator of minority-class performance. Experiments on a large public dataset show that featurecentric modeling enhances interpretability and improves detection of irregular consumption, providing a transparent and scalable approach for smart-grid analytics.

title: Decoupled Control of Active and Reactive Power at the PCC Using Local Measurements for an Inverter Interfaced Virtual Power Plant
authors: Firdous Ul Nazir
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This work develops a decoupled control of active and reactive power for an inverter interfaced virtual power plant (VPP), considering the power losses over the feeder, connecting the inverter to the point of common coupling (PCC). Although active and reactive power is controlled at the far end of the feeder, the control is achieved by using only the local measurements at the inverter terminals, thereby reducing the implementation costs on account of less communication needs. The corresponding active and reactive power injections at the PCC are estimated from local measurements at the inverter terminals consisting of voltage magnitude, current magnitude, active and reactive power, and parameters of the feeder. The proposed controller uses Parks transformation and PI control logic to implement the decoupled control. Results on a test network under different scenarios prove the proposed controller can accurately inject the contracted amount of active and reactive power at the PCC.

title: Influence of Psychological Stress on Short-Time Energy of Speech Signal
authors: Jan Cícha, David Haisman, Pavel Horský
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This study deals with influence of psychological stress on short-time speech energy in terms of features derived from statistical distribution. Results are presented for full-band speech (20-11025 Hz) and for speech restricted to telephone signals (narrow band 300-3400 Hz and wide band 50-7000 Hz). In all three bands, voiced speech reflects stress better than full continuous speech, i.e., both voiced and unvoiced. The proposed algorithm is suitable for stress indication in full-band speech as well as in wide-band speech representing mobile telephony.

title: Probabilistic Trust Modeling and Security Verification for Smart Grid Systems
authors: Khalid Sultan, Muhammad Ikram, Aya Rezk
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Smart Grids represent the future of sustainable and intelligent energy management; however, their distributed, heterogeneous, and dynamic nature introduces critical security and trust challenges. Traditional cybersecurity approaches often fall short in modeling the uncertainty and partial knowledge inherent in Smart Grid environments. In this paper, we propose a novel formal trust-based framework for evaluating the security of Smart Grids under uncertainty. Our approach extends the Probabilistic Computation Tree Logic of Trust (PCTLT) with a group operator, resulting in the Probabilistic Computation Tree Logic of Group Trust (PCTLT+). We use this logic to formally specify trust-related security properties and verify them using a model checking technique. A scenario of a Smart Grid Energy Management System is introduced to illustrate key security concerns, such as device authenticity, data integrity, privacy protection, and command legitimacy. The proposed framework enables rigorous and interpretable reasoning about security through quantifiable trust relationships, providing a foundation for developing resilient and scalable Smart Grid infrastructures. Our work addresses a critical gap in current Smart Grid research by formally incorporating trust and uncertainty into the security evaluation process.

title: Investigation of Flashover Incidents in Medium Voltage Capacitor Bank Circuit Breakers
authors: Abdul Haleem Medattil Ibrahim, P Aliya, Tareg Ghaoud, Qais Atef Qawaqneh, Ahmed Saeed Habib Sajwani, Jassim Abdullah, Hassan Al Hammadi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Medium voltage (MV) capacitor bank circuit breakers in utility distribution networks experience repeated switching duty, exposing interrupters and associated components to high transient electrical stress. Recent flashover incidents in the MV capacitor bank circuit breakers motivated a detailed investigation based on real event data, on-site measurements, operational observation, and correlation with prior studies. The paper analyzes the dominant contributors to flashover incidents, including inrush current behavior, transient recovery voltage stress, harmonic distortion, chassis earth currents, residual currents during capacitor bank switching-off events, and the effects of switching sequence and timing. The study further evaluates the limitations of existing circuit breaker configurations, particularly under floating neutral MV capacitor bank installations, and identifies practical mitigation options including detuned reactor configurations, multi step switching, adaptive operational control, and enhanced interrupter capability requirements. With the findings from this study, engineering recommendations are provided to improve reliability, mitigate flashovers, and guide future development of MV capacitor bank switching specifications for non-earthed systems.

title: Development of a Cost-Effective Modular Vital Signs Monitoring System for Educational and Remote Healthcare Applications
authors: Netzha Valentino Vazquez Belmonte, José Ulises Meza Moreno, Guillermo Rey Peñaloza Mendoza
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a modular vital signs monitoring system intended for accessible healthcare applications. The system integrates a Raspberry Pi 4B as the central processing unit and an ESP32 microcontroller for communication through the UART protocol. Commercial biomedical sensors, including an ECG module, pulse oximeter, and a Bluetooth-based blood pressure monitor, are used for realtime measurement of physiological parameters. A custom user interface, developed entirely in Python using PyQt5 and PyQtGraph, provides real-time visualization, configurable signal selection, and alarm management. Preliminary testing demonstrates the system's capability to display simultaneous ECG leads (DI, DII, DIII), <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SpO}_{2}$</tex> waveforms, blood pressure readings, and body temperature in a unified interface. Experimental results showed the stable acquisition of ECG and plethysmographic (SpO2) signals, with an average end-to-end latency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 0 ~ m s} \pm \mathbf{1 5}$</tex> ms. Body temperature and blood pressure readings closely matched commercial monitors, while ECG traces displayed clear P-QRS-T complexes. Although <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SpO}_{2}$</tex> values exhibited fluctuations and BLE communication was occasionally susceptible to disconnections, the system proved reliable for educational use and holds potential as a cost-effective alternative for pre-hospital monitoring in low-resource environments.

title: A Numerically Efficient and Accurate Model for Real-Time Simulation of Solid-State Transformer using Implicit-Explicit Integration Methods
authors: Hengyu Li, Walid Hatahet, Jared Paull, Fei Zhang, Yuanshi Zhang, Liwei Wang, Wei Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Electromagnetic transient (EMT) models of power electronic converters are essential for converter design, control, and fault analysis. This paper proposes a switching-function-based detailed equivalent model (SFB-DEM) using combined implicit and explicit (ImEx) multi-step Gear's integration methods for numerically efficient and accurate EMT simulation. The proposed SFB-DEM integrates the benefits of implicit and explicit solvers, featuring converter circuit decoupling, node number reduction, and constant nodal-network conductance(G)-matrix in the EMT model. The SFB-DEMs employing the ImEx 2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">nd</sup> and 3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rd</sup> order Gear's (i.e., ImEx-G2O and ImEx-G3O) methods are implemented for solid-state transformer (SST) simulation. Additionally, a switching interpolation technique is proposed and integrated with the ImEx-G2O and ImEx-G3O solvers to account for intra-time-step switching events. The proposed SST SFB-DEMs greatly accelerate the EMT simulation, compared to the conventional detailed model (DM) and variable conductance(G)-matrix DEM (VG-DEM). For the SST with 60 SMs, the proposed SFB-DEM with ImEx-G3O method achieves the EMT simulation speedup by 171 and 7.5 folds, compared to the DM and VG-DEM, respectively.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp1-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Digital Twin of Wireless Physical Layer in Advanced Manufacturing Environment
authors: Minhajur Rahman, John-Davis C. Oyedum, Ivan Seskar, Yuebin Guo, Narayan B. Mandayam, Yingying Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a high-fidelity Digital Twin of the wireless physical layer for a representative manufacturing environment using Sionna’s ray-tracing engine. A detailed 3D model of the factory floor is integrated with Sionna to generate path loss, channel impulse response (CIR), and link-level calculations for an OFDM system. Using software-defined radio via the COSMOS testbed, we conducted measurements under both line-of-sight (LoS) and non-LOS (NLoS) conditions, employing CIR sounding and link-level analysis. The Digital Twin achieves a path loss exponent of 1.611 and shadow fading of 0.728 dB, closely matching the measured results and 3GPP Indoor Factory predictions, though underestimating shadow fading. CIR comparisons show an accurate capture of multipath components in most scenarios, with delay spread values that closely follow the measurements and remain within the bounds of the 3GPP factory model. The SNR vs. BER(Bit Error Rate) results revealed a systematic offset, which we addressed by applying a gain calibration to the Digital Twin so that simulated and measured SNR values aligned, enabling consistent link-level predictions. Then, we extended the Digital Twin to generate predictions in a 100 MHz wideband channel, producing BLER(Block Error Rate) maps that pinpoint optimal IIoT placement and demonstrate robustness in multipath-rich factories.

title: UCO: Load-Aware Collaborative Computing Offloading Algorithm for UAV Swarms
authors: Liqiong Chen, Xianhui Zhang, Shiya Chen, Sun Huaiying
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: With the widespread application of drones in scenarios such as inspection, logistics, and emergency communications, the contradiction between their limited computational resources and the high real-time requirements of tasks has become increasingly prominent. To address computational offloading challenges in cooperative drone missions, this paper proposes a load-aware lightweight task scheduling algorithm (UCO, UAV Cooperative Offloading). Centering on minimizing average task response time, the method integrates real-time computational load and location data to construct a distributed task offloading decision model. By designing an iterative task forwarding mechanism based on load information, the algorithm enables dynamic task allocation within the UAV swarm, preventing individual node overload. Simulation results demonstrate that compared to random offloading and nearest-node offloading strategies, the UCO algorithm effectively reduces average task response time while significantly improving swarm load balancing. This validates the algorithm’s effectiveness and superiority in dynamic UAV swarm environments.

title: Technology Comparison for Medium-Voltage Switchgear: AIS vs. GIS
authors: Luis Ivan Ruiz Flores, Leoncio E. Morales Ocampo, Brenda Campos Castillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a comparison of technologies in Medium Voltage Panels that exist in the electricity market. The manufacturing industry that has had facilities for more than 3 decades requires modernizing its electrical systems and energy distribution with efficient medium voltage panels. Today, there are gas-insulated technologies that allow agile protection and selectivity in the coordination of protections. The use of gas insulation is widely used for industrial installations that require optimizing electrical safety and human safety. Based on the above, the comparison of two insulation media is presented, considering the durability of materials, cost, size and long-term maintenance. The purpose is to contribute to the design of safe facilities, considering that the manufacture of this equipment is already a reality in the electricity market. It also tries to contribute to the technical knowledge of engineers who make decisions in projects of this nature, such as the engineers in charge of the Auxiliary Services of electrical maintenance and the Supervision of internal Operation of the Industry in selecting one of the two technologies for a better use in the long term or during its electrical operation and that can be visible in the electrical model for electrical studies that can allow an agile decision-making of the technical personnel in a possible integration of primary electrical equipment.

title: Control-to-Output Power Mapping in Clamped-Type Active Magnetic Energy Harvesters
authors: Yael Ditkovich, Moshe Shvartsas, Alon Kuperman
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The paper establishes an analytical relation between the power supplied to a certain constant voltage load (CVL) by a pre-designed clamped-type active magnetic energy harvester (AMEH) and the transfer window opening instant, serving as the system control input, for different values of primary current magnitude. Feasible control variable regions are identified and analyzed thoroughly, demonstrating the possibility of smooth output power regulation from maximum value down to zero level. Such a feature is useful in applications where load capability to absorb power is limited (e.g. battery charging). Experimental results accurately match corresponding analytical predictions.

title: Role of Energy Storage Systems in Modern Power Systems and Smart Grid: Technologies, Applications, and Simulation-Based Insights
authors: Aisha Naimi, Abdulla Yousuf, M. Eid, Sara Alessa, Fatima Aldhifiri, G. Amjad Hussain, Sanam Kouser
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The integration of Energy Storage Systems (ESS) has emerged as a cornerstone in the evolution of modern power systems and smart grid technologies. This report presents a comprehensive analysis of the current state-of-the-art energy storage technologies—including Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS), pumped hydro storage, flywheels, and super capacitors-tors—highlighting their operational roles and economic signifyicance. Through a detailed literature review, the study explores the contribution of ESS in peak shaving, load shifting, voltage and frequency regulation, grid flexibility, and renewable energy integration. Mathematical models and real-world case studies are employed to evaluate the cost savings and performance enhancement offered by ESS deployment. The discussion further identifies key challenges such as battery degradation, high capital costs, regulatory barriers, and material sustainability. Finally, future research directions are proposed to address these gaps through technological innovation and policy development. This work underscores the critical role of ESS in enabling resilient, efficient, and sustainable energy infrastructure.

title: Evaluation of CNN-Based Models for Binary Classification of Power Line Insulators
authors: Nermin Komar, Medina Kapo, Mirza Batalovic, Emir Buza
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: To keep power transmission systems up and running it is important to monitor the condition of the power line insulators. This paper compares the performance of three deep learning models (ResNet50, DenseNet121, and MobileNetV2), in classifying power line insulators as either defective or normal (non-defective). All models were built using pretrained ImageNet weights and adjusted with additional layers for binary classification. The results show the strengths and weaknesses of each model and suggest DenseNet121 as a strong choice for this type of image classification task.

title: Ku-Band Compact Circular Polarized Patch Antenna for Cubesat Applications
authors: Furkan Cağrı Babacan, Arda Çetin, Ahmet Caner Gül, Semih Doğu
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this article, a circularly polarized patch antenna is proposed. The suggested antenna consists of a single patch as its central element. In addition, two parasitic patches are inserted and the corners of the center element are truncated. The effects of these methods on bandwidth, reflection coefficient, radiation, pattern, axial ratio, and gain are analyzed. The final simulation results indicate that the proposed antenna operates effectively over the frequency range of 12.5–16 GHz. In particular, it achieves circular polarization over 13.6-14.5 GHz, indicating its ability to transmit and receive signals without polarization loss. Furthermore, the antenna demonstrates an impressive average realized gain of 8 dBi, highlighting its efficiency in radiating power and enhancing signal strength within the designated Ku-band.

title: Resilient Operation of Two-Way Distribution Network in the Presence of Renewable Energy Resources Considering Demand Response Programs
authors: Abbas Zare Ghaleh Seyyedi, Mohsen Gitizadeh, Jamshid Aghaei
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: It is very important to use methods to increase resilience in the electricity distribution network. In this paper, considering the double-feed distribution network and using load response programs to increase resilience, it has been used. In the formulation considered, renewable energy sources such as wind and solar have also been considered. Simulations have been performed on a 33-bus distribution network in 4 study cases. The results show that the cost has decreased by 8 to 14 percent and the resiliency has increased by 2 to 4 percent.

title: QM-OCL: Quantum Many-Shot Out-Of-Context Learning for Metamodeling Techno-Economic Stability in Microgrids and Smart Grids
authors: Syed Farhan Ahmad, Hassan Gillani, Al Raji Billah, Adam Wesolowski, Gregory T. Byrd, Abdallah Namoun
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This study investigates the use of Quantum Machine Learning (QML) for metamodeling the techno-economic stability of an islanded smart microgrid, which can also be applied to larger and more extensive grid systems. Using a physics-accurate simulator, we generated a small, many-shot dataset for the proposed microgrid architecture that is powered by a wave energy generator. To address the scalability challenges of both classical simulation and quantum computation, we propose a Quantum Many-shot Out-of-Context Learning (QM-OCL) pipeline. This pipeline uses Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for data dimensionality reduction, which was also shown to mitigate the barren plateau phenomenon in the optimization landscape of the Quantum Neural Network (QNN). The QNN was trained in a context-free manner, and its performance was benchmarked against classical models, including Shallow Neural Networks (NNs), Deep Neural Networks (DNNs), and Support Vector Classifiers (SVCs). QNN achieves an accuracy of 0.75 on this limited data, slightly outperforming most state-of-the-art classical models that achieve accuracies in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.70-0.77$</tex>. While the approach currently shows some limitations in generalization, this is expected given that the QNN algorithm is still in its early stages of development. This work highlights the potential of QML for metamodeling complex, data-scarce systems like smart grids/microgrids and shows that dimensionality reduction can significantly improve the trainability of QNNs. Future work will focus on larger datasets and a quantitative analysis of barren plateau mitigation.

title: Strategic Mathematics for Sustainability: Integrating SDGs and AI in Digital Engineering Education
authors: Ulises Ojeda Sánchez, Jose M. Nieto-Jalil, Adrian Isrrael Tec Chim, Alfredo Antonio Carrasco Reyes
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study reports an educational innovation in MA1053: Strategic Mathematics for a Sustainable Future (Digital Education, Tecnológico de Monterrey; Feb-July and Summer 2025). The course integrates algebra, calculus, and linear regression with AI, Python, and Excel to analyze PM2.5, aligned with the SDGs. Using a single-group pre-post design (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{n} \boldsymbol{=} \mathbf{6 0}$</tex>), we assessed domain-specific cognitive performance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0}$</tex> 100) and procedural/ethical transfer via rubric (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-4 \rightarrow 0-100$</tex>). Significant gains were observed (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha=.05$</tex>, Holm): Algebra <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta=8.54$</tex> [7.72, 9.36], d_z=2.69; Calculus <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta=12.04$</tex> [11.02, 13.05], d_z=3.06; Regression <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta=9.75[8.99,10.51], \mathrm{d} \_\mathrm{z}=3.31$</tex>; overall <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta=10.11[9.56$</tex>, 10.65], d_z=4.79. Project-rubric means increased from 50.26 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$68.02(\Delta=17.76$</tex>; one-tailed Wilcoxon post <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>$</tex> pre, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p<.001)$</tex>, with the largest improvements in Modeling and Visualization/Regression. A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> heatmap of correlations among <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta$</tex> indicated modest crossdomain coherence, consistent with area-specific skill growth. We conclude that integrating AI and emerging technologies can enhance mathematical learning and sustainability-oriented formation. Strengthening cross-domain “bridging” tasks may further generalize gains. The main limitation is the single-cohort design without a control group; future work should extend to multiple sites/cohorts and track vertical transfer.

title: Current Optimization for Nonunity Power Factor and Unbalanced DC-Link Voltage in Three-Phase Vienna Rectifiers
authors: Yi-Hung Liao, Jia-Sheng Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: The suppression of current zero-crossing distortion and dc-link voltage oscillations has been a key research focus for three-phase Vienna rectifiers in recent years. In addition, under variable power factor (PF) operation, the phase difference between the input current and grid voltage increases the likelihood of the Vienna rectifier entering a nonsynthetic interval at a high modulation index. This prevents the effective synthesis of the reference voltage vector, leading to severe current distortion and voltage oscillations. In order to reduce the impact of the nonsynthetic interval on the three-phase Vienna rectifier, this article proposes a nonunity power factor current optimization (NUPF-CO) strategy to effectively reduce the negative impact of the nonsynthetic interval on system performance. This strategy allows the three-phase Vienna rectifier to avoid current zero-crossing distortion, even under variable power factor operation and actively unbalanced output voltage, while ensuring good neutral point current disturbance suppression and improving voltage utilization. Finally, a 2.5 kW three-phase Vienna rectifier is constructed for verification. The performance of the proposed NUPF-CO strategy under variable power factor conditions is compared with that of conventional strategies.

title: Single-stage Non-isolated High Conversion Ratio Step-down Converter for Voltage Regulation Modules
authors: Dinh Phuc Nguyen, Huang-Jen Chiu, Dung Anh Nguyen, Yu-Chen Liu
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: This paper proposes a non-isolated converter with an ultra-high step-down voltage conversion ratio and low voltage stress on switching devices, achieved within a moderate duty cycle for voltage regulation modulators (VRMs). By incorporating clamping capacitors and additional inductors into the buck converter topology, the proposed design achieves a significantly higher step-down conversion ratio while reducing voltage stress and improving efficiency. In the proposed converter, the clamping capacitors store energy to act as a voltage source, thereby reducing voltage stress on the switching devices. While the main inductor serves as the primary component for energy transfer to the output, additional inductors are connected in parallel to reduce the burden on the clamping capacitors, reduce current stress, and ensure natural balance. Furthermore, the switch network is scalable to achieve the desired voltage conversion ratio, depending on the application. Finally, a 48V-to-1.5V/25W prototype operating at 300kHz was developed and tested, demonstrating the feasibility of the proposed converter.
