title: Towards a Sustainable Industrial Metaverse: A Digital Twin Framework for Mining and Energy Infrastructure with AR/VR Interfaces
authors: Mahek Patel, David Tandel, Musab Bin Khaleeq, Sujay Kadam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: We present a dual-infrastructure digital twin architecture for mining and power operations, integrating IoT-based fleet and battery monitoring systems with a unified dashboard. Building on a deployed MERN-stack platform, we propose an AR/VR metaverse layer for immersive control room operations, powered by low-cost hardware and future-ready 6G networks. Our system optimizes heavy earth moving machinery (HEMM) dispatch and battery-powered mobile Wi-Fi tower uptime, contributing to safety, efficiency, and sustainability. We highlight real-world use cases, architectural extensions, and discuss how this vision aligns with the FNWF 2025 themes of digital twins, metaverse, and green intelligence.

title: Proactive FWA Assurance: An End-to-End Framework for Deterministic 5G Broadband Experience
authors: Junaid Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Fixed Wireless Access (FWA) has emerged as a critical enabler of broadband connectivity, particularly in underserved and remote regions. However, delivering a deterministic, fiber-like experience over FWA networks remains challenging due to fluctuating radio conditions, suboptimal customer premises equipment (CPE) placement, and limited end-to-end visibility across the service chain. This paper presents a holistic FWA Assurance Framework designed to proactively detect, localize, and resolve performance degradations across the customer lifecycle. The solution integrates multiple innovations: (i) a geospatially enhanced WTTx Suite for precise pre-sales qualification using 3D RF propagation modeling and predictive analytics; (ii) an AI-driven CPE placement optimizer via mobile apps to reduce installation errors; (iii) a real-time FWA Insight Dashboard for end-user performance monitoring leveraging OSS data and intelligent KPIs; and (iv) an integrated Customer Care Assistant (CCA) platform powered by decision-tree-based RCA for contextual complaint resolution. Deployed at scale, the framework resulted in a 40 percent reduction in complaint volumes and a 30 percent improvement in the mean time to resolution (MTTR) while enabling proactive retention and upselling strategies. The solution demonstrates a scalable blueprint for FWA quality assurance and has been recognized as a replicable best practice across OpCos.

title: Enhancing IoT Network Security through Adaptive Curriculum Learning and XAI
authors: Sathwik Narkedimilli, Sujith Makam, Amballa Venkata Sriram, Sai Prashanth Mallellu, MSVPJ Sathvik, R. Venkatesha Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: To address the critical need for secure IoT networks, this study presents a scalable and lightweight Curriculum Learning framework enhanced with Explainable AI (XAI) techniques, like LIME, to ensure transparency and adaptability. The proposed model employs a novel neural network architecture utilized at every stage of Curriculum Learning to efficiently capture and focus on both short- and long-term temporal dependencies, improve learning stability, and enhance accuracy while remaining lightweight and robust against noise in sequential IoT data. Robustness is achieved through staged learning, where the model iteratively refines itself by removing low-relevance features and optimizing performance. The workflow includes edge-optimized quantization and pruning to ensure portability that could easily be deployed in edge IoT devices. An ensemble model incorporating Random Forest, XGBoost, and the staged learning base further enhances generalization. The results demonstrate 98% accuracy on CIC-IoV-2024 and CIC-APT-IIoT-2024 datasets and 97% on EDGE-IIoT, establishing this framework as a robust, transparent, and high-performance solution for IoT network security.

title: Self-Supervised Learning for Multi-Lead ECG Classification Reducing Annotation Burden and Improving Generalization
authors: Bilgin Demir, Ervin Domazet
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Electrocardiography (ECG) is widely used for diagnosing cardiovascular diseases, but automated interpretation is limited by costly annotations, miscalibration, and inefficiency on edge devices. This paper presents a compact self-supervised framework combining masked autoencoder pretraining, supervised fine-tuning, isotonic calibration, interpretability, and efficiency profiling. Using the publicly available PTB-XL and INCART 12-lead ECG datasets for development and validation, the model achieves strong performance with few labels, improved reliability, and sub-millisecond inference for trustworthy, low-footprint ECG monitoring.

title: Tuning of the Conventional Control Technique in High-Gain Converter
authors: Chirag Patel, Preeti Sharma, Siddharth Joshi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This study introduces a quadratic DC-DC converter with active clamping designed for low-duty ratios and high voltage gain, employing a PI control strategy. It achieves maximum voltage gain with shorter duty cycles, reducing stress on components and addressing non-minimum phase issues. With a 0.5 duty cycle, it can amplify input voltage by up to 15 times. The design and evaluation utilize MATLAB/SIMULINK, covering controller design and converter functionalities. It also explores tuning methods, showing effective performance across varying load ranges and high frequencies.

title: Enhancing Automatic Grading of SQL Query Assignments Using Generative AI : A Case Study on SPJ Query Assignment
authors: Yosei Tsuboi, Tetsuro Kakeshita
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The grading of SQL query assignments is a timeconsuming task for instructors, especially in large classes where ensuring both accuracy and consistency is difficult. To address this issue, we developed and evaluated an automatic grading tool for SQL query design using generative AI in this paper. The system targets SPJ (Selection, Projection, Join) query tasks from the Information Systems Experiment course. By incorporating model answers, lecture materials, and common student errors into carefully designed prompts, the tool aimed to improve grading accuracy and feedback quality. Comparative experiments were conducted with different prompt configurations as well as with an existing rubric-based tool developed by Ando et al. The results demonstrated that the optimized GPT-based prompt design achieved 96.8% accuracy (387 out of 400 items correctly graded), while also providing detailed feedback that specified “what was wrong,” “why,” and “how to fix it.” This feedback was found to support student learning and reduce grading inconsistencies for instructors. The findings confirm the potential of GPT-based systems as effective complements to existing rubric-based methods. This research highlights the promise of generative AI in delivering scalable, fair, and pedagogically meaningful assessments in database education.

title: Design of a UAV Rescue System for Mountainous Areas Integrating PEFT-Enhanced Voice Control and rPPG-Based Vital-Sign Detection
authors: Xiang-Shun Yang, Chi-Hung Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are widely deployed in rescue operations in mountainous areas for terrain mapping, victim search, and material delivery. However, most systems still rely on manual operation, making it difficult for rescuers to manage control and vital-sign assessment in complex terrain. This study introduces a UAV rescue system that integrates natural language understanding and image-based vital-sign detection. With parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT), LLaMA 3.2 achieves $95.33 \%$ accuracy in converting speech to control commands. Under 5 G communication, the end-to-end latency from speech to action averages 165 ms, supporting real-time flight control. Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) yields a mean absolute error of 3.733 bpm compared to electrocardiogram (ECG) for vital-sign monitoring. These preliminary results demonstrate the system’s feasibility and potential in voice-based UAV control and non-contact vital-sign detection.

title: Research on the Identification and Prediction of the Age of Strong-Flavor Baijiu Based on Characteristic
authors: Xiang Gao, Ze Nan Zhu, Yao Yao, Yi Li Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To achieve rapid and non-destructive discriminati on of the vintage and authenticity of Strong-flavor Baijiu, this stu dy developed an analytical method that integrates ultraviolet abs orption spectroscopy with fluorescence excitation-emission matri x spectroscopy. Samples of both authentic and defective Baijiu fr om various aging years were collected. Their spectral data were a cquired, preprocessed, and subsequently analyzed using PCA an d LDA for feature extraction and pattern recognition. The results demonstrated that the multi-spectral fusion features effectively c aptured the intrinsic compositional changes during the aging pro cess, revealing significant clustering and discrimination trends a mong samples of different vintages and qualities. Furthermore, a n online vintage detection platform was developed, which integra tes multi-spectral data fusion technology and a random forest pre diction model. This platform achieved accurate vintage predictio n with a mean absolute error (MAE) of less than 0.5 years. This work provides a reliable and efficient solution to the technical ch allenges of vintage identification in the Baijiu market, holding sig nificant potential for practical application in quality control and market regulation.

title: Design of Insert Assembly Workstation in Injection Mold and Visual Algorithm
authors: Chen Zihao, Jing Xuedong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper focuses on the needs for precise positioning and efficient operation in the automated assembly process of inserts in injection molds, and conducts research on the design of workstation assembly based on machine vision algorithms. Firstly, in response to the process characteristics and technical requirements of insert assembly, the overall structural design and process planning of the workstation are completed. Through two chapters, the mechanical structure layout, transmission system selection, control system architecture and assembly operation process of the workstation are elaborated in detail, laying a hardware and process foundation for automated assembly.To achieve high-precision recognition and positioning of inserts, the KNN algorithm is introduced for improvement based on the traditional SURF algorithm. Feature points of inserts and assembly stations are extracted via the SURF algorithm, and the KNN algorithm is utilized to optimize the matching and classification of these feature points. This effectively enhances the accuracy and anti-interference capability of feature matching, addressing the issue that traditional algorithms tend to suffer from insufficient matching precision due to the influence of illumination and noise in complex industrial environments.Experimental results indicate that the improved SURF-KNN algorithm achieves higher matching accuracy than the traditional SURF algorithm in recognizing inserts in injection molds, which meets the precision requirements of automated assembly. The workstation based on this vision algorithm can stably perform the grabbing, positioning and assembly of inserts, significantly improving production efficiency and providing a feasible technical solution for the automated assembly of inserts in injection molds.

title: Blockchain-Powered Framework for Trustworthy AI: Ensuring End-to-End Data and Model Integrity with Privacy Preservation
authors: Kavian Amirmozafarisabet, Meisam Namazi, Mohammad Naserameri
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Rapid deployment of AI, particularly in sectors such as healthcare, finance and smart infrastructure, necessitates reliable capabilities (1) to assure data integrity (2) model update verifiability and (3) privacy preservation along the AI lifecycles. In this paper, we propose a blockchain based framework for trustful AI and traceable end-to-end training and inference. The framework leverages a distributed ledger to immutably bind the hash-locked commitment of data and model parameters through deployed smart contracts defining automated verification protocols. Secure multiparty computation [PADDP13] and zero-knowledge proofs are some of the privacy mechanisms used during collaborative training in federated learning environments to keep sensitive data safe. In expanding on our work in blockchain-based AI integrity frameworks, the new architecture shown integrates anomaly detection and provenance tracking to prevent malicious contributions. Extensive experimental evaluations over standard datasets confirm the ability of our solution to efficiently provide reliable verification without additional computational background for domain independence. This work has the potential to form the bedrock of future AI deployments that are transparent, safe, and ethically responsible.

title: CLIP Can Accurately Count Crowds Through Reparameterized Large Kernel Convolution
authors: Mingzhen Huang, Huailin Zhao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The CLIP (Contrastive Language-Image Pretraining) model has demonstrated remarkable performance in zero-shot image classification and object detection tasks, owing to its powerful cross-modal alignment capability. However, accurately applying CLIP to counting tasks (regression tasks) remains a significant challenge due to the fundamental differences between counting and recognition tasks. Meanwhile, large-kernel convolutional neural networks (ConvNets) have recently gained considerable attention in computer vision, but their architectural design still faces two critical issues: on one hand, existing large-kernel ConvNets predominantly follow the design principles of traditional small-kernel convolutions or Transformers, lacking specialized optimization for large-kernel characteristics; on the other hand, although Transformers dominate in multimodal domains, whether ConvNets possess similar cross-modal perception capabilities remains insufficiently explored. To address these challenges, this study focuses on investigating the potential of CLIP in crowd counting tasks and innovatively proposes integrating a reparameterized large-kernel convolution module into the CLIP framework. This approach not only effectively mitigates the discretization errors inherent in traditional classification-based crowd counting methods but also enhances counting accuracy through multi-scale feature fusion and spatial attention mechanisms. Extensive experiments on multiple benchmark datasets, including SHA, SHB, QNRF and NWPU, demonstrate that our method achieves significant improvements in key metrics such as MAE and RMSE, outperforming previous approaches and recent strong baselines. This research not only expands the application scope of CLIP to regression tasks but also provides new insights and empirical evidence for the architectural design of large-kernel ConvNets and their cross-modal capabilities.

title: Modulated Convolutional Neural Network for Radio Link Failure Prediction in 5G
authors: Nirmala Devi Lavadya, Nageswar Rao Amgoth
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Radio Link Failure (RLF) is a challenging problem in 5G networks as it may decrease communication reliability and increases latency. This is against the objectives of 5G, particularly for the ultra-Reliable Low Latency Communications (uRLLC) traffic class. RLF can be predicted using radio measurements. Radio Link Failure (RLF) prediction in 5G networks is an emerging research area that aims to improve network reliability and performance. RLF prediction in 5G networks enables network operators to proactively manage network resources, optimize performance, and implement preventive measures to minimize service disruptions. By identifying potential link failures in advance, operators can take corrective actions, such as adjusting transmission parameters, optimizing resource allocation, or re-routing traffic to maintain reliable and un-interrupted connectivity for 5G users. The existing works performed the RLF prediction for one day ahead of the present date. The proposed work planned to extend the span of prediction to the next five days instead of one. By using N-day (previous day data) and weather forecasted data, the RLF of N+4 day is predicted. According to this, Modulated Convolutional Neural Network (MCNN) is proposed for link failure prediction. The input data is collected from Radio Link Failure prediction dataset. Then, the distance correlation and noise elimination are used to enhance the quality and relevance of the data. The proposed work obtains the 79.03%, 65.93%, 67.51% of precision, recall and F1-score, which are higher than existing techniques. The analysis shows that the proposed scheme is appropriate for RLF prediction.

title: Robust Metric for the Labeling Quality of the Cervical Cytology Similarity Graph
authors: Yasuhiro Iida, Bojan Mrazovac, Yasuo Ishigure, Tasuku Mariya, Ikuma Sato, Ayahiko Niimi
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We propose a novel metric for assessing the labeling quality of image datasets in cervical cytology, specifically contributing to facilitating the detection of noisy labels. While graph-based machine learning with a similarity graph has recently been shown as a promising technique for detecting noisy labels hidden in large image datasets, a stable metric for assessing labeling quality remains an open challenge. This is because graph structure can vary depending on several factors, even when built from a single dataset, making the labeling quality metric value susceptible to changes in graph structure. In this study, we first detail the limitations of an existing, recently proposed metric, and then introduce our novel approach. Our metric addresses these limitations by considering the label distributions between datasets and graph cliques. We demonstrate the stability of our proposed metric through an experimental evaluation on three real-world benchmark datasets.

title: High-Performance IP-over-WDM Networking: Fixed-Wavelength, Programmable 10G SFP, and Passive WDM Implementation
authors: Zlate Bogoevski, Danijela Efnusheva, Ana Cholakoska Cilakova, Tomislav Shuminoski, Hristijan Gjoreski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The integration of Internet Protocol (IP) services over Wavelength Division Multiplexing (WDM) networks is a key solution for improving efficiency, bandwidth utilization, and scalability in modern telecommunications systems. This study evaluates the performance of fixed-wavelength <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 G}$</tex> Small Form-factor Pluggable (SFP) transceivers within an IP-over-WDM architecture using passive WDM components. A dedicated optical link was established between a router and a switch, utilizing passive multiplexers and demultiplexers to manage signal transmission over specific wavelength channels. Results confirmed that the fixed-wavelength 10G SFPs offered stable, low-latency performance with minimal error rates and high resilience to optical impairments. The study demonstrates that passive WDM technology provides a cost-effective, energy-efficient solution for optical communication. It supports optimized fiber utilization and offers straightforward scalability, making it suitable for high-capacity, next-generation networks requiring reliable and high-performance data transmission.

title: The Impact of Data Noise on Machine Learning Performance for EV Charging Classification
authors: Joud Almomani, Obada Al-Khatib, Mohamad Nassereddine, Abigail Copiaco
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The accurate classification of electric vehicle (EV) charging consumption levels is crucial for various applications, including grid management and personalized user services. This study investigates the robustness of several machine learning models when classifying EV charging consumption under varying levels of Gaussian noise applied to the dataset. Our findings reveal a significant disparity in the resilience of various models. Although ensemble methods, particularly AdaBoostM2, maintained high classification accuracy even with substantial noise (accuracy around 94.7% at the highest noise level), linear models, such as Logistic Regression (LR) and Support Vector Machine (SVM), exhibited considerable performance degradation. The confusion matrices visually corroborated these trends, illustrating the impact of noise on the predictive capabilities of each model. The stable overall performance of the Decision Tree (DT) also provided a valuable point of comparison. These results underscore the superior robustness of ensemble methods for EV charging classification in potentially noisy real-world scenarios.

title: A Uniform Framework for Testing Embedded Audio Systems: Methodology and Experimental Validation
authors: Teodora Novković, Jelena Kovačević, Ivan Kaštelan
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The increasing complexity of latest-generation audio technologies such as Dolby Atmos, DTS:X, and MPEG-H poses significant challenges in the development, testing, and certification of embedded audio systems. Current testing practices are resource-intensive, and often rely on technologyspecific tools, resulting in limited reusability and long-lasting certification processes. This paper presents a uniform framework for testing embedded audio systems, developed to unify and standardize testing procedures across diverse technologies and platforms. The proposed solution CUTE (Completely Unifying Test Executor), introduces modular architecture with unified APIs, multi-agent distributed execution, and IoT-enabled recovery mechanisms. Together with the GRANT (Generator of Random Tests) tool, this framework enables automated generation of test cases, extended coverage, and reduced manual effort. The framework was validated on multiple state-of-the-art audio technologies. Experimental results demonstrated significant improvements: faster error detection, reduced test execution time, lower code complexity and improved team productivity. The contributions of this work include a novel methodology for framework development, implementation of uniform testing framework, and comprehensive experimental validation. The results confirm effectiveness of a uniform framework that provides standardized and scalable testing of latest-generation embedded audio systems.

title: Computer Vision-Based Color Detection and Distance Estimation with an Online Graphical Interface
authors: Alejandro Álvarez López, Ángel Hernández Cárdenas, Jesús Alberto Sánchez Tiburcio, Neyzer E. Vázquez Espinoza, Alfredo Cristóbal-Salas, Mario González-Lee, José R. García-Martínez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the development and implementation of a computer vision system that simultaneously addresses two related problems: (i) real-time color identification and (ii) distance estimation using a standard camera. For the color detection task, the proposed method integrates OpenCVbased preprocessing, HSV color segmentation, and morphological filtering for robust object recognition. A graphical user interface was developed to facilitate camera selection, enable or disable detection, and provide real-time visualization. Experimental evaluation of the classification module yielded an overall accuracy of 93.3 %, with perfect recognition of red objects (100 %) and 90 % accuracy for both green and blue objects. In parallel, the system performs distance estimation based on the detected object's size and position in the image frame. Under controlled conditions, the method demonstrated high precision: for a reference distance of 11 cm, the system reported 10.9 cm with an error of only 0.1 cm; for a real distance of 15 cm, the error was 0.2 cm; and for a short separation of 5.2 cm, the estimated value was 5.3 cm, corresponding to an error of 0.1 cm. These results confirm that the proposed solution offers reliable real-time performance for both color classification and distance estimation. The combination of traditional image-processing techniques with a simple but effective computational pipeline enhances the stability and usability of the system, making it suitable for applications in robotics, automated monitoring, and educational environments.

title: Applying Multi-Agent LLMS to Threat Analysis and Risk Assessment in Automotive Security
authors: Anja Obradov, Bogdan Pavković, Dimitrije Stojanović, Nenad Četić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Threat Analysis and Risk Assessment (TARA) is essential for identifying threats and managing risks, but is often resource-intensive due to manual steps, expert involvement, and iterative revisions. To address this, we propose an automated TARA framework using LLM agents that generate threat scenarios, derive cybersecurity goals and requirements, and refine them through a writer-reviewer loop. The proof of concept, demonstrated on a keyless entry system, produces structured JSON artifacts, ensuring traceability and supporting compliance-driven cybersecurity engineering in automotive systems.

title: Optimized Vertical Coils for Achieving Uniform Magnetic Fields at Greater Transfer Distances
authors: Ananth Bharadwaj
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This article presents a novel vertically oriented multi-coil transmitter (Tx) designed to achieve a uniform magnetic field distribution at extended transfer distances for nearfield resonant-based wireless power transfer (WPT) applications. The proposed Tx pad consists of four identical rectangular coils strategically positioned in the XZ and YZ planes. Key design parameters, including central coordinates, side lengths, number of turns, and current circulation, are jointly optimized through computational modeling based on analytical equations governing the magnetic field intensities of rectangular coils. The performance of the proposed Tx pad is evaluated against a conventional planar coil positioned in the XY-plane. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed configuration enhances field uniformity, improves misalignment tolerance, and ensures reliable power transfer at greater distances. These findings highlight the potential of the optimized vertical coil design as an effective solution for WPT systems requiring extended range and robust performance.

title: Reduction of Energy Consumption Through Energy Storage Controlled by Artificial Intelligence in Buildings and Homes
authors: Adolfo de Jesús García-Méndez, José de Jesús Sánchez-Hernández, Jesús García-Guzmán
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In a century in which economic, scientific-technical, cultural, political and environmental circumstances demand greater and better energy consumption, new systems are necessary where various technologies and strategies are addressed to maximize energy efficiency and reduce the environmental impact. The proposal in this work is an energy storage system for houses and buildings with an automated control system in which artificial intelligence intervenes with the ability to control the loads connected to the electrical network of the house or building, by which the energy obtained by the system is stored in batteries so that this energy can be used at any time, with its respective transformation process from direct current to alternating current.

title: Human-Centered Hybrid CPS for Intelligent Forecasting in Cathodic Protection Systems
authors: Eduardo Trutié-Carrero, José M. Nieto-Jalil, Diego Seuret-Jiménez, Luz Edain Nava Borrego, Jorge Cantó
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the design, development, and deployment of a human-centered cyber-physical system (HCPS) for forecasting the ON potential in cathodic protection systems for critical hydrocarbon-transport infrastructure. The proposal is built on a hybrid architecture that combines long short-term memory (LSTM) networks with Mamdani-type fuzzy logic, enabling the capture of complex spatiotemporal patterns while managing the uncertainty inherent to nonlinear, stochastic systems subject to environmental perturbations. We introduce a multiscale preprocessing pipeline for reconstructed ON-potential time series to feed the model, optimized via adaptive dynamic weighting. In tandem, the research contributes two advances: (i) the definition of a fuzzy recursive operator, and (ii) the formulation of a recursive equation modeling the dynamic behavior of the ON potential. The procedure achieved an experimentally validated forecasting accuracy of 83 %. This multidisciplinary approach not only improves prediction and operational resilience but also reframes the role of artificial intelligence in high-criticality industrial environments. The proposed system lays a robust foundation for future developments in prescriptive maintenance, extreme-scenario simulation, and technology transfer to other critical infrastructures.

title: Moisture-Induced Space-Charge Dynamics in Low-Density Polyethylene (LDPE) Resolved by PEA
authors: Jose M. Nieto-Jalil, Rosmarbel Morales-Nava, Adrian Isrrael tec Chim, David I. Ibarra-Zarate, Diego Seuret-Jiménez, Juan M. Martínez Huerta
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: We use the pulsed electroacoustic (PEA) method to quantify how moisture uptake alters space-charge formation and transport in low-density polyethylene (LDPE) films. Specimens were exposed to controlled water-vapor environments for up to 12 h, and space-charge density profiles were recorded every 50 s under applied fields reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 \text{kV} / \text{mm}$</tex>. Moisture increases the density of deep traps, stabilizing negative charge at the electrode-polymer interface and enabling bulk space-charge through field-assisted ionization. Humidified films exhibit shorter charge-packet transit times, indicating higher effective carrier mobility. At elevated fields, the emergence of multiple packets evidences a nonlinear transport regime governed by trap saturation and dynamic retrapping. These effects erode LDPE dielectric stability, with implications for medium-voltage cable insulation. We interpret the observations using coupled models that combine Schottky-type injection, drift-dominated transport, and Poisson electrostatics, and emphasize the need for predictive multiphysics frameworks that integrate rigorous moisture quantification, polymer morphological evolution, and the nonlinear dynamics of charge migration.

title: Taming mmWave Connectivity Prediction with DRaGon: AI Propagation Modeling for Cluttered Industrial Environments
authors: Melina Geis, Simon Häger, Christian Wietfeld
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Future 6G networks are expected to enable a wide range of industrial applications that demand ultra-high data rates. To meet these requirements, communication systems will increasingly rely on millimeter-wave (mmWave) frequencies, which offer large available bandwidths but exhibit complex and sensitive propagation behavior. Accurate network planning for such environments requires reliable Radio Environmental Maps (REMs), which in turn depend on precise channel modeling. Machine learning (ML) has shown promise in bridging the gap between computation time and prediction accuracy left by traditional modeling methods, but it has not yet been transferred to large-scale, complex Indoor Factory (InF) environments. In this paper, we present an ML-based propagation model for taming mmWave connectivity prediction in a densely cluttered real-world industrial scenario. The model utilizes features derived from privacy-preserving level-of-detail environmental representations, such as top and side-view image projections. We evaluate two ML model types – LGBM and ANN – on a dataset collected in a complex industrial environment. Both models accurately capture the underlying propagation characteristics and outperform traditional empirical models by 8.18 dB in prediction RMSE and by being approximately 30-times faster than ray tracing. We demonstrate the potential of ML-based models to support fast and reliable connectivity map generation, making them suitable for efficient mmWave network planning for industrial scenarios.

title: P3-FSLNet: A Compact Spatio-Temporal Model With Contrastive Few-Shot Learning for Subject-Independent P300 Detection in Devanagari Script-Based P300 Speller_supp1-3639248.docx
authors: Narendra D. Londhe
publish: N/A
abstract: Brain–computer interface (BCI) systems frequently necessitate time-intensive subject-specific calibration, thereby motivating the development of subject-independent P300 detection approaches. Existing methodologies that employ transfer learning and knowledge distillation encounter challenges with limited generalizability due to substantial intersubject variability and constrained data availability. Furthermore, their applicability is often questioned, as most lack comprehensive external validation and cross-script evaluation. To address these limitations, we introduce P3-FSLNet, a few-shot metalearning framework that integrates prototypical networks and contrastive learning within a spatial-temporal convolutional neural network augmented by dual-channel attention for the selection of relevant electroencephalogram channels. Episodic metatraining facilitates the transfer of robust knowledge across different subjects. Evaluated on a self-recorded Devanagari script dataset, P3-FSLNet attains a classification accuracy of 93.17%, surpassing state-of-the-art methods by 1%–14%, while simultaneously reducing trainable parameters by up to 400 times. External validation using English-script datasets from BCI Competition II and III confirms its robustness in cross-subject and cross-script generalization. These findings demonstrate the efficacy of P3-FSLNet and represent a substantial advancement toward the development of script-agnostic P300 spellers that are lightweight, scalable, and conducive to multilingual applications.

title: Charge Transport in a Protein-Ligand complex: A Preliminary Quantum Statistical Model
authors: Roisin Braddell, Jone Uria-Albizuri, Jean Bernard Bru, Serafim Rodrigues
publish: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications
abstract: Experiments show that protein-ligand binding activates long-range charge transport with a nanosiemens conductance over nanometer scales in the linear response regime (cf. Ohm’s law superimposed with telegraph noise observed in 2019). Inspired by these observations, we investigate charge transport of a 1D-semiconductor at nanoscales, from first principles of quantum mechanics only. The charge carriers are fermionic (like electrons) and do not interact with each other, but can move (quasi-)freely in two interconnected 1D (nanometric) lattices, only one of which is conductive. Electric currents and their quantum fluctuations under the influence of numerous parameters such as voltage, temperature, length, etc. are computed and discussed, having in mind bioelectronics, in particular emergent laws in protein complexes.

title: Reflectance Prediction-based Knowledge Distillation for Robust 3D Object Detection in Compressed Point Clouds
authors: Hao Jing, Anhong Wang, Yifan Zhang, Donghan Bu, Junhui Hou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Regarding intelligent transportation systems, low-bitrate transmission via lossy point cloud compression is vital for facilitating real-time collaborative perception among connected agents, such as vehicles and infrastructures, under restricted bandwidth. In existing compression transmission systems, the sender lossily compresses point coordinates and reflectance to generate a transmission code stream, which faces transmission burdens from reflectance encoding and limited detection robustness due to information loss. To address these issues, this paper proposes a 3D object detection framework with reflectance prediction-based knowledge distillation (RPKD). We compress point coordinates while discarding reflectance during low-bitrate transmission, and feed the decoded non-reflectance compressed point clouds into a student detector. The discarded reflectance is then reconstructed by a geometry-based reflectance prediction (RP) module within the student detector for precise detection. A teacher detector with the same structure as the student detector is designed for performing reflectance knowledge distillation (RKD) and detection knowledge distillation (DKD) from raw to compressed point clouds. Our cross-source distillation training strategy (CDTS) equips the student detector with robustness to low-quality compressed data while preserving the accuracy benefits of raw data through transferred distillation knowledge. Experimental results on the KITTI and DAIR-V2X-V datasets demonstrate that our method can boost detection accuracy for compressed point clouds across multiple code rates. We will release the code publicly at https://github.com/HaoJing-SX/RPKD.

title: Multi-Material Additively Manufactured Wideband Dual-Polarized Conical Four-Leaf Antenna Array with Bandwidth Enhancement
authors: Zhichao Sun, Jiexin Lai, Xiaojing Lv, Bobby Chan, Md Ashif Islam Oni, Shuvashis Dey, Yang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This communication presents a wideband dual-polarized conical four-leaf antenna array utilizing metal-dielectric additively manufactured technology, enhancing the bandwidth without introducing additional resonant modes. The antenna element comprises a metal-dielectric co-printed octagonal pyramid-shaped radiator and a two-layer feeding structure. Four obliquely isosceles triangular patches are optimally positioned on alternating facets of the pyramid to maximize bandwidth, excited via a cross-slot coupled feed in the ground. Compared to conventional slot-coupled patch antennas, the proposed design significantly broadens bandwidth and improves port isolation without incorporating extra resonant structures. A 4×4 antenna prototype was fabricated and measured for validation. Measurements demonstrate an overlapped impedance bandwidth (IMBW) better than 60% across both ports covering the entire Ku-band, with isolation exceeding 27 dB and a peak gain of 15.8 dBi. This approach leverages radiator geometry optimization instead of additional resonant structures for bandwidth enhancement and enables customized design via multi-material additive manufacturing, greatly simplifies the antenna configuration while establishing a promising pathway for future wideband antenna development.

title: Quantum-Enhanced Hardware Platforms for 6G Mobile Edge Computing
authors: Sakineh Ghaderi, Riccardo Bassoli, Frank H. P. Fitzek
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: 6G will push mobile edge computing to strict limits in latency, energy, security, and resilience. We evaluate the feasibility of Mobile Edge Quantum Computing (MEQC) with a hardware-grounded framework comparing six leading modalities: NV centers, silicon spins, superconducting circuits, trapped ions, neutral atoms, and photonic processors against edge metrics (SWaP, temperature envelope, control/I/O bandwidth, readout throughput, maintainability, and maturity). We scope only shallow variational loops and Grover-class search under realistic trainability/noise limits, and outline three integration patterns (tightly coupled, LAN-attached, and in-network) with PQC-first security and selective QKD. NV and Si spins emerge as the most credible edge options; photonics fits networking; others suit central-edge/cloud. Our contribution is a deployability-oriented comparison, edge integration patterns, and standards-anchored guidance for architects.

title: A Goal-Oriented Semantic Communication for A Reliable Cybernetic Avatar Teleoperation System
authors: Zie Eya Ekolle, Homare Murakami, Takeshi Matsumura
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Due to the urge to advance the human society toward a state of freedom from the limitation of body, brain, space and time, many technologies have been developed to enable the achievement of this goal. An important technology considered to enable the achievement of this goal is the Cybernetic Avatar (CA) teleoperation system. A CA teleoperation system is a robotic system designed to act as human surrogates in remote environments. While being an important enabler to achieve freedom from human limitations, the amount of data generated by the CA operation increases rapidly especially in a multiple operators and avatars scenarios. This leads to a communication bottleneck problem, especially in resource limited situations, where the bandwidth is not sufficient to efficiently transmit the large amount of data. Many approaches have been proposed to address this challenge, but one promising approach is semantic communication, which consist of transmitting the meaning of data rather than the raw data. In this paper, we propose a semantic communication model using a goal-oriented approach. We applied this model to improve the communication performance in a CA teleoperation. Simulation results show an improvement on the reliability of the CA teleoperation.

title: Analysis of Use Cases in 6G Mobile Networks
authors: Darko Koloski, Toni Janevski, Tomislav Šuminoski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Next generation mobile networks, 6G, will bring pervasive and seamless connectivity and expand integrated sensing and communication as well as native artificial intelligence use. The ITU umbrella for 6G is IMT-2030, which requires further improvement in performances towards ultra-low latency, very high data rates and hyper-reliability, and therefore defines new use cases besides improvements to existing ones from 5G. The initial 3GPP standardization process for 6G networks is expected to be done in the following period 2026-2029, with worldwide commercialization anticipated around 2029-2030 and beyond. This paper presents a comprehensive analysis of the main trends of 6G. It delves into the development and analysis of 6G mobile technology, encompassing both its benefits and challenges, and contributing with performance analysis of selected important use cases in 6G mobile networks.

title: PREDICT: Predictive Resource Reservation and Edge Selection for Reliable Task Offloading in Vehicular Edge Computing
authors: Liubing Xiao, Liqiong Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The high mobility of vehicles in Vehicular Edge Computing (VEC) introduces significant challenges, primarily frequent task interruptions due to unstable vehicle-to-edge (V2E) connectivity. Most existing task offloading strategies are fundamentally reactive, making decisions only after a task is generated, which often fails to mitigate the risks posed by rapid network topology changes. To address this limitation, this paper proposes a novel proactive scheduling paradigm named PREDICT (Predictive Resource Reservation and Edge Selection). The core of PREDICT lies in its lightweight trajectory prediction module, which forecasts short-term vehicle positions. Leveraging these predictions, the framework proactively reserves virtual computing resources at candidate edge servers and incorporates a stability-aware edge selection strategy. This shift from reactive to proactive decision-making allows the system to anticipate and avoid potential offloading failures. Simulation results in a typical urban scenario (vehicle density: $\mathbf{3 0}$ vehicles/km; task arrival rate: 0.5-1 task/s) show that the proposed approach reduces task-interruption rates by 42.7% (from 18.2% to 10.4%), decreases average task delay by 31.5% (from 3.2 s to 2.2 s), and limits the energy overhead to within 7.9%. Under high-mobility conditions (vehicle speed: $25 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}$), it maintains a task completion rate of 82.3%, outperforming Q-learning by over 40%, demonstrating superior robustness and generalization in highly dynamic environments.

title: Statistical Framework for Distributed Honeypots: Enhancing Cyber Threat Detection and Forecasting
authors: Saurabh Chamotra, Ferdous Ahmed Barbhuiya
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Timely detection and mitigation of cyber threats remain critical challenges in modern network defense. This paper introduces a statistical framework for real-time anomaly detection and threat forecasting using data from a distributed honeypot infrastructure. The system combines geographically dispersed honeypot clusters with a multivariate analysis pipeline to identify coordinated attack campaigns and emerging threats. Key contributions include a surge detection algorithm based on statistical hypothesis testing, time series differencing, and multivariate deviation scoring, as well as an evaluation of ARIMA-based forecasting accuracy across varying data windows. A two-year deployment across four clusters revealed early indicators of several high-impact exploits, demonstrating the framework’s effectiveness and scalability for proactive threat detection.

title: Design and Comparison of Pcb- and Thin-Film-Based Ka-Band Wilkinson Power Dividers
authors: Ahmet Kahraman, Semih Doğu
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Efficient and broadband power dividers/combiners play a critical role in wireless communication, imaging, and radar networks. Modern trends demand designs that offer high performance and broadband frequency response, while remaining cost-effective, having short lead times, and allowing easy repeatable fabrication. This work investigates Wilkinson power dividers implemented on two platforms: conventional printed circuit board (PCB) substrates and thin-film alumina substrates. Simulations were made in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 0 - 4 0 ~ G H z}$</tex> range using a full-wave frequency-domain solver. Insertion loss, return loss, and isolation performances were evaluated. The thin-film approach offered lower loss, while the PCB approach provided a more cost-effective solution.

title: Comparative Analysis of Traditional and Deep Learning Methods for Global Horizontal Irradiance Forecasting in Diverse U.S. Climates
authors: Ilhaam A. Omar, Maryam Tariq, Gharisa AlMehairi, Maher Maalouf
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Accurate global horizontal irradiance (GHI) forecasting is vital for integrating solar energy into power grids. This study compares twelve models, including classical time series methods (e.g., Holt-Winters, SARIMA), multivariate models (e.g., MLR, SARIMAX), and deep learning architectures (LSTM, CNN, CNN-LSTM, TFT), across three climatically diverse U.S. cities: Rochester, Seattle, and Tucson, using 2021 data. A rollingwindow framework trained models on seven-day windows for 24-hour forecasts. Results show performance is highly locationdependent, driven by local weather variability. Univariate models performed well in stable climates (e.g., SARIMA achieved MAE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.14 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> in Tucson), but poorly in variable ones (e.g., Holt's RMSE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1,797.69 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> in Seattle). Multivariate models like SARIMAX, using Lasso-selected features, improved performance in such regions (e.g., MAE of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.77 ~\mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> in Rochester). Deep learning models yielded the best accuracy, with CNN-LSTM achieving MASE between 1.13 and 1.49, and TFT capturing complex temporal patterns. These findings suggest that complex models are best for volatile climates, while simple ones suffice in stable regions. This work provides practical guidance for model selection based on climate and a structured evaluation framework for solar forecasting.

title: Implementation of Integral Moving Average Filter Based Control of Grid-Tied Solar PV System
authors: Dasari Venkayya, Subham Kumar Jalan, B. Chitti Babu, Sabha Raj Arya
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper proposed an improved control method for grid-tied photovoltaic systems using an integrated moving average filter (i-MAF), which provides robust system operation and better dynamic characteristics under varying grid conditions. Unlike conventional methods, which extract load current components by converting the fundamental component to a DC quantity using a sample, control, and hold block with a proportional-integral (PI) controller, the proposed method computes the average load current directly, providing the DC quantity for the fundamental component. This DC quantity, combined with the current gain of the outer voltage control loop, generates the reference currents and effectively manages active and reactive power flow. Power quality concerns, such as unity power factor, harmonic mitigation, and reactive power compensation, were addressed during power management are avoided by suppressing the total harmonic distortion. Additionally, when PV array power is unavailable, the voltage source inverter (VSI) functions as a DSTATCOM, which enhances the utilization of PV systems. The proposed control method is validated through a MATLAB®/Simulink model and evaluates its performance using dSPACE-1104-based laboratory prototype.

title: Packet-Loss-Aware Neural Compression for Telepathology Over 5G-Class Networks: A BreakHis Case Study
authors: Elzana Dupljak, Ervin Domazet, Amra Feta Abazi
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Telepathology must deliver diagnostically reliable histology images over variable-quality wireless links. We present an edge-to-cloud framework that pairs a pathologyaware learned image codec with a 5G-class, packet-loss-tolerant transmission stack. The codec is trained end-to-end with a packet-erasure layer so that it learns to reconstruct despite missing packets; lightweight Reed-Solomon forward-error correction (FEC) can be added when needed. Using the BreakHis breast histopathology collection (82 patients; benign and malignant classes at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \times / 100 \times / 200 \times / 400 \times$</tex>), we extract <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \times 256$</tex> patches, apply Reinhard stain normalization, and simulate random packet loss of 1-5% with packet size 128 bytes. On validation data, the method maintains SSIM <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.70$</tex> with PSNR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 21.6 \text{dB}$</tex> at 1-2% loss, and degrades gracefully at 5% loss; qualitative grids confirm preservation of nuclei and gland boundaries. FEC further stabilizes worst-case outcomes at the cost of small redundancy. The results indicate that channelaware neural compression, optionally combined with light FEC, can enable low-latency, high-fidelity telepathology on today's 5G-class networks and provide a practical path toward future 6G-ready deployments.

title: Emphasizing Cybersecurity in Insurance: Case Study Bosnia and Herzegovina
authors: Ajla Ćerimagić Hasibović, Muhamed Hasić, Kara Westerfield
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Like other financial industries, the insurance industry is facing increasingly extensive and complex cyber threats. This paper analyzes the role of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) in strengthening cybersecurity in the insurance company by log analyzing. The paper also emphasizes the importance of real-time threat and anomaly detection and the impact on the cyber insurance market through refined risk assessment and fraud detection. Due to its importance, a theoretical basis is provided on the implementation of various AI techniques in the context of cybersecurity in insurance. In all implementations, it is important to ensure that cybersecurity is not compromised at any point, while maintaining the competitiveness of the insurance company in the market.

title: Potential of Quantum Computing Applications for Smart Grid Digital Twins and Future Directions
authors: Arianne Ornella Lemo N., Ahmad Mohammad Saber, Deepa Kundur, Adam W. Skorek
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The convergence of digital twin technology and quantum computing is opening new horizons for the modeling, control, and optimization of smart grid systems. This paper explores the current research landscape at the intersection of these fields, with a focus on how quantum algorithms, such as the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA), can enhance the performance of digital twins in smart energy systems. We conduct a thematic literature review and identify key research trends, technical challenges, and gaps in real-world adoption. A conceptual framework is proposed to integrate quantum modules into classical digital twin architectures. Through a concrete use case, we illustrate the potential benefits of this hybrid approach for smart grid operation. The study concludes by highlighting future research directions toward building scalable, secure, and interoperable quantum-enhanced digital twins for cyber-physical energy systems.

title: Data Centers as Demand Response Resources in Active Distribution Network Planning
authors: Vineeth Vijayan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The rapid growth of data centers (DaC) is introducing new challenges for electric distribution networks. Characterized by high, continuous, and often rapidly scaling power demand, DaCs can strain local grid infrastructure, increase power loss, reduce hosting capacity for distributed energy resources, and complicate voltage and thermal management at the feeder level. At the same time, DaCs provide demand response (DR) potential through flexible IT workloads, workload shifting, adaptive cooling, and on-site backup and storage systems. This paper reviews recent strategies for using these capabilities in DR, covering optimization models, market mechanisms, and operational planning. The findings highlight challenges and outline directions for integrating DaCs as active resources in distribution systems.

title: A Mamdani Fuzzy Logic Approach for Demand-Based Inventory Purchase Planning
authors: Zayra E. Santos-Flores, Luz M. Ramos-González, Javier Calderon-Sánchez, José R. García-Martínez, Omar A. Barra-Vázquez, Irving Mora-González
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a fuzzy inference system designed to optimize purchase decisions by integrating three key variables: Income, Consumption, and Sales. The proposed model uses triangular membership functions with narrow bases to approximate singleton behavior, enhancing the precision of fuzzy set representation. The inference process is based on a rule base derived from historical data analysis and expert knowledge from materials planning personnel. Defuzzification is performed using the weighted average method, yielding crisp percentage values for purchase orders ranging from 0% to 100%. The system's performance was evaluated through surface plot analysis, which revealed nonlinear and interdependent relationships between the input variables and the purchase output. Results demonstrate that the approach provides accurate and adaptive recommendations for inventory control, offering a valuable decision-support tool for optimizing resource allocation and maintaining stock levels in dynamic operational environments.
