title: Sensor-Embedded Tissue-Mimicking Material for Long-Term Transcranial Electrical Stimulation
authors: Kajal Chandraprakash Jain, Jan-Hendrik Helm, Mikail Deniz Cayoglu, Frank Goldschmidtboeing, Katharina Jerg, Juergen Hesser, Peter Woias, Laura Maria Comella
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Experimental transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) research depends on tissue-mimicking materials (TMMs) for a validation of electric field distribution within the human head. Compared to conventional gel-based TMMs, conductive polymer composites, such as PDMS with multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs), offer improved shelf-life and stable conductivity. However, integration of embedded sensors for real-time field mapping remains largely unexplored. Here, we present a fabrication method for sensor-integrated TMMs made from doped PDMS, achieving a conductivity of 3.3 S/m at 1.5 wt% doping with MWCNTs, with electrical sensor structures manufactured by photolithography. DC stimulation revealed irreversible resistance increases, highlighting the suitability of AC or pulsed excitation for long-term studies. Voltage distribution mapping within the TMM was achieved through embedded copper sensors, and results were consistent in trend with computational simulations, validating the experimental approach. This work demonstrates the feasibility of sensorintegrated polymer TMMs for TES, ensuring reproducible sensor placement and providing a foundation for advanced brain phantom studies.

title: A Segment-Wise Multiwavelet Framework with Morphological Alignment for Denoising Partial Discharge Signals
authors: Hassan Ali, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Yasen Abdullahi Harrye, Wesam Rohouma
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a novel denoising method for partial discharge (PD) signals in smart grid condition monitoring, termed SEMMA (Segment-wise Adaptive Multiwavelet Denoising with Morphological Alignment). Aimed at improving the reliability of diagnostic systems in high-voltage equipment, SEMMA adaptively selects the most suitable wavelet basis for each signal segment to accommodate local non-stationary and transient features. Noise suppression is achieved through wavelet thresholding, followed by a morphology-preserving alignment strategy that ensures structural coherence and continuity across segments. Comprehensive experiments on synthetic PD signals under severe noise conditions demonstrate that SEMMA significantly outperforms traditional methods such as Energy-Based Wavelet Selection (EBWS) and SNR-Based Wavelet Selection (SNRBWS). It achieves consistently lower mean squared error (MSE), higher correlation coefficients (CC), and improved signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), confirming its effectiveness in enhancing signal fidelity. These results underscore SEMMA's potential for robust, real-time deployment in predictive maintenance frameworks for smart grid infrastructures.

title: Audio Fakes in the Noise: Hybrid Dnn-Based Detection with Se-U-Net, Resnet-18, and Wav2vec2-Xlsr Embeddings
authors: Andrei Axente, Mircea Giurgiu
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents a new processing pipeline and hybrid deep neural network (DNN) model to improve Audio Deepfake Detection (ADD) in noisy conditions. The model combines front- and back-end DNNs, trained either jointly or with a frozen front-end after optimal performance. The front-end uses either an SE-U-Net denoiser on mel spectrograms or wav2vec2-XLSR embeddings, while the back-end employs a ResNet-18 classifier. Experiments achieve 2.61 % Equal Error Rate (EER) under severe noise (0-20 dB SNR).

title: Recommended Steps for Developing Optimized and Secure Smart Contracts
authors: Marko Štaka, Sonja Ristić, Miroslav Stefanović, Danilo Nikolić, Darko Stefanović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Blockchain technology and smart contracts are central to decentralized applications. Operating on blockchain introduces challenges in design, development, and execution costs. On Ethereum, gas fees make optimization essential. This paper analyzes common mistakes affecting gas consumption and outlines strategies to improve efficiency. Using literature review and error systematization, key issues are identified and practical steps proposed. These recommendations, grounded in scientific research, aim to help developers design optimized and cost-effective smart contracts.

title: Benchmarking Functions Versus Containers for Compute-Intensive Workloads
authors: Evgenija Krajchevska, Marjan Gusev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Platform choices for compute-intensive jobs are often made without a disciplined, workload-specific comparison. This paper examines two dominant execution models, Functions-as-a-Service and Containers-as-a-Service, using a simple CPUbound kernel. We implement functionally equivalent services on both models, vary input sizes and resource allocations, and exercise sequential and bursty request patterns at comparable resource tiers to characterize performance, cost trade-offs, and scaling behavior. The study provides a controlled, reproducible protocol for comparing the models on compute-bound tasks and reports how memory and concurrency influence latency. The methodology is extensible, meaning the kernel can be swapped for other algorithms while preserving the measurement pipeline.

title: Shannon and Fisher Entropies for the 2P and 3D States of the Hydrogen Atom Confined in a Penetrable Spherical Box
authors: Andrei Solórzano Pérez, Jose Manuel Nieto-Jalil
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: A straightforward way to study the electronic structure and certain physical properties of atoms and molecules under high pressures is through the confinement (caging) model, in which the atom is placed at the center of a spherical box with impenetrable walls. The hydrogen atom confined inside penetrable and impenetrable spherical cavities is perhaps the most studied compressed system, and exact solutions exist for both types of confinement. The physical properties of the hydrogen atom confined within impenetrable-wall cavities (AHCI) have been widely analyzed; however, the same system embedded in penetrable spherical cavities (AHCP) has received less attention. A more physical model suggests using a spherical box with penetrable walls. Therefore, in this work, we compute via the variational method, the Shannon and Fisher information entropy in position space, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S_{r}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$I_{r}$</tex>, for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 \mathbf{p}$</tex> and 3d states of a hydrogen atom subjected to spatial confinement by penetrable and impenetrable spherical cavities. Additionally, we calculate the tunneling probability for the penetrable confinement and seek to relate it to the overlaps of the radial probability densities as a function of the cavity radius and the height of the confining barrier. To model the penetrable confinement, we employ a logistic potential which, unlike earlier reports that used a discontinuous step potential, is a continuous function. The wavefunction is expanded in terms of Slater functions that satisfy appropriate boundary conditions; in some cases, we find notable differences with respect to the impenetrable potential.

title: Detection of Suicidal Behaviors in Medical Students Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: José G. González Rodarte, Alejandro Mauricio-González, Margarita L. Martinez-Fierro
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: According to the World Health Organization (WHO) suicide is the third leading cause of death among individuals aged fifteen to twenty-nine years. This age group often coincides with higher education, where high levels of stress, anxiety and depression—factors that have a significant influence on suicide behavior—have been detected. The incidence is higher among medical students even during their professional practice. To address this issue, we developed machine learning models to perform a binary classification: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0}$</tex>= no suicidal behaviors, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1}$</tex>= suicidal behaviors. The dataset used in this study comprised 688 instances and 342 features, collected from an original self-reported questionnaire developed by experts and applied to medical students. The instrument includes items on socioeconomic status, substance use, trauma and related factors, and all responses were labeled by domain experts. The dataset was processed and transformed using techniques such as Frequency Encoding, Multi-Label Binarizer, Forward and Backward Selection. Two algorithms were trained—Support Vector Machines (SVM) and Random Forest (RF)—and evaluated, achieving an AUC (area under the curve) of 0.81 and 0.80, respectively.

title: Forward and Inverse Kinematics Implementation in a 4-DOF Master–Slave Robotic System with WiFi Communication
authors: José G. Pérez-Juárez, Emmanuel Portilla-Huidobro, Rodrigo Vidal-Martínez, Asael Rosas-García, José R. García-Martínez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents the kinematic modeling and experimental validation of a 4-DOF robotic manipulator implemented in a master-slave configuration. Both robots were controlled by ESP32 microcontrollers connected via WiFi, with the master executing predefined trajectories and transmitting joint angles <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(q_{1}, q_{2}, q_{3}\right)$</tex> to the slave for motion replication. Forward kinematics was derived using the Denavit-Hartenberg method, while inverse kinematics was solved geometrically. Two experimental tests were performed: (i) point evaluation and (ii) trajectory tracking. For the first test, three target points were repeated 30 times each, obtaining average errors of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.02 \mathrm{m}$</tex> in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$X, \pm 0.02 \mathrm{m}$</tex> in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Y$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 0.01 \mathrm{m}$</tex> in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$Z$</tex>, with RMSE values ranging from 0.0014 m to 0.0254 m. In trajectory tracking, a semicircular path with a radius of 0.336 m and a circular trajectory were implemented, achieving errors of 0.005 m and 0.006 m, respectively. These results confirm the accuracy and reliability of the proposed kinematic model for educational and industrial robotic applications.

title: Two-Way AF Relaying Over 6G Bands
authors: Volkan Özduran
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates the outage performance of amplify-and-forward (AF) two-way relaying under half-duplex (HD) and full-duplex (FD) operation across sixth-generation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \mathrm{G}$</tex>) candidate bands (e.g., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.6,7.8,15$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \text{G H z}$</tex>), with emphasis on an outdoor roadside vehicle-to-everything (V2X) setting. Because the end-to-end signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) is intractable in closed form, an upper bound is employed to derive compact lower-bound outage CDFs for both HD and FD. The bounds are validated by exact end-to-end Monte Carlo simulations. Results show that FD attains a modest outage advantage over HD when residual loop-interference is sufficiently suppressed, and that increasing the carrier frequency from 4.6 to 40 GHz degrades outage performance due to stronger frequency-dependent path loss when antenna gains are fixed.

title: Early Detection and Classification of Faults in Hybrid Ac/Dc Microgrids using Shannon Entropy
authors: Mir Uzair Kanth, Premalata Jena
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Hybrid AC/DC microgrids (HMGs) face significant challenges in the detection and classification of faults due to variable short circuit levels, bidirectional power flows across interlinking converters, and the absence of a unified protection strategy. This paper presents a novel framework that integrates Shannon entropy and Pearson correlation analysis to address these issues for rapid fault detection and classification across AC/DC subgrids of the HMG. The proposed method leverages Shannon entropy, a measure that quantifies current signal uncertainty and irregularity, to enable real-time fault detection. Further, fault classification is achieved by computing Pearson correlation coefficients between fault-induced entropy distributions of current signals and predefined entropy patterns corresponding to various fault scenarios. The framework is validated using a modified IEEE 33-bus HMG testbed simulated in MATLAB/Simulink. Simulation results confirm the method's efficacy for high-speed and accurate fault detection and classification, under diverse operating conditions.

title: Performance of Collaborative Multi Robots: Communication and Task Allocation
authors: Navin Kumar, Sreeja Kochuvila, R. Venkatesha Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Collaboration and coordination among multi robots in industrial environments and unknown environment such as risk, disastrous area presents an exciting opportunity in manufacturing and production processes as well as emergency and rescue activities. Coordination and collaboration involves effective communication among robots and efficient task allocation and performance. In this paper, we have proposed architecture and developed algorithm for effective communication and task management. Through performance analysis, we showed the error and task completion time as a function of number of robots. We have also presented coordination overhead when number of robots is more. It is found that there is decrease in task completion time as number of robots increases, which is obvious however, the rate of decrease is lesser as the number of robots increases. It is also found that the coordination overhead increases so as the error; almost linearly with the number of robots. Thus, a trade-off between scaling up robots and managing the higher error rate must be maintained. The investigation is expected to be very useful in automation of production, logistic, agriculture and other industry.

title: AI-Native transformation for next-generation Telecommunication Networks
authors: Shrihari Vasudevan, Abid Ahmed Salem, M.J. Prasath, Leif Jonsson, Massimo Iovene
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper posits that inherent Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a critical enabler of the next generations (5G, 5G Advanced, 6G and beyond) of Telecommunications (Telco). It discusses the evolving role of AI in Telco, distinguishes between two fundamental paradigms to incorporating AI in Telco and describes the AI-Native concept. The paper discusses features and maturity levels that characterize an AI-Native transformation. Particular attention is provided to the highest levels of AI-Native, towards realizing autonomous networks. Finally, the paper presents a practical Telco use-case and describes an advanced AI-Native implementation of the same.

title: Load Balancing and Autoscaling in a 5G Dense Network using Cloud Computing
authors: M Appana, GL Syria, R Kankipathi, Navin Kumar, R. Venkatesha Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Load balancing and auto-scaling are vital to the challenges of 5G dense networks where high-speed data and low latency in most applications are critical. This work explores the potential use of cloud computing in the dynamic allocation of resources with seamless performance avoiding network congestion. With the real-time monitoring and predictive algorithms, the system will adapt to the changes in the demand that has resulted in up to a 30% reduction in latency and 25% in throughput than the conventional approach not only enhances network efficiency and reliability but also reduces operational costs, offering a practical solution for service providers and a better experience for users.

title: Smart 5G Network Slicing for Collaborative UAV Swarms via Federated Reinforcement Learning
authors: Pradyumna Ku Patra, Onur Sahin, Vanlin Sathya, Ashutosh Dutta
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: We present in this paper an AI empowered framework for smart 5G network slicing in the context of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarm secured-interconnected environments, using Federated Reinforcement Learning (FRL) to optimize the dynamic bandwidth reservation according to mission-critical requisition. The architecture of the proposed model allows for on-the-fly adaptation in a heterogeneous mixed swarm that are carrying out surveillance, mapping, and relaying communication. The architecture preserves both privacy and incurs low communication latency as well as high scalability, since decentralized agents are jointly trained without the exchange of raw data. Simulation results demonstrate that our FRL-based slicing approach achieves significant performance improvement in throughput, task success ratio and resource utilization compared to traditional methods under different mission loads.

title: Dynamic Security Architecture for 5G O-RAN: A Closed Loop Paradigm
authors: Joel Renjith, Aditya D Venkatesh Prasanna, Aryan Gupta, Aditya Arakere, Radhika M. Hirannaiah, Prasad Honnavalli B
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The evolution from 4G to 5G has introduced Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) architecture, characterized by clearly defined, open interfaces that enable flexibility and interoperability. While these open interfaces promote innovation, they also demand advanced security measures to ensure resilient network performance. This paper presents a novel, layered, closed-loop, distributed security architecture tailored for 5G O-RAN. Leveraging the architecture’s modular design, the proposed system comprises a Lightweight Filtering Entity (LFE) and a High-Level Deciding Entity (HLDE) to ensure performance-optimized security that continuously adapts to combat new threats to the network. The LFE operates at lower network levels in real-time, filtering packets with minimal overhead, while the HLDE conducts near-real-time analysis of traffic flows, dynamically updating LFE rule sets to identify and mitigate anomalous activity. This dynamic, disaggregated approach safeguards the O-RAN environment while preserving network responsiveness and throughput efficiency. Initial testing demonstrates the efficacy of this distributed security solution in maintaining secure and efficient O-RAN operations.

title: A UAV-Assisted Architecture for Fault-Tolerant LoRa-Based V2I Communication
authors: Hemanth Durga Kumar Siripalli, Fazal Shaik, Meka Naga Nandini Devi, Ch Madhu Bhushan, Firoj Gazi, Md Muzakkir Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Reliable data exchange between vehicles and road-side units (RSUs) is critical for intelligent transportation systems, yet communication is often disrupted by low signal strength, intermittent connectivity, and missing acknowledgments. This paper proposes a deterministic, UAV-assisted architecture for fault-tolerant V2I communication using LoRa and IEEE 802.11 backhaul links. In the proposed system, UAVs are triggered when RSUs detect degraded RSSI or ACK loss, thereby providing a redundant relay path to maintain session continuity. All logic is implemented on off-the-shelf embedded hardware without reliance on cloud or simulation platforms. Experimental results from real hardware deployments demonstrate a 14% improvement in message delivery ratio, steady latency of approximately 34 ms, and enhanced SNR performance in low-coverage areas. The architecture is lightweight, interpretable, and immediately deployable for real-world ITS applications.

title: Improving parameterized Reservoir Computing based on Small-World Network
authors: Liu Rui, Xiao Qin
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Series analysis can not only be used for prediction in economic and financial fiels, but also can extract information related to dynamic mechanism from the series, which provides a basis for in-depth understanding of dynamic system mechanism. Reservoir Computing (RC) is a machine learning parad igm based on the recurrent neural network (RNN) framework, this paper modified the reservoir model in the literature, changing the ER random network in the reservoir model to a small-world network. Through the comparison results with the $E R$ random network, SW network and BA network, it is found that the prediction effect of using the modified small-world network is better. We conducted experiments using two typ es of data: one was the Henon chaotic series, and the other was wind speed prediction. We found that the prediction effect of the modified model was closer to the real data.

title: Downlink Beamforming in 5G Massive MU-MIMO Systems Using SRS-Based Channel Estimation
authors: Saikumarreddy Moyella, Pradeep Gautam, Peddinti T N Mrunalini, Pradeep Naru
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents the simulation and performance evaluation of a massive multi-user multiple-input multiple-output (MU-MIMO) 5G gNodeB system operating under time-division duplexing (TDD), exploiting channel reciprocity for efficient downlink channel state information (CSI) acquisition. Uplink Sounding Reference Signals (SRS) are processed at the base station (BS) using the linear minimum mean square error (LMMSE) estimation technique to obtain accurate channel estimates. These estimates are used to compute regularized zero-forcing (RZF) beamforming weights for simultaneous multi-user transmission. The system performance is evaluated in terms of cell throughput and error vector magnitude (EVM) for 64-QAM and 256-QAM modulation schemes by varying the number of users. Furthermore, spatial beam patterns are visualized to demonstrate effective user separation and interference suppression. The results confirm that the implemented framework enables high cell throughput and robust multi-user support in next-generation wireless networks.

title: Design of a Spatial Multi-Mode Energy Selective Antenna Integrating Electromagnetic Protection and Anti-Interference Capabilities
authors: Longjie Gai, Yanlin Xu, Peiguo Liu, Zhengwei He, Tao Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A spatial multi-mode energy selective antenna integrating electromagnetic (EM) protection and anti-interference capabilities for high-intensity radiation fields (HIRF) is proposed in this communication. 1-bit phase modulation of the element is implemented by embedding a feed phase network into the patch and actively controlling single pole double throw (SPDT) devices, which enables compact configuration and precise phase control. Additionally, an energy selective protective structure is created by etching cavities around the coaxial feed probe, allowing for joint energy and spatial domain manipulation. Furthermore, a reciprocal high-power injection testing method is introduced, significantly reducing the cost of conventional irradiation measurements. The measured results for different spatial modes show excellent agreement with full-wave simulations. Within the operational frequency band, the shielding effectiveness (SE) peaks at over 12 dB, the interference suppression capability (ISC) exceeds 10 dB, and the comprehensive protective capability (CPC) achieves over 22 dB.

title: Autonomous Reaction–Diffusion Circuits with Chemical Functional Elements: Trigger and Penstock
authors: Ivan S. Proskurkin, Alexandr A. Efimov, Ilya L. Malphanov, Dmitry A. Safonov, Anastasia I. Lavrova
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Recent developments in the engineering of reac-tion-diffusion systems have prompted a reassessment of chemically based strategies for implementing computational and neuromorphic functionalities. In this study, we report for the first time the design and experimental realization of two functional elements operating within the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction framework: a chemical trigger and a chemical penstock. These advances open new possibilities for developing autonomous chemical systems that function without the need for electrical power.

title: A new look at swelling of soft materials, taking into account deviations from the conventional second-order kinetic model
authors: Anastasia S. Vanina, Eugene B. Postnikov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The kinetics of water absorption leading to the swelling of hydrogels is an important characteristic of soft biomedical materials. Due to the structural features of some soft natural polymers, experimental data may be inconsistent with the classical kinetic model of the second order, which is conventionally associated with polymer swelling induced by water absorption. In this case, a more accurate procedure for data processing and regression is proposed, leading to a modified model that captures the specificity of such processes.

title: Fingerprint-Guided Group Contribution Analysis for Interpretable Profiling of Antitubercular Agents
authors: Anastasia I. Lavrova, Alexander V. Sychev, Eugene B. Postnikov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Understanding the structural determinants of antitubercular activity is critical for guiding the design of new therapeutic agents. In this study, we present a group contribution analysis of 385 newly synthesized compounds with confirmed activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis H37Rv, contained in two proprietary databases. Each compound was encoded using PubChem, Substructure, and Klekota-Roth fingerprinting schemes, and minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) were classified into four groups. By isolating substructures unique to the most active compounds, we identified specific functional groups potentially responsible for high antimycobacterial efficacy. This chemically grounded approach provides interpretable insights into structure-activity relationships and may serve as a foundation for subsequent machine learning-based drug discovery pipelines.

title: Adaptive Low-Complexity Multiple Access Scheme for Green Downlink Multi-User Multi-Antenna Systems
authors: Osama Elgarhy, Luca Reggiani, Muhammad Mahtab Alam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Multiple access schemes are essential for achieving high performance in cellular networks. Additionally, they significantly impact the power consumption of the Radio Access Network (RAN), which is the primary power-consuming component of the cellular network. Rate Splitting Multiple Access (RSMA) is currently regarded as a promising and attractive multiple access scheme. In this work, we introduce Selection Multiple Access (SMA) and compare it to RSMA. In SMA, the multiple access scheme is dynamically selected based on channel state information. We evaluated SMA and RSMA in terms of capacity, power consumption, energy efficiency, and processing time (used as a metric for complexity). RSMA demonstrated better capacity performance, offering up to 28% increase over SMA. However, it also consumes up to 24% more power compared to SMA. Furthermore, SMA achieves significantly better energy efficiency, with up to 47.59% improvement over RSMA, and offers much lower processing time, particularly when the users’ channels are sufficiently orthogonal.

title: Reliability-Aware Service Function Chain Placement in NFV-Enabled Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network
authors: Aryachandran S, Adarsh Raman, Sudarshan Chakravarthy Annadanam, Venkatarami Reddy Chintapalli
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Future communication networks must provide ubiquitous and seamless connectivity with global coverage to support critical applications that demand low latency and high reliability. Space-Air-Ground Integrated Networks (SAGIN) are envisioned as a key enabler of this vision by extending network reach beyond terrestrial limits. SAGIN harnesses the capabilities of Network Function Virtualization (NFV), which enables the virtualization of network functions, thereby reducing maintenance overhead and improving scalability. Service Function Chaining (SFC) adds additional flexibility by directing traffic through an ordered sequence of Virtual Network Functions (VNFs). However, deploying VNFs in SAGIN is particularly challenging due to the dynamic topology of the network, frequent handovers, and limited computational resources –especially in low-earth orbit (LEO) satellites and aerial nodes. To address these challenges, we propose a delay- and reliability-aware SFC deployment approach tailored for dynamic SAGIN environments. Our approach models the evolving network using a Reconfigurable Time Expansion Graph (RTEG) and applies a multi-constrained shortest path algorithm to determine optimal VNF placement. The simulation results show that the proposed approach significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art approaches in terms of SFC acceptance ratio by 40% and reliability by 10%, offering an effective solution for future integrated network deployments.

title: Attitude Estimation Hardware Interface for a Peripheral on Super General Purpose SoC
authors: Hibiki Shinozaki, Akira Yamawaki
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Advances in the Internet of Things (IoT) have increased the diversity of products, while the cost of developing new Systems-on-Chip (SoCs) continues to rise. To address this challenge, we previously proposed a versatile super general-purpose SoC, referred to as EPoC, which provides virtual hardware interfaces independent of peripheral specifications and dynamically reconfigurable at runtime. Built with high-level synthesis, EPoC enables rapid development of dedicated interfaces for a wide range of peripherals. To demonstrate its feasibility, we have applied EPoC to the ICM20948 sensor. Our prior work implemented a hardware interface for offset correction. In this paper, we further show that EPoC can realize more advanced processing by developing a hardware module that performs both filtering and attitude angle estimation for the same sensor. The proposed design is evaluated on an actual device, confirming the practicality and versatility of EPoC.

title: HPS-YOLO: A UAV-Based Small Object Detection Algorithm
authors: Yu Zhang, Bing Yao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Small target detection remains a key challenge in computer vision due to limited resolution and complex backgrounds. Although the YOLO series achieves a good balance of speed and accuracy, its performance on small targets in UAV scenarios is still limited. To address this issue, we propose HPSYOLO, an improved model based on YOLOv10. The main contributions include: (1) a Hybrid Channel-Spatial Attention (HCSA) module to enhance feature interaction, (2) a C2f_DWRSeg module for efficient fine-grained feature extraction, (3) the CARAFE operator to improve upsampling quality, and (4) an additional detection head for small targets. Experiments on the VisDrone2019 dataset show that HPS-YOLO improves mAP@0.5 and mAP@0.5:0.95 by 4.1% and 4.0% over YOLOv10, while reducing model size. These results verify the effectiveness of HPS-YOLO in small target detection tasks, especially in UAV aerial imagery and related applications.

title: SpikeTimeRx - A Divide-Attention Based SNN-Transformer Neural Receiver for Multi-Carrier Communication
authors: Raghavendra M A N S, Vidya Sagar T, Tharakadatta Hegde, Hari Prasad S V
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper proposes SpikeTimeRx, a novel hybrid architecture based neural receiver model that integrates the energy efficiency of spiking neural networks with the robust feature extraction of Transformers, through a Divided Space-Time Attention mechanism. The proposed architecture is tailored to support two distinct input processing approaches and offers compatibility with the 5G uplink-shared channel. Trained using tapped delay line (TDL) channel models, SpikeTimeRx is observed to offer performance close to that of the perfect CSI based receiver, under diverse channel conditions.

title: Beam Management for 5G FRl LEO based Non-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Ravikanth Pasumarthy, Sachin Gupta, Dhanmeet Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As part of 3GPP Release-17 and beyond there is evolution supported for Satellite networks (NTN) based on 5G network architecture with focus to provide coverage and capacity. NTN deployments based on 5G architecture align with ubiquitous connectivity being considered as part of 6G network architecture. Beam Management is one of the key features supported in Payload of NTN solution primarily to reduce the overall payload SWaP and to address the dynamic traffic demands of cells on ground. This paper provides approach and design considerations for Beam Management in FRl/LEO based Non-Terrestrial Networks. It defines the key input considerations for allocation of satellite beams to cells on the ground and approach for dynamic adaptation of beam management algorithms for efficient resource allocation and scheduling by MAC Scheduler. Simulations conducted to evaluate network capacity demonstrate key benefits of the proposed architecture of intelligent beam management and resource allocation in realizing full potential of 5G NTN and provide valuable insights for future system design and optimization.

title: Reliable Recovery Algorithm for Multi-Face Images Authentication Technology
authors: Ali Tariq Al-Tamimi, Rasha Thabit
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Face image authentication technology (FIAT) has drawn interest for secure communication and digital forensics. While single-face images are handled by current techniques, multi-face authentication is still not well studied. In order to restore tampered multi-face regions, this study examines four different recovery strategies. According to experimental results, all techniques restore faces; nevertheless, Bicubic Interpolation offers the best reconstruction quality and lays a solid basis for future multi-FIAT by reaching the maximum visual quality.

title: Observer-Based Attack Detection Scheme to Supervise Line Differential Protection
authors: Shayan Soltani, Siavash Yari, Navid Vafamand, Dariush Salehi, Masood Mottaghizadeh, Akhtar Hussain, Innocent Kamwa
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Differential relays are essential for protecting transmission lines, but their reliance on communication networks makes them vulnerable to cyberattacks, especially false data injection attacks (FDIAs). This paper explores how such attacks can be exploited and proposes a detection method to distinguish attacks from internal faults. The proposed approach compares positive-sequence voltage measurements at the relay terminal with estimates from two observers, each based on state-space models (for healthy and faulty conditions) using both local and remote inputs. Under normal or fault scenarios, one observer's estimate matches the measured voltage, reflecting the true system state. In contrast, during an FDIA, both observers deviate, leading to noticeable mismatches. Simulation results on the IEEE 39-bus system demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in identifying FDIAs.

title: EEG-Based and Self-Perceived Assessment of Auditory Discrimination and Attentional Responses to Intensity, Pitch and Localization Changes
authors: Sergio M-Cam, Priscila Montoya-Beltrán, Ricardo Ortega-Ramírez, Luz M. Alonso-Valerdi, David I. Ibarra-Zarate
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Auditory displays use sounds to communicate or monitor states and processes without the need for visual indicators. These auditory cues need people's attentional shift towards them. Auditory attentional processes can be measured through perceptual tests, and electrophysiological tests, such as auditory evoked potentials, that function as an indicator when different stimuli are presented. Assessment through auditory evoked potentials often use the oddball paradigm composed by frequent and deviant stimuli, where deviant stimuli can vary different auditory features (pitch, intensity, time, localization, speech). This study tests the attentional acoustic feature differences perceived through auditory evoked potentials. The discrimination paradigm was applied to 12 normal hearing students 18 – 25 years old, to measure their electrophysiological response changes using electroencephalogram readings in pitch, intensity, and localization of deviant sounds. Participants were also asked to fill in a questionnaire about their perception of attention during the test and the ease of discrimination. N2-P3a complex analysis indicated better attentional discrimination for pitch changes, followed by intensity and localization, supported by participant's questionnaire answers and number of deviants count-ed. These findings suggest that from these features, pitch changes can be widely considered when designing auditory displays that aim to easily shift people's attention towards the sound.

title: Proposal for an ISMS for a University Computing Center
authors: Jazmín Morales Toxqui, Felipe Mauricio Méndez Luna, Hannia Monserrat Landa Rodríguez, Julio Hernández Vargas
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive and replicable design proposal for an Information Security Management System (ISMS) tailored to the computing centers of higher education institutions. Building upon ISO/IEC 27001, ISO/IEC 27002, and ISO/IEC 27005 standards, the study applies these frameworks to the Computing Center II (CC2) of the Facultad de Contaduría y Administración (FCA) at Universidad Veracruzana (UV), Xalapa campus. The proposal introduces a methodological framework for risk assessment, the establishment of security controls, and a systematic improvement cycle based on quantitative and qualitative data. The novelty lies in its scalability and applicability to similar university computing centers, emphasizing continuous monitoring, awareness programs, and documented control mechanisms to ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability of information assets.

title: Enhanced Deep Reinforcement Learning Algorithms for Microgrids Energy Management
authors: Ayodele Benjamin Esan, Hussain Shareef
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Future energy systems require utilities to intelligently manage diverse energy sources including renewables to meet rising electricity demand. Microgrids, as localized smart grids, play a critical role in this transition. However, day-ahead energy scheduling remains challenging due to the stochastic nature of solar and wind generation and the non-linear dynamics of diesel generators. Traditional heuristic methods like Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) often yield suboptimal results. This paper proposes an enhanced deep reinforcement learning (DRL) framework, combining DRL with classical Quadratic Programming (QP). In this two-phase approach, DRL identifies feasible decision regions, while QP refines solutions to optimal continuous values. Two state of the art DRL algorithms: Double Deep Q-Network (DDQN) and Dueling DDQN (D3QN) were tested on an energy management problem for a microgrid in NSW, Australia. Training results showed that DDQN achieved the highest reward and lowest cumulative cost (AUD 1,243,227) with less than 0.2% constraint violations. In testing, DDQN further outperformed D3QN, achieving a lower operating cost (AUD 8,127) with zero constraint violations and less than 0.1 second execution time. Compared to GA, both DRL approaches achieved significantly lower costs by 25.4% (D3QN) and 26.5% (DDQN) and had much faster computation.

title: Acoustic Classification of Internal Combustion Engines According to Fuel Type
authors: Marko Milivojčević, Dejan Ćirić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This work presents an overview of research based on the fact that the human ear can distinguish between gasoline and diesel engines by sound alone. As part of the study, an acquisition system was developed with an innovative microphone placement, improving upon existing approaches and enabling the creation of a high-quality audio database collected in real-world conditions. The database was analyzed to identify the most relevant acoustic features, which were then used as inputs for machine learning and deep learning algorithms. The proposed approach achieved a high level of accuracy in classifying engines according to fuel type.

title: OCR Model for Text-Based CAPTCHA Recognition
authors: Alfredo Villasenor-Monsivais, Alejandra G. Silva-Trujillo, Juan C. Cuevas-Tello
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: CAPTCHAs serve as crucial tools to differentiate between human users and automated bots during online interactions, such as website registrations and surveys. These systems are essential for preventing malicious activities such as spamming and creating fake accounts. CAPTCHAs can be broadly categorized into OCR-based and non-OCR-based methods, with image and distorted character challenges being the most prevalent. Although designed to be easily solvable by humans, CAPTCHAs pose significant challenges for automated systems due to their reliance on cognitive skills such as visual recognition and pattern identification. This paper presents the design, development, and implementation of an OCR model to solve alphanumerical textbased CAPTCHAs of variable lengths. The proposed model is based on a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture trained on the EMNIST ByClass dataset. The model achieved an accuracy of 87.5 % in the test set, demonstrating its effectiveness in predicting text-based CAPTCHAs from the IMSS (Instituto Mexicano del Seguro Social) web portal, which belongs to the Mexican Government.

title: Balancing Accuracy and Adaptability: Hybrid Analytical–Neural Control in Omnidirectional Robots
authors: Sebastian Mendez-Villegas, Julio Antonio Caballero-Mora, Alexandro López-González, Janet López-Romero, Juan C. Tejada
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents and experimentally compares three navigation and trajectory-tracking strategies on an omnidirectional mobile robot (RoboMaster S1) equipped with a Vicon motion capture system and controlled in Python. (1) Classic potential-field control (P): the desired trajectory is encoded as an attractive field that generates the wheel velocities. (2) Neural network (NN) + proportional-integral (PI) control: a feed-forward NN predicts wheel velocities directly from the trajectory, while a PI loop compensates tracking errors. (3) Hybrid potential + NN control: the potential field provides the reference, and a second NN—trained on the residual error of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P}$</tex> method—supplies an online corrective signal (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta$</tex>). The contributions are: (i) empirical validation of a neural model for velocity prediction in omnidirectional platforms; (ii) integration of NNbased compensators with analytical laws; and (iii) a comparative experimental assessment of potential-based, neural, and hybrid schemes. Results show that the hybrid approach consistently improves tracking accuracy without sacrificing interpretability.

title: Use of Emerging Technologies in the Design of a Sailboat
authors: Luis Fernando Mena-Zamudio, Edna D. Rosas-Huerta, Mariano Azzur Hernández Contreras, Agustín L. Herrera-May, José Hernández-Hernández
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study addresses the design of a recreational sailing yacht through the integration of emerging technologiesspecifically 3D printing and virtual reality-as support tools in various stages of the naval design process. A scaled model of the hull was fabricated using 3D printing, meeting the dimensional requirements established by the ITTC and achieving a surface finish suitable for future hydrodynamic testing. In addition, a virtual reality environment was implemented to provide an immersive visualization of the vessel's interior, facilitating spatial and ergonomic validation of the design. The results obtained, including the calculation of the Stability Index (STIX) in accordance with international standards, confirmed the yacht's suitability for operation under demanding sea conditions. This study demonstrates that the combined use of emerging technologies not only enhances the efficiency and quality of the design process, but also serves as a valuable pedagogical and innovative tool in the naval engineering field.

title: Design and Fabrication of a Forearm Prosthesis for Pronosupination Movements
authors: César Hernández-Enríquez, Enrique A. Morales-González, Uwaisu Yusuf, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado, Ernesto A. Elvira-Hernández, Jose Hernandez-Hernandez, Agustín L. Herrera-May
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Pronosupination movement of the human forearm allows essential activities of daily living such as feeding or grooming. A forearm prosthesis can imitate the biomechanics of pronosupination. However, the design of the forearm prosthesis has significant challenges to enhance its performance. Herein, we design a prototype for a forearm prosthesis with a pronosupination movement based on a simple mechanism. This prototype can generate the motions of the pronosupination of the human forearm with good performance. Furthermore, the proposed prototype includes a simple mechanism, which decreases its manufacturing cost. The prototype's performance is tested with suitable results, reproducing the biomechanics of the human forearm using an easy-to-operate mechanism. This prototype design can be optimized for future research on a human forearm prosthesis.

title: Mašinsko Učenje U Oblasti Kognitivnog Radija: Dvodecenijska Evolucija I Pravci Daljeg Razvoja
authors: Uroš Bojanić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Sažetak—Ovo istraživanje prati evoluciju tehnika mašinskog učenja u kognitivnom radiju i pruža sistematski pregled razvoja u ovoj oblasti tokom perioda od 2007. do 2025. godine, i to kroz tri etape: klasične metode (2007-2015), duboko učenje (2016-2020) i savremenu veštačku inteligenciju (2021-2025). title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp4-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: State of Charge Estimation in Li-ion Batteries Using a Robust Nonlinear Observer with Low-Cost Sensors
authors: Majid Gharebaghi, Omid Rezaei, Zhanle Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a robust Luenberger observer for accurate State of Charge (SOC) estimation in lithium-ion batteries. A Lyapunov-based strategy is used to make the system work appropriately with model uncertainties as well as measurement problems. The proposed observer jointly estimates SOC, terminal voltage, and sensor-induced measurement errors using a second-order battery model. This method is particularly useful for stationary energy storage systems using low-cost sensors. Low-cost sensors typically have a large bias with inaccurate measurements. We conducted the experiment using a 25 A lowcost current sensor. In the experiment, we added bias as an error to the current measurement. The experimental results show that, compared to the conventional Sliding Mode Observer (SMO), the proposed Luenberger observer significantly decreases the measurement error, effectively improving the accuracy of the SOC estimation. In addition, the observer decreases chattering effects and offers robust performance. The proposed observer can be used to reduce the battery management systems using low-cost sensors, without compromising the SOC estimation accuracy.

title: Analysis of the Aerodynamic and Hydrodynamic Stability of FPSO in Deep Waters of the Gulf of Mexico
authors: José Hernández-Hernández, Edna D. Rosas-Huerta, María E. Tejeda-del-Cueto, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado, Ernesto A. Elvira-Hernández, Agustín L. Herrera-May
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In the offshore oil and gas industry, FPSO (Floating, Production, Storage, and Offloading) vessels are widely used for the transportation of oil and gas. These FPSO vessels are designed to consider the extreme environmental conditions encountered during their navigation routes. These designs of FPSO vessels can include the analysis of their aerodynamic and hydrodynamic stability. Thus, a FPSO vessel must maintain its stability under normal working conditions and in critical weather states, such as hurricanes and cyclones. Herein, we report the analysis of the effect of ocean waves and wind on the stability of an FPSO operating in the deep waters of the Gulf of Mexico (at water depths exceeding 500 m). This analysis considers the FPSO dynamic response under various heeling angles. Thus, we propose a design methodology for FPSO vessels to ensure their aerodynamic and hydrodynamic safety under severe environmental conditions. The proposed methodology utilizes a computational tool based on the Airy theory to determine hydrodynamic forces, and another based on the finite control volume method to determine aerodynamic forces. This methodology is applied to an FPSO operating under high wind velocities of 136 knots (70 m /s) and wave heights ranging from 1.12 m to 14.14 m, with wave periods of 6 to 22 s. The FPSO stability is modeled using MAXSURF and ANSYS Fluent software. Our methodology can be used to evaluate the technical feasibility of operating floating units in highly complex environments, such as the deep-water field of the Gulf of Mexico. The proposed methodology can be useful for naval designers of FPSO vessels, regarding the influence of high aerodynamic and hydrodynamic forces.

title: Dynamic Accuracy Estimation in a Wi-Fi-Based Positioning System
authors: Marcin Kolakowski, Vitomir Djaja-Josko
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The paper presents a concept of a dynamic accuracy estimation method, in which the localization errors are derived based on the measurement results used by the positioning algorithm. The concept was verified experimentally in a Wi-Fi based indoor positioning system, where several regression methods were tested (linear regression, random forest, k-nearest neighbors, and neural networks). The highest positioning error estimation accuracy was achieved for random forest regression, with a mean absolute error of 0.72 m.

title: OptičKa MrežA za Daljinsko Upravljanje TračNim Transporterima
authors: Branimir Davidović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: U radu je analizirano rešenje mreže transportera i bagera za proizvodnju uglja. Stanice pokreću trake koje prenose materijal. Razmatran je problem upravljanja kretanjem sistema transportera na daljinu. Medijum za prenos podataka za upravljanje sistemom su optička monomodna vlakna. Oprema na sistemu je umrežena pomoću svičeva, a prelaz između optičkih i bakarnih provodnika realizuju elektrooptički pretvarači. Optički pojačavači daju mogućnost širenja mreže i komunikacije na veća rastojanja. Diskutovan je razvoj i mogućnosti 5G mreže i IoT komunikacije u cilju optimizacije mreže.

title: Small Signal Stability Assessment of Large-Scale Grid Connected PV Systems
authors: Ghazi A. Ghazi, Essam A. Al-Ammar, Hany M Hasanien
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As the capacity of renewable energy sources, particularly photovoltaic (PV) systems, increases in advanced power networks, managing voltage control in these grids is becoming more challenging. Renewable energy converters offer benefits in weak grid conditions due to their inherent voltage support. However, existing research on these converters' stability characteristics is limited, necessitating further analysis. This paper investigates how passive system parameters affect the small signal stability (SSS) of a smart gridconnected <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100-\text{MW} \text{PV}$</tex> plant. The study employs eigenvalue analysis and participation factor, comparing the performance of twin-delayed deep deterministic (TD3) controllers to proportionalintegral (PI) controllers, with stability assessments supported by Bode plots. A sensitivity analysis was also conducted to evaluate the impact of varying passive parameters on eigenvalues and overall system performance. Results from mathematical analysis were validated through MATLAB Simulink simulations, revealing that passive parameters significantly affect the SSS of large-scale gridconnected PV systems.

title: CEDAR: A Communication Protocol for Collaborative Event Detection and Reporting in Duty-Cycled Underwater Acoustic Networks
authors: Aleksa Albijanić, Slavica Tomović, Igor Radusinović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents an energy-efficient and reliable protocol for collaborative event detection and reporting in underwater acoustic networks. The protocol is motivated by the requirements of long-range, event-driven passive acoustic monitoring (PAM) in maritime surveillance, where unattended nodes must operate for extended periods, suppress false alarms through local consensus, and deliver timely reports despite the severe constraints of the acoustic channel. The design integrates three core mechanisms: (i) a hierarchical structure that minimizes redundant transmissions by aggregating detection data under a designated coordinator, (ii) a duty-cycled MAC that conserves energy while remaining responsive to detections, and (iii) an anycast forwarding scheme that exploits multiple candidate relays to minimize reporting latency. Evaluation with the DESERT Underwater simulator demonstrates that the proposed solution sustains low reporting latency even under stringent duty-cycling conditions and scales efficiently with network size.

title: A Method of Converting Data Between Different Mediums by Forming a Shared Distribution Between Multiple Generative Models
authors: Dejan Bogosavljev, Željko Lukač
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper examines a method of combining the generative capacities of two distinct generative models trained on datasets that present the same semantic information in different mediums. One variational autoencoder is trained on a dataset that contains images of hand written digits, while the other is trained on a dataset that contains audio recordings of people pronouncing digits in English. The first variational autoencoder is trained to reproduce images of hand written digits using standard techniques, after which the latent data distribution is saved. The second variational autoencoder is trained in such a way as to make the latent data distribution match the saved one, effectively making the two models use a shared latent space. It is shown that establishing this shared latent space makes it possible to convert the same information from one medium to another.

title: Machine Learning Methods for Error Correction in the OAM-Based Wireless Communications
authors: Jelena Z. Trajković, Slobodan V. Savić, Darko M. Ninković, Andjelija Ž. Ilić, Milan M. Ilić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Orbital angular momentum (OAM) of electromagnetic (EM) waves is proposed for data rate increase in short-range wireless communications. Misalignments of the transmitter relative to the receiver hinder the realization of such systems. We generated data by computational modeling using analytical expressions to investigate the potential of machine learning (ML) for the correction of lateral and tilt offsets. Mean absolute error (MAE) was below 0.07° and 0.4 mm for tilt and lateral offsets, respectively.

title: A Maturity Model for Governing Digitalization Projects: DEWA's Digital PMO Approach
authors: Syed Abdul Kareem Shajahan, Sana Zargham Abdulghafor Ziaei, Omar Abdelghafour Alkhaja, Khalid Khalil Alhosani, Khalid Abdulla Abdulqader Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Dubai Electricity and Water Authority (DEWA) has adopted a systematic and governance-driven approach to digital transformation through its Digital Project Management Office (DPMO). The DPMO operates as a centralized platform ensuring that digital programs are directly connected to DEWA's strategic objectives and yield quantifiable benefits. By implementing a maturity-oriented governance model, DEWA has institutionalized a structured methodology that governs all phases of digital project delivery—from initiation and planning to execution and performance evaluation. This approach provides a repeatable and transparent framework for managing digital initiatives and serves as a benchmark for other public-sector entities aspiring to strengthen digital governance with measurable and consistent results.

title: A Generic Algorithm for Universal TDM Communication Over Inter Satellite Links
authors: Miroslav Popovic, Marko Popovic, Pavle Vasiljevic, Ilija Basicevic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The original Python Testbed for Federated Learning Algorithms is a light FL framework, which provides the three generic algorithms: the centralized federated learning, the decentralized federated learning, and the TDM communication i.e., peer data exchange in the current time slot. The limitation of the latter is that it allows communication only between pairs of network nodes. This paper presents the new generic algorithm for the universal TDM communication that overcomes this limitation, such that a node can communicate with an arbitrary number of peers, assuming the peers also want to communicate with it. The paper covers: (i) the algorithm's theoretical foundation, (ii) the system design, and (iii) the system validation. The main advantage of the new algorithm is that it supports real-world TDM communications over inter satellite links.

title: Spectrum Data Monitoring based on Frequency Occupancies for Dynamic Spectrum Access
authors: Sathish Babu Sekar, K Tamizhelakkiya
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The massive growth of emerging future networks faces challenges such as complex and dynamic spectrum access (DSA) patterns. An accurate mobile traffic spectrum activity evaluation (SAE) plays a prominent role in dynamic resource allocation, spectrum monitoring, wireless interference detection, energy savings, and network optimization. Recently, collaborative combining of DSA with deep learning (DL) has been widely accepted with appreciable performance. We present a suitable frequency channel occupancy (FCO) and frequency band occupancy (FBO) algorithm that exploits time and frequency correlations to improve quality of service (QoS) and reduce computational complexities. A heterogeneous DSA model has been adopted and tested according to the third generation partnership project (3GPP) standard for evaluating spectrum activities. We adopt the applicability of FCO and FBO techniques in the design of DSA networks that enlightens the efficient spectrum utilization for a typical indoor UMa scenario.

title: A Novel Method for GPTP-Based Time Synchronization of 5G UEs Considering Asymmetric Uplink/Downlink Latency
authors: Anas Bin Muslim, Ralf Tönjes, Thomas Bauschert
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: For Precision Time Protocol based Time Sensitive Networking (TSN) time synchronization it is assumed that the latency in uplink and downlink direction is the same, which is true for fixed TSN-Ethernet networks. However, with TSN-5G integration (where the 5G system acts as a TSN bridge), an equal uplink/downlink delay cannot be assumed for the 5G wireless links, thus drastically decreasing the synchronization accuracy. In the 3GPP standardization, Device Side and Network Side Time Translators (TT) were introduced to resolve this issue. In this paper, a novel method is presented to increase the synchronization accuracy for 5G User Equipment (UE) without requiring the TT. Our method works by time-stamping the radio resource request and grant messages within the UE and utilizes the measured delay in the PTP synchronization process. Through simulations with OMNeT++ we investigated our approach for various traffic scenarios and showed that TSN time synchronization over a 5G network with high accuracy is possible even without TT.

title: 6G Network Design with Custom-Tailored IRSs for Sustainable Millimeter-Wave Connectivity Enhancements in Industrial Environments
authors: Simon Häger, Melina Geis, Kevin-Ismet Šabanović, Pascal Jörke, Stefan Böcker, Christian Wietfeld
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Private millimeter-wave (mmWave) networks offer immense potential for indoor factory (InF) environments by enabling ultra-high data rates and network capacity to support advanced industrial applications. However, their performance is significantly challenged in non-line-of-sight (NLOS) situations, where severe attenuation may lead to insufficient connectivity. Traditionally, this limitation requires the deployment of additional base stations (BSs), which increases both the costs and energy consumption. To address these challenges efficiently, future 6G networks will leverage intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRSs) to illuminate under-connected regions. The passive-static HELIOS IRS concept has reached a high maturity level compared to other solutions, with field experiments successfully demonstrating its ability to enhance various link metrics in predetermined regions. This work now investigates how to systematically determine the required number of IRSs, their placement, and preconfigured reflection characteristics. Our proposed brownfield network planning scheme for IRSs thereby takes an important step toward solving the open research problem of 6G hybrid network planning. Using a real-world production scenario from previous measurement campaigns, we demonstrate that one BS with three custom-tailored passive IRSs eliminates the need for a second active BSs while maintaining the required service quality level. Index Terms—6G network planning, mmWave communication, static-passive IRS, indoor factory, ray-tracing, reflection model.

title: Optimization of Radio Coverage using mm Wave to provide Data Services: use case 100ft MG Road, Bengaluru
authors: Abisri S, Anitha E, R S Abhinav Vikram, Kartik P. Fondekar, Navin Kumar, R Venkatesha Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The deployment of millimeter wave (mmWave) communication is critical for meeting high data rate and low latency requirements of beyond 5G (B5G), the next-generation wireless networks. This becomes more difficult in highly mobile and high traffic environment. This study investigates the radio coverage characteristics of mmWave frequencies in a specific urban 100-foot (30.48-meter) MG road scenario in Bengaluru city of India. Using simulation, we analyzed signal propagation, path loss at 28GHz bands under line-of-sight (LoS) situations. We optimized the antenna placement to provide and maintain high data rate user experience throughout the street. It is ensured that a minimum signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 19dB for 100MHz and 13dB for 400MHz is maintained throughout the street. Received signal strength indicator (RSSI) remained stable across both bandwidths ranging from -66dBm to -74dBm, confirming its independence from system bandwidth. This would allow sufficient data rate services to mobile users. The results highlight strong directional beamforming to enhance coverage in such unique environment. Our findings provide insights into optimal antenna placement and the feasibility of mmWave deployment for dense urban corridors. This work supports the planning and design of efficient 5G and beyond networks in short-range, high-capacity road environments.

title: Denial of Service Attacks Targeting Layer 2 in 5G RAN
authors: Arpit Tripathi, Ashutosh Rajput, Ashit Kumar Subudhi, Koteswararao Kondepu, Abhishek Thakur, Bheemarjuna Reddy Tamma
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks on legitimate users using a Fake Base Station (FBS) remain a persistent threat to the integrity and reliability of 5G networks. These attacks exploit gaps in lower-layer authentication procedure by impersonating legitimate base stations, resulting in wastage of radio resources. Traditionally, these attacks and their detection techniques often operate at the Non-Access Stratum (NAS) or Radio Resource Control (RRC) layers, missing the signs of such attacks originating at Layer 2. In this work, we introduce two DoS attacks on Random Access Channel (RACH) and RRC procedures over 5G RAN and study their impact on users. We further introduce a user-side threshold-based FBS detection technique to mitigate the impact of FBS. We demonstrate these DoS attacks and assess the effectiveness of the proposed detection technique on both physical testbed and simulation environments. Attack scenarios, including RACH drop and RRCSetupRequest drop, are emulated to demonstrate the effectiveness of these attacks. The results indicate that the proposed DoS attacks using FBS can significantly drain radio and compute resources, even without going through the registration process. With a threshold-based detection technique, we can minimize the impact of these attacks before they escalate.

title: MLN-BEV: Instance Prediction Algorithm for Temporal Fusion of Dynamic and Static Objects
authors: Weichao Li, Daizheng Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Currently, most temporal fusion methods for multi -temporal bird’s-eye view (BEV) do not fully consider the motion characteristics of dynamic objects. To address this, we propose a novel algorithm, MLN-BEV. MLN-BEV introduces an innovative Motion-aware Neural(MLN) Module, which creatively fuses the time intervals, surrounding vehicle pose information, and velocit y vectors to model the dynamic behavior of objects. This provides feature representations with both spatial and temporal informati on for the bird’s-eye view, while also optimizing the learning resu Its with label information. Additionally, to address the issue of mu Iti-scale feature fusion, we propose a novel MAFF module that en hances multi-scale feature fusion capabilities, further improving $\mathbf{t}$ he model’s ability to perceive features at different scales. Thismo dule effectively integrates features from multiple layers, ensuring high accuracy even in complex scenarios. To validate the effective ness of MLN-BEV, extensive experiments were conducted on the NuScenes dataset. The results show that, the MLN-BEV model ac hieves $\mathbf{6 1. 3 \%}$ and 39.2% improvement in IoU, significantly enha ncing the accuracy of vehicle prediction.

title: Research on Gold Stock Price Forecasting Based on PSO-BP Neural Networks : —A Case Study of the Shandong Gold
authors: Xiaoli Xiong, Qin Xiao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Stock price prediction is a classic problem in financial time series analysis. In this paper, to improve the prediction accuracy of gold-related stock prices, the particle swarm optimization algorithm is introduced. This can overcome some shortcomings of the traditional backpropagation neural network. The traditional BP neural network is relatively sensitive to the initial weights and is prone to fall into the situation of local optimum. This paper selects Shandong Gold as the research object, uses its daily trading data from 2014 to 2024, adopts the sliding window method to construct the sample, then establishes the standard BP model and the mixed PSO-BP prediction model, and compares these two models. The empirical results show that The predicted values and measured values of the PSO-BP model fit more closely, and the prediction error has been significantly reduced. Among them, MAE decreased by 52.74%, RMSE decreased by 50.88%, MAPE decreased by 56.35%, while the coefficient of determination increased to 0.9781. These findings prove that the PSO-BP model is more precise and practical in predicting the stock price of gold, and can provide investors with a more reliable quantitative analysis tool.

title: Smartphone-Based System for Quantifying Tremor and Freezing of Gait in Parkinson’s Disease
authors: Guillermo J. Armoa, Victoria E. Abarca, Dante A. Elias
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The primary objective of this study was to develop a smartphone-based system for the quantitative assessment of motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease (PD), with a focus on tremor and freezing of gait (FOG). The system employed inertial sensors embedded in iOS devices to capture motion data at 50 Hz and integrated signal processing with machine learning techniques for symptom quantification. For FOG assessment, a Random Forest classifier achieved 90% accuracy using time- and frequency-domain features. Tremor analysis relied on spectral methods to identify characteristic oscillations within the $\mathbf{4 - 6 ~ H z}$ range typically associated with PD. Technical validation with five healthy control subjects demonstrated consistent system performance, supporting its applicability in clinical settings. All controls exhibited a Freezing Index (FI < 2.5) and a Tremor Index ($\mathbf{T I} \boldsymbol{\lt} \mathbf{2 5 \%} \boldsymbol{)}$. These findings highlight the potential of the proposed system as a portable solution for the objective monitoring of Parkinson’s disease symptoms, complementing clinical evaluations and supporting personalized therapeutic approaches.

title: Price-Driven, Load-Aware Power Scaling for Green Proximal Spectrum Sharing in Multi-Operator Cellular Networks
authors: Vijeth J Kotagi, Neha R Pudakalakatti, Rahul Thakur
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The rapid growth of mobile data and the dense deployment of small cells have intensified spectrum scarcity and energy consumption. A promising future direction of multi-operator cellular deployments allows users to associate with neighboring Base Stations from other operators, if that link offers a stronger Signal-to-Interference-plus-Noise Ratio. While "Proximal Spectrum Sharing" improves spectrum usage and users’ experience, it leads to unpredictable traffic shifts, inefficient energy usage, and revenue imbalance among the operators.To overcome these limitations, we propose a game-theoretic model that jointly couples user association, pricing, and power into a single convergent algorithm. The interaction between the users and operators is formulated as a two-level game: an ordinal potential game governing user association, and a concave profit-maximization game handling pricing decisions. We establish convergence to a Nash Equilibrium where no player benefits from unilateral deviation. Extensive simulations validate our framework, resulting in lower power consumption and higher operator revenue
