title: Robust Infrared UAV Detection Method Based on Spatiotemporal Transformer in Thermal Crossover Dynamic Scenarios
authors: Hengrui Hu, Tianhui Li, Bo Liu, Hui Zeng
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Infrared Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) detection remains challenging due to thermal crossover interference, small target characteristics, and dynamic background clutter. Existing methods, such as Siamese trackers and single-frame detectors, often struggle to balance spatial discriminability and temporal continuity, leading to degraded robustness in complex environments. To address these issues, we propose IRST-DETR, an end-to-end video detection framework that integrates spatiotemporal features for robust UAV detection. IRST-DETR combines a spatial branch with a detail-enriched pyramid module (DEPM) for fine-grained feature extraction and a temporal branch using Video Swin Transformer to model motion dynamics. Hierarchical fusion modules, including the Temporal Gate Fusion Module (TGFM) and the Spatial-Temporal Attention Fusion Module (STAFM), adaptively merge spatiotemporal information, enhancing robustness against thermal noise. To rigorously evaluate performance in challenging conditions, we construct a specialized evaluation subset from Anti-UAV410, focusing on cluttered infrared scenes with dynamic thermal interference. Extensive experiments on Anti-UAV300, Anti-UAV410, and the challenging subset demonstrate that IRST-DETR achieves state-of-the-art performance. It outperforms Siamese trackers by 2.8% in state accuracy and surpasses single-frame detectors by over 9% in complex scenarios, with ablation studies confirming its efficiency. This work advances practical infrared UAV detection in real-world environments. Code and models are available at: https://github.com/henryHu-manboo/irst_detr.

title: MsgFilter: Proactive Anti-Harassment Sender-Anonymous Messaging System
authors: Siqin Li, Kun He, Min Shi, Yajing Huang, Ruiying Du, Jing Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Anonymous submissions inspire people to speak up since hiding their identities can protect them from negative influence by their own words. However, the abuse of anonymity may bring harassment to those public submission callers. Existing works only handle DoS attacks or block harassment senders in an active manner, which behave poorly in the early prevention of uncharacterized harassment. In this paper, we propose MsgFliter, a sender-anonymous messaging system with proactive anti-harassment mechanism. Our core idea is to prevent unanswered senders from sending messages continually while keeping their identities, messages, and sender types secret. To meet the functionality and security requirements of MsgFliter, we propose the Anti-Harassment Anonymous Authentication (AHAA) protocol. We associate messages from the same sender through linkable tags and invalidate linkability when a message is replied to. To achieve session indistinguishability, we further combine the proposed anonymous authentication with zero-knowledge proofs of disjunctive relations. We implement MsgFliter and compare its performance with related solutions. Experimental results show that our solution is practicable.

title: Performance Assessment of Homochiral Carbon Nanotube van der Waals Crystal Transistors
authors: Qimao Yang, Jing Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: Self-consistent dissipative quantum transport and ab initio density-functional theory (DFT) simulations are used to assess the performance potential of homochiral carbon nanotube (CNT) van der Waals (vdW) crystal FETs. At a gate length required for the upcoming technology nodes, the CNT vdW crystal FETs have a significant performance advantage over both the silicon and monolayer MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> FETs for high-performance transistor applications. The high packing density of the homochiral CNTs in the CNT vdW crystal boosts the current per channel width, and the interaction between CNTs at the vdW distance only has a small impact on the band structure, which maintains high band-structure-limited velocity and light effective mass. The homochiral CNT vdW crystal FET can achieve a predicted on-current of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim {2700}{\,}\mu \textrm {A}/\mu \textrm {m}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> at an off-current of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sim \!{10}^{-2}{\,}\mu \textrm {A}/\mu \textrm {m}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and a power supply voltage of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\textrm {DD}}={0}.{4}{\,}\text {V}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> at a gate length of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${12}{\,}\text {nm}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. As the gate length is further scaled down below <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${10}{\,}\text {nm}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, the CNT vdW crystal FETs, however, suffer from significantly degraded subthreshold swing and large leakage current due to pronounced quantum tunneling effects, while monolayer MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> has a better performance than both the CNT vdW crystal and silicon FETs at a gate length of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${6}{\,}\text {nm}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>. For RF applications, the CNT vdW crystal FET outperforms both the silicon and monolayer MoS<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub> FETs in the presence of parasitic capacitance due to its larger carrier velocity and transconductance per channel width.

title: Fusing Hyperspectral Proximal Sensing to Enhance Chlorophyll-a Estimation from Sentinel-2
authors: Na Li, Yunlin Zhang, Kun Shi, Yibo Zhang, Weipeng Lin, Xiayang Luo, Boqiang Qin, Guangwei Zhu, Hongtao Duan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Accurate quantification of chlorophyll-a (Chla) is vital for understanding, assessing, and managing eutrophication, aquatic ecosystem health, and biogeochemical cycling. However, satellite-based Chla estimation in Case Ⅱ waters remains challenging due to complex optical properties, limited synchronized field data, and uncertainties in spectral-temporal matching. This study introduces a novel approach that integrates Sentinel-2 multispectral imagery with coincident hyperspectral proximal sensing (HPS) measurements to enhance the Chla estimation accuracy in optically complex waters. First, a band-conversion fusion method with high consistency (slope=1, R2=0.95) was proposed by leveraging strong correlations between Sentinel-2 and HPS spectra. Subsequently, a high-precision machine learning-based fused Chla model (R2=0.93, NRMSE=24.2%, MAPE=31.6%) was developed using a fusion dataset combining HPS measurements (N=1728) and Sentinel-2 data (N=100). This model significantly outperformed the unfused Sentinel-2-only model and four existing literature algorithms. When applied to Sentinel-2 time-series data (2016–2024) over Lake Taihu, the fused model revealed a notable eutrophication mitigation trend, with Chla decreasing from 30.78 μg/L to 19.56 μg/L. Comparative analyses demonstrated that fusing HPS data improved Sentinel-2–derived Chla estimation performance because strict temporal synchronization of HPS measurements reduced spectral uncertainty and enhanced sensitivity to Chla variability. Recalibrating Sentinel-2 spectra reduced MAPE from 41% to 9.7%, and expanding field-matched datasets enhanced the model reliability and robustness by 23.4% and 10.8%, respectively. The study underscores the transformative potential of multisource data fusion for advancing satellite-based water quality monitoring, particularly in optically complex aquatic systems. The proposed framework offers a transferable methodology for estimating other biogeochemical parameters through integrated spaceborne and proximal sensing approaches, providing a foundation for improved environmental monitoring and management.

title: High Space-bandwidth Product Label-free Examination of iPSC-derived Brain Organoids via Fourier Ptychographic Microscopy
authors: Mikolaj Krysa, Mikolaj Rogalski, Piotr Arcab, Pawel Goclowski, Kamil Kalinowski, Piotr Zdańkowski, Vishesh K. Dubey, Mukesh Varshney, Balpreet S. Ahluwalia, Maciej Trusiak
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Quantum Electronics
abstract: Fourier ptychographic microscopy (FPM) is a promising quantitative phase imaging technique that enables high-resolution, label-free imaging over a large field-of-view. Here, we present the first application of FPM for the quantitative analysis of human brain organoid slices, providing a powerful, cost-effective, and label-free enhancement to the current gold-standard fluorescence microscopy. Brain organoids, prepared as thin (5 μm) slices, were imaged with a custom-built FPM system consisting of a standard light microscope (4x, 0.2 NA objective) and a 7×7 LED array. This configuration achieved a synthetic numerical aperture of 0.54 and a spatial resolution of approximately 488 nm across an area of 2.077 × 3.65 mm. Fluorescence microscopy was used in parallel for neurons, astrocytes, and nuclei labeling, providing rich fluorescence imaging. Moreover, we designed an automated method to merge classical resolution fluorescence images to visualize the whole brain organoid and align it with the numerically increased space-bandwidth product FPM image. The provided alignment method enables rich phase-fluorescence correlative imaging. Based on the segmentation performed on the stitched fluorescence images, we devised a quantitative phase analysis revealing a higher mean optical thickness of the nuclei versus astrocytes and neurons. Notably, nuclei located in neurogenic regions consistently exhibited significantly higher phase values (optical path difference) compared to nuclei elsewhere, suggesting cell-type-specific biophysical signatures. The label-free, quantitative, and high-throughput capabilities of the FPM approach demonstrated here make it a powerful and accessible tool for future structural and functional studies of whole-section brain organoid development and disease modeling studies.

title: AI-assisted Mobility Management in Urban Environments using O-RAN
authors: Georg Hoelger, Varun Gowtham, Karl Schrab, Robert Protzmann, Alqama Rao, Marius Corici, Ilja Radusch, Thomas Magedanz
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Key innovations in the context of 6G networks have given rise to ultra dense networks particularly influential in urban environments. Correspondingly, the network mandates a proactive mobility management system capable of administering optimized handover of the user equipment (UE) considering prevailing conditions of the operating environment. We aim to combine AI-assisted mobility management algorithms with Eclipse MOSAIC for evaluating AI-driven Intent Based Networking (IBN). Taking advantage of the Open RAN Alliance (O-RAN) standards, this article proposes a novel handover mechanism inter-linked with simulated urban environment coupled with a handover algorithm focused on ensuring UE Quality of Service (QoS) constraints. This paper is the first part of a series of papers and therefore includes a preliminary evaluation setup and is planned to be extended in subsequent work.

title: Integrated Aerial Access and Backhaul with THz-Noma for 6G Networks
authors: Pola Preetham, Pranay Utpal, Sandeep Thota, Sourabh Solanki, Chandan Kumar Sheemar, Vibhum Singh, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: To meet the capacity and flexibility demands of future 6G networks, this paper proposes a novel unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-assisted communication framework that leverages integrated aerial access and terahertz (THz) backhaul. The system employs a UAV as an aerial access node, integrating THz backhaul for high-capacity core connection while providing multi-user connectivity via sub-6GHz access links enhanced with non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA). THz links enable ultra-high data rates through directional beamforming to mitigate molecular absorption and path loss, while NOMA enhances connectivity by serving multiple users simultaneously using power domain multiplexing with successive interference cancellation. A joint optimization problem is formulated to maximize the sum rate of multiple ground users, considering UAV positioning, power allocation, and beamforming under Rician fading. The resulting non-convex problem is solved using a sequential least squares programming algorithm with a multi-start strategy. This integrated design is particularly well-suited for cellular and IoT deployments in remote or emergency scenarios where conventional terrestrial infrastructure is unavailable.

title: Comparative Analysis of 5G Testbeds in Disaggregated Open RAN Architectures
authors: Sathish Nallamolu, Ipsita Sannigrahi, Pradeep Gautam, Naru Pradeep
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Deploying 5G testbeds using disaggregated Open Radio Access Network (Open RAN) architectures has gained prominence due to their adaptability, cost efficiency, and interoperability. This paper deals with the design and implementation of 5G testbeds that leverage open-source RAN solutions, Software Radio Systems RAN (SRSRAN), and OpenAirInterface (OAI), in two functional split configurations. Option 8, utilizes a software-defined radio (SDR) in a monolithic setup, and Option 7.2x incorporates a Radio Unit (RU) with a disaggregated Central Unit (CU) and Distributed Unit (DU) connected via Ethernet-based midhaul. Under deployment scenarios like Terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial, this testbed architecture examines key performance metrics such as latency, synchronization stability, and computational efficiency. A detailed investigation of real-time processing challenges, hardware-software codesign considerations, and network disaggregation impacts is conducted. The report emphasizes how open-source RAN frameworks can facilitate vendor-neutral deployments and enable sophisticated 5G feature testing in terrestrial and Non-Terrestrial network (NTN) scenarios.

title: DeepStack: A Deep-learning Integrated Cognitive Protocol Stack for Efficient Networking
authors: Ankit Srivastava, B.S. Manoj
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper proposes DeepStack, a deep learning integrated network protocol stack, to optimize network performance when using HTTP and VoIP applications. DeepStack is a new direction towards a fully AI-driven network protocol stack. By analyzing diverse mobile and stationary node scenarios using a network simulator, data on protocol stack parameters collected and their interrelationship on network performance metrics have been analyzed. Our proposed DeepStack then generates optimized parameter values to achieve user-requested performance figures. The critical decision-making is, thereby, transformed into the deep learning model to make better decisions. The accuracy and precision of the results obtained are greater than 84%. Our DeepStack approach offers a real-time adaptation to changing network conditions, leading to results that outperform traditional approaches.

title: Exploring the Integration of Virtual Reality in Multivariable Calculus: A Study on Technology Acceptance and Student Engagement
authors: Julio Cesar Avila, Jose M. Nieto-Jalil, Ludovic Guillaume Florent Betton
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This exploratory mixed-methods study examines virtual reality (VR) integration in multivariable calculus using Oculus Quest and GeoGebra 3D. Fifty engineering students participated (experimental <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=26$</tex>; control <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=24$</tex>). The intervention provided approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5}$</tex>-minute weekly VR activities for six weeks to visualize surfaces, tangent planes, and level sets; the control received equivalent 2D instruction. Outcomes were technological acceptance (TAM) and academic engagement (UWES-S), complemented by brief portfolio reflections. Analytically, we conducted pre-post comparisons within groups and between-group tests on change scores (t/Wilcoxon as appropriate) and report small, non-significant effects; qualitative data contextualized the results. Acceptance was high (usefulness, ease of use, and intention above 4 on a 5-point scale), while engagement gains were modest and not statistically significant, suggesting short exposure limits impact. Operational feasibility was high with minimal infrastructure. We discuss novelty effects, recommend longer and collaborative VR tasks, and outline a longitudinal agenda-including learning outcomes-to assess whether sustained, well-scaffolded VR can deepen engagement and conceptual understanding in STEM.

title: A Simplified Algorithm for Evaluation of the Pollution Levels from the Measurements at a Spot Affected by Multiple Contamination Sources
authors: Dan L. Lacrama, Florin Alexa, Florentina A. Pintea, Antoanela Naaji
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper is focused on the necessary actions to be employed for protecting the environment. Continuous measurements must be done in sensible spots, thus the contamination level to be kept under control and any exceeding limits event must be quickly signaled. In the industrial cities where multiple polluting sources are located, it is critical to determine quickly who is responsible for the overflow and take rapid measures to correct it. While the continuous measurements have to be performed at the spots of interest for pollution monitoring, it is also highly important to improve the data processing speeds and prompt alerting protocols. Thereby, the real time response to the environmental threats would be enabled. A solution to achieve this prompt operational reaction is proposed in this paper.

title: Energy Trading Potential Index for a Peer-to-Peer Smart Grid Community
authors: Muhammad Hamza Bin Aqeel, Naveed Ul Hassan, Muhammad Jawad, Rana Saif Ul Islam, Shahzain Ahmed, Ijaz Haider Naqvi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The increasing integration of distributed renewable energy resources among households has sparked growing interest in peer-to-peer (P2P) energy trading as a means to enhance local energy sharing and prosumer participation. Blockchain technology is often proposed to support these systems due to its ability to ensure transparency security and decentralized control. However blockchain is resource-intensive complex and not universally suitable. Therefore there is a critical need to evaluate whether a given community has sufficient trading activity to justify such infrastructure. This paper proposes a novel methodology to quantify the energy trading potential (ETP) of a P2P community. The P2P energy trading market is modeled as a bipartite graph with consumers and prosumers as nodes and edge weights capturing the potential of each trading pair based on willingness to trade (reflected through buy/sell prices) demand-supply compatibility and communication strength. The total edge weight is normalized to define the Energy Trading Potential Index (ETPI) ranging from 0 to 1 where higher values indicate stronger trading opportunities. Simulations show that the method generally favors balanced communities (with roughly equal numbers of consumers and prosumers) though deviations may occur due to other factors. ETPI serves as a decision support tool throughout the life cycle of a P2P system helping to justify or optimize energy trading infrastructure.

title: Organisational and Technical Challenges for Conflict-free use of Civil Airport Airspace by Drones
authors: Hristo Stanev, Slav Mitev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This article analyses the organizational and technical challenges for the integration of drones into the airspace of civil airports, with an emphasis on creating conditions for conflict free with general air traffic. The study includes a review of modern technologies for detection and counteraction of drone flights, based on up-to-date data from 2025. The results support the need to use integrated regulatory frameworks, such as UTM (Unmanned Aircraft Systems Traffic Management), to ensure aviation safety. The article offers recommendations for future developments to support the harmonious use of the airspace of civil airports by drones and manned aircraft.

title: Cost-Efficient and Grid-Friendly Energy Management of Electric Vehicle Fleets via Deep Q-Learning Optimization
authors: Thomas Tongxin Li, Mohannad Alhazmi, Huizu Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a Deep Q-Learning-based optimization framework for cost-efficient and grid-supportive energy management of electric vehicle (EV) fleets. By formulating the charging and discharging scheduling problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), the proposed model enables real-time adaptation to fluctuating electricity prices, varying grid load conditions, and renewable energy supply dynamics. A standard Deep Q-Network (DQN) architecture is employed to learn the optimal policy without relying on model-based assumptions or complex handcrafted heuristics. The state representation integrates key operational factors, including battery energy levels, time-of-day indicators, electricity prices, grid load, and renewable energy availability. Extensive simulation studies demonstrate that the DQN-based strategy can reduce operational costs by up to 43% and significantly mitigate peak grid loads compared to conventional uncontrolled charging baselines. Sensitivity analyses further reveal the influence of reward structure design on system performance. The results validate that Deep Q-Learning offers a scalable, adaptable, and efficient solution for intelligent EV fleet energy management in dynamic and uncertain smart grid environments.

title: Combined Synchronverter-VSM Based HVDC Transmission Design with Power-Hardware-In-the-Loop (PHIL) Implementation
authors: V. Evangelopoulos, M.-E. Karaitsi, T. Kavvathas, T. Alexandridis, G. C. Konstantopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The paper investigates a combined strategy of the Synchronverter (SV) and the Virtual Synchronous Machine (VSM) technologies for the converter stations of an HVDC transmission system. Both the SV and the VSM provide frequency and voltage support to the corresponding AC grids with the addition of virtual inertia provision that enhances the frequency dynamic response. Based on the dynamic model of the HVDC system, a detailed control design that includes both the inner current and voltage control loops, along with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$S V$</tex> and VSM dynamics is analytically presented. Finally, the proposed design is experimentally validated on a unique Power-Hardware-In-the-Loop (PHIL) setup consisting of two Typhoon HIL units that emulate the two converter stations in real time, interacting with two programmable bidirectional DC power supplies and a realistic transmission line module of 160 km. The proposed approach is tested under real grid frequency variations, obtained from a smart meter, illustrating experimentally the desired power flow and DC voltage control, together with the frequency support provided for both grids.

title: Hyperparameter Tuning with Modified Metaheuristics for Intrusion Detection in IoT Networks
authors: Ivan Kosta, Snezana Anetic, Luka Jovanovic, Milos Antonijevic, Miodrag Zivkovic, Nebojsa Bacanin
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Intrusion detection in Internet of things (IoT) networks is critical for safeguarding devices and communication infrastructures. This study investigates IoT intrusion detection using XGBoost classifiers optimized via multiple metaheuristic algorithms and introduced a modified version of a recently proposed optimization metaheuristic. Hyperparameter tuning was performed across thirty independent runs, and models were evaluated using standard evaluation metrics. Results demonstrate that the proposed modified optimizer helps tune extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost) classifier performance consistently so that it outperforms other evaluated approaches, achieving the highest objective function values, lowest error rates, and balanced detection of normal and anomalous traffic. Convergence analysis and error distributions further confirm the stability and reliability of this approach. These findings highlight that careful metaheuristic optimization of XGBoost hyperparameters can significantly improve intrusion detection performance in heterogeneous IoT environments.

title: Area-Optimized RISC-V Matrix Extension Implementation for Edge Devices
authors: Ivan Čejić, Andrija Nešković, Mladen Berekovic, Saleh Mulhem, Vuk Vranjković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Matrix operations are a key computational kernel in modern embedded and compute-intensive Machine Learning (ML) workloads. Consequently, RISC-V Instruction Set Architectures (ISAs) now include matrix extensions to boost the performance and efficiency of these operations. However, such extensions require additional matrix register files and dedicated computing units, leading to a huge area overhead without significant or even proportionate performance gains. This work tackles this design problem and introduces an area-efficient open-source matrix unit tightly coupled to a 64 -bit RISC-V core. The proposed unit implements a subset of the XuanTie-RV matrix extension v0.3, focusing on 8-bit integer inputs with 32-bit accumulators, matrix load/store, and configuration instructions. We synthesize our design with IHP SG13G2 130 nm open PDK, and benchmark it with matrix operation workloads up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \times 256$</tex> The results show that our matrix unit requires only 143 kGE, reaching 110 MHz, with a sustained throughput up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.2 \text{MAC} / \text{cycle}(57 {\%}$</tex> of peak). To demonstrate the area efficiency of our proposed design, a performance comparison with the state-of-the-art (SoA) matrix and vector unit architectures reports that our design is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times$</tex> smaller in area than SoA matrix unit, while consistently outperforming the SoA vector unit in matrix multiplication tasks.

title: Electrophysiological and Morphological Signatures of Active Versus Passive Movements in the Elbow Joint
authors: Haruki Higa, Momoko Oshiro, Satoshi Shimabukuro, Tomo Akamine, Emi Tamaki
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Proprioception is fundamental to motor control. Quantitatively distinguishing between active and passive movements within the same task is essential for understanding human motor control and may inform clinical and rehabilitation applications. However, few studies have compared agonist muscles during active and passive movements of the same joint in the same direction. In this study, data from agonist muscles (biceps brachii and triceps brachii) were obtained using surface electromyography (sEMG) and optical myography (OMG), two sensing modalities commonly used for proprioceptive assessment. Differences between active and passive movements were evaluated. The results show that sEMG amplitudes are significantly larger during active than passive movements in both muscles (after Holm correction). In contrast, OMG identifies phase-specific biceps segments with greater deformation during active movement; however, the scalar metrics-root-mean-square (RMS) and standard deviation (SD)-do not differ significantly. These findings suggest that differences between active and passive movements are expressed clearly in electrophysiological signals, whereas they appear only locally in muscle deformation. Future work should examine agonist-antagonist muscle groups and investigate active-passive differences under multiple velocity conditions.

title: Impact of Vessel Elasticity and Micropolar Fluid Behavior on Hemodynamic Performance in Microvessels Blood Flow
authors: Priti Chaudhary, Neelam Choudhary, Saurabh Rana
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Blood flow in microvessels is strongly influenced by red blood cells (RBCs) and vessel wall compliance, making simple models inadequate. This study presents a novel two-layer model that unifies an RBC micropolar core, a surrounding Newtonian plasma layer, and a compliant vessel wall under pulsatile pressure gradient. Our analysis shows this unified approach significantly reduces peak axial velocity and wall shear stress fluctuations compared to rigid-wall models, while producing flatter velocity profiles that align with in vivo observations. These findings highlight the critical role of microstructural effects and fluidwall interactions in microvascular hemodynamics.

title: Design and Evaluation of a Skill-Independent Shooting Game for Flow Measurement Using Self-Report and HRV
authors: Takahiro Ueno
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Flow is an optimal psychological state of immersion and focused attention, typically arising when task challenge matches individual skill. Previous studies often employed Tetris to manipulate difficulty and evaluate flow through self-reports and physiological measures such as heart rate variability (HRV). While informative, these paradigms suffer from strong skill dependency, limiting the generalizability of physiological indicators. This study introduces a skill-independent shooting game designed to reduce prior experience effects. Using intuitive gyroscope-based controls, the game implements three difficulty levels (Easy, Medium, Hard) to elicit varying levels of concentration. Ten university students played randomized sequences while self-reported flow scores and electrocardiogram data were collected. HRV features (low- and high-frequency components) were extracted from $\mathbf{R}-\mathbf{R}$ intervals for analysis. Results showed a consistent increase in self-reported flow with task difficulty (Easy: 4.0, Medium: 5.4, Hard: 6.5). HRV analysis revealed group-level tendencies toward reduced autonomic variability under higher challenge, though individual variability remained. In sum, the findings replicate the general direction of Tetris-based research while demonstrating that a skillindependent design can yield more consistent group-level outcomes. The proposed paradigm thus provides a practical and generalizable tool for advancing flow research through both subjective and physiological indices.

title: Boundary-Spanning Search and Green Technological Innovation: The Roles of Dynamic Capabilities and Environmental Dynamism
authors: Xiaolong Chen, Yuhua Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Green technological innovation is vital for firms’ sustainable development. This study, based on the knowledge-based view and contingency theory, distinguishes between reactive and proactive boundary-spanning search and explores their effects on green technological innovation. We further examine the mediating role of dynamic capabilities and the moderating role of environmental dynamism using survey data and hierarchical regression. Results show that both search types significantly promote green innovation. Reactive search enhances exploitative dynamic capabilities, while proactive search strengthens exploratory capabilities. These capabilities partially mediate the effects of the two search types. Environmental dynamism amplifies the link between proactive search and exploratory capability, as well as its indirect effect on green innovation, offering insights into firms’ green innovation strategies.

title: Introducing Feature Selection Fusion into Person Verification Based on Finger-writing of a Simple Symbol
authors: Kota Fukui, Takumi Fukuda, Hibiki Fujie, Isao Nakanishi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Handwriting verification is one form of biometrics. Among its various approaches, finger-writing verification of a simple symbol is the most convenient, in which a user is verified by writing a simple symbol with a finger on a smartphone screen. In a previous study, an error rate of 11.9% was achieved. Furthermore, by selecting and fusing individually high-performing features, an equivalent error rate was obtained, even though the number of used features was reduced. In this study, we propose a new feature selection method focusing on individuality, and a fusion method that combines this with three other selection methods. By using the proposed method, we finally achieved the error rate of 5.8%.

title: Terrestrial FSO Optics System Design: A Way to Reduce Optical Power Spill at the Receivers
authors: Smita Srivastava, Gyan Deep Verma, Abhishek Mani Shukla, Abhishek Dixit
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we design both the transmitter and receiver optical systems using Zemax optical design software. Additionally, we present the corresponding mathematical formulations that characterize the optical components. The developed optical system is then employed to evaluate key performance metrics namely, the received power, geometric loss, and outage probability, using Monte Carlo simulations within the context of a free-space optical (FSO) communication system. The transmitter optics system utilizes a collimator and proposed beam expander (BE) to reduce the divergence angle thereby geometric loss of the optical beam. In the receiver optics systems, we propose three different designs: the first design consists of a beam reducer followed by a collimating lens, whereas the second and third designs consist of a collimating plano-convex (PCX) lens and plano-concave (PCV) lens. The first receiver optics design emphasizes minimizing the beam diameter rather than maximizing power. The subsequent designs focus on enhancing power at the cost of increased beam diameter. These designs show a trade-off between received power and beam diameter in the receiver’s configuration to achieve an efficient FSO communication system. Further, we compare the outage probability performance for conventional and proposed FSO optics system. Our proposed optics with FSO system show a transmit power gain of around 22 dB compared to the conventional.

title: Hybrid Block Sparsity-Integrated PMRDN for Channel Estimation in XL-MIMO OFDM Systems
authors: Shubh Raj Gupta, Salihath P, Vani Devi M
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a hybrid block sparsity-enhanced extension of the polar-domain multi-scale residual dense network (PMRDN), designed for efficient channel estimation in extremely large MIMO (XL-MIMO) systems with orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM). While the original PMRDN model estimates the channel for each subcarrier independently, the proposed hybrid block sparsity-integrated PMRDN (HBS-IPMRDN) performs joint estimation across all subcarriers in a single forward pass, capturing inter-subcarrier correlations and reducing computational complexity. A hybrid block sparsity module is integrated to enforce structured sparsity along the subcarrier frequency, suppressing weak and noisy components and thereby improving estimation accuracy. Simulation results show that HBS-IPMRDN achieves up to 15 dB and 20 dB improvements in normalized mean square error (NMSE) over PMRDN and simultaneous orthogonal matching pursuit (SOMP), respectively, under low SNR conditions of-5 dB.

title: Assessment of 21-Year Field-Exposed PV Module Performance and Degradation in the Composite Climatic Zones of India
authors: Dushyant Kumar Singh, Birinchi Bora, Arup Dhar, Chandan Banerjee, Mohammad Rihan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Long-term performance and degradation analysis of photovoltaic modules is critical for defining testing criteria, as well as for evaluating recycling and reuse potential. This study presents the performance and degradation assessment of monocrystalline silicon PV modules that have been field-exposed for 21 years in the composite climatic zones of India. The observed annual power degradation rate ranges from 0.8 % to 4.0 %, surpassing typical warranty limits. Despite this degradation, the analysis indicates considerable potential for reusing PV modules that have experienced up to 25 % performance loss, particularly in secondary use for low voltage applications. Additionally, area requirement analysis at a latitude of 30° shows that accommodating modules with 25 % degradation would require approximately 36 % more land compared to non-degraded modules, an important consideration for project economics and land use planning.

title: Dynamic Programming for Peak Shaving with the Solar Based Ev Charging Station
authors: Kalpana Chauhan, Rajeev Kumar Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: There is high demand of electricity in the campuses within a specific time duration. This specific demand duration creates the demand peaks, for which there is need to pay extra charges to the grid. Heuristic methods, a genetic algorithm (GA), linear programming (LP), and mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) are all outperformed by the suggested DPPSEV-PV. Peak loads and overall energy expenditures are significantly reduced when DPPSEV-PV is compared to alternative methods. By attaining the lowest peak load and total cost, DPPSEV-PV demonstrates its superiority in managing the complex dynamics of EV and PV integration. In contemporary power networks, the DPPSEV-PV algorithm offers a reliable and effective EV and PV penetration rate, leading to cost reductions and ideal energy management. The installation of an AC charging station on the university campus has been the subject of analysis.

title: Optimizing Rvpp Bidding Strategies in Energy and Reserve Markets Under Different Regulations
authors: Hadi Nemati, Pedro Sánchez-Martín, Lukas Sigrist, Luis Rouco, Álvaro Ortegay
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The concept of the Renewable-only Virtual Power Plant (RVPP) provides a solution for aggregating multiple dispatchable and non-dispatchable renewable sources for market participation while capturing the uncertainties of stochastic units. However, technical and regulatory barriers associated with portfolio bidding in markets often prevent or limit their full integration and participation. This paper investigates the effects of different aggregation strategies imposed by market regulations on the profitability of RVPP. Simulation results compare different energy and reserve markets mechanisms, taking into account uncertainties related to non-dispatchable RVPP units and electricity prices.

title: Detecting Changes in the Photoplethysmographic Response of the Prefrontal Cortex by an Fnirs Device
authors: Martínez-Castillo J., González-Mejía G., Espinoza-Maza J. J., Zapata-Rodríguez U. G., Ortiz-Martínez F., Mendoza-Barron G., Mabil-Espinosa P.
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In this study, we report the effectiveness of an optode array in detecting local photoplethysmographic changes in the prefrontal cortex during the performance of a 2-back memory task in healthy human subjects. This approach is proposed as a cost-effective and functional alternative to avalanche photodiodes and photomultiplier tubes commonly used in near-infrared functional spectroscopy systems and which are more expensive to implement. The experimental protocol involved five participants aged between 22 and 35 years (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 6.02$</tex> years), who were seated in front of a computer screen. Using an array of five optodes placed over the midline of the prefrontal lobe, participants were asked to recall an alphabetical symbol from a sequence of symbols presented on the screen as part of the task. During task performance, signal changes from photodiodes at different locations on the prefrontal cortex were recorded. Time-resolved measurements revealed signal variations indicating a significant increase in the absorbance of 850 nm infrared light during task execution compared to baseline periods.

title: Rényi Entropy Based Cognitive Load Evaluation via Photoplethysmography
authors: Milan Milivojević, Dragi Dujković, Ana Gavrovska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: There is an increasing focus on quantifying individual mental effort during complex task performance. This is especially relevant when analyzing physiological signals affected by cognitive task, where photoplethysmography (PPG) signals are popular data source for cognitive effort evaluation. Entropy as a common feature is used for cognitive assessment due to its ability to quantify complexity and randomness within the PPG signal. This paper specifically applies Rényi entropy as a generalized measure, using different entropy orders to assess pre- and post-cognitive load phases. The results demonstrate the potential of Rényi entropy for discriminating between the resting and the workload state.

title: Optimizing Speech Emotion Recognition with Attention-Driven Deep CRNN
authors: Valentin-Dimitrie Popescu, Mircea Giurgiu
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel Deep Neural Network (DNN) architecture for Speech Emotion Recognition (SER) leveraging exhaustive feature selection and an improved Convolutional Recurrent Neural Network (CRNN). Focusing on the standard RAVDESS dataset, we aim to overcome limitations associated with data scarcity by applying several data augmentation methods to enrich the training data. An exhaustive search for optimal acoustic features combinations is performed, and the enhanced CRNN model incorporates additional layers and regularization techniques to improve performance. Our results demonstrate a significant increase in accuracy, highlighting the effectiveness of the proposed methods, particularly in real noisy environments and underscoring their potential for improving human-computer interaction through enhanced emotion recognition.

title: Modeling of Central-Loop TDEM Systems Using Explicit and Implicit FDTD Methods
authors: Osman Said Bişkin, Talha Saydam, Serkan Aksoy
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this study, Time Domain ElectroMagnetic (TDEM) problems involving a lossy half-space and a lossy halfspace with a conductive buried object beneath a thin upper layer are solved by using diffusion equation based explicit ForwardDifference (FD), implicit Backward-Euler (BE), and implicit Crank-Nicolson (CN) Finite Difference Time Domain (FDTD) methods. In two-dimensional Cartesian coordinates, a transmitter antenna and a centrally located receiver antenna are placed at the air-soil interface. The first problem is validated using an analytical solution while the second problem is verified by comparing the implicit FDTD results with the explicit FDTD results. According to the results, although the BE-FDTD and the CN-FDTD methods consume 1.07 and 1.20 times more memory compared to the FD-FDTD method, their computation times are reduced by factors of 44.60 and 40.46, respectively.

title: Reconstruction of Missing Samples in Signal Defined on a Directed Graph
authors: Petar Drašković, Miloš Daković, Jonatan Lerga, Ali Bagheri Bardi, Ljubiša Stanković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Incomplete signals defined on graphs present a significant challenge for their analysis and processing. This paper presents a method for missing graph signal values reconstruction on directed graphs, whose adjacency matrices are often not diagonalizable. We perform modification of the adjacency matrix, i.e., adding new edges, with the aim of achieving diagonalizability, allowing the application of spectral analysis - i.e. graph Fourier transform as well as advanced reconstruction algorithms. The presented results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Scalability Analysis of SaaS Infomatrix ERP
authors: Petar Ordanoski, Marjan Gusev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and performance evaluation of scalability in the Infomatrix ERP system, a true cloud-based SaaS developed by Infoproject LLC. Through architectural analysis and performance testing, the system demonstrates horizontal scalability. A shared database supports up to 5,000 concurrent users while maintaining 3 -second response times. Results confirm efficient scaling, cost reduction, and the effectiveness of true SaaS architecture in enterprise environments.

title: Real-Time Kinematics Positioning GNSS Landslide Monitoring System - Comprehensive Review
authors: Asja Muharemović, Dejan Jokić, Jasmin Kevrić, Marko Simeunović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Landslides pose a serious hazard worldwide, and monitoring their slow displacements is crucial for early warning and risk mitigation [1]. Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) sensors provide continuous 3D positioning in all weather, but conventional geodetic-grade GNSS are expensive and fragile in harsh terrain. Recent years have seen the rise of low-cost GNSS units that offer centimeter-level accuracy at a fraction of the cost [2]. This paper reviews technical innovations that enable such performance, focusing on real field deployments. Key advances include high-precision positioning techniques (RTK and Precise Point Positioning, PPP) and hybrid PPP-RTK corrections that speed up convergence, data-driven approaches like “Virtual RINEX” (VRINEX) to emulate reference observations [3] [4], and integration of inexpensive MEMS inertial sensors to suppress GNSS noise [5]. Open-source processing (e.g. RTKLIB-based workflows) and community tools now make low-cost GNSS monitoring more accessible. Field tests confirm that properly deployed dual-frequency low-cost GNSS stations can track subcentimeter displacements. We summarize 14 representative studies, compare their setups and results (Tables 1&2), and conclude that multi-constellation dual-frequency receivers, short baselines or VRINEX references, and hybrid processing are recommended for cost-effective landslide monitoring. Future work should emphasize long-term autonomous networks and real-time PPP-RTK services to further democratize GNSS hazard monitoring.

title: Flexible Contract Parameterization for Battery Energy Storage Systems in Wholesale Electricity Markets
authors: Akash Kumar, Swathi Battula, Abheejeet Mohapatra
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: With the growing integration of renewable energy sources in the power grid, the associated inherent power injection intermittency and unpredictability have intensified challenges related to grid stability and supply-demand imbalances. Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) offer a promising solution by providing the flexibility necessary to support the generation or demand ramping needs. However, existing market structures often hinder the participation of BESS, primarily due to the lack of adequate compensation for their diverse capabilities. To address this issue, a flexible contract for BESS has been introduced in the literature. However, the effectiveness of a flexible contract depends on systematically determining its parameters. This paper presents a comprehensive methodology to determine parameters of a flexible contract for BESS offering grid services.

title: Phase demodulation for distributed acoustic sensing based on improved phase-locked loop
authors: Jiaying Chang, Mingda Zhu, Ruihao Duan, Xinxin Wang, Minghai Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS) system based on phase-sensitive optical time-domain reflectometry (Φ-OTDR) uses optical fiber as a medium to detect external vibration information. To improve the noise immunity of phase demodulation in DAS systems, this paper introduces an enhanced phase-locked loop demodulation method. The approach incorporates a Kalman filter (KF) to optimize the Costas loop (CL) and employs a moving average filter (MAF) to further suppress noise in the phase demodulation process. In addition to significantly improving phase demodulation performance, the method effectively reduces the influence of random noise on the demodulation accuracy. Simulation and experimental results show that the proposed KF-CL-MAF algorithm reduces both phase demodulation distortion and mean square error by an order of magnitude, while increasing the output signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) by approximately 11 dB compared to existing demodulation methods. This improvement provides a more reliable technical solution for high-precision vibration monitoring with DAS systems in complex environments.

title: A Comparative Analysis of a Leading Communication Service and a Professional Audio Streaming Tool for Academia
authors: Flavio Everardo, Norberto E. Naal-Ruiz, David I. Ibarra-Zarate, Gabriel R. Gil-Muñoz, Sebastián Portillo, Esteban Vergara-Mena
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of two web services in real-time audio streaming, one dedicated to online communication and the other to professional audio streaming. These services have different architecture and software design processes that directly impact the workflow of users to playback, capture, or process digital signals without compromising audio data quality. The audio streaming services were compared in terms of frequency content and dynamic features before and after streaming acoustic signals in four conditions. The results of this study indicate the importance of dedicated audio-specific tools as alternatives to handle remote processes while guaranteeing high-quality audio on the other end. The relevance of our study supports the idea of using precise audio software for audio streaming, turning it into an ideal remote tool for academic areas.

title: PWM Strategy for Leakage Current in a Transformerless Multinivel Inverter for PV System Applications
authors: Cesar Limones, Leonel Estrada, Nimrod Vazquez, Luis Fernando Gaona-Cardenas, Hector Hidalgo, Hector Lopez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a pulse with modulation (PWM) strategy for a transformerless grid-connected inverter for photovoltaic (PV) systems based on two cascaded inverters. The cascaded inverter consists of two inverters, where the upper inverter is the T-type inverter (TT) and the lower inverter is the full bridge (FB). This inverter is called 7L-TT-FB. Disconnection of the transformer at the grid connection results cause leakage current to flow through the ground, which is hazardous. In order to minimize the effect of leakage current, the common mode voltage (CMV) is usually maintained to be constant at all modes of operation. In this paper, a different PWM strategy in the multilevel inverter is proposed to deal with the leakage current issue; no topology modifications were made and a traditional current controller. The proposal is based on the capacitor leakage voltage evolution. Numerical results that constitute the theoretical are presented.

title: Development of A Matlab Tool to Analyze Technical, Economic, Social, and Ecological Challenges in Second-Life Battery Applications
authors: Kheireddine Tekaya, Heiko Fechtner, Torben Wolkowski, Benedikt Schmuelling
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Electric vehicles are becoming increasingly important on the vehicle market and annual sales figures continue to rise. Due to the limited lifespan of the traction batteries in these vehicles, there will be a high volume of battery modules in the coming years that are at the end of their first life cycle and can either be recycled or repurposed for a second application. The aim of this work is to develop a tool that evaluates the usability of a retired battery module based on a limited amount of key data and taking into account technical, economic, social and ecological aspects. The data basis for the tool was developed using literature research and by conducting an online survey on brand awareness and popularity of the car manufacturers with the largest sales on the German market. The result of this work is a MATLAB tool that enables the user to evaluate a battery module in terms of technical, economic, ecological and social aspects based on a limited amount of technical data, the price, the car brand and the country in which the reprocessing into a second-life battery takes place. The user can individually prioritize the aspects to obtain an overall assessment of the battery module.

title: Implementation of the Personal Software Process (PSP) in Software Engineering Education: A Case Study
authors: Luis Ángel Rueda Díaz, Patricia Martínez Moreno, José Antonio Vergara Camacho, Gerardo Contreras Vega
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The Personal Software Process (PSP), developed by Watts Humphrey, is a methodology designed to improve individual performance in software development through disciplined planning, tracking, and analysis practices. This study implemented PSP in an academic setting to evaluate its impact on the productivity and quality of software developed by university students. The study was conducted in the Software Processes course, where 18 students applied PSP while individually developing an address book application. Standardized templates were used to record time per phase, defects introduced, defects removed, and other relevant metrics. This case study used a quantitative approach with a non-experimental, cross-sectional design. Analysis of the collected data revealed patterns in the effort invested, code quality, and individual productivity. The results indicate that applying PSP enabled students to gain greater control over their time, improve early defect detection, and reflect upon their work habits. The study concludes that integrating PSP into the classroom fosters the development of practical skills related to quality, self-regulation, and continuous improvement in software engineering performance.

title: ML-Aided Indoor Illumination Estimation for Supercapacitor-Based ZE-IoT with Photovoltaic Energy Harvesting
authors: Amila Perera, Marcos Katz
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Accurate estimation of indoor illumination is critical for sustaining the operation of battery-free Photovoltaic (PV) Energy-Harvesting (EH) based Zero-Energy Internet of Things (ZE-IoT) nodes. Most of these nodes rely on supercapacitors for energy storage, which offer high cycle life but exhibit low energy density compared to batteries. Consequently, the available runtime depends heavily on the limited optical power density typically found in indoor environments. Using dedicated optical sensors to monitor illumination increases node complexity, raises energy overhead, and is susceptible to noise. To address these challenges, this work proposes a novel Machine Learning (ML) approach that estimates indoor incident illumination on ZE-IoT nodes from supercapacitor voltage variations, thereby eliminating the need for dedicated illumination sensors. For concept evaluation, a Random Forest regressor with Leave-One-Out Cross-Validation (LOO-CV) is employed to infer optical power availability from the supercapacitor’s discharge behavior. Experimental validation using a ZE-IoT prototype based on the LIoT platform demonstrates an average estimation error of ±29.8 lux. By transferring illumination estimation to the network side, the proposed method reduces node complexity, supports energy-constrained operation, and enables proactive outage mitigation in sustainable ZE-IoT deployments.

title: Weather Forecast and Energy Prediction for Solar PV Optimization
authors: Yasmine Hany, Yasmine Zaghloul
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents an advanced machine learning model to enhance weather and energy forecasting while optimizing solar photovoltaic (PV) system performance. The proposed framework focuses on three objectives: improving weather prediction accuracy, enhancing energy forecasting reliability, and maximizing solar PV efficiency through tilt angle optimization. A Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM)-based model was developed to predict key weather parameters, such as temperature, irradiance, and diffuse radiation, with systematic refinements using a Dynamic Error Correction Model (DECM) to minimize prediction errors. Energy forecasts were validated using the PVsyst simulation tool [4]. Additionally, a machine-learning-driven tilt angle optimization method was implemented to determine weekly angles that enhance energy efficiency. The results highlight significant improvements in prediction accuracy and system adaptability, with practical validations through extensive experiments. The model demonstrates strong performance in predicting key weather parameters for PV system optimization, with accurate forecasts of Global Horizontal Irradiance (GHI) and diffuse irradiance, achieving RMSSE values of 0.3365 and 0.4047, respectively. Temperature predictions showed moderate accuracy (RMSSE 0.6135), and the DECM further refined forecasts, significantly reducing GHI errors to 0.2065. This approach avoids the cost of fully automated tracking systems while significantly improving performance over a static annual tilt. Notably, it has been practically implemented in real life at the German University in Cairo (GUC) on a groundmounted PV model, demonstrating its effectiveness beyond simulations.

title: Enhancing Lightweight 2D Human Pose Estimation via Hierarchical Channel Attention (HCA)
authors: Dong Jiang, Meng Dai
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Lightweight human pose estimation often faces a trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency, especially in capturing both global skeleton structures and local joint details. To address this challenge, we propose a Hierarchical Channel Attention (HCA) module that models channel dependencies hierarchically by combining coarse-grained global channel selection with fine-grained local channel optimization. The module is lightweight, easily integrable, and enhances keypoint feature representation with minimal additional parameters and computational cost. Experimental results on the MPII dataset demonstrate that HCA improves PCK@0.5 by 1.46% on MobileNetV2 and 1.50% on ShuffleNetV2, outperforming existing lightweight attention mechanisms such as SE, CBAM, and ECA.

title: Acoustic Foundation Model-Based Vehicle Speed Classification in Real-World Environments
authors: Ivana Čavor, Slobodan Djukanović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Accurate, non-invasive traffic monitoring is increasingly important in urban environments. This paper explores the use of acoustic signals from roadside microphones for vehicle speed classification. We evaluate Whisper, a pretrained audio foundation model (AFM) fine-tuned on the public VS13 dataset, against a physics-inspired Modified attenuation (MA) baseline. Using leave-one-vehicle-out cross-validation across 10 km/h speed intervals (speed classes), both methods achieve nearly identical accuracy when a misclassification of one interval is tolerated: 94.68% (MA) and 94.63% (Whisper). These results indicate that AFMs can match physics-based baselines while requiring less feature engineering, positioning them as promising candidates for future acoustic traffic monitoring systems.

title: Power Transformer Design Optimization using Single and Multi-Objective Evolutionary Algorithms
authors: Ayyoub W. Al Hourani, Mohammad A. Abido, Mahmoud Kassas
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Power transformers are critical components of electric power systems and represent significant capital investments. In a competitive manufacturing environment, achieving optimal transformer designs that comply with IEEE standards while minimizing cost and maximizing performance is essential. This paper investigates the application of Evolutionary Algorithms (EAs) for power transformer design optimization, considering both single-objective and multiobjective constrained problems. A detailed transformer calculation model is developed and validated against industrystandard software, demonstrating high accuracy. The performance of several EAs, including the Genetic Algorithm (GA), Differential Evolution Algorithm (DEA), and Nondominated Sorting Genetic Algorithms (NSGA-II and NSGAIII), is comprehensively evaluated. Results indicate that multiobjective optimization provides superior trade-offs between cost and performance, offering a more balanced and effective design approach. The study confirms the potential of EAs in power transformer optimization and outlines future research directions, including hybrid methodologies integrating EAs with machine learning to enhance convergence and computational efficiency.

title: Imperceptibility and Robustness in GAN-Based Steganography Under Cover Image Degradations
authors: Uroš Krstić, Ana Gavrovska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) offer a powerful end-to-end framework for image steganography, fundamentally addressing the trade-off between visual imperceptibility and message robustness against real-world processing. This paper presents a GAN-based approach to image steganography that embeds secret messages as residuals. The architecture uses a Generator conditioned on noise and the message, coupled with a Discriminator to ensure imperceptibility and an Extractor to recover the message. This adversarial setup forces the Generator to produce visually realistic images while maintaining high message fidelity under various distortions such as JPEG compression or noise. The results highlight the potential of GAN-driven frameworks for secure image steganography and short message transmission, establishing a foundation for future data-hiding scenario comparisons in modern communication systems.

title: High-Gain DC–DC Conversion Topology for a Renewable Energy System
authors: Chirag Patel, Preeti Sharma, Siddharth Joshi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The Study presents an innovative DC-DC converter topology designed for renewable energy systems, delivering high voltage gain. The configuration combines a coupled inductor, a boost mechanism, and a voltage multiplier unit to enable substantial voltage step-up. The coupled inductor not only boosts voltage but also distributes the input current with an auxiliary inductor, reducing magnetic component losses. Furthermore, regenerative clamp circuits are incorporated to suppress voltage spikes across the switches during simultaneous switching events. A comprehensive theoretical analysis, including operational modes and steady-state performance, is provided. PSIM Simulation is used to verify the results.

title: Smart carbon dioxide biosensors based on chlorophyll, Folium apocyni herbal medicine, and Rhizoma polygonati sugar carbon dots
authors: Zhuldyz Omarova, Guldan Nazarbek, Omar Mirza, Ainur Shaimoldina, Yingqiu Xie
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study focuses on the role of chlorophyll, the Folium Apocyni herbal medicine, and Rhizoma polygonati sugar carbon dots in developing carbon dioxide biosensors. The experimental approach focuses on evaluating fluorescence intensity, phosphatase activity, and surface effects as potential detection mechanisms. The observed changes highlight their potential applicability in creating effective and reliable biosensors.

authors: John Cosmas, Kareem Ali, Adam Kapovits, Anastasius Gavras, Israel Koffman, Benjamin Azoulay, Emmanuel Plascencia, Kevin Acuna-Condori, Bastien Béchadergue, Barthélemy Cagneau, Luc Chassagne, Christos Tsokos, Efstathios Andrianopoulos, Christos Kouloumentas, Milan Milosevic, Fabio Caetano, Chris Roeloffzen

The intended use case is smart transportation of materials in Industry 4.0 factories.
