title: Robot Path Planning Method Based on an Improved TD3 Algorithm
authors: Lanfeng Zhou, Qingqi Cheng
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To address the lag in environmental perception and slow policy convergence commonly observed in traditional path planning algorithms for dynamic environments, this study proposes a hybrid reinforcement learning framework that integrates a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) with Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3). By constructing a spatiotemporal feature fusion network, the method achieves: (1) temporal modeling of dynamic obstacle motion patterns via a GRU module; (2) policy optimization under the TD3 framework using dual Q-networks; and (3) a hybrid training strategy based on prioritized experience replay. Simulation results in ROS Gazebo dynamic obstacle scenarios show that, compared to vanilla TD3, the proposed approach improves path smoothness by $\mathbf{1 0. 5 \%}$ and decreases collision rate by $\mathbf{2 5. 0 \%}$.

title: A Novel Measurement Framework for Sub-6 GHz Reflectarray and RIS Evaluation
authors: Emani N S S Anjana, Golla Srinikhil, Anand Mohandas
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: With the evolution of wireless communication, particularly 5G and the upcoming 6G networks, technologies like Reflect Arrays (RA) and Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) are gaining attention for improving signal quality, reducing interference, and optimizing spectrum usage. This paper presents novel test methodologies to evaluate RA and RIS performance, focusing on the sub-6 GHz frequency range. We introduce a systematic approach involving link budget calculations, far-field measurements, and noise floor assessments, applied in three testing environments: an anechoic chamber, open-air testing with narrowband FM, and a 5G network-in-a-box (NIB) setup. To ensure realistic benchmarking, our methodology compares RA/RIS systems against both a vacuum reference and a copper plate of the same size. While copper plates reflect signals without directional control, RA/RIS structures provide enhanced gain and beam-shaping capabilities. This comparative framework highlights the practical benefits of RA/RIS over passive reflectors, offering clearer insights into their true performance in real-world conditions.

title: The Raman Effect and its Application in Optical Amplifiers
authors: Slav Mitev, Hristo Stanev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: With the increase in bit rate and optical fiber length, there is a need for new methods for the regeneration and enhancement of the optical signal. One of the newest methods of this kind is associated with optical amplifiers based on nonlinear effects. In the late 20th and early 21st centuries, research and development of optical amplifiers based on stimulated Raman scattering has emerged. The configuration principles of amplifiers using stimulated Raman scattering are reviewed. The types of Raman amplifiers and their advantages and disadvantages in optical amplification are also presented.

title: Reducing Size Variability and Suppressing Leftover Feed in Sillago japonica Aquaculture Using a Feeding AI Trained in Simulation
authors: Ryu Irie, Hiroshi Ikeoka, Koichi Isawa
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Japan’s food security has become a national emergency issue, and the fisheries sector is no exception, facing serious challenges including labor shortages and declining catches due to factors such as global warming. As a solution, aquaculture technology for marine products is expected to play a crucial role. However, proper management and operation according to fish conditions and water quality are important, and particularly delicate handling is essential for feeding operations. This is because feeding has strong dependencies on critical factors for successful aquaculture, such as fish growth periods and water quality deterioration due to leftover feed. Many fish species are difficult to manage with simple timer-based feeding approaches, necessitating continuous human monitoring in many situations. Therefore, technological innovations are desired to enhance laborsaving and scalability. To address these issues, we developed an automatic feeding system for Sillago japonica aquaculture utilizing AI and IoT, comprising the following four processes: (A) image input via camera, (B) image recognition via supervised learning, (C) feeder control via reinforcement learning, and (D) feeding action via microcontroller. In particular, the control policy in (C) has been implemented through training in a dedicated aquaculture simulator. In this work, we redefined the reward design to suppress the occurrence of leftover feed in addition to conventional parameters, aiming not only to shorten the shipping period but also achieve labor-saving in water quality management. Simulation results demonstrate that our system effectively maintains fish growth while reducing size variability and suppressing leftover feed, indicating a viable path toward automated, labor-efficient aquaculture operations with improved water quality management. This study assumes an indoor, landbased aquaculture environment.

title: Feasibility Analysis for the use of Satellite Internet Through Solar Panels in Connectionless Communities
authors: Diego Leon Infanzon Mere, Juan Antonio Pinilla Rodríguez, José Adolfo Jiménez Solís, Sergio Roman Jara, Carlos Javier Gasca Caballero
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The Internet is a tool which, according to the United Nations, promotes the fulfillment of sustainable development goals (SDGs) by providing access to information that promotes education. However, it is not within the reach of all communities due to geographical impediments. To address this, technologies such as satellite internet helps provide access to places where wiring does not reach. Another technology that supports SDGs is solar energy obtained from photovoltaic panels as it provides non-polluting energy through its cells. This chapter explores the feasibility and performance of transmitting satellite internet through power lines powered by solar energy, utilizing Power Line Communication (PLC) technology to increase the number of users who have access to the Internet as well as giving nonpolluting energy. By leveraging existing electrical infrastructure, this approach aims to enhance digital connectivity while promoting the use of clean energy solutions.

title: Enhancing Power Distribution System Resilience Through Cyber-Attack Detection with Hankel Matrix Analysis
authors: Mohd Anas Khan, Mohd Shahrukh, Ranjana Sodhi, Tukesh Soni
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Ensuring a resilient system operation under extreme conditions such as cyber-attacks is crucial, particularly when Distributed Generators (DGs) rely on neighbors information exchange for frequency regulation, voltage restoration, and power sharing. To this end, a novel cyberattack detection scheme is proposed in this paper that enhances the resilience of secondary control systems against both, the node and the communication link attacks. The proposed detection method utilizes the Hankel matrix to identify a wide range of cyber-attacks, including step, ramp, and simultaneous multi-link intrusions, while effectively distinguishing them from natural disturbances like faults or load variations-significantly reducing false alarms. The effectiveness of the proposed detection scheme is validated through detailed simulations on a 4-DG AC microgrid system under various attack scenarios, demonstrating its superior accuracy in detecting and locating stealthy and complex attacks and provides a cost-effective, scalable solution that does not depend on network reconfiguration.

title: Application of 1D-Convolutional Neural Networks for Whispered Speech Recognition
authors: Branko R. Marković, Veljko Lončarević, Jovan Galić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation of 1DCNN for whispered speech recognition. At the front end, MFCCs were used to construct feature vectors, while the back end employed a 1D-CNN for training, validation, and testing. Speech patterns were taken from the Whi-Spe database, considering two speakers (one male and one female). Four types of feature vectors were examined through different scenarios: Normal/Normal, Whisper/Whisper, Normal/Whisper, and Whisper/Normal. The results confirm the effectiveness of 1DCNN for speech recognition.

title: Joint Learning of Graph Structure and Parametrized Graph Shift Operators
authors: Đorđe Borozan, Miloš Brajović, Isidora Stanković, Ljubiša Stanković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks extend deep learning to irregular data by leveraging graph structures, but their performance depends on the underlying graph and Graph Shift Operator. A framework is proposed that jointly learns the graph structure and Parametrized Graph Shift Operator, unifying operators such as adjacency and Laplacian matrices. By optimizing both topology and operator parameters, the model adapts to the task, achieving competitive performance on citation and real-world datasets compared to fixed-operator or fixed-structure approaches.

title: Exploiting Machine Learning for Industrial Defrost Cycle Characterization
authors: Tassadaq Nawaz, Anjuman Ara Kali, Omer Ali, John McLaughlin, Lizy Abraham
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Food loss and waste (FLW) exert considerable economic and environmental repercussions. The World Food Program (WFP) reports that 20 percent of edible food is wasted annually, equating to approximately 1 billion meals on average. The significant economic repercussions of FLW amount to nearly 1 trillion dollars each year. Moreover, 10 percent of total greenhouse gas emissions result from food loss, which is nearly five times greater than the emissions produced by the aviation industry. The European Union (EU) established stringent objectives to substantially decrease food loss and waste (FLW) by 2030 and achieve net-zero emissions by 2050. To achieve these objectives, one specific area where food loss and waste (FLW) totals 620 million metric tons is within the food cold chain sector alone. A considerable portion of food loss in this sector is attributed to outdated infrastructure and a lack of technological resources, resulting in inadequate defrosting and subsequent food waste. This article introduces the machine-learning based approaches to characterize the industrial defrost cycle that will help in mitigation of food wastage by enabling timely intervention and necessary actions. Two defrost classification frameworks, Window-based and Cycle-based, are proposed in this paper. The machine-learning models, such as SVM, KNN, RF, and NB, are trained either on real-time sensors data or on features extracted from the real data. The results show that classification accuracies of 0.97 and 1 are achieved for the Window-based framework and the Cycle-based framework, respectively.

title: AVATAR : An Automated Validation And Test Architecture And Platform For Emerging Radio Access Networks
authors: Murali P V, Charan Sureddi, Sai Charan Chakali, Anish Kumar Bharti, Nagoor Vali Sayyad, Jibin Tom, Pruthviraj R, Neha Hullikuppi, Tanvi Bhandari, Sivadas M P, Satish Kumar S, Binu Paul, Rajesh Khanna J G V, Bhaskara Rao S, Dilip Krishnaswamy
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a transformative automated testing framework integrated with a web platform, enabling real-time testing and validation for advanced telecommunication systems, spanning xG networks (4G, 5G, 6G), telecom hardware (switches, routers), and software applications like Network Management Systems (NMS) and Element Management Systems (EMS). Anchored by a high-speed communication layer, it ensures low-latency, bidirectional data exchange, while a dynamic web-based interface empowers intuitive test case management with animated visualizations. A custom automation framework executes tests across diverse ecosystems, enhanced with AI-driven capabilities such as automated root cause analysis, intelligent test prioritization, and natural language orchestration. It excels in validating Open RAN, network slicing, AAA protocols, and 5G/6G security, generating ORAN-compliant reports for interoperability. Supporting end-to-end and subsystem testing, it delivers real-time monitoring, rich visualizations, and adaptability across wired, wireless, and software-driven domains, advancing intelligent network management and zero-touch automation, thus setting a benchmark for next-generation telecom systems.

title: Bayesian-Optimized Hybrid Deep Learning and Machine Learning Frameworks for Wind Power Forecasting
authors: Abdul Haseeb, Ammar Arshad, Attique Ur Rehman, Muhammad Mansoor Ashraf, Ghulam Amjad Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Accurate short-term and medium-term wind power forecasting (WPF) is essential for the stable and reliable integration of wind energy into modern power systems. While artificial intelligence (AI) has improved forecasting accuracy, the potential of Bayesian-optimized hybrid deep learning (DL) and machine learning (ML) models for WPF remains underexplored. This study introduces a novel approach that combines hybrid DL architectures with ML models, optimized using Bayesian Optimization (BO), to enhance prediction performance. The proposed framework integrates Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), and Residual Networks (ResNet) into a BO-CNN-ResNet-LSTM framework, capturing both spatial and temporal patterns. Alongside, traditional ML models are also optimized for comparison. The methodology is tested using historical wind power data from Pakistan for day-ahead and week-ahead forecasts. Results show that under limited data availability, the Bayesian-optimized Random Forest (BORF) model outperforms the hybrid DL model. For example, in Gul Ahmad WPP, BO-RF achieves a Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) of 0.0036 % for day-ahead forecasting, compared to 0.0874 % for the hybrid DL model. This suggests that ML models work better with smaller datasets due to their efficiency, while hybrid DL models excel with larger datasets by leveraging deep feature extraction. This study establishes a data-adaptive framework where ML is preferred for small datasets, and hybrid DL is more effective in data-rich environments, improving WPF reliability and supporting the smooth integration of wind energy into power grids.

title: Joint Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning and Message-Passing for Resilient Multi-UAV Networks
authors: Yeryeong Cho, Sungwon Yi, Soohyun Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management
abstract: This paper introduces a novel resilient algorithm designed for distributed unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in dynamic and unreliable network environments. Initially, the UAVs should be trained via multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) for autonomous mission-critical operations and are fundamentally grounded by centralized training and decentralized execution (CTDE) using a centralized MARL server. In this situation, it is crucial to consider the case where several UAVs cannot receive CTDE-based MARL learning parameters for resilient operations in unreliable network conditions. To tackle this issue, a communication graph is used where its edges are established when two UAVs/nodes are communicable. Then, the edge-connected UAVs can share their training data if one of the UAVs cannot be connected to the CTDE-based MARL server under unreliable network conditions. Additionally, the edge cost considers power efficiency. Based on this given communication graph, message-passing is used for electing the UAVs that can provide their MARL learning parameters to their edge-connected peers. Lastly, performance evaluations demonstrate the superiority of our proposed algorithm in terms of power efficiency and resilient UAV task management, outperforming existing benchmark algorithms.

title: FSLog: Adversarial Margin for Cross-System Few-Shot Log Anomaly Detection
authors: Jiyu Tian, Mingchu Li, Jianyuan Gan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Log-based anomaly detection (LAD) is imperative to ensure both the reliability and security of software systems. Although many deep learning approaches have been designed to capture complex and diverse anomaly patterns from log files, they heavily rely on large-scale annotated data. However, collecting sufficient labeled data is impractical when a software system has just been deployed. In this paper, we propose a cross-system few-shot learning log-based anomaly detection approach, namely FSLog, to solve the abnormal label scarcity problem, which is the main challenge of recent LAD research. Specifically, we leverage a pre-trained model from source system to enrich feature representations so that data instances from target system can also be effectively represented. To this end, we introduce a novel adversarial margin loss to enhance our feature distinguishability while preserving their generalizability. Further, we also develop a masked interactive temporal network for robust feature extraction of temporal relationships for log samples. We evaluate the proposed FSLog on three publicly available datasets based on a standard few-shot learning setup protocol. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves the best performance in detecting abnormal logs when compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Statistically Feasible Robust Scheduling of Harbour EH-VPP Considering Photovoltaic and Hydrogen Demand Uncertainties
authors: Yingjun Wu, Jiangfan Yuan, Zhengxi Yin, Xueyan He, Jiayan Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industry Applications
abstract: Electric-hydrogen coupled virtual power plants (EH-VPPs) have emerged as a promising solution to enhance energy flexibility and economy in harbors by aggregating distributed energy and hydrogen systems. However, scheduling becomes challenging due to the uncertainty of ship hydrogen demand under varying navigation environments. This paper proposes a robust scheduling method for EH-VPPs that jointly considers PV output errors and navigation-induced hydrogen demand uncertainty. A hydrogen demand estimation model is developed based on environmental factors, including wave height and wind speed. To address the difficulty in obtaining accurate data distributions, a robust uncertainty model is formulated, and a statistically feasible chance-constrained framework is introduced to describe the impact of State Of Hydrogen and State Of Charge constraints. A robust optimization model integrating statistical feasibility is then established. Case studies demonstrate that the proposed method increases profits by ​​13.8%​​ compared to conventional robust optimisation method, and the violation probability of hydrogen and charge constraints is maintained below ​​5%​​, while violation rate is 0, under the conventional robust optimisation method, which is overly conservative.

title: Teaching Inverse Matrices through Matrix Cryptography and COIL: A Binational Qualitative Study Aligned with SDG 4
authors: Gerardo Rocha Feregrino, Pilar Alejandra Carrasco Espinoza
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This qualitative case study examines a binational Collaborative Online International Learning (COIL) activity that uses matrix cryptography to teach matrix inversion and connect linear algebra with SDG 4 (Quality Education). Forty undergraduate students from Mexico and Chile worked in mixed teams to decrypt a message encoded with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 10$</tex> matrix using Python/MATLAB/Excel. They then linked the decrypted content to SDG 4 targets and proposed feasible on-campus actions. Data sources included team reports, recorded presentations, and individual reflections. An inductive, reflexive thematic analysissupported by Atlas.ti-identified three interrelated dimensions: (i) technical (procedural autonomy, cross-tool validation, and understanding of invertibility conditions), (ii) pedagogical (meaningful learning under the SDG 4 framing), and (iii) emotional-collaborative (motivation, intercultural communication, and sense of purpose). We present qualitative indications of conceptual understanding of invertibility, based on textual evidence of diagnosis and justification in student artifacts; however, no objective pre/post tests were administered. We discuss design implications for STEM courses and propose a replicable rubric for post hoc conceptual evaluation.

title: Virtual Laboratories Assisted by AI with Intelligent Feedback for Sustainable Engineering: A Quasiexperimental Evaluation in Agricultural Irrigation
authors: Adrian Isrrael tec Chim, Jose M. Nieto-Jalil, David I. Ibarra-Zarate, Jorge Alvarez, Ulises Ojeda
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Limited access to physical laboratories in engineering hinders equity, experimental repeatability, and the connection with real-world challenges. This study evaluates the integration of virtual laboratories assisted by Generative AI with intelligent feedback to enhance practical teaching in the course Physical Experimentation and Statistical Thinking, through an authentic challenge: designing a sustainable agricultural irrigation system using a Mariotte Bottle. A quasi-experimental design with a mixed-methods approach was implemented with 93 students (control group <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=47$</tex> with physical practice; experimental group <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=46$</tex> with physical practice plus simulations). Instruments included pre/post-tests, validated Likert surveys <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\alpha>0.85)$</tex>, standardized rubrics, and qualitative analysis of reflections. Statistical analysis (t-test, ANOVA, correlations, and effect sizes; power <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>0.80$</tex>) showed significant advantages for the experimental group in conceptual retention, motivation, and consistency in problem-solving. The normalized gain was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g}=0.67$</tex> compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{g}=0.34(\mathrm{p}<0.05)$</tex>. Reflections explicitly linked learning outcomes with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 2, 4, 6, 9, 12, and 13, emphasizing ethical and social dimensions. Overall, the findings indicate that AI-assisted virtual laboratories complement rather than replace physical practice, providing a replicable, scalable, and ethically grounded model for STEM innovation in higher education.

title: Comparison of 60 GHz and 80 GHz Vehicle-to-Vehicle Channels Using Delay and Doppler Characteristics
authors: Ales Prokes, Tomas Mikulasek, Josef Vychodil, Radek Zavorka, Jiri Blumenstein, Jaroslaw Wojtun, Jan M. Kelner, Cezary Ziolkowski, Aniruddha Chandra
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The aim of this paper is to provide a comparison of channel characteristics for vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) communication at 60 GHz and 80 GHz frequency bands in a high-mobility scenario where two vehicles pass each other in opposite directions. The study is based on measurements of the time-varying channel impulse response capturing the behavior of multi-path propagation during vehicle motion. By directly comparing these two frequency bands under identical measurement conditions, we attempt to quantify the differences in power delay profile, root mean square (RMS) delay spread, RMS Doppler spread, and intervals (regions) of stationarity in time domain. The results show that these bands do not differ significantly, but the 80 GHz band exhibits somewhat greater RMS delay spread and RMS Doppler spread when calculated over the entire delay-Doppler spectrum, and conversely exhibits shorter stationarity regions. However, the characteristics of the measurement setup in the two bands and their influence on comparative measurements must be considered. In particular, attention must be paid to the impact of antennas.

title: High stability Electro - Optic modulator Bias Controller for Photonic based high speed QPSK Communication Systems
authors: Meena D, Vidyamol S, Preenu Acha Prasad, Vishal Sundar M, Hariesh P
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The recent advancements in communication systems demand advanced modulation schemes to accomplish high speed data links with improved spectral efficiency. Optical modulation techniques are increasingly preferred due to its higher bandwidth and ultra-low loss transmission terabit link capabilities. These systems depend on Single Sideband (SSB), Quadrature Phase Shift Keying (QPSK), Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (QAM) and Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) schemes. These optical systems are highly dependent on Electro-Optical modulator based configurations with a critical requirement of operating it with high stability. The bias point of the modulator plays a pivotal role in defining its modulation characteristics for optimal performance. Conventional bias controllers are designed for specific requirements, often expensive and lacks flexibility for multi-format operation. In this work, we propose a low-cost, reconfigurable bias controller with comparatively less set up time for modulator configurations that is further extended for usage in optical QPSK communication applications. The paper includes various results obtained during the performance evaluation. The controller’s embedded program can be modified to adapt with different modulation formats without hardware-level changes. Experimental validation demonstrates the effectiveness of these modulators with stable operations having minimal drift.

title: Fast and Energy Efficient Cell Selection for N2L Handover in DSS
authors: Goutham L, Prem Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Dynamic spectrum sharing (DSS) enables the co-existence of fourth-generation Long-Term Evolution (4G-LTE) and fifth-generation New Radio (5G-NR) systems within the same frequency band, supporting efficient spectrum utilization. We propose a low-latency 4G-LTE cell selection technique for user equipment (UE) transitioning from NR to LTE (N2L) within a DSS deployment. Our proposed method leverages prior knowledge of 4G-LTE cell information shared through 5G-NR signaling, allowing the UE to skip the primary synchronization signal (PSS) and secondary synchronization signal (SSS) detection phases and directly initiate master information block (MIB) decoding. This targeted optimization significantly reduces the processing latency and associated energy consumption. Simulation result demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme, showing significant reductions in cell selection time and improved power efficiency compared to the existing procedures.

title: Multi-node Implementation for an IoT-based Outdoor Noise Monitoring System
authors: Wesley Angelo O. Lim, Ernest Angelo D. Valencia, Jan Angelo R. Viaña, John Richard Hizon, Marc Rosales, Paul Jason Co
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Noise is the unwanted sound emitted from daily human activities that can cause harmful health effects from prolonged exposure. Existing noise monitoring solutions are limited by the type of data they collect and the number of edge devices being deployed. This restricts the potential applications that could be developed in conjunction with the collected noise data. The developed monitoring system measured the continuous equivalent A-weighted sound pressure level (L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Aeq</inf>) for noise level quantification, and the Mel-frequency Cepstrum Coefficients (MFCC) were extracted to enhance the system’s analyzing capabilities for further in-depth studies such as noise classification. Four sensor nodes were deployed, each comprised of an INMP441 microphone, a Teensy 4.1 for EDGE computing, and an ESP32 for Wi-Fi communication. Overall, the system exhibited reliable L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Aeq</inf> measurements with an average error of 0.62 dBA when compared to a PAA3x audio analyzer and an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> value of 0.9977, corresponding to a strong linear response. The MFCC computation achieved acceptable accuracy with efficient runtime despite hardware constraints. The system was successfully deployed using Wi-Fi in two outdoor locations with varying noise levels and Wi-Fi signal strengths, with payload transmission success rates ranging from 90% to 94%.

title: Myoelectrically-Controlled Functional Electrical Stimulation System (Myo-FES) with Integrated Flex Sensor for Home-Based Stroke Rehabilitation and Functional Recovery Monitoring : A Proof-of-Concept Study
authors: Matteo Saibene, Muhammad Ahmed Khan, Cihan Uyanik, Sadasivan Puthusserypady
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Stroke is a leading cause of death worldwide and a major contributor to acquired disability. Survivors often endure motor impairments and cognitive deficits, significantly impacting their quality of life. Numerous technologies have been developed to help stroke survivors regain motor functions and perform Activities of Daily Living (ADLs). Out of these, Functional Electrical Stimulation (FES) has shown great promise as an effective neurorehabilitation treatment, assisting post-stroke patients in regaining functional mobility. In this work, we have developed a novel Myoelectrically Controlled FES (Myo-FES) system with closed-loop feedback for home-based upper-limb stroke rehabilitation. The Myo FES system integrates Electromyography (EMG) and flex sensor (FS) to deliver adaptive FES stimulation based on voluntary muscle activation while simultaneously tracking rehabilitation progress. A pilot study conducted on three subjects demonstrated the system’s functionality and highlighted its potential application for upperlimb stroke rehabilitation.

title: Quantifying proficiency of sport motions with smartphone’s gyroscope and accelerometer
authors: Eugene B. Postnikov, Igor E. Anpilogov, Anastasia I. Lavrova, Nicolas H. Kruchynsky, Maxim V. Vorobiev
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: We consider an approach to quantifying details of motions in sports training, exemplified by rowing and fencing. To get time series, we used the data recorded using a smartphone MEMS gyroscope (for rowing) and accelerometer (for fencing). The high temporal resolution of the recorded data allows for characterising in detail the non-stationary wavelet-spectral content and instantaneous stochasticity of executed motions, which characterise the skills formed. The principal component analysis (PCA) of the set of such parameters allows for distinguishing between a sportsman’s proficiency and has advantages over the analysis of video records of the same motions.

title: Transistor Assisted Sen Transformer Unified Power Flow Controller and Sen Transformer Comparison in Realization of the Optimal Power Flow with the Objective of Generation Cost Reduction
authors: Salah Eldeen Gasim Mohamed Hassan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Optimal power flow (OPF) analysis is regularly carried out in power systems. It may be restricted by reaching transmission lines capacity, that can be freed-up with use of power flow controllers (PFCs). This paper techno-economically compares the transistor assisted Sen transformer (TAST), unified power flow controller (UPFC), and Sen transformer (ST) in realization of the OPF with the objective to reduce the generation cost in a modified IEEE-30 bus system. OPF analysis is performed in the base case using MATPOWER and two lines are found loaded fully restricting further dispatch of low-costing generation. Two TASTs, two STs, and two UPFCs are integrated interchangeably to free-up capacity of these lines. The results demonstrate that the least overall generation and PFCs cost is achievable with the TASTs. In the considered test system, the TASTs assure USD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$42,365.7$</tex> and USD <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$92,723.7$</tex> overall annual savings as compared to use of STs and UPFCs, respectively.

title: The April 28 Iberian Blackout: Technical Insights From Official Sources Available in June 2025
authors: Dubravko Sabolić, Igor Ivanković, Zoran Bunčec, Srđan Skok
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: On April 28, 2025, the Iberian Peninsula experienced one of the most extensive blackouts in European history, affecting nearly all of mainland Spain and Portugal. This paper provides a structured technical synthesis of the event based solely on official documents and institutional communications available as of June 2025, including reports by the Spanish Government, Red Eléctrica (the national transmission system operator), ENTSO-E public updates, and selected expert commentary. At the time of writing, formal root-cause investigations are still ongoing, and final conclusions may evolve. However, the information currently available indicates that the blackout was not caused by a single fault or cyberattack, but by a complex sequence involving voltage instability, insufficient dynamic reactive support, uncoordinated generator tripping, and systemic protection cascades. These events occurred under conditions of low demand and high instantaneous solar generation, which reduced system inertia and voltage controllability. The incident underscores the need for updated grid code enforcement, more granular visibility of distributed generation, enhanced dynamic voltage support mechanisms, and stronger contingency planning frameworks for low-inertia, inverter-dominated systems.

title: Time Series Forecasting Approach for Power Demand Prediction Based on Feature Engineering, Optuna-Based Hyperparameter Tuning, and Ensemble Learning
authors: Joud Almomani, Ghalia Nassreddine, Obada Al-Khatib, Rajesh Rajamoni Kala, Mohamad Nassereddine
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Power demand prediction is an essential task for an efficient energy management system, grid stability, and operational planning. This paper presents a novel method for time series forecasting that integrates advanced feature engineering, Optuna-based hyperparameter tuning techniques, and ensemble learning models. First, data is collected and preprocessed. Then, a feature engineering step is performed to create time series variables, lag features, and rolling window statistics. The created variables are used to detect seasonality, temporal dependencies, and consumption trends. The Optuna technique is employed to tune the parameters of three ensemble learning models: CatBoost, LightGBM, and XGBoost. These models are trained and tested using a real-world power consumption dataset. The performance is computed based on a time-series cross-validation method. The results indicate that the CatBoost model, with optimal parameters, outperforms other models by reaching the highest <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> score of 0.9987 and the lowest error metrics (mean absolute percentage error of 0.50%). This study validates the effectiveness of the proposed methodology that incorporates advanced feature selection and model optimization to generate highly precise predictions.

title: Quantifying Diagnostic Uncertainty in EEG-Based Dementia Classification Using Conformal Prediction
authors: Shubham Singh, Pedro G. Lind, Anis Yazidi, Rabindra Khadka
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Early and accurate differentiation between Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) and dementia is crucial in clinical practice: MCI represents a critical window where interventions ranging from lifestyle modifications and cognitive training to enrollment in disease-modifying trials can meaningfully slow or even halt progression. Misclassifying MCI as dementia risks exposing patients to unnecessary pharmacological treatments and the psychosocial burdens of a dementia diagnosis, while overlooking early dementia delays essential support services and increases the likelihood of safety-critical complications. Deep learning models for EEG-based dementia classification have achieved high accuracy. However, these methods lack transparency and do not provide prediction reliability. To this end, we introduce CP-EEGViT, a transformer-based framework that integrates conformal prediction (CP) to produce calibrated, uncertaintyaware prediction sets. We adapt a DINO-pretrained Vision Transformer to 3D EEG inputs via a novel spatiotemporal patch embedding and weight inflation technique, and evaluate two conformal methods, namely Split Conformal Prediction and Adaptive Log Conformal Prediction(ALCP), on a publicly available EEG dataset from Chung-Ang University Hospital, South Korea. At a 80% confidence level, margin-based conformal prediction reduces critical misclassifications from $\mathbf{4 5. 2 \%}$ (without CP) to 6.5% and defers 77.8% of ambiguous samples for expert review. The adaptive log-conformal approach yields more efficient singleton predictions (56.9%) with a false-negative rate of 22.6%. Our CP-EEGViT model also converges faster and outperforms non-pretrained baselines under limited data conditions. Integrating the adaptive log conformal prediction method within an EEG-based dementia, MCI decision system can enhance interpretability by providing calibrated prediction sets and coverage guarantees to every decision, while simultaneously safeguarding patient care by flagging low-confidence cases for expert review in safety-critical settings.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp8-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Optimized Scheduling and Resource Allocation in 4G/5G Carrier Aggregation Network Deployments
authors: Uroš Savković, Igor Tomić, Nataša Nešković, Aleksandar Nešković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates advanced scheduling strategies for carrier aggregation (CA) in LTE/5G networks, with a focus on improving resource allocation and user experience. Among conventional approaches, normalized scheduling with a unit weight factor emerges as a balanced solution, enabling more efficient utilization of spectrum while preserving fairness across users. The evaluation was carried out through controlled drive test campaigns in a mature multi-band LTE network, using a consistent methodology that yields results directly applicable to operator-grade benchmarking. Results demonstrate a significant increase in higher-order CA activations and measurable throughput gains, with average Physical Downlink Shared Channel (PDSCH) and File Transfer Protocol (FTP) rates improving by more than 16% compared to the baseline. These findings confirm that CA optimization provides both technical gains and a dependable basis for operator and regulatory performance evaluations.

title: Half-Power Beamwidth Evaluation of Uniform Linear Arrays in Multi-User MIMO Systems
authors: Ioana-Adriana Manea, Cristina-Maria Andras, Florin Alexa
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The evolution of 5G technology, which promises higher data rates, ultra-low latency, and massive device connectivity, represents a key point in the advancement of wireless communication. Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) technology is a crucial facilitator of these developments, as it employs multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver ends to enhance spectral efficiency and link reliability. This paper investigates the influence of antenna configurations by analyzing radiation patterns generated in MATLAB. Simulations assume half-wavelength spacing and uniform linear array (ULA). Results indicate that increasing the number of antennas increases directional gain, narrows the main lobe, and improves angular resolution. These changes are reflected in the half-power beamwidth (HPBW), which is a key parameter in antennas characteristics. A narrower HPBW signifies enhanced directivity and spatial resolution, which are critical features for 5G networks and future wireless communication systems.

title: Influence of RTV Coating Thickness on Electric Field Intensity Values in the Vicinity of Overhead Transmission Line Conductors
authors: Adnan Mujezinović, Ajdin Alihodžić, Maja Muftić Dedović, Maja Grbić, Aleksandar Pavlović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The aim of the paper is to investigate the influence of the RTV silicon coating thickness on the electric field intensity values on the surface of high-voltage overhead transmission line conductors. For this study, the mathematical model based on the Charge Simulation Method (CSM) was used. The analysis are performed for the case of 400 kV overhead transmission line. The electric field intensity is calculated over the circumference and in the immediate vicinity of the conductors. The obtained results show that increasing the thickness of the RTV coating has a strong influence on reducing electric field intensity values on the conductor surface and in its immediate vicinity. Furthermore, increasing the thickness of the RTV coating decreases the electric field intensity gradient in the vicinity of the conductor and consequently decreases the probability of the stationary AC corona occurrence.

title: AI-Driven Real-Time Detection and Mitigation of Cyber-Intrusions in Grid-Forming Inverters
authors: Uzair Asif, Reza Behnam, Mohammad B. Shadmand
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a decentralized strategy to detect and mitigate coordinated false data injection (FDI) cyber-attacks that impact the optimum power flow in a grid-forming inverters (GFMIs) network. A data-driven coordinated cyber-attack is injected on the adaptive load sharing commands (ALSC) and output voltage measurements in the communication line between the supervisory and primary controllers. To detect and mitigate such intrusions, a decentralized long short-term memory (LSTM) is proposed for each GFMI that predicts the ALSC based on the time series data of measured active power, frequency, and rate of change of frequency (ROCOF). The training dataset is developed during normal disturbances like step load changes of the network, which enables accurate detection of the ALSC deviation for each GFMI and identifies the anomalies in the communication line. Moreover, it minimizes the dependency on the centralized supervisory controller and the associated communication infrastructure. The effectiveness and robustness of the proposed strategy are validated on a modified 9-bus IEEE system with multiple GFMI.

title: Optimization of IT Services Using Cloud Platforms with AI-Based Intelligent Resource Management
authors: Saračević Kenan, Tanović Anel
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper explores the application of machine learning techniques to optimize IT service reliability in cloud computing environments. A real-world dataset containing execution details of service workloads, such as resource requests, scheduling parameters, and success or failure outcomes, was analyzed. The XGBoost classifier was employed as the core predictive model, supported by hyperparameter tuning and strategies to address class imbalance within the dataset. Model performance was evaluated using standard classification metrics, including accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Additionally, the impact of decision threshold adjustments was examined, along with an analysis of false positive and false negative predictions to better understand model behavior. The results demonstrate the potential of machine learning to proactively detect service failures and contribute to intelligent resource management in dynamic cloud environments.

title: Decarbonization of Cement Sector: A MACC Analysis with Few Insights from the UAE
authors: Tanay Das, Sarthak Mazumder, Sherin S Das, Sonam Mittal, Ashu Verma
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The cement industry is a cornerstone of the rapidly growing infrastructure of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and a significant contributor to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. This work presents a pioneering assessment of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> mitigation pathways for the UAE cement sector using a bottom-up Marginal Abatement Cost Curve (MACC) analysis. This study evaluates a portfolio of 10 distinct technologies across four primary decarbonization pathways: carbon capture (CC), alternative binders, alternative fuels, and energy efficiency. The findings reveal that adoption of belite clinkers, excess heat recovery, and the switch to alternative fuels offer negative abatement costs, indicating they are economically profitable under current conditions. In contrast, technologies such as CC, multistage preheaters, and the adoption of Calcium Sulphoaluminate (CSA) entail significant positive costs, necessitating policy support. This study provides a technology-based MACC analysis and a phased policy roadmap to support the UAE's Net Zero 2050 goal.

title: Design and Evaluation of an Autonomous Vehicle-to-Vehicle Wireless Charging System
authors: Shahad Elshehaby, Noora Almheiri, Reham Ahmed, Mina Saad, Husameldin Mukhtar, Rida Gadhafi, Sabina Abdul Hadi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The design, implementation, and assessment of an autonomous WiBotic vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V) wireless charging system are presented in this paper. By enabling mobile wireless energy transfer between EVs, the solution overcomes one of the main drawbacks of permanent charging infrastructure. As a mobile power donor, a Magni Silver mobile robot with a WiBotic wireless charging kit autonomously finds its way to vehicles with low battery levels. Charging requests are coordinated by a central dispatch system. The effects of coil distance, ferrite material utilization, and battery state-of-charge (SoC) on charging efficiency are demonstrated experimentally, with peak efficiencies exceeding 80% under ideal circumstances. The results show that ferrite tiles greatly improve performance at longer ranges, and wireless power transfer works best at low SoC levels and at 20–50 mm coil separations. To guarantee successful deployment, the system also incorporates real-time mapping and robot operating system (ROS)-based autonomous navigation. With potential usage in fleet operations, smart campuses, and future EV ecosystems, this study offers a scalable and infrastructure-independent approach to EV energy replenishment.

title: CBPF: Efficient Packet Filtering Algorithm using Cascading Bloom Filter in Software Defined Networks
authors: Vignesh S, Akhil M Reji, Erukala Charan Teja, Harish SA, Vidya Sagar Thalapala, Koppala Guravaiah
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Communication networks must now meet new demands from the changing world of network applications, which call for improved performance, dependability, and flexibility. Programmable data planes provide the potential for adaptive network re-configurations in order to satisfy these requirements. However, maintaining consistency throughout these reconfigurations is a major challenge. A useful state management system is proposed to automate the adaptive data plane state management with the support of P4 makes it quickly identify network states, which is essential for data plane re-configurations. In addition, proposing a novel data structure for session management using Cascading Bloom filter in the data plane primitive, with application scope extending into in-network data plane monitoring. The proposed approach with Cascading Bloom filter proves to be efficient and can be a possible replacement for existing filtering algorithms and other use cases which include storing and retrieval of session-specific telemetry with minimal loss of information.

title: Real World Traffic Simulators’ Integration with Network Simulator for Evaluating 5G and beyond V2X Networks
authors: Nadine Hasan, Abhinav Kumar, Kotaro Kataoka, Digvijay S. Pawar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Network simulators (NS), such as NS-3, offer a cost-effective solution for testing variable-scale communication networks and validating their deployment. NS-3 provides a suitable platform for testing real world Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) networks. However, the existing Mobility Models in NS-3 are deterministic and insufficient for real-world traffic network simulation, limiting the generation to small vehicle densities. There exist traffic simulators, such as the Simulator for Urban Mobility (SUMO) and Verkehr In Städten-SIMulationsmodell (VISSIM), that can provide various traffic engineering applications, and real world traffic data essential for testing V2X networks. To enable real world V2X network simulation in NS-3, an Application Programming Interface (API) is required to convert real traffic data to an NS-3 compatible data format. This paper designs and presents an API for integrating traffic data from SUMO and VISSIM into the NS-3 data format that can aid in future real V2X tests and implementations. Detailed simulation results present the efficacy of the proposed API in converting real-world traffic data through the successful compilation of NS-3, forming a platform for testing real world 5G and beyond V2X networks.

title: Effectiveness of Eye Shields During Kendo Strikes
authors: Satori Iwamoto, Suguru Shin, Megan Hsu, Gary Chu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study evaluated the effectiveness of face shields in protecting the eyes from splinters generated during standard kendo head strikes. A shinai was coated with red paint to simulate splinter dispersion and used to strike a kendo dummy. Results showed that the dummy equipped with a face shield exhibited no paint marks in the eye region, indicating effective protection. In contrast, the dummy without a face shield sustained direct impact to the left eye area. These findings demonstrate that face shields provide effective protection against potential eye injuries during kendo practice.

title: Causal Behaviour Models for Network Digital Twin in Autonomous Networks
authors: Devanathan Ramachandran Seetharaman, Ranjith Sampath Kumar, Abid Ahmed Salem, M.J. Prasath
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Network Digital Twin (NDT) is a real-time virtual representation of a telecommunications network, replicating the behaviour of the physical network. NDT is the considered to be the key enabler of the zero-touch networks to validate the configurations and policies before implementing in the actual network. For building an NDT, data-driven behaviour modelling is challenging due to the limited historical configurations changes done in the real network. We propose a method of building an NDT as a collection of causal behaviour models, replicating a specific aspect of the network. Our approach enables gradual scaling of the NDT by adding new causal behaviour models dynamically when enough observational data is available for each network configuration.
