title: Implicit Neural Compression of Point Clouds_supp1-3648141.pdf
authors: Qianqian Yang
publish: N/A
abstract: Point clouds have gained prominence across numerous applications due to their ability to accurately represent 3D objects and scenes. However, efficiently compressing unstructured, high-precision point cloud data remains a significant challenge. In this paper, we propose NeRC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, a novel point cloud compression framework that leverages implicit neural representations (INRs) to encode both geometry and attributes of dense point clouds. Our approach employs two coordinate-based neural networks: one maps spatial coordinates to voxel occupancy, while the other maps occupied voxels to their attributes, thereby implicitly representing the geometry and attributes of a voxelized point cloud. The encoder quantizes and compresses network parameters alongside auxiliary information required for reconstruction, while the decoder reconstructs the original point cloud by inputting voxel coordinates into the neural networks. Furthermore, we extend our method to dynamic point cloud compression through techniques that reduce temporal redundancy, including a 4D spatio-temporal representation termed 4D-NeRC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. Experimental results validate the effectiveness of our approach: For static point clouds, NeRC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> outperforms octree-based G-PCC standard and existing INR-based methods. For dynamic point clouds, 4D-NeRC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> achieves superior geometry compression performance compared to the latest G-PCC and V-PCC standards, while matching state-of-the-art learning-based methods. It also demonstrates competitive performance in joint geometry and attribute compression.

title: Learning Time-Varying Graph Signals via Koopman
authors: Sivaram Krishnan, Jinho Choi, Jihong Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal and Information Processing over Networks
abstract: A wide variety of real-world data, such as sea measurements, e.g., temperatures collected by distributed sensors and multiple unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) trajectories, can be naturally represented as graphs, often exhibiting non-Euclidean structures. These graph representations may evolve over time, forming time-varying graphs. Effectively modeling and analyzing such dynamic graph data is critical for tasks like predicting graph evolution and reconstructing missing graph data. In this paper, we propose a framework based on the Koopman autoencoder (KAE) to handle time-varying graph data. Specifically, we assume the existence of a hidden non-linear dynamical system, where the state vector corresponds to the graph embedding of the time varying graph signals. To capture the evolving graph structures, the graph data is first converted into a vector time series through graph embedding, representing the structural information in a finite-dimensional latent space. In this latent space, the KAE is applied to learn the underlying non-linear dynamics governing the temporal evolution of graph features, enabling both prediction and reconstruction tasks.

title: Dynamics of -Learning in Networked Stochastic Games_supp1-3641365.pdf
authors: Jinzhuo Liu
publish: N/A
abstract: Stochastic games form the foundational mathematical framework for describing multiagent interactions and underpin the theoretical foundations of multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) and optimal decision making. However, previous research has typically focused on either two-agent settings or large-scale well-mixed agent populations, where the considered interaction scenarios were far from realistic. In this article, we consider structured populations where agents can interact with immediate neighbors. By using the pair-approximation method, we develop a new dynamical model to describe the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Q$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-learning dynamics in stochastic games on regular graphs. Through comparisons with agent-based simulation results, we validate the accuracy of our dynamical model across various stochastic games, population structures, and algorithm parameters. Our research thus provides both qualitative and quantitative insights into the effects of state transition rules and graph topologies in population dynamics. In particular, we show that, under certain conditions, state transitions can significantly promote the evolution of cooperation in social dilemmas. We also explored the effects of agent degree on cooperation, and unlike previous findings, we show that this can have either positive or negative implications for cooperation depending on the transition rules.

title: Power-Grid Reactive-Aware Billing for EV Chargers
authors: Mehmet Emre Ciftcibasi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: With rising EV integration across Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) nations, harmonic-rich loads from chargers increasingly compromise grid power quality and billing fairness. Existing metering practices, primarily based on FFT and displacement power factor, often fail to capture harmonic distortion and non-orthogonal power interactions. In this paper, we propose an exact metering framework using the Arithmetic Tensor Transform (ATT), which resolves perharmonic real, reactive, and distortion powers without spectral leakage or loss of orthogonality. Unlike FFT-based estimations, ATT provides lossless, symbolic decomposition of power components, enabling precise, fair, and harmonics-aware billing, supporting fairer billing and improved compliance with IEEE 519 limits.

title: Lead Poisoning From Non-FDA Regulated Hemorrhoid Cream
authors: Megan Hsu, An-Phuc Ta, Hillary Chu, Alexis Leo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Lead poisoning poses a significant health risk, particularly in the context of unregulated herbal medicines. This case report details the death of a 59-year-old woman who succumbed to cerebral edema and encephalopathy following the use of a lead-contaminated herbal cream intended to treat hemorrhoids. The case underscores the dangers associated with unregulated herbal products, which may contain harmful substances such as heavy metals. Despite the perception that herbal remedies are safer and more affordable than conventional treatments, their natural appeal does not eliminate the risk of contamination. Many plants can accumulate metals from their environment, exacerbating the risk of lead exposure. This case underscores the urgent need for stricter regulations and oversight in the herbal medicine industry to prevent such health hazards. Implementing stronger regulatory measures are essential to ensure that all medicinal and cosmetic products are free from harmful contaminants and to safeguard public health against the significant risks associated with lead poisoning.

title: The Dominated Chromatic Number of Certain Ladder Graph
authors: Qiu Yu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Dominated coloring, as an integrated branch of domination and coloring theories in graph theory, holds significant application value in fields such as resource scheduling and node deployment. This paper focuses on the research of domination coloring theory and algorithms for three special ladder graphs, aiming to initiate the study on specific domination coloring of specific graphs. Firstly, this paper presents the definitions of three distinct yet highly related ladder graphs, deduces their domination chromatic numbers through theoretical analysis, and designs corresponding algorithms. It provides a theoretical basis and algorithmic reference for applications such as connected domination in other complex graphs.

title: Crack Segmentation with Covariate Shift Adaptation for Multi-Resolution Images
authors: Kazuma Nakata, Yusuke Fujita
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Crack detection on concrete surfaces is essential for maintaining the structural integrity of aging infrastructure. However, supervised deep learning models often suffer from performance degradation when the training and test data distributions differ. This paper addresses covariate shift caused by differences in image resolution-termed Multi-Resolution Adaptation (MRA)-by introducing a one-step framework for crack segmentation. The proposed method jointly trains a U-Net-based segmentation model and a lightweight importanceestimation model that assigns weights to training images according to their estimated likelihood of appearing in the test domain. The training in this method is done in one step, reducing effects of underfitting inherent in two-step approaches and only requires unlabeled images in target domains. Class Activation Mapping (CAM) is employed to visualize the regions contributing to importance estimation, revealing that resolution differences are captured mainly through background surface texture rather than crack structures. Experiments conducted on a public dataset with artificially generated multi-resolution images demonstrate that the proposed approach improves Intersection over Union (IoU), particularly when low-resolution images constitute as little as 1% of the training data. These results confirm that one-step covariate shift adaptation effectively enhances model robustness to multiresolution domain shifts while requiring only unlabeled target domain images.

title: Temporal Feature-Guided Latent Diffusion Network for Generating Future Low-Dose CT Images in Early Cancer Monitoring
authors: Kai-Ze Lei, Shuenn-Yuh Lee, Chun-Rong Huang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Early detection and monitoring of lung cancer progression is critical for improving early cancer diagnosis. In this work, we present a temporal feature-guided latent diffusion network (TFLD-Net) to generate future low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) images in the following years from two previous annual images. Our method integrates a temporal feature extractor to jointly capture global anatomical structures and localize the temporal changes in a compressed temporal latent space. A temporally conditional latent diffusion model is proposed to synthesize the future image in the latent space for early cancer monitoring. Experiments conducted on the NLST dataset demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms state-of-the-art generative models in both pixel-level fidelity and perceptual quality, achieving higher PSNR and SSIM, as well as lower FID and LPIPS scores. Qualitative results further confirm its ability to reconstruct subtle disease progression and maintain anatomical consistency, which are critical for clinical interpretation.

title: Reactive arthritis following enterococcus urinary tract infection : A rare clinical presentation and diagnostic considerations
authors: Yevgeniy Sazhnyev, Camille Ng, Gary Chu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Reactive arthritis (ReA) is a sterile inflammatory arthritis typically triggered by gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections, with common pathogens including Chlamydia trachomatis and Salmonella. Though rare, urinary tract infections (UTIs) caused by Enterococcus faecalis can also trigger ReA. Diagnosis is clinical, established through a recent infection history and characteristic joint involvement. We present a 61 -year-old female with a history of depression and ADHD, who was found in a state of self-neglect and diagnosed with failure to thrive. During hospitalization, she developed symptoms of a UTI, and urine culture grew Enterococcus faecalis. Patient’s symptoms subsequently evolved to include joint stiffness, ocular discharge, and nasal congestion, she was diagnosed with reactive arthritis, likely triggered by her prolonged UTI. The patient was treated and showed improvement throughout her admission. This case highlights the importance of considering reactive arthritis in patients with atypical infectious triggers such as Enterococcus faecalis UTI, especially in the context of prolonged catheterization and persistent infection. Early recognition and appropriate management can improve outcomes. Further research is needed to better characterize the spectrum of pathogens implicated in ReA and to optimize diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. ()

title: Multimodal Gesture and Speech-Based Interaction Interfaces for AI-Driven Mobile Robots in Smart Homes
authors: Wai Yie Leong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The integration of multimodal interfaces in AIdriven mobile robots within smart home environments has ushered in a new paradigm of human-robot interaction (HRI). As traditional input modalities fall short in delivering naturalistic and inclusive control experiences, gesture and speech-based systems have emerged as a promising solution for seamless, intuitive, and adaptive user engagement. This paper presents an exploration into the design, implementation, and evaluation of multimodal gesture and speech-based interaction systems tailored for autonomous mobile robots in residential settings. We propose a hybrid interaction architecture that fuses real-time computer vision with natural language processing (NLP) models, leveraging deep learning frameworks such as CNN-LSTM for gesture recognition and Transformer-based ASR models for contextual speech understanding. The results indicate a significant improvement in command accuracy (92.7%), response time (1.4s), and user satisfaction score (4.6/5), particularly under noisy and dynamic conditions. The study also uncovers challenges in co-articulation, gesture segmentation, and crossmodal error compensation. Our findings provide valuable insights into multimodal HRI interface co-design for AIintegrated domestic robotics, paving the way toward inclusive, adaptive, and context-aware smart home ecosystems.

title: An Arduino UNO-Based Open Hardware Gain-Adjustable Optical Power Meter
authors: Andreja Maksimović, Vladimir Ignjatijević
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Optical power meters (OPMs) are elementary devices, necessary in a wide variety of applications to determine the power of incident light. As an alternative to costly commercial devices, very efficient device designs were proposed in the literature. However, for most non-electrical engineers in research and education, these solutions are often complex to implement. To address this issue, we propose a simple open-hardware, cost-aware solution for an OPM built around the widely used Arduino UNO platform.

title: Resilient Autonomy: A Research Survey on Fault-Tolerance in Heterogeneous Architectures for Autonomous Vehicles
authors: Suad Nesimi, Ervin Domazet
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Autonomous vehicles increasingly rely on heterogeneous computing architectures that integrate central processing units (CPUs), graphics processing units (GPUs), and field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) to manage perception, planning, and control in real time [5]. While these platforms—such as Tesla's Dojo, NVIDIA DRIVE, and Mobileye EyeQ—offer impressive advances in computational efficiency, energy management, and latency reduction, their approaches to fault tolerance remain less explored. Safety-critical systems require fault tolerance because any one piece of hardware or software could remove all trust in the system's reliability [1], [2]. This paper describes the types of heterogeneous architecture used in autonomous vehicles, and it concentrates on the way current systems avoid redundancy, failure, and graceful degradation. Based on public domain information and available research on top market players, the paper sheds light on the absence of elementary fault tolerance mechanisms. The study also emphasizes the lack of sufficient research attention to fault tolerance in heterogeneous autonomous systems and describes relevant research directions to improve safety in the next generation of vehicles.

title: AI-Enhanced Fuzzy Predictive Energy Management System
authors: Kalpana Chauhan, Rajeev Kumar Chauhan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents an optimal energy management strategy based on enhanced AI fuzzy. The system is for a grid and photovoltaic-based Electric Vehicle (EV) charging station designed for university campuses. In the proposed system there is integration of Photovoltaic (PV), utility grid and Battery Energy Storage System (BESS) that will provide supply to support multiple EV charging ports with Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) functionality. A Fuzzy Logic Controller (FLC) manages real-time energy flow. To improve decision accuracy, a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network is developed to predict future values State of Charge (SoC), PV output, and dynamic grid pricing. A hybrid Genetic Algorithm and Particle Swarm Optimization (GA-PSO) technique optimizes charging schedules and grid usage to lower costs and improve renewable energy use in the campus. The integrated LSTM-FIS-GA-PSO framework simulations is done in MATLAB Simulink show less reliance on the grid, better use of PV systems, and more efficient battery operation under changing load and solar conditions.

title: Classification of Baleen Whale Social Calls Using Convolutional Neural Networks and Melspectrograms
authors: Aleksa Samardzija
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Automatic data analyses are needed to analyze the increasing volumes of baleen whale vocalization data collected by passive acoustic monitoring. In our work we explore the effectiveness of using mel-spectrograms as inputs to convolutional neural networks for the automatic classification of the 40 Hz fin whale and D blue whale social calls. Our work shows promising results, achieving a high level of precision and recall for both classes.

title: Energy Management in Customized Microgrid: A Comparative Analysis of Reinforcement Learning Approaches
authors: Hamed Kheirandish Gharehbagh, Hatef Azami, Hamed Badihi, Behnam Mohammadi-ivatloo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The demand for reliable and uninterrupted energy supply has become increasingly critical with the global trend toward digitalization. Microgrid energy optimization plays a key role in achieving cost savings and reducing emissions. While traditional mathematical optimization approaches have been widely used, they often struggle with infeasibility and complexity in dynamic environments. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel application of reinforcement learning (RL) for microgrid energy management, emphasizing the structured definition of the RL environment—state, action, and reward spaces. A customized microgrid configuration, including photovoltaic (PV) generation, a diesel generator (DG), and external grid integration, is used as a case study. Comparative results demonstrate the advantages of Q learning over SARSA in terms of adaptability and performance.

title: The Impact of Renewable Energy on the Power Grid Restoration Process After Natural Disasters
authors: Mohsen Tavakoli, Hossein Ameli, Sasan Azad, Mohammad Taghi Ameli
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: With the increasing use of renewable resources for various reasons such as environmental issues, energy security, sustainability, and energy storage, it is important to study the behavior of the power grid by considering these resources, especially in times of crisis. In situations where disasters cause heavy losses, using the capacity of these resources can help to continue energy supply and reduce losses. In this regard, this research examines and compares the process of restoring the power grid after a storm in the presence of renewable resources, including wind and solar power plants, and its uncertainty is considered through the information gap method. Modeling is implemented on the IEEE standard 69-bus network, and recovery is examined in two cases of the presence and absence of renewable resources. The results show that using renewable resources in the recovery process can reduce the time of the recovery process by 28% and the losses caused by disasters due to the storage and continuity of energy up to 34%, especially in inaccessible locations.

title: Detection and Recognition of UAVs by Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Veton Rushiti, Slobodan Kalajdziski, Biljana Risteska Stojkoska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The use of drones (UAVs) is multi-dimensional in positive aspects, but it is worrying that they are also used by malicious people in negative aspects. Drones can be misused for smuggling, illegal surveillance, or security violations. The development of an anti-drone system is very necessary in order to prevent the aforementioned problems. This paper discusses the construction of an intelligent system that will detect and recognize drones using data provided by optical technology (camera). Based on the obtained results, they show that the use of techniques for dataset preparation and model training is very promising.

title: Non-Uniform $k$-Connectivity for Energy-Efficient and Reliable Underwater Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Cagla Tantur Karagul, Mehmet Burak Akgun, Huseyin Ugur Yildiz, Bulent Tavli
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs) have diverse applications, including coastal monitoring, environmental observation, and defense operations. Resilient underwater missions require reliable connectivity, often realized through <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> connectivity, where each sensor node sustains at least <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> disjoint paths to the base station (BS). However, maintaining <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> paths for every node introduces substantial energy overhead, limiting network lifetime. To address this challenge, we propose a nonuniform <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-connectivity scheme, assigning higher <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex> values to critical nodes and lower ones to less critical nodes, for reducing the total energy consumption. We formulate this approach as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) model and evaluate it on a coastal UWSN scenario. Our results show that overall energy consumption can increase up to 6.17-fold in a fully 3-connected network compared to the 1 -connected case, whereas non-uniform <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$k$</tex>-connectivity can reduce this overhead to 4.16-fold, achieving a more balanced trade-off between reliability and energy efficiency.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp3-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Transformer Architectures for Distracted Driving Behavior Detection: A Comprehensive Review of Vision-Based Approaches
authors: Muhammad Fawzan Anwari Muhammad Saiful Anuar, Fadhlan Hafizhelmi Kamaru Zaman, Syahrul Afzal Che Abdullah, Kok Mun Ng, Kanendra Naidu Vijyakumar, Shyh Kang Ng
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Distracted driving is a leading cause of road accidents, with visual and manual distractions being particularly prevalent. Traditional computer vision methods, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have been extensively utilized for detecting driver behavior; however, they face challenges in effectively modeling long-range dependencies and complex spatiotemporal patterns. Recent advancements in Vision Transformer (ViT) demonstrate significant potential to address these limitations by leveraging global attention mechanisms and a scalable architecture. This review presents a comprehensive review of ViT-based approaches in distracted driving detection, which covers both image-based and video-based methods. It examines several architectural innovations, such as lightweight ViT variants, pose-aware attention-enhanced models, and hybrid ViT-architecture designs. The review also explores multi-modal and multi-view fusion strategies, which integrate several inputs such as RGB, infrared, depth, and physiological signals to enhance model robustness across diverse driving scenarios. In addition, the paper highlights benchmark datasets and performance comparisons used in distracted driving behavior detection. Finally, this review highlights the current challenges, including computational cost and interpretability, while also proposing directions for future research. Overall, ViT-based models present a promising foundation for developing the next generation of intelligent driver monitoring systems.

title: A Generalizable Channel-Resilient Algorithm in Radio Frequency Fingerprint Identification
authors: Junxian Shi, Linning Peng, Hua Fu, Aiqun Hu
publish: IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
abstract: The identification of radio frequency fingerprint (RFF) extracted from wireless signals subjected to channel interference faces a formidable challenge. Traditional equalization-based channel removal methods require known pilot signals and may potentially eliminate RFF features while suppressing channel effects. To address this challenge, the channel divide-and-conquer normalization (CDCN) algorithm is proposed to remove effects of arbitrary channels while preserving RFF features in the sense of cosine similarity. Through cross-scenario experiments on 60 off-the-shelf ZigBee devices in eight different scenarios, the CDCN algorithm with region of interest (ROI) achieves high accuracy of up to 99.98% on ResNet-9 and is verified to be generalized and practical.

title: An HCAI Methodological Framework: Putting it Into Action to Enable Human-Centered AI_supp1-3631590.pdf
authors: Wei Xu
publish: N/A
abstract: Human-centered artificial intelligence (HCAI) is a design philosophy that prioritizes humans in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems, aiming to maximize AI’s benefits while mitigating its negative impacts. Despite its growing prominence in literature, the lack of methodological guidance for its implementation poses challenges to HCAI practice. To address this gap, this article proposes a comprehensive HCAI methodological framework (HCAI-MF) comprising five key components: HCAI requirement hierarchy, approach and method taxonomy, process, interdisciplinary collaboration approach, and multilevel design paradigms. A case study demonstrates HCAI-MF’s practical implications, while the article also analyzes implementation challenges. Actionable recommendations and a “three-layer” HCAI implementation strategy are provided to address these challenges and guide future evolution of HCAI-MF. HCAI-MF is presented as a systematic and executable methodology capable of overcoming current gaps, enabling effective design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems, and advancing HCAI practice.

title: Simulation of Flash Memory Architecture Using VHDL in Xilinx ISE
authors: Ramírez-Cruz U. D., Zapata-Rodríguez U.G., Zapata-Rodríguez U.G., Mendoza-Barron G., Mabil-Espinosa P., Caldelas-González E.I., Martínez-Castillo J.
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The flash memory has become over time a fundamental component in modern digital systems due to its nonvolatile nature, high speed writing capabilities and high data store density. This paper presents the design and simulation of a NAND type flash memory model using VHDL in XILINX ISE VIVADO environment. This model implements main flash operations: read, write or program, and block erase and is validated both functionally and quantitatively. The simulation results show read, write and erase latencies of 45-55 ns, 180-220 ns, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5-2 \mu \mathrm{s}$</tex> respectively, achieving a data throughput between 8 and 12 MB/s. The architecture was simplified to a 1 KB single page design with separate address and data lines for improved clarity for the study. Despite the restrictions, the model successfully replicates the essential behavior of NAND flash memory serves as a tool for understanding memory architecture, logic and hierarchical VHDL design. To test functionality a testbench was developed, generating clock signals and applying stimulus to simulate memory access. As a practical application sample ECG (electrocardiogram) data was stored and retrieved from memory demonstrating a potential use in biomedical signal and embedded healthcare systems. This simulation results confirm the correct data storage, ensuring the reliability for implementation in FPGA systems. This work could be implemented to develop a layout design.

title: Mechanical Evaluation of 3D-Printed Hand Prosthesis Joints
authors: Denisse Uscanga-Tlalpan, Gerardo Diaz-Arango
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Upper limb amputations are regarded a major challenge for rehabilitation, affecting independence and quality of life. Prostheses are artificial devices designed to replace missing body parts, and their effectiveness is based on functional adaptation to patient needs. In this work, STL models of hand prostheses incorporating two articulation systems were evaluated: direct joints and flexible TPU bands. The fingers were manufactured from PLA, the forearm structure was produced in PET-G, and finger flexion was achieved by the use of flexible and rigid tensioners. Mechanical testing involved repeated 10-second-second loading and deformation was analyzed using GOM Correlate software. The mechanical performance of both systems was compared to assess structural integrity and functional efficiency.

title: Solar Power Forecasting Using Modified Particle Swarm Optimization and Long Short-Term Memory
authors: Luka Jovanovic, Jovana Arsic, Ivan Kosta, Valentin Thomas, Nebojsa Bacanin, Miodrag Zivkovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of photovoltaic power production is essential for reliable grid integration and efficient energy management. This work explores long short-term memory (LSTM) networks optimized through an adaptive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>-hill climbing particle swarm optimization (AHCPSO) strategy for hyperparameter tuning. The proposed approach addresses two common PSO limitations-premature convergence and weak early exploration-by adaptively regulating search diversification and intensification. Comparative experiments against well established and recently proposed algorithms as well as the conventional PSO were conducted on real PV output data from publically available sources. Results show that LSTM-AHCPSO achieves the most stable optimization performance with the lowest variance, while delivering superior accuracy across error metrics (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}=0.8757$</tex>, MAE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.0444$</tex>, RMSE <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.0817$</tex>). Forecasts produced by the best model closely track actual PV generation, demonstrating its robustness and consistency.

title: Probabilistic RANSAC with Laplacian-Softmax Weighting for Sparse Image Reconstruction
authors: Isidora Stanković, Miloš Brajović, Miloš Daković, Ljubiša Stanković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper introduces a probabilistic variant of random sample consensus (RANSAC) for image reconstruction. Classical RANSAC samples pixel subsets uniformly to fit local models and identify inliers, but uniform draws are expensive on large images and fragile under widespread corruption. We replace them with likelihood-guided sampling that preserves the standard RANSAC pipeline while concentrating trials on cleaner pixels. Experiments on noisy images show comparable reconstruction quality with fewer iterations and substantially lower runtime.

title: XGBoost Session-Level Energy Demand Prediction for EV Charging Stations Using Behavioral and Contextual Data
authors: Jelena D. Velimirović, Lazar Z. Velimirović, Ivana Petkovski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper proposes a data-driven approach to predict session-level EV energy demand using contextual station data and user behavior from historical logs. A large realistic dataset and a time-aware, user-level anti-leakage split ensured robust evaluation. The XGBoost model outperformed other regressors, offering accurate forecasts without vehicle telemetry. This scalable method enables operators to predict energy demand reliably, supporting smarter EV charging network management and allowing future integration of detailed user or technical data.

title: Machine Learning Model for Cyber Security Attack Detection in Smart Grid Network
authors: Hamad AlMarzooqi, Yassmeen Walweel, Marwan Saeed, Hussam Al Hamadi, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Mohammad Hasan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Smart grids, as advanced cyber-physical systems, are increasingly vulnerable to cyberattacks due to the integration of IoT, cloud services, and remote communication protocols. This study investigates the efficacy of supervised machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) models in detecting cyberattacks within smart grid networks. Using a real-world dataset simulating 37 power system events, including 28 cyberattacks, models such as Extra Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost, Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) were trained and evaluated using standard metrics including accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and confusion matrix. The Extra Trees classifier achieved superior performance (98 % accuracy, 0.99 F1), followed closely by Random Forest and XGBoost. DL models improved with training epochs but did not outperform tree-based ensembles. The findings highlight ensemble learning's robustness for privacy-aware real-time detection.

title: Embedded Fuzzy Logic Controller for a Pneumatic Levitation System
authors: Luis F. Olmedo-Garcia, Luis D. Ramírez-González, Omar A. Barra-Vázquez, José G. Pérez-Juárez Trinidad Martínez-Sánchez, Maria I. Cruz-Orduña, Zayra E. Santos-Flores
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents the design and experimental validation of an embedded fuzzy logic controller (FLC) for regulating the position of a sphere in a pneumatic levitation system. Pneumatic levitation relies on controlled airflow to counteract gravity, but its nonlinear dynamics and sensitivity to disturbances make control challenging. The proposed controller, implemented on an ESP32 platform, provides a low-cost and efficient realtime solution without requiring precise system modeling. An HC-SR04 ultrasonic sensor was integrated for position measurement, chosen for its simplicity and affordability. Despite its susceptibility to fluctuations, the FLC demonstrated robustness in compensating for imprecise measurements, outperforming conventional model-based strategies. The experimental results confirmed the effectiveness of the proposed approach, achieving steady-state errors below 4 %, overshoot under 6 %, and settling times of around 2 seconds across different reference positions.

title: TinyML Unleashed: Accelerating TensorFlow Lite Micro Kernels with RISC-V Vector Extension
authors: Ahmed Mahmoudi, Christopher Horn, Saleh Mulhem, Rainer Buchty, Mladen Berekovic, Rolf Meyer
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The widespread use of machine learning on embedded devices has intensified the demand for efficient inference acceleration. The RISC-V Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) integrates vector extensions that provide advanced data-processing capabilities to address this need. However, existing compiler autovectorization techniques remain limited. In this paper, we hence explore the capabilities of manual vectorization for common Machine Learning kernels using TensorFlow Lite for Microcontrollers (TFLM) as the runtime engine. Our optimizations achieve throughput improvements ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$28 \times$</tex> compared to scalar implementations, and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \times$</tex> compared to compiler auto-vectorization on a commercial RISC-V board.

title: Design and Simulation of Grid-Connected Vertical Axis Wind Turbines for Roadside Energy Harvesting from Vehicle-Induced Airflow
authors: Abdullah Alsahli, Saud Almutairi, Saleh Buolayyan, Mansour Alajmi, Khalid Sultan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a grid-connected energy harvesting system that utilizes vertical-axis wind turbines (VAWTs) to convert vehicle-induced airflow on highways into usable electrical power. A detailed MATLAB/Simulink model was developed to simulate a system comprising 30 Savonius-type VAWTs driving induction generators, capacitor-based power factor correction, roadside lighting loads, and bidirectional grid interaction. The system was evaluated under varying wind speeds, turbine inertia constants, and with/without reactive power compensation. Results show that increasing wind speed significantly enhances power generation and power factors, higher inertia improves dynamic stability, and capacitive compensation reduces reactive power drawn from the grid. A prototype of the system is implemented and illustrated. The proposed approach demonstrates technical feasibility for roadside renewable energy integration, with potential environmental and economic benefits.

title: Robust $\mathrm{L}_{1}$ Control of Uncertain IBRs in Dynamic Virtual Power Plants
authors: Navid Vafamand, Shayan Soltani, Abbass Rabiee, Innocent Kamwa
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The increasing integration of inverterbased resources (IBRs) in modern power systems leads to a reduction in overall system inertia and stability margins. They produce power less than conventional fossil-fuel-based plants, positioning them as price followers in energy markets. Moreover, accurate modeling of IBRs is a hard task, requiring robust approaches to be developed. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a novel hierarchical <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{1}$</tex> performance controller to shape a dynamic virtual power plant (DVPP). The proposed approach uses a two-layer control design. The first layer involves a global controller that uses the adaptive divide-and-conquer approach to design desired models for the IBRs. The second layer comprises local controllers that enable the DVPP to control the IBRs. The local controller uses the desired model to compute the operating point for the IBR and a robust state-feedback law to stabilize the tracking error dynamics of IBRs. Since the IIBR models are uncertain, the computed operating point is not accurate and introduces a persistent bounded disturbance in the tracking error dynamics. A robust <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{1}$</tex> controller design is proposed to deal with the system uncertainties and minimize the effect of the persistent bounded disturbance on the IBR power. The controller gains are derived by solving a set of linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Unlike many existing methods, the proposed framework avoids directly coupling the dynamic reference and source models, thereby reducing design complexity and enhancing the scalability of the DVPP. Furthermore, this work explicitly incorporates parameter uncertainties in IBR models, which is not the case in state-of-the-art methods. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated through simulations, highlighting its capability to maintain reliable power generation in the presence of faults.

title: A Study on a Deep Learning-Based Long-Term Bad Driving Behavior Recognition
authors: Fengzhi Dai, Jiabin Chen, Hucheng Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: A deep learning network based on behavioral identification is suggested in order to increase the recognition rate of long-term bad driving circumstances. The model may concentrate more on subtle visual features because the Inception-ResNet architecture is used as the feature extraction network; Following the approach of the Dual-Stream Network, the input is processed using both image flow and optical flow streams. Spatio-temporal attention mechanisms are incorporated into each stream to enhance the network’s focus on spatial and temporal information. Comparative experiments are conducted on both the public dataset UCF-101 and the self-built dataset UH-Face, and the results demonstrate that the proposed method enhances the network’s extraction of spatial and temporal information. Compared to other algorithms, it achieves improved recognition performance for certain signature unsafe driving behaviors such as drinking water and smoking.

title: A Polar Feature Based Convolutional Random Forest Classifier for Modulation Classification in Resource Constrained Application
authors: Sathish Babu Sekar, K Tamizhelakkiya
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Advances in beyond fifth generation (B5G) networks trigger new ways of information transfer, adopting driving artificial intelligence machine learning (AIML) techniques to address serious challenges such as spectrum utilization, interference identification, energy consumption, and mobile traffic regulation. The Modulation Classification (MC) is a promising solution for Cognitive Radio (CR) and Dynamic Spectrum Access (DSA) to meet the exponential needs of B5G networks. The labeled datasets created using software defined radio (SDR) for a typical indoor scenario. Leveraging the knowledge of polar feature extraction from the RF samples not only reduces the computational training overhead and the effects of multipath but also ensures more reliable for low-latency resource-limited applications. In this paper, we propose a convolutional RF classifier for classifying the modulation classes BPSK, 8-PSK and variants of QAM. The classification accuracies were found to be improved by 10-12% for the 8PSK and 64QAM schemes compared to the traditional model.

title: Development of a Digital Twin Platform for Green Infrastructure Evaluation
authors: Albert Martin B. Castillo, Chrystelle Reye C. Gonzalbo, John Richard E. Hizon, Glen Angela E. Annang Percival Magpantay, Julius Rhoan Lustro, Joshua C. Agar, Marc D. Rosales
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Existing assessment tools for green infrastructures often rely on static, retrospective datasets, limiting their effectiveness in dynamic environmental monitoring and analysis. This study focused on the development of an integrated green infrastructure evaluation system utilizing digital twin technology to enable realtime monitoring and 3D visualization of environmental parameters within a unified platform. A preliminary deployment was conducted at two sites: the Electrical and Electronics Engineering Institute (EEEI) building, representing a non-GI baseline, and the National Engineering Center (NEC) building, which incorporates key green infrastructure features. The system combined wireless sensor nodes with digital twin visualization through Autodesk Revit and Tandem, enabling real-time data collection and spatial analysis. To reduce system power consumption, Thread mesh networking and battery-operated nodes were used. A Node-RED web application was also developed to interpret raw sensor data in relation to occupant comfort obtained through a survey interface. This approach facilitated a comprehensive analysis of the correlations and interactions among various GI parameters, allowing a comparative evaluation between the NEC and EEEI rooms. Results showed that the NEC building maintained better indoor air quality, more consistent environmental comfort, and lower pollutant accumulation compared to the EEEI, highlighting the environmental benefits of GI features.

title: A Predictive Approach for Transport Protocol Multi-Connectivity Scheduling
authors: Roshith Sebastian, Benjamin Barth, Tomaso de Cola, Cristian J. Vaca-Rubio, Luis Blanco, Marius Caus, Engin Zeydan
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this era of 5G and beyond, Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN) plays a pivotal role in providing ubiquitous connectivity. Hence, it is essential to maintain connectivity with NTN, although a device is already connected to a Terrestrial Network (TN). The ideal approach would be to handle this at transport protocol layer as independent networks are involved. Establishing Multiple-Paths (MPs) between NTN and TN by means of MPTCP is a promising approach to realise this. Both the networks have different data rate and the available capacity, which varies over time based on the traffic demand. In this work, we start by presenting a solution to predict the traffic demand on NTN link based on federated Kolmogorov Arnold networks (fed-KANs). This predicted traffic demand is then used as an input to the MP scheduler to efficiently utilize the bandwidth available on both the NTN and TN. The goal is to minimize the data file transfer time and increase throughput. The proposed scheduling mechanism reduces the file transfer time compared to benchmark MP schedulers and achieves higher aggregated throughput. This shows that a scheduling mechanism with the knowledge of expected traffic demand performs better than classical schedulers which do take this into consideration.

title: Leveraging Minimal Path Sets for Reliability Block Diagram Evaluation
authors: Shakthivelu Janardhanan, Yaxuan Chen, Wolfgang Kellerer, Carmen Mas-Machuca
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: A Reliability Block Diagram (RBD) is a graphical tool to evaluate a system’s availability, depending on its components and their interconnections. In communication networks or electric power grids, maintaining high availability between a source and destination is crucial. However, in today’s large-scale networks with several nodes and edges, the network’s availability evaluation using RBDs is computationally intensive. Hence, we introduce (i) our novel Minimal Path Sets (MPSs)-based RBD evaluation technique, and (ii) PyRBD3, our open-source implementation of our novel method to evaluate availability using RBDs. Additionally, we compare PyRBD3’s performance on different topologies against the state-of-the-art solutions.

title: Transhumeral Prostheses and Compliant Mechanisms: A Pathway for Rehabilitation
authors: Gerardo Mora-Aquino, Ernesto A. Elvira-Hernandez, Mario Antonio Peña Meza, Jesus Delgado-Maciel, Victor A. Jarvio-Cordova, Huber Giron Nieto, Oliver Ochoa Garcia, Jaime Martinez-Castillo, Saul M. Dominguez-Nicolas, Agustín L. Herrera-May, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In recent years, prostheses have become a means for amputees to return to their everyday activities, particularly transhumeral prostheses designed to restore arm mobility. However, the widespread adoption of prostheses is hindered by challenges related to restricted movement, a lack of tailored design, and high cost. One approach to tackling these obstacles is the integration of compliant mechanisms into the design of prostheses. Absence of maintenance and wear, fewer parts, higher precision, and ease of manufacture are some of the advantages of compliant mechanisms. This review summarizes recent developments in transhumeral prostheses as well as the integration of compliant mechanisms in the design of prostheses. Design guidelines encompassing material selection and topologies for compliant mechanisms are also addressed, as well as the challenges that prevent the widespread adoption of compliant mechanisms. It is anticipated that this review will serve as a starting point for researchers interested in compliant mechanisms and prosthetic design.

title: Multi-Layer Device-Level Electro-Thermal Real-Time Simulation and Multi-Purpose HIL Testing of Power Electronics Converters
authors: Hao Bai, Xinyang Li, Jiaxin Tang, Zhen Yao, Ning Mao, Rui Ma, Wentao Jiang, Yang Zhou, Shengrong Zhuo, Fei Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Real-time simulation (RTS) of power electronic converters (PECs) has become increasingly crucial throughout their lifecycle in modern electrified transportation systems, yet remains constrained by computational limitations. This paper presents a multi-layer device-level electro-thermal RTS methodology that simultaneously addresses electrical-thermal coupling effects and semiconductor switching characteristics while maintaining computational efficiency. A novel multi-purpose hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) testing framework is subsequently developed by systematically integrating the proposed electro-thermal RTS, enhancing both functional verification capabilities and testing efficiency. Experimental validation is conducted through an FPGA-based implementation for an interleaved bidirectional DC-DC converter. The real-time simulation results demonstrate high consistency compared to offline LTspice simulations. Successful integration with the HIL testing confirms the methodology's effectiveness in enabling concurrent electro-thermal analysis and control strategy verification, significantly advancing the development of reliable PECs for electrified transportation.

title: A Pairwise Comparison Relation-Assisted Multiobjective Evolutionary Neural Architecture Search Method With Multipopulation Mechanism_supp1-3647894.pdf
authors: Yu Xue
publish: N/A
abstract: Neural architecture search (NAS) has emerged as a powerful paradigm that enables researchers to automatically explore vast search spaces and discover efficient neural networks. However, NAS suffers from a critical bottleneck, i.e., the evaluation of numerous architectures during the search process demands substantial computing resources and time. In order to improve the efficiency of NAS, a series of methods have been proposed to reduce the evaluation time of neural architectures. However, they are not efficient enough and still only focus on the accuracy of architectures. Beyond classification accuracy, real-world applications increasingly demand more efficient and compact network architectures that balance multiple performance criteria. To address these challenges, we propose the SMEMNAS, a pairwise comparison relation-assisted multiobjective evolutionary algorithm (EA) based on a multipopulation (MP) mechanism. In the SMEMNAS, a surrogate model is constructed based on pairwise comparison relations to predict the accuracy ranking of architectures, rather than the absolute accuracy. Moreover, two populations cooperate with each other in the search process, i.e., a main population that guides the evolutionary process and a vice population that enhances search diversity. Our method aims to discover high-performance models that simultaneously optimize multiple objectives. We conduct comprehensive experiments on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet datasets to validate the effectiveness of our approach. With only a single GPU searching for 0.17 days, competitive architectures can be found by SMEMNAS, which achieves 78.91% accuracy with the MAdds of 570 M on the ImageNet. This work makes a significant advancement in the field of NAS.

title: Seasonal Variability of Sea Ice Bulk Density During the MOSAiC Expedition: Results from Synergistic In-Situ, Airborne, and Satellite Observations
authors: Yi Zhou, Xianwei Wang, Ruibo Lei, Dmitry V. Divine, Chentong Zhang, Yu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Satellite-based retrievals of Arctic sea ice thickness and its thermodynamic modeling typically assume a constant sea ice bulk density (IBD), disregarding its intricate seasonal variations influenced by factors such as ice age, temperature, brine content, and air intrusion. This study investigates the seasonal variability of IBD during the Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) expedition, spanning from late October 2019 to April 2020. To achieve this, we integrated sea ice thickness and snow depth observations from 15 ice mass balance buoys, snow bulk density measurements from snow pits, along with high-resolution total freeboard data from airborne laser scanning (ALS) and the Ice, Cloud, and land Elevation Satellite-2 (ICESat-2) within the MOSAiC Distributed Network (DN; 50 km radius). Assuming hydrostatic equilibrium, the regionally integrated IBD was calculated for the buoy-deployed level ice floes, covering 11 sites on second-year ice (SYI) and 4 sites on first-year ice (FYI). These buoy-based IBD estimates were then compared with direct measurements obtained at the MOSAiC Main Coring Sites (MCS). Our findings provide preliminary evidence of IBD seasonality during the Arctic freezing season: (1) From late October to early December 2019 (transition phase), the IBDs derived from both MCS-FYI and regional integration increased from ~880 to 910 kg m<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sub>, possibly due to a reduced air volume fraction in the ice; (2) From late December 2019 to late April 2020 (quasi-stable phase), all IBDs largely persisted within 900−920 kg m<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sub>, with modal values near 910 kg m<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−3</sub>, consistent with historical observations for the same period. However, the IBD at MCS-SYI remained relatively stable throughout the study period due to the low porosity of the sampled SYI cores. For cross-validation, the regional-scale IBD retrievals were further upscaled to characterize mean level ice conditions across the MOSAiC DN, yielding IBD seasonal patterns consistent with those observed at the buoy and coring sites. To better represent IBD in the contemporary Arctic Ocean, we propose a time-varying proxy model and explore multiple parameterizations based on the MOSAiC synergistic observations. Furthermore, the uncertainties associated with IBD retrievals and developed parameterization schemes are also assessed.

title: Multi-Tree Genetic Programming With Deep Contextual Bandits for Learning-Assisted Scheduling of Cluster Tools Integrating Stockers
authors: LiangChao Chen, YiMing Lai, Yan Qiao, NaiQi Wu, Xin Luo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: This work proposes a dynamic scheduling problem of a single-armed cluster tool (SACT) by considering the wafer lots simultaneously stored in a stocker to be processed at it. In other words, the investigated system integrates a stocker and an SACT, which is named as an S-SACT system. Multiple wafer types (more than two) may be processed simultaneously by different processing chambers (PCs) in the SACT. Thus, PC cleaning is necessary when switching between wafer types. Stochastic lot arrivals necessitate dynamic decisions on lot sequencing in the stocker and their PC assignments, generating a partially-determined schedule that is updated when a new lot arrives. Then, an activity-driven simulation is used to obtain the final schedule. Generating high-quality partially-determined schedules is challenging. To address this, we propose a two-stage learning-assisted evolutionary framework combining Multi-tree Genetic Programming (MTGP) and Deep Contextual Bandit (DCB). In stage one, MTGP automatically generates scheduling rules that produce high-quality partially-determined schedules in dynamic environments offline, forming the action set for stage two. In stage two, DCB is pre-trained to select the most effective action with over 90% probability, then deployed to choose actions in real time while continuously updating its rule-selection agent. Computational experiments demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing approaches across all tested cases.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp9-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.
