title: Integration of MLOps into the Software Development Lifecycle: A Systematic Review
authors: Kenia Cancañón-Rodríguez, Mirna Muñoz, Himer Avila-George
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Machine Learning Operations (MLOps) extends Development and Operations (DevOps) practices to manage the end-to-end lifecycle of machine learning models. However, the alignment between MLOps and the traditional software development lifecycle (SDLC) remains insufficiently defined. This study presents a systematic literature review of peer-reviewed works published between 2018 and 2025 in IEEE Xplore, Scopus, and the ACM Digital Library. The review was conducted following a protocol for evidence-based software engineering. A total of 71 primary studies were included after deduplication and screening. A phase-based taxonomy of MLOps tools was synthesized and an SDLC-MLOps compatibility framework was derived to classify alignment levels as high, medium, or low across development phases. Inter-rater agreement, measured using Cohen's Kappa, yielded a value of 0.91, while the average study quality score was 0.73. The results show convergence around pipelines, model registries, and containerized deployment, alongside persistent fragmentation in process models and organizational practices. The findings provide implications for practice, including maturity-based adoption strategies, role definition, governance mechanisms, and continuous monitoring. Additionally, opportunities for future research are identified in the areas of ML-specific testing and harmonized metrics across software engineering and data science disciplines.

title: Evaluating Readout Strategies in Liquid State Machines: Coding Schemes, Classifiers, and Separability Metrics
authors: Carlos-Alberto López-Herrera, Héctor-Gabriel Acosta-Mesa, Efrén Mezura-Montes, Adriana-Laura López-Lobato, Jesús-Arnulfo Barradas-Palmeros
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Liquid State Machines (LSMs), a form of Reservoir Computing (RC) based on spiking neurons, have shown promising results for tasks involving complex, temporally structured data. However, research on the impact of coding schemes, classifier choice, and separability metrics applied to LSM remains insufficient. In this work, six coding schemes, six classifiers, and three separability metrics across two synthetic benchmark tasks (Frequency and Pattern Recognition) are systematically evaluated. This allows us to contrast readout strategies and assess how well separability metrics align with classification accuracy. Our results showed that rate-based coders combined with linear classifiers yield the most accurate performance. Among separability metrics, K-Nearest Neighbor Overlap Score (KNN-OS) provides the most consistent correlation with accuracy, while Silhouette Score (SS) and Davies-Bouldin Index (DBI) display important limitations. These findings contribute to a clearer understanding of readout design in LSMs and provide practical guidance for selecting coding strategies, classifiers, and evaluating metrics in future applications.

title: Towards 6G: A 5G system Latency Analysis
authors: Sruthi N T, Debabrata Dalai, B.S. Manoj
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper conducts a study of the 5<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> Generation (5G) system latency analysis using an open source 5G testbed. Next-generation wireless technology testbeds are crucial for testing and validating emerging technologies in research institutions and industries. The feasibility of studying real-time next-generation wireless systems is significantly constrained by licensing restrictions from network operators and vendors. Therefore, to bridge the gap, an open source 5G network testbed is developed using open source software such as Open5GS, srsRAN, and programmable Software Defined Radio (SDR). The proposed 5G testbed focused on a typical 5G cellular system consisting of User Equipment (UE), gNodeB (gNB), and Core Network (CN). In addition, various elements of latency were analyzed using the proposed testbed to investigate and minimize latency in 5G networks. The results show that the developed 5G testbed experiences a general UE registration latency of 414 ms and a PDU session establishment latency of 15 ms. The results show that 57.2% of the registration delay is caused by Access and Mobility (AM) policy association, in the Access and Mobility Management Function (AMF), while 38.5% of the session establishment delay occurs during the policy rules checking in the Policy and Control Function (PCF).

title: Perception Offloading for Autonomous Mobility in a Beyond-5G Edge-enabled Environment
authors: Tiago Mostardinha, João Gameiro, Pedro Valente, Pedro Rito, Duarte Raposo, Susana Sargento, Carlos Marques, Miguel Mesquita, Filipe Pinto
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an architecture integrating Multi-access Edge Computing (MEC) nodes into 5G base stations and roadside units to enable dynamic service orchestration for on-demand perception offloading. In this approach, compute-intensive perception tasks, such as object detection, are instantiated as services on nearby edge nodes, with resources being allocated adaptively based on the locations and trajectories of the vehicles. The system was designed to support user mobility through service replication and seamless handovers between perception service instances in different edge nodes as vehicles move across coverage areas, ensuring continuous service delivery and Quality of Service (QoS) guarantees. We evaluate the proposed architecture in a real-world 5G edge-enabled testbed using an autonomous vehicle running an object detection service. The results demonstrate that offloading perception via 5G and MEC yields substantially lower processing latency, and that smart orchestration mechanisms are able to react to user mobility and platform stress situations, avoiding service degradation, thus validating the approach for Cooperative, Connected, and Automated Mobility (CCAM) use cases.

title: Liver Tumor Segmentation: A Comparative Study of Optimized CNN Models and a Dual-Model Approach
authors: Aviel Malayev, Miri Weiss Cohen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This research presents a comprehensive comparative analysis of three deep learning architectures-U-Net, ResUNet, and TransUNet-for liver tumor segmentation in CT scans, using the LiTS17 dataset. The study evaluates each model under varied hyperparameter configurations, with a focus on different loss functions and learning rates, and assesses performance using Accuracy, True Positive Rate (TPR), and Dice Score. Results highlight significant differences in segmentation capabilities, emphasizing the impact of hyperparameter selection on model effectiveness. The contribution of this work is the development of a novel dual-model approach. The first model, trained with Dice Loss, is dedicated to segmenting the liver, while the second model, using Weighted Binary Cross-Entropy, focuses exclusively on tumor detection within the previously segmented liver region. This division of tasks enhances both accuracy and specificity in tumor delineation. This study offers new insights into the relative strengths of leading segmentation models and proposes a promising dual-model strategy to advance precision in medical image analysis.

title: Hardware Efficient CRC Algorithm for 5G-NR
authors: Samudrala Soujanya, Prem Singh, Ekant Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a hardware-efficient implementation of a CRC computation algorithm compliant with 3GPP fifth generation (5G) new radio (NR) specifications. The proposed design utilizes parallel processing and precomputed CRC values stored in lookup tables to enable low-latency and high-throughput operation. Implemented on an Xilinx RFSoC platform, the architecture ensures that CRC computation completes well within the duration of a 5G-NR slot, across all numerologies. The design supports dynamic configuration for different CRC polynomials and payload lengths, enabling seamless adaptation across different physical layer channels. Compared to traditional bit-serial implementations, the proposed approach offers substantial improvements in latency and power efficiency while maintaining low hardware resource usage. These results demonstrate the suitability of the design for real-time 5G-NR physical layer processing. Its scalability and low-complexity architecture make it well-suited for integration into high-throughput baseband processing in 5G-NR systems.

title: Implementation of a Large Language Model (LLM) for Spanish-Nahuatl Translation
authors: Eduardo Sánchez Lucero, José Crispin Hernández Hernández, Edmundo Bonilla Huerta, Samuel Pérez Zistecatl
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the design and training of a large language model (LLM) for bidirectional translation between Spanish and Nahuatl, focusing on technical accuracy and cultural relevance. A bilingual corpus of 7,500 sentence pairs was constructed, a Transformer model was trained from scratch with Sentence-Piece tokenization, and a functional web prototype was deployed. BLEU and chrF++ metrics confirm the viability of the system, which preserves linguistic features of Nahuatl frequently omitted by generic translators. The model has immediate applications in educational and community contexts and represents a technical and social contribution toward digital inclusion and the preservation of indigenous languages. The work was carried out at the TecNM/Apizaco Institute of Technology (ITA) and supported by the Secretariat of Science, Humanities, Technology and Innovation (SECIHTI).

title: Integration of Classification, Survival, and Explainability Models for Breast Cancer Recurrence Prediction Using Clinical and Molecular Data
authors: Celia Chumbimuni, Mariana Ravines, Claudia Huanca, Leonardo Camarena, Nhikori Tovar
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Breast cancer is the most common neoplasm in the Americas, and its incidence is projected to increase by 40 % by 2040, representing a growing global clinical burden. Despite advances in diagnosis and treatment, approximately 30 % of patients experience recurrence after initial therapy. To address this challenge, we developed an integrated framework for recurrence prediction that combines classification, survival, and explainability models, using the Combined MSK Breast Cancer Cohort, derived from three public studies of the Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. The dataset included clinical and molecular variables preprocessed through KNN imputation, standardization, class balancing with SMOTE, and strict data leakage control. Six classifiers (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, Gradient Boosting, SVM, and Logistic Regression) and two survival models (CoxPH and Random Survival Forest) were trained using stratified 5-fold cross-validation. Gradient Boosting achieved the best performance (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{AUC}=0.977; \mathrm{F} 1=0.96$</tex>), while Random Survival Forest obtained the highest concordance index (C -index <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.835$</tex>), outperforming the Cox model. SHAP and LIME values identified endocrine therapy, prior recurrence, and tumor laterality as key predictors, reflecting strong clinical consistency. The proposed approach demonstrated high accuracy, transparency, and reproducibility, establishing itself as a potential tool for risk stratification and therapeutic decision support in breast cancer patients.

title: Assessing the Impact of Network Regularizers on the Performance of Convolutional Neural Network Architectures Evolved by DeepGA
authors: Jesús-Arnulfo Barradas-Palmeros, Efrén Mezura-Montes, Héctor-Gabriel Acosta-Mesa, Carlos-Alberto López-Herrera, Francisco-Javier Hernández-Somohano
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Overfitting is a persistent problem in Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) that limits the model's generalization capabilities. To counteract overfitting, network regularizers are incorporated into the training process. In this work, the impact of applying different regularization strategies to CNN architectures evolved with the Deep Genetic Algorithm (DeepGA) is studied. DeepGA follows an Evolutionary Neural Architecture Search (ENAS) process that considers both network performance and complexity. Experiments were conducted on the CIFAR-100 and CIFAR-10 datasets using the same set of evolved architectures, allowing a controlled comparison of performance and training cost. Random Erasing (RE), Dropout (DO), and Label Smoothing (LS) are the selected regularizers, which involve input, internal, and label regularization, respectively, and are applied individually and in combination. Results show that the combined configurations, especially <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R E}+\mathbf{D O}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R E}+\mathbf{D O}+\mathbf{L S}$</tex>, resulted in the most significant improvement in test accuracy, significantly outperforming the non-regularized baseline. Nonetheless, the use of regularizers expanded the computational cost due to an increase in the training time. The findings provide insights into the role and interaction of regularizers in evolved CNN architectures, highlighting their benefits in boosting the model's performance.

title: RIS Selection in 6G Networks
authors: Volkan Özduran
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) selection in candidate sixth-generation (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \mathbf{G}$</tex>) bands. A single-RIS activation rule that maximizes the end-to-end (e2e) SNR is adopted to capture performance gains while minimizing system overhead. The analysis covers passive <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\rho=1)$</tex> and absorptive (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0<\rho<1$</tex>) operation and employs a frequencydependent path-loss model at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.6,7.8,15$</tex>, and 40 GHz. Under double-Nakagami- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$m$</tex> fading, closed-form outage expressions are derived and combined with order statistics for RIS selection, then validated by Monte-Carlo simulations. Results show that max-e2e-SNR selection achieves the diversity order and improves reliability as the number of elements <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N$</tex> and panels <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T$</tex> increase. Absorptive operation introduces an SNR penalty proportional to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\rho^{2}$</tex>, and higher carrier frequencies shift outage curves to the right because of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$f_{c}^{-4}$</tex> large-scale loss. These findings quantify the reliability-overhead trade-off and provide frequency-aware guidance for RIS deployment.

title: A Machine Learning Framework with Enhanced Generalizability for Lithium-Ion Batteries SOC Estimation
authors: Usama Ali, Muhammad Ahmad Iqbal, Ijaz Haider Naqvi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The state of charge (SOC) is a critical parameter for the battery management system in lithium-ion batteries to ensure safe and efficient operation. Many data-driven approaches for SOC estimation have gained attention in recent years. However, these models often lack generalizability across different charge and discharge cycles, even for lithium-ion batteries of the same chemistry and manufacturer. This study aims to improve the generalizability of SOC estimation of lithium-ion batteries using neural network-based models. Three neural network-based models are implemented and evaluated using standard electric vehicle (EV) discharge profiles, including UDDS, US06, HWFET, and WLTP Class 3 and two synthetic profiles generated through the combination of the aforementioned standard EV discharge profiles. The first model uses only voltage as input, resulting in a root mean square error (RMSE) between 4% and 5%. The second model adds current as an input feature, reducing RMSE to approximately 2%. In the third model, SOC from the previous time step is also included with voltage and current and achieves an RMSE of less than 1% across all tested profiles. The results demonstrate that the proposed third neural network-based model significantly improves the accuracy and generalizability of SOC estimation under real-world EV driving conditions.

title: Agentic BDD Testing of Dialog Systems: Stabilizing the Dialog Manager via Failure-Driven Evolution
authors: Olga Dukić, Olga Ristić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We present a lightweight agentic framework for behavior-driven (BDD) testing of dialog systems. It runs YAML scenarios against a production Dialog Manager (DM) via a thin API and applies a two-layer test oracle (substring on text + expected DM state), logging per-step metrics. On an educational chatbot (3 flows, 6 scenarios), minor fixes improve 85/90 (94.4%) to 89/94 (94.7%) and cut flaky cases from 16.7% to 11.1%, with 100% pass in flows A and B. The framework acts as a CI/CD quality gate.

title: Circular Analysis of Long-Term GNSS Horizontal Positioning Error Time Series Observed in the Sub-Equatorial Region
authors: Lucija Žužić, Renato Filjar
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Ionospheric effects characterisation is a prerequisite for the development of robust and resilient GNSS Positioning, Navigation, and Timing (PNT) services needed for the modern GNSS-dependent society and civilisation. Here, we present the results of the study of circular properties of single-frequency commercial-grade Global Positioning System (GPS) horizontal positioning errors in the sub-equatorial scenario. The research reveals daily occurrence patterns of GNSS performance degradation in the observed region, thus setting the stage for improvements of the GNSS ionospheric error corrections.

title: How Helpful is AI, Really? Quantifying the Impact of Various Platforms on Student Exam Outcomes
authors: Aspasia Oikonomou, Ilias K. Savvas
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Teaching Quantum Computing is challenging. This study investigated if Artificial Intelligence (ChatGPT-4, Gemini 1.5 Pro, DeepSeek-V3) could enhance learning compared to traditional methods for University students without a strong background in physics. Results showed traditional methods were slightly superior for developing quantum literacy. A key AI limitation was difficulty processing essential visual diagrams. While promising, AI cannot yet fully replace conventional teaching, offering insights for integrating it into complex scientific pedagogy.

title: Linking Body, Behavior, and Perception: A Multi-Domain Clustering Approach to Elderly Health Profiling
authors: Nantaporn Ratisoontorn, Thanit Sinphatthakul, Korawat Phonyiam, Piyawan Thongploy
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The demographic transition toward an aging society has introduced diverse challenges linked to anthropometric characteristics, lifestyle behaviors, and health-related attitudes. An in-depth understanding of health determinants is crucial for clarifying how variations in elderly health and their underlying factors interact, thereby enabling the development of effective and tailored interventions. This paper presents a multi-domain clustering framework that integrates physical (body measurements and composition), behavioral (dietary and sedentary patterns), and perceptual (self-perceived weight and weight control intentions) domains. Beyond data expansion, the framework addresses a fundamental limitation in prior health modeling—the omission of self-perception as a mediating determinant linking physical conditions and behavioral responses. Using data from 400 Thai older adults, the study evaluates multiple clustering methods and examines perception-action links across clusters. The analysis shows that k-means clustering provides the most robust structure, identifying three distinct health profiles. The first group, with balanced gender representation, exhibits the largest body sizes and strong weight-loss intentions. The second, predominantly male, underestimates weight status and shows low motivation to change. The third, mainly low-income females, presents smaller body frames but relatively high fat percentages and frequent misperceptions, reflecting both perceptual and socioeconomic challenges. These findings highlight the interplay among gender, socioeconomic status, body composition, and perception in shaping elderly health and provide a foundation for more targeted strategies to support healthy aging.

title: A Large Language Model-Driven Multi-Agent Human-Machine Interaction Framework
authors: Libowen Wu, Huailin Zhao, Wen Zheng, Xiaohu Yuan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper proposes a multi-agent humanmachine collaboration framework driven by large language models (LLMs) to support natural language-based task execution in office environments. The system employs a twostage pipeline-command preprocessing and task execution—integrating functional agents for instruction correction, intent clarification, task planning, and multi-robot scheduling. Experiments in a real office setting demonstrate the system’s effectiveness in handling ambiguous and multi-task instructions with high accuracy and interaction flexibility.

title: Resource Monitoring in an Open Virtualized RAN
authors: Lavanya Malakalapalli, Abhishek Bhattacharyya, Andrea Fumagalli, Koteswararao Kondepu
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Virtualized Radio Access Networks (vRAN) enable flexible and scalable network architectures by decoupling RAN functions from proprietary hardware and deploying them as software components on general-purpose platforms. This allows for dynamic scaling of resources — such as allocating additional resources during peak hours to meet traffic demands and reducing resources when activity is low, thereby optimizing resource utilization and reducing operational costs. The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) introduces openness and intelligence into traditionally closed and hardware-driven RAN. In 3GPP TS 28.552, highlights the importance of 5G network performance measurements and management metrics essential for intelligent orchestration and optimization in vRAN environments. This study proposes a lightweight µApp to monitor infrastructure-level parameters — CPU usage, memory consumption, and disk I/O — at both the Centralized Unit (CU) and Distributed Unit (DU). By leveraging O-RAN interfaces and modular design, the proposed system improves real-time visibility into vRAN environments and supports intelligent orchestration through fine-grained system-level telemetry. In addition, the proposed framework can be used to change the metrics real-time with the help of the considered µApp. This allows dynamic scale-in/scale-out of computing resources depending on traffic loads, which allows reduction in Operating Expense (OpEx).

title: Real-time Elimination of Harmonic Drift for Hemispherical Resonator Gyro Based on FRP Control Scheme
authors: Hanshi Li, Weinan Xie, Qi Wang, Guoxing Yi, Changhong Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The performance of the hemispherical resonator gyroscope (HRG) in whole-angle (WA) mode is affected by the angle-dependent harmonic drift. Suppressing this drift is essential to improve its temperature stability and operational range. In this article, a novel real-time method for eliminating harmonic drift based on a forward and reverse precession (FRP) control scheme is proposed. First, the sources of harmonic drift in HRG are analyzed. The HRG dynamical equations incorporating multiple error sources are derived and analyzed through numerical simulation. Subsequently, a real-time error identification algorithm is developed and validated through simulation. Finally, a temperature experiment is conducted to validate the method. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method can accurately identify and compensate for errors at different temperatures, effectively suppressing the harmonic components in angular velocity by more than 97%. The bias instability (BI) of the HRG remains consistently around 0.024°/h across various temperatures, indicating strong temperature stability. Additionally, the scale factor nonlinearity (SFN) is reduced five-fold to 0.84 ppm. Most importantly, this method can be applied to all Coriolis vibratory gyroscopes to effectively eliminate their common angle-dependent harmonic drift.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp2-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Powering Data Centers: Business Case Insights into DC-Coupled Vs AC-Coupled PV with Bess
authors: Hamideh Bitaraf, Gian Schelling, Mauro Damonte, Alexandre Oudalov, Sharif Nackouzi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: As the global data center market is growing, the demand for utility-scale solar PV coupled with Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) is increasing. This study compares ACcoupled and DC-coupled solar PV systems with BESS as energy hubs for powering data centers. The analysis is conducted from the perspective of the energy hub developer, focusing on the Power Purchase Agreement (PPA) prices offered to data center operators. The DC-coupled configuration offers advantages by reducing transformer CAPEX due to smaller size requirements, higher efficiency, and enhancing economic feasibility. The findings evaluate the impact of solar PV investment, BESS investment, and internal rate of return management to offer competitive PPA prices, ensuring the economic viability of renewable energy solutions for data centers.

title: An Alternative Architectural Language
authors: Stefan Tubić, Zaharije Radivojević, Miloš Cvetanović, Saša Stojanović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Describing architectures of complex software systems involves multiple viewpoints and views which is supported by a number of architectural languages by creating views in separate places. This paper presents AFD an alternative architectural language for modeling complex software systems through functional decomposition and creation of views side by side. AFD streamlines translation of created descriptions to other architectural languages. Experiences with AFD in describing architectures of complex software systems and solving problems are also presented.

title: Design and Analysis of an Aerator to Reduce Biofouling on Ships
authors: Mariano Azzur Hernandez, Mariana Silva Ortega, Jesus Alberto Limon Baltazar, Veronica Garcia Valenzuela, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Biofouling on marine structures and ships is a global issue that requires significant attention. This causes a substantial increase in the aerodynamic drag of vessels and high maintenance costs. Therefore, we present an aeration-based method to reduce microbial fouling without chemical treatments. We evaluated its efficiency using a test structure (120 cm wide by 90 cm high) and experimental panels measuring 15× 20 cm. These were placed in underwater systems behind the panels, which injected air bubbles into the base of the structure to inhibit the formation of biofilms by microorganisms. These field trials were conducted at the Aeronautics Port in São José da Barra, Rio de Janeiro. This makes it an attractive, non-invasive, and sustainable system for treating these types of structures.

title: Synthetic Aperture Radar Position Estimation Using Stereo Cameras
authors: Adrian Oblu, Adrian Focsa, Cristina Despina-Stoian, Stefan Toma
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the development of a real-time 3D tracking system for a hand-held radar sensor intended for Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) imaging applications. Unlike conventional SAR platforms that utilize motorized translation stages or Global Positioning System (GPS)-based positioning, the proposed approach enables manual operation of the radar sensor along a quasi-linear trajectory. The sensor is continually detected using a deep learning approach and it's spatial position estimated using a stereo vision system comprising at least two synchronized video cameras. Through controlled experiments and SAR image simulations, we evaluate the performance of the tracking system and its suitability for coherent SAR image reconstruction. The results indicate that the achieved localization accuracy is sufficient to enable the application of robust autofocus algorithms, thereby supporting the feasibility of manually operated SAR imaging using vision-based position tracking.

title: Hybrid Permission–API GNNS with Temporal Descriptors and Adaptive Ensembles for Android Malware Detection
authors: Saatvik Arya, Minakshi Arya, Shubhavi Arya
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We present a hybrid Android malware detector that unifies permission-API GNNs, temporal descriptors, and an adaptive ensemble resilient to concept drift. Contributions: (1) heterogeneous GNN with attention on permission-API edges; (2) burst/delta/entropy features for evolving behavior; (3) ensemble reweighted by recent performance, calibration, subtype fit, and stability; (4) hierarchical, statistically validated explanations. On TUAN-DROMD (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4,464 \text{apps}$</tex>), across 17 models, the adaptive ensemble yields <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F} 1=0.9917 \pm 0.0023$</tex>; the hybrid GNN <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.9868 \pm 0.0023$</tex> state-of-the-art accuracy with actionable interpretations for real deployments.

title: Load Forecasting and Optimization of EV Charging for Grid Stability in Campus Microgrids
authors: Yaser Qudaih, Elham Jibril, Japi Gezachew, Nuhamin Denbel, Bezawit Tinsae, Mohd Sharizal Alias, Abdrabbi Bourezg
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Grid stability is threatened by growing numbers of electric vehicles (EVs), especially if charging is not planned. In this study, smart EV charging optimization is combined with short-term load forecasting to address this concern in the Higher Colleges of Technology campus in Dubai. A 24-hour baseline demand was forecast by using an artificial neural network (ANN) model. A 50-EV simulated fleet was scheduled using four metaheuristic algorithms: Differential Evolution Particle Swarm Optimization (DEPSO), Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), a GA-PSO hybrid, and Genetic Algorithm (GA) for peak demand reduction. Peak loads from peak of almost 680 kWh were successfully cut by the algorithms. Though DEPSO proved to be the most computationally efficient, the hybrid GA-PSO achieved the largest reduction, bringing the peak down by 27.4 %. In this study, it has been shown that, at the level of a campus, grid reliability can be enhanced using a simpler charging coordination system.

title: Non-Contact Heart Rate Monitoring with Millimeter-Wave Radar: Wavelet-AMP and Spectral Analysis Design
authors: Chi-Hung Wang, Yu-Hsiang Hsiang, Xiang-Shun Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Conventional heart-rate monitoring typically relies on adhesive Electrocardiography (ECG) electrodes or wrist-worn Photoplethysmography (PPG). These methods are effective but can compromise comfort during prolonged wear. They are also vulnerable to sweat, skin tone variation, and electrode loosening, which can degrade accuracy. In long-term clinical care or multiuser scenarios, frequent sensor replacement and disinfection are necessary, which increases the risk of cross-infection. We propose a non-contact heart-rate monitoring system based on the TI IWR6843AOPEVM 60-GHz Millimeter-Wave (mmWave) Frequency-Modulated Continuous-Wave Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (FMCW-MIMO) radar to address these limitations. The system first applies the Range-Angle Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) to localise reflections from the thoracic region. Cardiac-related echoes are then selected for subsequent analysis. In the signal-processing stage, we employ a Wavelet DenoisingAdaptive Moving-Average Amplitude Processing (WaveletAMP) pipeline. Wavelet denoising is used to suppress noise, followed by adaptive moving-average amplitude amplification to enhance subtle cardiac micro-displacements. Short-time spectral analysis is performed in the $0.8-2 \mathrm{~Hz}$ band, with additional strategies to reduce respiratory interference. Within each observation window, the median of per-packet estimates is reported. This approach minimizes the impact of outliers and transient noise. Experimental validation demonstrates that the proposed method yields a mean difference of approximately 1.3 beats per minute (bpm) compared to the electrocardiography (ECG) reference. The waveform trends also match closely. Overall, the technique avoids deep learning or computationally intensive spectrogram processing. It maintains a relatively low computational burden and can offer potential value for bedside monitoring and extended clinical care.

title: Data Integration Applications of Palmprint and Palm Vein Fusion Recognition in AIoT Systems
authors: Chi-Hung Wang, Xiang-Shun Yang, Zhi-Jia Huang, Hong-Cheng Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: With the improvement of information security and public health awareness, contactless biometric technology is gaining increasing attention. Palm prints and palm veins are heterogeneous and complementary, and are often used for identity verification, but a single feature is easy to imitate and offers limited protection. Although dual-feature fusion can enhance recognition accuracy, it remains susceptible to interference and alignment errors. As the sensing base expands, the centralized architecture faces challenges such as data integration and model synchronization delays, affecting overall performance. Thus, this study proposes a cloud recognition system combining palm print and vein. The system uses RGB and NIR dual camera modules to capture images synchronously. It improves fusion quality through adaptive grayscale conversion and weighted color channel overlay, while introducing a data-enhanced attention mechanism to focus on identifying areas. The images are stored in AWS S3, and Lambda triggers EC2 to perform YOLO v13 model recognition, with results written to DynamoDB for multi-point synchronization and centralized management. Experimental results show that fusion recognition accuracy reaches $\mathbf{9 9. 5 0 \%}$ (mAP@50), surpassing single-feature performance. Under the AIoT architecture, cloud inference only accounts for about one-fifth of local CPU usage, effectively reducing device load. Overall, this study optimizes non-contact image quality, verifies the feasibility of cloud integration, and compares recognition performance differences between devices and on-premises/cloud architectures.

title: Industrial Open RAN Deployment: A Comparative Performance Evaluation of Open and Commercial gNBs
authors: Hubert Djuitcheu, Khurshid Alam, Andrew Sergeev, Florian Spinty, Achim Autenrieth, Jörg-Peter Elbers, Jochen Seitz
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this work, we present a field evaluation of two Open radio access network (RAN) next generation NodeB (gNB) implementations—one open-source, based on OpenAirInterface (OAI), and one commercial-deployed in a real industrial factory hall. The testbed features disaggregated gNBs with a central unit (CU) and Distributed unit (DU) split, distinct radio units (RUs), and an OAI 5G core, covering an area of 39m × 20m. We measured key performance indicatorss (KPIs) such as latency, jitter, throughput, reference signal received power (RSRP), Signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio ratio (SINR), and energy consumption using a robot-mounted user equipment (UE) at 31 locations. The results reveal significant differences in KPIs between the two systems, despite nearly identical measurement conditions, which raises important questions about their suitability for industrial environments. By providing the comparative analysis of open-source and commercial gNB implementations in a real-world deployment, this paper offers valuable insights to guide the selection of reliable solutions for critical industry applications.

title: ML based Anomaly Detection for Enhanced 5G mmWave Beam Tracking in Transitory Environment
authors: Digvijay Katyal, Nenavath Srinu, Prince Arya, Sarvesha Anegundi Ganapathi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The deployment of 5G millimeter-wave (mmWave) technology has revolutionized wireless communication by providing high data rates and low latency. However, both short-term changes (such as moving pets or human hands) and long-term changes (such as human blockages) can severely impact the performance of beam tracking algorithms, which are essential for maintaining stable communication links in mmWave networks. This paper addresses the challenge of short-term changes in the environment resulting in sudden signal variations in 5G mmWave systems by proposing a novel anomaly detection setup.The proposed anomaly detection setup leverages machine learning-based techniques, specifically One-Class Support Vector Machine (OCSVM), Random Forest and XGBoost to effectively identify and mitigate anomalies over a few tens of milliseconds, improving the beam tracking operation. By detecting and handling such anomalies, the proposed anomaly detection setup enables beam tracking algorithms to maintain accurate and consistent communication links even in the presence of changing environments.To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, a comprehensive analysis is conducted using conventional beam tracking algorithm i.e. Round Robin (RR). The results show that the proposed anomaly detection setup significantly improves the accuracy and robustness of beam tracking by effectively mitigating the impact of short-term large signal variations, highlighting its utility even with conventional beam tracking algorithm.

title: Impact of ADAS and V2X Penetration Rates on Cooperative Active Safety
authors: M. C. Lucas-Estañ, B. Coll-Perales, M. I. Khan, J. Gozalvez, O. Altintas
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: A major driver of connected and automated driving is cooperative active safety. The effectiveness of cooperative safety applications depends on the ability of vehicles to detect traffic safety risks in advance. Such risks can be identified either through ADAS (Advanced Driving Assistance Systems) or via V2X (Vehicle to Everything) communications. More vehicles are gradually being deployed with ADAS, but ADAS sensors can be limited by their sensing range and field of view. On the other hand, V2X can experience communication ranges beyond the ADAS sensing range, but its impact is highly dependent on the V2X penetration rate. This paper analyzes the impact of ADAS and V2X penetration rates on the effectiveness of cooperative active safety applications considering an emergency braking maneuver use case in a highway scenario. Results show that while ADAS and V2X each enhance traffic safety, their combined deployment further amplifies these gains, with the effect becoming more pronounced as V2X is deployed more rapidly.

title: Mobility-Aware Resource Allocation in 5G O-RAN using ns-3
authors: Ashit Kumar Subudhi, Alex Piccioni, Andrea Marotta, Fabio Graziosi, Rajesh M. Hegde, Koteswararao Kondepu
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The growing multiple user elements devices in Beyond 5G (B5G) networks requires adaptive and effective radio resource allocation methods. The Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) structure enables this flexibility with architecture and RAN intelligent control mechanisms. Despite accounting for present conditions, traditional dynamic resource allocation approaches frequently fail to respond effectively to fast-changing user mobility patterns. The paper investigates resource allocation by employing Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Variational AutoEncoder (VAE) models to forecast UE requirements and the Channel Quality Indicator (CQI) by analyzing mobility patterns, thereby improving throughput. The evaluation is performed in ns-3, which accurately depicts the 5G O-RAN implementation. The results show that for the users with higher demands, the LSTM and VAE models increase the user throughput by 7<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">.</inf>25% and 14<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">.</inf>41% compared to dynamic users without any prediction model.

title: Fusion Edge Selection Method Using a Slime Mold Model
authors: Megumi Uza, Itsuki Kunita
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Adaptive structural changes in biological systems have attracted increasing attention in the field of information engineering, particularly in the context of network operations. These biological mechanisms have been applied to the design of various algorithms and optimization techniques. In network optimization, merging and integrating multiple networks requires careful selection of edges to ensure overall network stability and efficiency. In this study, we focus on the network formation behavior of the unicellular organism Physarum polycephalum, and propose a heuristic method for selecting fusion edges. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed method enables the selection of candidate fusion edges and the formation of fusion paths. Furthermore, the distribution of flow along the fusion paths formed by the proposed method was found to be rapid. However, the shortest path property of the fusion routes is not guaranteed, and parameter tuning is required depending on the network size and the number of nodes and edges. In future work, we aim to incorporate automatic parameter adjustment mechanisms and dynamic extraction of path candidates, which may enable gradual and adaptive network integration.

title: Research on the development of the modern industrial system empowered by artificial intelligence technology
authors: Ma Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The construction of a modern industrial chain and industrial system is an important part of promoting the construction of a modern economic system, which lays an important foundation for the construction of a modern power and will play a strategic supporting role for a long time. Based on artificial intelligence technology, it is an urgent need for China to build a modern industrial system and promote the industry to the middle and high-end level, and it is also an important measure to maintain the high-speed growth of the industrial economy. Based on the relevant yearbooks and survey data, this paper uses the DEA-Malmquist method to evaluate the R&D and innovation performance of the above-mentioned regional industrial base, compares the current situation of the construction of modern industrial system in Jiangsu, Shanghai, Zhejiang, Anhui, Guangdong, and Beijing, and analyzes the relevant industries in the four provinces and two cities in combination with the relevant data of the artificial intelligence industry chain. Strengthen the introduction and training of regional talents, and put forward countermeasures and suggestions for the construction of a modern industrial system empowered by artificial intelligence.

title: Crack-YOLO: A Instance Segmentation Algorithm for Pavement Crack Based on YOLOv8
authors: Ruijun Yang, Zhichao Zhou
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: In order to solve the problems of low accuracy of existing crack recognition algorithms and independent detection and segmentation tasks, a road crack instance segmentation algorithm based on an improved YOLOv8 model is proposed. In the original backbone network, DSConv was introduced to improve the c2f module, enhancing feature extraction capabilities while maintaining computing speed; Secondly, SCSA attention mechanism was added to the neck network to further enhance feature extraction capability and improve detection accuracy. The experimental results on the open-source dataset Crack-seg show that the mAP50 of the proposed method for the target box (BBox) and mask (Mask) has increased by 3.1% and 4.6% respectively compared to the original algorithm.

title: A Field Study of Prompt Programming with LLM
authors: Daichi Deguchi, Tomoya Senda, Yusuke Kajiwara
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study investigates prompt programming for K-12 learners in anticipation of language-driven robot operations. We built an “AI programmer” platform that splits roles: learners plan and test in natural language (requirements, test criteria, defect reports) while a large language model (GPT40) designs and revises executable code. In a two-hour cameraapp workshop with 24 Japanese students aged 9-13 (no prior LLM programming), participants iteratively specified, generated, tested, and refined features. About 80% reached a self-defined challenge task; self-reports across process understanding, creativity, transfer, and post-interest averaged $\approx 3 / 4$, with the achiever group scoring $\geq 1$ point higher on completeness, transfer, interest after, and ease of addition/modification. Rapid arrival at a working artifact appeared to boost self-efficacy and creative expression. Frictions included response variability, fragile coordinate/dimension handling, and naming inconsistencies, motivating safety nets that combine automated tests, lightweight static checks, and self-repair prompts. Limitations include a single-country, short-term sample and one model; future work will broaden contexts and integrate automated testing pipelines.

title: Kubernetes based Microservice Placement with Dynamic Resource Allocation
authors: Adnan I S, Sandeep G, S Prabhas, Navin Kumar, Satya Kumar Vankayala, Sandesh Komarala, Seungil Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper addresses the critical challenge of dynamic resource allocation for Kubernetes-based microservice placement, which plays a pivotal role in optimizing resource utilization and ensuring scalability in cloud environments. Efficient resource allocation is essential as it directly impacts system performance, cost efficiency, and the ability to meet real-time demands in distributed computing systems. A comprehensive approach combining simulation and modeling techniques is proposed to develop an effective solution for resource management. Experimental results demonstrate a significant improvement in resource utilization by 82% and a reduction in latency by almost 19 ms, validated through rigorous testing scenarios. The proposed framework offers a robust solution for microservice orchestration, providing valuable insights for cloud service providers and developers, and advancing resource management strategies in modern computing systems.

title: Parameter-Free Dual-Granularity Weighted Multi-View Fuzzy $c$-Means Clustering
authors: Zhe Liu, Jiahao Shi, Sukumar Letchmunan, Yulong Huang, Muhammet Deveci
publish: IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems
abstract: It remains a challenge in multi-view clustering to effectively integrate heterogeneous views while reducing the impact of noise and redundancy. To tackle this issue, we propose a parameter-free dual-granularity weighted multi-view fuzzy <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$c$</tex-math></inline-formula>-means clustering framework. The basic idea is to introduce a product-to-one constraint at both the view and attribute levels, enabling adaptive and balanced weight assignment without introducing extra parameters. Two weighting strategies are developed: (i) vector-form weighting, which assigns global importance to views and attributes, and (ii) matrix-form weighting, which further captures cluster-specific relevance. Moreover, both Euclidean and non-Euclidean (exponential transformation) distance measures are incorporated, yielding four algorithmic variants: PDW-MFC-V, PDW-MFC-M, PDW-MAFC-V, and PDW-MAFC-M. Extensive experiments on nine real-world datasets show that our algorithms outperform thirteen related algorithms across multiple metrics. These results confirm that dual-granularity weighting effectively models the relative importance of views and attributes, while the non-Euclidean distance improves robustness to noise. Overall, the proposed framework offers a flexible, parameter-free, and robust solution for multi-view clustering, providing fine-grained interpretability and stable performance across diverse datasets.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp6-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.

title: Fundamental Limits of Coded Caching with Fixed Subpacketization
authors: Minquan Cheng, Yifei Huang, Youlong Wu, Jinyan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Communications
abstract: Coded caching is a promising technique to create coded multicast opportunities for cache-aided networks. By splitting each file into F equal packets (i.e., the subpacketization level F) and letting each user cache a set of packets, the transmission load can be significantly reduced via coded multicasting. It has been shown that a higher subpacketization level could potentially lead to a lower transmission load, as more packets can be combined for efficient transmission. On the other hand, a larger F indicates a higher coding complexity and is problematic from a practical perspective when F is extremely large. Despite many works attempting to design coded caching schemes with low subpacketization levels, a fundamental problem remains open: What is the minimum transmission load given any fixed subpacketization level? In this paper, we consider the classical cache-aided networks with identically uncoded placement and one-shot delivery strategy, and investigate the fundamental trade-off between the transmission load and the subpacketization level. We propose a general lower bound on the transmission load for any fixed subpacketization by reformulating the centralized coded caching schemes via the combinatorial structure of the corresponding placement delivery array. The lower bound also recovers existing optimality results for the bipartite graph scheme (including the well-known Maddah-Ali and Niesen (MN) scheme and the conjugate MN scheme) as well as the grouping bipartite graph scheme. Furthermore, by carefully exploiting the combinatorial structure and computing the union size of sorted sets, we establish a new optimality result, i.e., the partition scheme can achieve the optimal rate-subpacketization trade-off.
