title: Design and Functional Simulation of a Specialized EEPROM for Reliable Storage of Physiological Data in FPGA Environments Using Xilinx ISE
authors: Jazmín Stephanie Hernández Martínez, Zaid Segundo Hernández Martínez, Daemon Vera, Victor Champac, Pedro Mabil-Espinosa, Jaime Martínez-Castillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The design and simulation of a specialized EEPROM memory for storing photoplethysmography (PPG) signals represents a significant contribution to biomedical engineering. This work presents the development of an EEPROM model designed in VHDL and simulated on the Xilinx ISE platform. The architecture is tailored to handle PPG signals, widely used in clinical and research environments to analyze cardiovascular conditions. Control signals such as clock (CLK), reset (RST), chip enable (CE), write enable (WE), and output enable (OE) were implemented, enabling complete control of read, write, and erase operations. A testbench validated memory performance under various scenarios, measuring capacity, speed, latency, and signal integrity. Simulation results show successful storage, retrieval, and erasure of data while maintaining fidelity with the input signal. This research demonstrates that specialized memory can serve as an efficient, cost-effective, and adaptable solution for portable or embedded biomedical devices requiring low power consumption and reliability.

title: Multi-Authority Attribute-Based Encryption With Attribute Verification Using Zero Knowledge Proofs
authors: Alejandro Peñuelas-Angulo, Claudia Feregrino-Uribe, Miguel Morales-Sandoval
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Multi-authority Attribute-based Encryption (MAABE) schemes distribute the responsibility of managing the scheme attributes and attribute keys among several attribute authorities. However, MA-ABE schemes often assume that the attribute authorities are always fully trusted parties and lack authenticity checks. This paper proposes a Ciphertext-Policy MAABE scheme that incorporates a user-authority mutual authentication mechanism exploiting the properties of Zero-Knowledge Proofs. A batch version of the Schnorr protocol validates the authority identity and the possession of claimed attribute keys. The complete scheme is enhanced using asymmetric pairings to improve security and performance. Furthermore, outsourced decryption is considered to exploit the available computing resources under a fog-enabled IoT environment. The proposed scheme's analysis shows the overall construction's efficiency and, particularly, the efficiency and suitability of the mutual verification protocol.

title: Prediction Air Temperature in Geothermal Heat Exchangers Using Pseudorandom Numbers: The New DARL Model
authors: C. Ramírez-Dolores, J.C. Zamora-Luria, J.A. Altamirano-Acosta, L. Sarao-Cruz, P. Jiménez-Palma, J. Moreno-Falconi
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The use of Earth-Air-Water Heat Exchangers (EAWHE) for sustainable air conditioning has not been widely studied. Due to their experimental nature, methods of characterizing internal thermal air distribution impose high dependence on instrumentation by sensors and entail data acquisition and computational costs. This document presents an alternative method that estimates air temperature distribution while minimizing the need for a dense network of sensors in the experimental system. The proposed model, DARL (Data of Air and Random Length), can predict the temperature of air circulating inside EAWHEs. DARL is a significant methodological advance that integrates experimental data from boundary conditions with simulations based on pseudo-random numbers (PRNs). These PRNs are generated using Fermat's prime numbers as seeds to initialize the generator. Ordinary linear regressions and robust statistical validations, including the Shapiro-Wilk test and root mean square error, have demonstrated that the model can estimate the thermal distribution of air at different lengths with a relative error of less than 6.2 %. These results demonstrate the model's efficiency, predictive capacity, and potential to reduce dependence on sensors. The model is thus established as a viable alternative for designing, evaluating, and optimizing geothermal systems under real operating conditions.

title: Optimization of Cnn Architectures for Training on Resource-Constrained Edge Devices Using Pso
authors: Vladimir Nikic, Dusan Bortnik, Milan Lukic, Ivan Mezei
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Deploying convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on edge devices is challenging due to strict memory and computational limitations. This work introduces an improved particle swarm optimization (PSO) approach for neural architecture search, specifically adapted for memory-constrained environments. The method incorporates memory-aware initialization and a fitness evaluation mechanism that penalizes infeasible models, ensuring architectures remain within predefined memory budgets. To assess its performance, a digit classification dataset was employed, and the algorithm was evaluated under four memory constraints (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$128,256,512$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1024 \mathbf{k B}$</tex>). Experimental results show that the proposed method consistently produces efficient architectures and achieves up to 99.05 % accuracy within a 1024 kB memory budget, demonstrating its suitability for resource-constrained edge deployment.

title: Evolving Protection Frameworks for Smaller Microgrids
authors: Umme Mumtahina, Sanath Alahakoon, Peter Wolfs
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper examines protection system strategies for microgrids with capacities up to a few megawatts and compares them to traditional protection schemes used in transmission and distribution systems. These microgrids, often powered by distributed energy resources (DERs) such as solar PV and battery storage, introduce unique challenges due to limited fault currents, bidirectional power flows, and frequent transitions between grid-connected and islanded modes. In grid-connected mode, conventional protection may suffice, but in islanded operation, adaptive protection schemes are necessary—particularly to address low fault current scenarios. The paper explores solutions across various microgrid sizes, from LV networks below 200 kVA, where sensitive earth fault detection remains viable, to MV/LV networks where directional impedance and differential protection are recommended. Communication-assisted schemes and star topologies are also discussed for improved selectivity and coordination. Overall, the paper emphasizes the need for flexible, adaptive protection frameworks that accommodate the dynamic behavior of microgrids while ensuring safety and reliability.

title: Optimal Energy Scheduling for Enhanced Resilience in Clustered Microgrids Integrating Hydrogen Storage and Demand Response
authors: Ahmed Babiker, Saba Al-Mubark, Fahad Al-Ismail
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Nowadays, due to rapid development and industrialization climate change becomes more severe and results in more frequent occurrences of natural disasters, such as hurricanes, storms, and heat waves. Such phenomena are exerting pressures on the power grids that have never been experienced before, resulting in blackouts and the subsequent disruptions of societies. This paper proposes a Preventive Resilience Optimization Framework (PROF) to build a more resilient power system by integrating hydrogen (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex>) energy and controllable distributed generators (CDGs) into networked microgrids (NMGs). Instead of just focusing on how to recover after a disaster and ensure that power systems remain stable and reliable even in the face of increasingly frequent and severe natural disasters. The framework is developed using mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) to minimize operational costs and maximize resilience by reducing dependence on the main utility grid. By incorporating large-scale and long-duration <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{H}_{2}$</tex> energy storage solutions the framework aims to provide a reliable and sustainable energy supply during and after extreme events. The findings demonstrate that the preventive framework incorporating hydrogen systems and controllable distributed generators significantly reduces operational costs during critical outages.

title: Web Application for Predicting Image Memorability Using a Machine Learning Model
authors: Valerijan Matvejev, Dražen Drašković, Boško Nikolić, Dragan Bojić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Visual attention i.e. the automatic selection of the most important information within a visual stimulus - is a topic within computer vision that attracts considerable scholarly interest. In this study, the focus was on examining the complex relationship between covert (implicit, hidden) and overt (explicit, observable) attention and human memory through a memorability experiment on static images. Thirty images for the experiment were selected from the FIGRIM [1] dataset. The collected eye-tracking data were first used to compute fixation maps and visual saliency maps, and then the IOVC (Inter-Observer Visual Congruency) metric; together with the percentage of successful image memorization (the memorability score), these served as the key parameters of the study. A significant correlation between the IOVC score and the memorability score indicated the possibility of automating the prediction of whether viewing an image would lead to successful memorization based solely on its fixation map. Inspired by this insight, we first trained a machine learning model on the collected viewing data to infer, from a fixation map, which of the 30 images had been viewed. The goal was to train a classifier capable of distinguishing images using only their viewing (eye-tracking) data. The trained model achieved close to 90% accuracy in determining whether an arbitrary fixation map would lead to successful memorization of the given image. A web application that could be used for commercial use for memorability prediction was developed.

title: Analysing and Improving National Renewable Energy Forecasts: A Case Study in Belgium
authors: Ada Canaydin, Zeynep Benay Uslu, Joris Depoortere, Fahad Mehmood, Hussain Kazmi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The installed capacity for renewable energy capacity has grown significantly in many countries in recent years. In Belgium, solar and wind energy capacity rose from under 5 GW in 2016 to about 15 GW by 2024, with considerable further expansion foreseen in the coming years. Transmission system operators (TSOs) must manage generation data from renewable sources and provide accurate forecasts to balance electricity supply with demand. Poor data quality and large forecast errors can disrupt grid operations and lead to costly interventions to minimize imbalances and congestions etc. In this paper, we examine the energy generation data and forecasts publicly shared by Belgium's TSO, Elia as part of its transparency commitments. Our analysis finds some minor data quality issues, but a tripling in (absolute) forecast errors for solar and wind energy from 2017 to 2024 across various time scales. Our analysis also shows that while it plays a part, these errors cannot be attributed solely to capacity growth, highlighting a decline in forecasting accuracy. We also show that machine learning techniques can improve these existing forecasts with publicly available data, and consequently reduce balancing and system operation costs.

title: Assessment of Carbon Intensity and Carbon Payback Period for Domestic Photovoltaic Systems
authors: Khadijah Khan, Hayder Ali, Hassan Abbas Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems play a significant role in the global shift toward sustainable energy, offering a distributed and emissions-free power source. While PV systems produce clean energy during operation, their production and installation still generate greenhouse gas emissions (GHGs). Key factors such as module technology, geographic location, and the local energy grid's emission profile affect the Carbon Intensity (CI) and Carbon Payback Period (CPBP) of these systems. This paper introduces a framework for calculating CI and CPBP specifically for domestic PV installations and examines the impact of different PV module technologies. To illustrate the framework's application, a case study was conducted on two 42 kWp PV systems installed in Lahore, Pakistan, allowing for a comparison of module technologies. Empirical data showed that the CI for polycrystalline silicon (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p - S i}$</tex>) modules was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 3. 4} \text{gCO}_{2} / \mathbf{k W h}$</tex>, while for Copper Indium Selenide (CIS) modules, it was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 8. 6} \mathbf{g C O}_{\mathbf{2}} / \mathbf{k W h}$</tex>. The CPBP was calculated at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1. 6 6}$</tex> years for the p-Si system and 2.24 years for the CIS system. The methodology presented gives insights into the environmental performance of solar PV deployments and can be extended to evaluate key environmental metrics (CI and CPBP) for multiple module technologies in different regionsKeywords-Carbon intensity, carbon payback period, lifecycle assessment, photovoltaics, sustainability

title: Circuit Breaker Surface Icon Recognition Based on an Improved YOLOv8 Approach
authors: Xunan Wu, Xizhong Shen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To address the challenges of missed detections caused by inconsistent icon scales on circuit breaker surfaces and the difficulty in balancing detection performance with computational complexity in existing detection models, this paper proposes an improved YOLOv8-based detection method for circuit breaker surface icons to meet industrial application requirements. Specifically, to enhance detection accuracy without increasing model complexity, the SRA attention module is integrated into the backbone network to fuse spatial positional information of icons and improve feature extraction capabilities. Subsequently, to further strengthen the model’s multi-scale perception, a Bidirectional Feature Pyramid Network (BiFPN) is incorporated into the neck network. This architecture effectively aggregates multi-scale feature information by incorporating weighted bidirectional connections and a feature reuse mechanism. The improved network is termed FSI-YOLO. Training and comparative experiments were conducted on a selfbuilt circuit breaker surface icon datasets comprising $\mathbf{1, 8 0 0}$ images. Experimental results demonstrate that compared to YOLOv8n, the improved network achieves 1.3 and 3.1 percentage point improvements in $\mathrm{mAP}(0.5)$ and $\mathrm{mAP}(0.95)$, respectively.

title: Integrating Retrieval-Augmented Generation and Large Language Models for Financial Question Answering
authors: Yu-Jen Chen, Ping-Han Chen, Tzu-Chia Tung, Yung-Chien Chou, Yu-Chin Chu, Sian-Wun Du, Wei-Chien Wang, Chiou-Shann Fuh, Chung-Ming Yang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Customer service systems in the financial industry require accurate and effi-cient question-answering solutions. Traditional methods, such as rule-based chatbots, struggle with complex queries, while Large Language Models (LLMs) face challenges like hallucination and outdated knowledge. This study explores the effectiveness of Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) in answering financial questions using various retrieval methods, including BM25, embedding models, and reranker models. Experimental results show that BM25 is the fastest but less accurate, while the Reranker Model achieves the highest accuracy $(0.8933)$ at a high computational cost. The best balance is found by combining BM25, a Reranker Model, and Recursive Token Chunker, improving accuracy (0.92) while reducing execution time (2427 seconds). This approach enhances AI-driven financial services by providing reliable and up-to-date responses.

title: Intelligent Surfaces for Intelligent Sensing: A 5G NR-Based CommSense Approach using RIS
authors: Pooja Yadav, Rubeena Aafreen, Mohammed Zafar Ali Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) enable programmable wireless propagation environments that can enhance both communication and sensing performance. This paper introduces a RIS-assisted CommSense system leveraging 5G New Radio (NR) OFDM waveforms for environmental sensing and channel-state discrimination. Unlike prior works that rely on brute-force or heuristic phase searches, we propose an analytical per-element RIS phase alignment rule that coherently combines cascaded RIS paths and supports finite-bit quantization modeling for practical hardware. The proposed method achieves $\mathcal{O}(M)$ computational complexity, significantly lower than randomized-trial baselines $\left( {\mathcal{O}(TM)} \right)$, while maintaining comparable or improved performance. We further refine the framework with a hybrid local-search extension for robustness under imperfect CSI. The paper also clarifies the two-hop path-loss model, defines all units, and provides an explicit LoS channel formulation for hybrid LoS+RIS links. Simulation results using standardized Clustered Delay Line (CDL) and Tapped Delay Line (TDL) channel profiles demonstrate enhanced channel discriminability and provide insight into why CDL-based channels exhibit stronger PCA separability than TDL counterparts. This study bridges analytical modeling, algorithmic efficiency, and interpretability for RIS-enabled 5G CommSense systems.

title: Point cloud matching-based AR navigation for robot-assisted laparoscopic partial nephrectomy
authors: Masanao Koeda, Toshihiro Magaribuchi, Atsuro Sawada, Katsuhiko Onishi, Hiroshi Noborio
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper describes the robot-assisted partial nephrectomy support system with Augmented Reality that we are developing. This system is based on point cloud matching between the intra-abdominal point cloud generated from stereo endoscopic camera images and the patient’s organ 3DCG model. By overlaying these point clouds with the matching results, it enables the accurate and intuitive visualization of tumor locations and the positions of blood vessels and other structures.

title: Optimization of Kinematic Control Laws in Differential Robots Using the White Shark Optimizer
authors: Luis M. Nieto, Diego Restrepo-Leal, José R. Rivera-Ruiz, Luis D. Ramírez-González, Edson E. Cruz-Miguel, José R. García-Martínez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the application of the White Shark Optimizer (WSO), a bio-inspired metaheuristic, for the automatic tuning of kinematic controllers in differential-drive robots. Unlike traditional approaches that rely on manual tuning or deterministic optimization, WSO leverages global search strategies to determine optimal controller gains, ensuring accurate trajectory tracking under non-holonomic constraints. The methodology is validated through simulations of circular and lemniscate-shaped trajectories, where the objective function is defined as the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) between the desired and actual trajectories. Results show that the proposed approach achieves highly accurate tracking with RMSE values close to 0.028 m in both scenarios, demonstrating WSO's efficiency, convergence stability, and potential as a competitive alternative to classical optimization methods in mobile robotics.

title: Spatial Patterns of Access to Water and Housing in Municipalities of the Mexican Republic: Structural Challenges for Sustainable Development and Smart Cities
authors: José Luis Hernández González, Rodolfo Eleazar Pérez Loaiza, Perfecto Malaquías Quintero Flores
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Building smart cities requires well-defined public policies. The use of new technologies allows improving the quality of life of their inhabitants, but the uncontrolled growth of large metropolises slows down sustainable urban development. It is necessary to identify clusters that prioritize the attention of structural problems. The present work refers to the United Nations (UN) Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 6 and 11, related to the consumption of drinking water and housing, based on spatial data that make it possible to identify critical patterns to guide public policies. The objective is to analyze the spatial autocorrelation of water use and housing in 2469 municipalities of the Mexican Republic, identifying relevant clusters for sustainable development. The database of the 2020 Population and Housing Survey of the National Institute of Statistics, Geography and Informatics (INEGI) was used, transforming the variables TVIVHAB, OCUPVIVPAR, VPH_AGUADV, among others, to correct biases. Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (ESDA) is carried out, which includes histograms, thematic maps, and scatter plots. The Moran's index revealed a positive autocorrelation of 0.78 for population density and high clusters surrounded by high neighbors in 28 percent of the municipalities identified through Local Indicators of Spatial Association (LISA). Thematic maps highlight critical areas of low service coverage, underlining the need for integrated policies to improve water and housing infrastructure, which contribute to sustainable urban development in accordance with what a Sustainable Urban Development policy implies from the perspective of the smart cities paradigm

title: Optimized SCADA Alarm Management Strategies for Power Distribution Network
authors: Gagandeep Singh Dua, Ansu Mathew, Sajan K. Sadanandan, Shiraj Shaikh, Omar Hukal, Abdulrahman Aljasmi, Ahmad Ahli, Tareg Ghaoud
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Alarm management in SCADA-driven power distribution networks remains a significant challenge, often over-whelming control room operators and compromising timely fault identification. This paper presents an integrated alarm management methodology to address alarm overload, redundancy, and poor geospatial association. Initially, a Python-based pre-processing engine is developed that performs operations such as cleaning, transformation and integration to handle raw SCADA alarm data. Subsequently, an advanced data-driven algorithm is implemented for classifying alarm groups, specifically battery charger alarms from the distribution automation (DA) secondary substation, thereby reducing the dependence on manual operator inspection. Furthermore, filtering techniques are designed to eliminate redundancies and prioritize critical alarms, along with a pattern recognition module that detects recurring power factor limit violations alarms and generates operator notifications. Additionally, to improve fault localization, an automated alarm correlation approach is created that links secondary substation events with the upstream network topology. The proposed modules are validated using real-world SCADA data from a utility in Dubai. The results demonstrate a significant reduction in alarm volume (e.g., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-40 {\%}$</tex> for voltage-related alarms), enhanced situational awareness through pattern recognition, and faster fault diagnosis enabled by alarm correlation. This work contributes to a scalable and interpretable framework for enhancing operational efficiency and resilience in power distribution control systems.

title: GraphNNK - Graph Classification and Interpretability
authors: Željko Bolević, Miloš Brajović, Isidora Stanković, Ljubiša Stanković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have become a standard approach for learning from graph-structured data. However, their reliance on parametric classifiers (most often linear softmax layers) limits interpretability and sometimes hinders generalization. Recent work on interpolation-based methods, particularly Non-Negative Kernel regression (NNK), has demonstrated that predictions can be expressed as convex combinations of similar training examples in the embedding space, yielding both theoretical results and interpretable explanations.

title: Improved SLAM Accuracy for Agricultural Robots via Depth Image Reconstruction
authors: Nikolay Gapon, Viacheslav Voronin, Marina Zhdanova, Alexander Zelensky, Evgenii Semenishchev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The study aims to improve the accuracy of autonomous positioning of agricultural robots by developing a new method for reconstructing deep images for SLAM systems. The developed method addresses the problem of data loss and involves hierarchical search for similar blocks and merging the found blocks using a neural network architecture. Testing on the Rosario dataset, which contains complex agricultural scenarios, demonstrated a significant improvement in the quality of depth maps. Compared to existing analogs, the mean error (RMSE) decreased by 20-30%, and the PSNR and SSIM metrics increased by 20-30%. The S-MSCKF algorithm was used to evaluate the impact on SLAM. After applying the reconstruction, the absolute trajectory error (ATE) decreased from 0.62 m to 0.25 m, and the RMSE decreased from 0.85 m to 0.39 m. The method significantly improves the accuracy of SLAM in challenging conditions, such as uneven terrain and variable lighting, and has high potential for implementation in autonomous agricultural machinery systems, increasing their reliability and safety.

title: Artificial Intelligence Noise Estimation for Adaptive Energy Detection in Dynamic Radio Environments
authors: Partemie-Marian Mutescu, Valentin Popa, Alexandru Lavric
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The expansion of wireless technologies such as IoT, 5G, and connected vehicles has significantly increased the demand for radio spectrum access, challenging conventional spectrum methods such as energy detection. The main purpose of spectrum sensing energy detection algorithms is to determine the state of the radio communication channel in order to avoid packet collisions and maintain a high level of performance. However, energy detection suffers in low signal-to-noise (SNR) environments and under dynamic channel conditions due to fixed threshold dependency and inaccurate noise estimation. This paper presents a novel framework for energy detection that embeds a feedforward neural network to enhance noise estimation for adaptive threshold computation without prior SNR parameter knowledge. Beyond wireless communications, the proposed method also supports ICT-driven infrastructures such as smart grids and IoT-based energy systems, where reliable spectrum sensing is essential for secure, scalable, and efficient data exchange. The main advantage of our approach is to increase detection capabilities in both low-SNR and dynamic spectrum environments by using a novel AI framework able to estimate the noise level and enhance radio channel state detection.

title: HVTC-GAN: A High-level Vision Task Cooperative GAN for SAR-to-Optical translation via Semantic Segmentation
authors: Hang Liu, Jiarui Lin, Cang Gu, Yujie Zhang, Huihui Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR), an active remote sensing technology that can be deployed on various aerial plat forms, generates images by emitting microwaves and analyzing the intensity of backscattered signals. The penetration capability of microwaves enables observation of Earth at all weather, day and night, broadening the application of SAR. However, SAR image interpretation remains challenging for non-experts. In contrast, optical images provide intuitive visual features but are weather-sensitive. To synergize these modalities, SAR-to-Optical Translation (S2OT) has gained research attention, but most studies prioritize visual quality or similarity metrics over practical applicability to downstream tasks. This study proposes a high level vision task-coordinated S2OT framework to address this gap. Semantic segmentation, emulating land cover classification, is integrated as the downstream task. Semantic segmentation loss guides the network to generate optical images that enhance task-relevant features. To preserve structural information in SAR images, we introduce SSIM loss and incorporate SAR derived semantic segmentation maps as auxiliary inputs. An identity loss further aligns the distributions of generated and real optical images, mitigating domain discrepancies. Extensive experiments confirm that S2OT improves downstream land cover classification. The inclusion of task-specific losses elevates translation quality: our HVTC-GAN surpasses the baseline methods in SSIM and PSNR metrics. Ablation studies validate the effectiveness of co-training S2OT with high-level vision tasks, demonstrating that task-oriented constraints enhance both translation fidelity and downstream utility. Code will be available at https://github.com/NWPU-LHH/HVTC-GAN

title: Design and Control of an Electrolytic Capacitorless Three-Phase On-Board Charger Based on Active Third-Harmonic Current Injection
authors: Chandrima Chatterjee, Soumya Shubhra Nag, Thomas Ebel
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: On-board chargers (OBCs) with conventional two-stage architecture, consisting of an active front-end (AFE) converter and an isolated dc-dc stage, require bulky line filters and dc-link capacitors, resulting in low volumetric efficiency. Active third-harmonic injection and current unfolding methods offer significant improvement in terms of efficiency and power density in power factor correction (PFC) applications. However, existing unfolding-based topologies require two isolated dc-dc converters capable of handling the rated power for PFC and output voltage regulation. This article presents a three-phase ac-dc converter with a third-harmonic current injection circuit that processes a fraction of the total power and a single isolated dc-dc converter for galvanic isolation. Line frequency switching in the rectifier produces varying dc-link voltages, eliminating the requirement of bulky electrolytic capacitors. The article discusses detailed operation and design procedures along with an elaborate comparative analysis between the proposed topology and the conventional two-stage and Swiss rectifier-based isolated topologies. A 6.6 kW prototype is developed and tested for experimental validation of the system in both balanced and unbalanced grid conditions. The experimental results demonstrate unity power factor (upf) operation throughout the operating range, achieving a peak efficiency above 97%.

title: Joint Design of Optical Phased Array Beamforming and OFDM Waveform in Optical Wireless Integrated Sensing and Communication
authors: Yunfeng Wen, Fang Yang, Jian Song, Zhu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Beamforming and waveform design are key essentials for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) in future wireless networks, which also inspires the emerging research of optical wireless ISAC (OW-ISAC). In this paper, we investigate the joint design of optical phased array (OPA) beamforming and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) waveform, thus extending the radio-frequency (RF)-ISAC paradigm to the optical band. First, the system model for the OPA-based OW-ISAC framework is introduced to facilitate simultaneous communication and sensing. Next, signal processing techniques are tailored for an optical OFDM waveform with precisely separated communication and sensing subcarriers. Then, the joint optimization problem of OPA beamforming and OFDM waveform design is formulated, decomposed, and resolved to reach a flexible compromise between communication and sensing performances. Moreover, numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed OW-ISAC scheme and reveal the trade-off between communication and sensing functionalities. Consequently, the capabilities of reliable communication and precise sensing will establish OW-ISAC as a powerful complement to RF-ISAC in the near future.

title: A Novel Adaptive Transform for Fetal Heart Rate Estimation
authors: Diego Seuret-Jiménez, Daily Quintana-Fuentes, José Manuel Nieto-Jalil, Damian Valdés-Santiago, Eduardo Trutié-Carrero
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study introduces the Adaptive Transform, a novel mathematical tool designed to analyze the frequency spectrum of filtered signals, offering an innovative integration of adaptive filtering and Fourier-based analysis. This technique dynamically adjusts its parameters based on the characteristics of the analyzed signal. Its main advantages include increased sensitivity to specific events, reduced interference from crossterms, and improved accuracy in detecting transient events. The researchers applied this new transform to abdominal electrocardiogram (AECG) signals from pregnant women to directly obtain the fetal heart rate (FHR). Using public data from the PhysioNet abdominal and direct fetal ECG database, the Adaptive Transform was applied to the AECG signals, achieving highly accurate FHR estimation. The extracted signal exhibited a spectral peak at 2.18097 Hz, with an absolute error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.7 \times 10^{-4}$</tex> Hz compared to the reference direct fetal electrocardiogram (FECG). These results position the Adaptive Transform as a promising tool for robust spectral analysis in fetal monitoring applications and other signal processing domains.

title: Multi-Task Learning Framework for Spanish Speech Emotion Recognition
authors: Alex Mares, Gerardo Diaz-Arango, Hector Vazquez-Leal, Jorge Eduardo Perez-Jacome-Friscione, Luis Hernandez-Martinez, Jose Luis Vazquez-Gonzalez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In this work, we present preliminary results from the first multi-task learning (MTL) framework for Spanish Speech Emotion Recognition, jointly predicting emotions, speaker profile, and regional accent from a unified six-corpus dataset. Using Pre-Trained Model embeddings with MTL, our system achieves <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0. 5 6 \%}$</tex> weighted F1-Score, +2.8 pp over the singletask baseline, with strong gains in underrepresented classes (e.g., Sadness <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 4. 3 6} \mathbf{~ p p}$</tex>). Speaker and accent recognition exceed 99.5% weighted F1-Score, reinforcing emotional decoding. Compared to prior work, MTL yields substantial improvements on challenging corpora (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{+ 3 0}$</tex> pp on EmoWisconsin, +2.02 pp on EmoMatchSpanishDB) and natural speech, underscoring its robustness for realworld applications. Additional resources and model details are available at: https://alxmares.github.io/HUB_Spanish_SER_HCI.

title: Expert-V: a Modular Virtual Laboratory System With Advanced Virtual Reality Simulation for Engineering Education
authors: Martin Hernández-Ordoñez, Arely Morales-Lastra, Rafael Rivera-López, Yael López-González, Pedro Lázaro-Gutiérrez, Altagracia Caridad Medina-Santiago, Gerardo Emilio Bravo-Ortigoza, Roberto Jerez-García
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Engineering education continues to face challenges related to limited access to laboratories, high equipment costs, and safety restrictions. This paper presents EXPERT-V, a modular virtual laboratory system that combines immersive VR simulation, adaptive AI analytics, and affordable hardware. The platform is implemented with Unreal Engine and validated through a robotic arm laboratory, achieving realistic kinematic modeling. Preliminary results demonstrate stable performance at 112 FPS with latency below 20 ms on mid-range computers. Cost analysis reveals a reduction of more than 90 % compared to physical laboratories, while maintaining pedagogical value through the provision of safe, interactive, and motivating learning experiences. EXPERT-V offers a scalable and context-aware solution that democratizes access to practical training, contributing to the reduction of educational inequities in Latin America.

title: Adaptive Cybersecurity for Industrial Environments Using Evolutionary Algorithms: A Methodological Proposal
authors: J. E. Soto Soto, J.I. Hernández-Vega, L. E. Gómez-Sánchez, L. A. Reynoso-Guajardo, C. Hernández-Santos, A. Alonzo-Garcia, J. F. Jimenez-Vielma, A. G. Silva-Trujillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The increasing digitalization of industrial processes under Industry 4.0 has significantly expanded the attack surface of critical infrastructures, making traditional static-rule cybersecurity approaches insufficient to counter emerging and dynamic threats. This paper presents a structured methodological framework for developing an adaptive cybersecurity system based on evolutionary algorithms. The proposed methodology integrates six progressive phases: data collection from simulated IIoT and SCADA environments using NADAGEN, GothX, and TRex; preprocessing through normalization and evolutionary feature selection; evolutionary modeling with GA, PSO, and DE; adaptive optimization through self-adjusting parameters; and validation in simulated industrial networks using Modbus/TCP, MQTT, and OPC-UA protocols. A detailed data-flow diagram and pseudocode illustrate the iterative process of rule generation, evaluation, and improvement. Expected results include higher detection accuracy, reduced false positives, faster response time, and improved resilience against zero-day attacks. The proposal establishes a replicable foundation for designing intelligent, scalable, and self-learning intrusion detection systems capable of adapting to evolving cyber threats in Industry 4.0 environments.

title: Experimental Evaluation of a Fuzzy Logic-Based Controller for a Two-Wheeled Balancing Robot
authors: Irving Mora-González, José R. García-Martínez, José G. Pérez-Juárez, Trinidad Martínez-Sánchez, Luis F. Olmedo-García, Rafael Rojas-Galván
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the design, implementation, and experimental validation of a fuzzy logic controller (FLC) for a two-wheeled balancing robot (TWBR). The controller is structured as a PD scheme, where the proportional action is determined through fuzzy inference using seven linguistic input values, while the derivative action is computed conventionally. The output of the fuzzy system is obtained through a weighted average defuzzification method and converted into PWM signals to drive the DC motors via an H-bridge circuit. The proposed methodology was implemented on an ESP32-WROOM-32 embedded platform, integrating real-time data acquisition from an IMU (accelerometer and gyroscope) to estimate the tilt angle of the robot. Experimental tests were conducted under two scenarios: one without external disturbances and another with manually applied perturbations. Results demonstrate that the fuzzy controller maintains stability within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 2^{\circ}$</tex> of the setpoint in disturbance-free conditions and successfully recovers equilibrium within a range of 75° to 105° under perturbations. These findings validate the robustness, adaptability, and efficiency of the proposed fuzzy control approach, making it a suitable alternative for embedded robotic applications where stability and real-time response are critical.

title: Power Electronics and Control for an off-Grid Agrivoltaic Irrigation System
authors: Michael Short, Rajitha Wattegama, Mahendeiran Ramasamy, Geetika Aggarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: An agrivoltaic system is one which combines agricultural production with solar energy generation on the same land, providing energy generation coupled with potentially higher crop yields while contributing to more sustainable land use, reduced carbon emissions and increased biodiversity. In many off-grid rural applications, a small microgrid must be implemented to manage generation, storage, and loads. In addition to other functionality, agrivoltaic control systems must implement integrated power and energy management, in addition to asset monitoring and control. In this paper, a prototype Integrated Energy Management and Control System (EMCS) for off-grid agrivoltaics implementations used in irrigation applications is presented, using a test system located in Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu, South India. The paper considers a novel integrated PV supply and irrigation system load power management design and presents simulation-based tests of the modified MPPT and coupled non-linear digital irrigation control system. Investigation of both DC bus ripple, voltage stability and irrigation system performance under environmental fluctuations are positive. Conclusions and areas for future development are outlined.

title: Overview of the RENEW Platform, an AI and DT-driven Solution Aimed at Optimizing Care for Hypertensive Patients
authors: Vitomir Djaja-Jośko, Marcin Kołakowski, Jacek Cichocki, Jerzy Kołakowski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: According to many recent studies and the newest statistical predictions presented by the respective EU agencies and scientific research centers, we live in an aging society, with a constantly increasing number of people affected by cardiovascular diseases (CVD). Among the main factors leading to CVD-related health complications, such as coronary disease, is hypertension. Hence, a need arises for the development of systems that aid hypertensive patients, their families, and caregivers. The primary objective of the RENEW project is to provide an intuitive and user-friendly platform that enables patients to continuously monitor their health and receive personalized treatment plans tailored to their specific needs.

title: Ultra-Wideband Multi-Purpose MIMO Antenna Design for Communication Applications
authors: Burak Alptug Yilmaz, Galip Orkun Arican, Nursel Akcam
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this study, a novel, multi-purpose, ultrawideband multiple input multiple output (MIMO) antenna design that is aimed to provide high data rate for 5G and WLAN communication applications, is presented. The dual-band antenna consists of 4 antenna elements. Its fractional bandwidths are 123% and 30% for first and second operating frequencies, respectively. For the whole operating frequencies, it has radiated with very good reflection performance better than −10 dB. Moreover, the isolation between antenna elements is better than −15 dB and −20 dB for the each of operating frequencies, respectively. Finally, Envelope Correlation Coefficient (ECC) is usually lower than 0.01.

title: Assessing Vehicle-to-Grid as A Flexible Energy Storage Solution for Buildings: Case Studies and Policy Outlook in Romania
authors: Mihaela Cretu, Mircea LĂncrĂnjan, Dan D. Micu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Energy storage solutions play a crucial role in ensuring grid stability, reducing energy costs, and improving overall system efficiency. Among emerging storage technologies, Vehicle-to-Grid (V2G) systems have gained significant attention due to their dual functionality - enables bidirectional power flow, allowing electric vehicles (EVs) to store excess renewable energy and discharge it back to the grid or directly to buildings when needed. By leveraging V2G, buildings can improve their energy flexibility potential, reducing reliance on centralized power systems while enhancing demand response capabilities. This paper develops a simulation-based optimization framework for building-level V2G, applies it to a Romanian university dormitory, and benchmarks results against stationary lithiumion and second-life EV batteries. Results indicate that while daily cost savings at single-building scale are modest, aggregated V2G systems significantly increase cost reductions and emission savings. Compared to stationary storage, V2G leverages existing EV capacity, offering superior cost-effectiveness per unit of flexibility. The study highlights Romania's emerging regulatory framework, the scalability potential of V2G, and the need for market incentives to enable widespread adoption.

title: Formal Verification of a Generic Algorithm for TDM Communication Over Inter Satellite Links
authors: Miroslav Popovic, Marko Popovic, Pavle Vasiljevic, Miodrag Djukic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The Python Testbed for Federated Learning Algorithms is a simple FL framework targeting edge systems, which provides the three generic algorithms: the centralized federated learning, the decentralized federated learning, and the universal TDM communication in the current time slot. The first two were formally verified in a previous paper using the CSP process algebra, and in this paper, we use the same approach to formally verify the third one, in two phases. In the first phase, we construct the CSP model as a faithful representation of the real Python code. In the second phase, the model checker PAT automatically proves correctness of the third generic algorithm by proving its deadlock freeness (safety property) and successful termination (liveness property).

title: Lcoe Reduction in African Off-Grid Rural Microgrids: a Systematic Approach Using Dsm and Innovative Bchp Integration
authors: Zahra Esfahani, Alireza Derakhshan, Shwetha Ramprasad
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Designing cost-effective and reliable off-grid microgrids (MGs) is particularly challenging in rural regions where energy demand is shaped by both household consumption and productive use of energy (PUE). This paper presents an integrated planning and optimization framework that reduces the Levelized Cost of Electricity (LCoE) while enabling scalable microgrid expansion. The approach combines demand-side management (DSM), consumer clustering, and a novel biomass-based Combined Heat and Power (BCHP) operation strategy adapted to seasonal Agro-processing loads. Using the XENDEE platform, the study performs system sizing and optimal energy dispatch based on real-world load data. Consumers are classified through a Multi-tier Framework (MTF), with PUE applications treated as high-tier loads requiring tailored energy support. DSM measures were selectively applied only to PUE loads, with household consumption patterns preserved as fixed constraints during optimization. The methodology is applied to extend an existing microgrid (MG) to serve additional demand, while maintaining the same LCoE and system size through strategic DSM and dynamic BCHP scheduling. Sensitivity analysis is conducted to validate the robustness of the proposed solution. Results confirm that the integrated approach ensures reliable power supply, improves load flexibility, and maintains cost stability—offering practical insights for microgrid planners and policymakers pursuing sustainable rural electrification.

title: Electromagnetic Interference from Constant-Current SMPS in Amateur Radio Bands up to 150 MHz
authors: Nikola Basta, Dragan Olćan
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: An assessment of radio-frequency interference due to the emanated electromagnetic field and the time-domain waveforms of the currents drawn from the electric power distribution network was performed. Three constant-current switching-mode power-supply units were analyzed. These units are LED drivers that are widely available on the local market. The observed interference spanned the HF and VHF bands, i.e., from 10 kHz to 150 MHz, which are of particular concern for the amateur radio services. A computational electromagnetic model was analyzed and solutions for interference mitigation were demonstrated.

title: Integrating V2X-Based Maneuver Coordination System with Autonomous Cooperative Driving
authors: Mauro Filho, Andreia Figueiredo, Pedro Rito, Miguel Luís, Susana Sargento
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Cooperative maneuver coordination is a cornerstone of Cooperative, connected and automated mobility (CCAM), enabling autonomous vehicles to negotiate and execute maneuvers through Vehicle to Everything (V2X) communication. The European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) has proposed the Maneuver Coordination System (MCS) to standardize this process, but its effectiveness depends on the correct integration with the autonomous driving stack and the accurate creation of trajectories to be exchanged among vehicles. This paper presents an updated MCS implementation featuring a modular architecture, Data Distribution Service (DDS) support, and a trajectory generation module aligned with the latest specifications. Validation in a two-vehicle overtaking scenario demonstrates that reliable trajectory exchange and real-time negotiation can be achieved, underscoring how V2X-enabled networks support safe and efficient cooperative driving.

title: RIS-Assisted Full Duplex MAC Protocol for NR-V2X with ML-Driven QoS Prediction
authors: Indulekha K P, T. G. Venkatesh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Next-generation vehicular communication systems require ultra-reliable and low-latency links to support safety critical and high-mobility scenarios. Full Duplex (FD) communication enhances spectral efficiency by enabling simultaneous transmission and reception; however, it is limited in its ability to suppress interference and maintain reliable coverage in the presence of wireless blind spots and dense traffic. To overcome these challenges, we propose a Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS)-assisted FD Medium Access Control (MAC) protocol for New Radio Vehicle-to-Everything (NR-V2X) Mode 2 systems, where RIS improves signal coverage and reliability through intelligent reflection. The proposed design augments the standard Sensing-Based Semi-Persistent Scheduling (SB-SPS) framework by integrating machine learning (ML)-based predictions of key Quality-of-Service (QoS) metrics, namely Packet Reception Ratio (PRR) and Channel Busy Ratio (CBR), which trigger dynamic RIS activation and resource retention decisions. A Discrete-Time Markov Chain (DTMC) model further evaluates long-term link reliability and supports adaptive resource reselection. Extensive simulations conducted on the proposed framework demonstrate a favorable trade-off between Packet Reception Ratio (PRR) and Wireless Blind Spot Probability (WBSP), ensuring robust performance across diverse vehicular densities and mixed packet transmission patterns.

title: An AI-Driven Framework for Real-Time Fault Detection and Demand Prediction in 5G Networks
authors: Junaid Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As 5G networks evolve into dynamic, multi-domain architectures spanning wireless, transport, and core layers, traditional assurance tools struggle to deliver real-time, end-to-end visibility. Operational silos, reactive troubleshooting, and fragmented alarm handling prolong Mean Time to Repair (MTTR), increase costs, and leave user demand unmet in congested areas.This paper presents an AI-driven assurance framework, developed under the TM Forum Catalyst program—an industry initiative for collaborative telecom innovation. The framework addresses these challenges through three modules: intelligent topology visualization, automated root cause analysis (Auto RCA), and Expected Demand Not Served (EDNS) models.The methodology emphasizes algorithmic transparency. Random Forest, XGBoost, and Gradient Boosting models were trained on 1.2M multi-domain alarm records from production and simulated 5G environments. Feature sets span alarm attributes, topology metadata, and service-level KPIs, with hyperparameters tuned via grid search and validation using a 70/15/15 split.Results show that Auto RCA achieves 0.94 precision, 0.91 recall, and an F1-score of 0.925, outperforming baseline threshold-based engines by 38%. The EDNS model forecasts underserved demand with a mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of 6.8%. Deployed across a multi-vendor testbed and integrated with OSS/BSS, the framework improved fault detection by 50%, reduced MTTR by 35%, and enhanced proactive demand handling by 27%. Recognized at TM Forum Catalyst 2024, it provides a replicable blueprint for intelligent, cross-domain assurance in next-generation networks.

title: QURE:Quantum-Resistant Encryption Strategies For Confidential Computing
authors: Deepanshu, Majid K, L. Valcarenghi, R. Bassoli, C. Jatoth, Koteswararao Kondepu
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Confidential Computing is the protection of data in use by performing computation in a hardware-based, attested Trusted Execution Environment. However, even without specific hardware features, one can still protect computation to some extent using software solutions. Confidential Containers (CoCo) play a crucial role in providing confidential computing without specific hardware. Confidential Computing protects data in use. In contrast, data at rest and data in transit are only secured by means of traditional classical encryption algorithms such as Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) or Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH). These algorithms face a significant threat from the advent of quantum computers, a threat known as the Quantum Threat. National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has been leading efforts to standardize Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC) algorithms such as — standardized quantum-resistant algorithms — CRYSTALS-Kyber and Dilithium that remain secure against quantum threats. These standardized PQC algorithms are built on mathematical problems believed to be hard for both classical and quantum computers, to protect our data against quantum attacks that powerful quantum computers could launch. This study presents an integration of confidential computing with PQC to secure data/computation in all stages of data —data in use, data at rest, and data in transit — even from quantum threats. Furthermore, the paper delivers a comparison of confidential computing with PQC to other traditional methods, such as Fully Homomorphic Encryption, and others. The study’s results demonstrate significantly lower overhead when using CC with PQC compared to FHE in experimental data payloads. It clearly stated that CC with PQC is a better feasible option than other traditional data in use methods.

title: User-Centric Comparison of 5G NTN and DVB-S2/RCS2 Using OpenAirInterface and OpenSAND
authors: Sumit Kumar, Juan Carlos Estrada-Jimenez, Ion Turcanu
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The integration of satellite networks into next-generation mobile communication systems has gained considerable momentum with the advent of 5G Non-Terrestrial Networks (5G-NTN). Since established technologies like DVB-S2/RCS2 are already widely used for satellite broadband, a detailed comparison with emerging 5G NTN solutions is necessary to understand their relative merits and guide deployment decisions. This paper presents a user-centric, end-to-end evaluation of these technologies under realistic traffic conditions, showing how differences in architecture and protocols impact application-layer performance. Utilizing the 6G Sandbox platform, we employ OpenAirInterface to emulate 5G NTN and OpenSAND for DVB-S2/RCS2, replicating transparent payload GEO satellite scenarios under uniform downlink conditions. A range of real-world applications, such as web browsing, file downloads, and video streaming, are tested across both systems and systematically analyzed. While the emulation lacks real-time capability, it reveals key strengths and limitations of each approach, helping identify suitable deployment scenarios for 5G NTN and DVB-S2/RCS2.

title: MQTT Messaging-Based Monitoring of Multi-Storied Residential Buildings in Smart Cities
authors: Aman Mark Kujur, Vipul Singh Negi, Suchismita Chinara, Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: All the traditional things, from infrastructure to supply chain, are rapidly being converted to smart things with the development of the Internet of Things and its massive sensor catalogue. The idea is theoretically amazing, but while implementing it, scaling becomes a major issue. Massive IoT methodologies take care of the pesky scaling issues, while enhancing the overall quality of the network’s communication. Smart cities are in the current research to make human life easy and comfortable. Most of the multi storied buildings are designed smart to achieve safety, security, and comfort. However, just deploying sensors into the buildings do not solve the purpose. Monitoring the buildings require data exchange between sensors to users for appropriate analysis and interpretation. It is really crucial to monitor all the sensor data to provide an amazing quality of life experience. However, the massive IoT technology solves the problem of handling hundreds of sensors at a time through light weight messaging protocols like MQTT and CoAP. An architecture is proposed that uses the MQTT Protocol paired with various sensors and edge devices for the monitoring of residential buildings and simplifying such projects. A methodology focusing on the scale, payload and quality of service is proposed in this manuscript. The edge broker scales the number of sensors from 217 per edge node to 1254 sensors with 5 Edge Broker nodes, which is an increment of 5.7 times.

title: Towards Cloud-Native RAN for 6G NTN-Based Connectivity in Aviation
authors: Babak Mafakheri, Farzad Veisi, Mohamed Hafidi, Tomaso de Cola, Leonardo Goratti
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The aviation sector is emerging as a key vertical in the development of 6G Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTN), driven by increasing demand for high-capacity and low-latency in-flight connectivity (IFC). In this work, we explore the potential of disaggregated and cloud-native Radio Access Network (RAN) architectures to support seamless gate-to-gate connectivity for commercial aircraft. We propose and analyze four deployment scenarios that distribute the functions of disaggregated gNB, the central unit (CU), the distributed unit (DU), and the radio unit (RU) across aircraft, satellite platforms, and ground infrastructure. Emphasizing latency budget considerations, we examine trade-offs between performance, scalability, and complexity across multi-orbit satellite constellations. We further argue that adopting cloud-native RAN principles, along with intelligent orchestration and AI-based adaptation, can enable flexible and resilient architectures for future 6G NTN-based aviation services.

title: Hybrid Autoencoder-Based Framework for Early Fault Detection in Wind Turbines
authors: Rekha R Nair, Tina Babu, Alavikunhu Panthakkan, Balamurugan Balusamy, Mohammed Saleh, Wathiq Mansoor
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Wind turbine reliability is critical to the growing renewable energy sector, where early fault detection significantly reduces downtime and maintenance costs. This paper introduces a novel ensemble-based deep learning framework for unsupervised anomaly detection in wind turbines. The method integrates Variational Autoencoders (VAE), LSTM Autoencoders, and Transformer architectures, each capturing different temporal and contextual patterns from high-dimensional SCADA data. A unique feature engineering pipeline extracts temporal, statistical, and frequency-domain indicators, which are then processed by the deep models. Ensemble scoring combines model predictions, followed by adaptive thresholding to detect operational anomalies without requiring labeled fault data. Evaluated on the CARE dataset containing 89 years of real-world turbine data across three wind farms, the proposed method achieves an AUC-ROC of 0.947 and early fault detection up to 48 hours prior to failure. This approach offers significant societal value by enabling predictive maintenance, reducing turbine failures, and enhancing operational efficiencyin large-scale wind energy deployments.

title: Enhancement of Routing Protocols for VANETs and FANETs Using Machine Learning
authors: Pavle Bugarcic, Nenad Jevtic, Marija Malnar
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The exceptional dynamism of vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) and flying ad hoc networks (FANETs) significantly complicates the process of selecting the optimal route for packet delivery, leading to a degradation of overall network performance. A highly effective way to overcome this issue is the integration of machine learning (ML) into the routing process, with a particular emphasis on a type of ML known as reinforcement learning (RL). One of the most important types of RL for VANETs and FANETs is Q-learning (QL). This paper presents an overview of the most significant RL-based routing protocols for VANETs and FANETs, along with their classification and comparison. Furthermore, a novel QL-based dynamic routing algorithm for urban VANETs (QDRAV) is introduced, which significantly improves their overall network performance. Simulation analysis and comparison of the new and existing routing protocols were conducted using the NS-3 simulator.

title: Neural Network-Based Estimation of PV Power Reserve for Optimal Power Sharing in Grid-Forming Inverter Systems
authors: Harsha Vardhan Reddy Modugu, Reza Behnam, Aasritha Kareti, Mohammad B. Shadmand
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents an optimal power-sharing algorithm (OPSA) that can address the power sharing of gridforming inverters (GFMIs) in modern power systems with high penetrations of distributed energy resources (DERs). Unlike conventional techniques that adopt static assumptions of power availability, the method presented here includes real-time estimation of the available power reserve from PV units using a data-driven two-layered feed-forward neural network. Since the PV units are interfaced through GFMIs operating in a gridforming mode, they do not follow maximum power point tracking (MPPT), but rather operate under flexible generation to support power balancing and system stability. According to this estimated power reserve, the supervisory controller regulates virtual impedance in real-time to allocate the power demand optimally among GFMIs. The adaptive control approach avoids inverter overloading, enhances the utilization of renewable energy, and assists system stability under varying irradiation and loads. Simulation results in various scenarios confirm the effectiveness of the implemented OPSA for achieving well-balanced power sharing and higher grid resiliency.
