title: A Systematic Review on Gait Analytics in Disorders with Motor Phenotypes Utilizing Inertial Measurement Units and Plantar Pressure Sensors
authors: Dimitrios G. Boucharas, Elena Moro, George Manis, Dimitrios I. Fotiadis
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Among the 97 studies included in this systematic review, 81 (83.5%) investigate Parkinson’s Disease (PD), reflecting the broader research landscape and the established utility of wearable sensors in capturing PD-specific gait impairments rather than an intentional PD-focused search strategy. Building on this context, this review synthesizes recent advances in gait analytics using Inertial Measurement Units (IMU) and Plantar Pressure Sensors (PPS) across disorders with motor phenotypes. Gait analysis has emerged as a critical tool for understanding motor dysfunction, enabled by portable sensor technologies capable of precise, real-time measurements in naturalistic settings. This review, spanning publications from 2020 to April 2024, examines studies identified through four major databases (PubMed, Scopus, IEEE Xplore, and Google Scholar). Eligible works were original, peer-reviewed studies applying quantitative gait analytics using IMUs and/or PPS in Arthritis, Diabetes Mellitus, or PD. Exclusion criteria comprised non-human studies, incompatible sensing modalities, use of more than ten different sensors, sensor-comparison–only studies, absence of gait protocols, and cohorts consisting solely of healthy individuals or those with gait-altering deformities. Together, IMUs and PPS are reshaping diagnostic and monitoring strategies for PD, Arthritis, and Diabetes, where gait abnormalities and neuropathic complications are central to functional impairment. Beyond PD, the review includes 12 Diabetes and 4 Arthritis studies, representing peripheral nerve and musculoskeletal conditions that remain comparatively underexplored. The included studies are synthesized by sensor modality, placement, analytical methodology, protocol design, cohort characteristics, and performance outcomes. Approaches ranged from statistical analysis to machine learning, deep learning, and rule-based models, with several reporting state-of-the-art results. The findings underscore the value of wearable sensors for monitoring disease progression, detecting gait-phase abnormalities, and supporting personalized interventions. Despite these advancements, significant limitations persist, including a lack of publicly available datasets, limited external validity, small or imbalanced samples, inconsistent sensor placement, and data integration challenges. Future directions emphasize standardized protocols, multi-center validation, and AI-driven multimodal fusion to unlock scalable, clinically reliable gait-analytics solutions across healthcare and rehabilitation.

title: LoRaWAN System for Tracking Number of People in a Room
authors: Kosana Pavlovic, Milan Lukic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The paper describes the implementation of a prototype of an embedded system that records a change in the number of people in a room. The system consists of a LoRa development board and a Time-of-Flight sensor. Changes in the number of people in the room are detected in real time. The updated data is transmitted through a LoRaWAN network to the Actility ThingPark Wireless platform, which forwards it to a third-party application server. Statistical analysis and graphical visualization are provided by a web interface at the corresponding URL address. The proposed solution demonstrates long-range IoT technology with low power consumption for applications in smart buildings such as safety management, energy optimization, and occupancy monitoring.

title: Subjective Perception of the Quality of Data Services for Smartphone Applications
authors: Lars Wischhof, Robert Müllner
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Due to the non-linear relation of Quality of Service (QoS) and Quality of Experience (QoE), an efficient resource assignment in mobile networks is challenging. To evaluate the impact of QoS variations on the perceived quality of data services, subjective tests for video streaming and web-browsing are performed in this study. The end user's view is assessed by rating the quality of different versions of a source using a modified version of the MUlti Stimulus test with Hidden Reference and Anchor (MUSHRA). Based on measurements in a live network, stimuli are generated by using a combination of network emulation and automatic user-interface control of a real mobile device. These stimuli include relevant effects observed in a live network, e.g. throughput dependent video startup time/resolution and interruptions caused by rebuffering. In this study, the contribution of each of these aspects to the overall quality impression is quantified. The results show that the highest subjective impairment is provided by an interruption of the video fluency, with the duration of the interruption having a significant influence. Increasing video startup times lead to a continuous decrease in the perceived quality but are rather tolerated than rebuffering interruptions. Video clarity plays a minor role. In contrast to streaming services, web-browsing as interactive service shows a smoother degradation of the perceived quality with decreasing throughput.

title: Relay-Enabled Dual-Hop Network in 6G Bands
authors: Volkan Özduran
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of amplify-and-forward based one-way half-duplex (HD) and full-duplex (FD) relay-assisted dual-hop network. The investigation considers that the aforementioned system operates in sixth generation (6G) candidate bands: 4.6 GHz, 7.8 GHz, 15 GHz, and 40 GHz. The outage probability is utilized for the performance analysis. Analytical and asymptotic derivations are validated by means of Monte-Carlo simulations. The obtained results reveal that when residual loop-interference is sufficiently suppressed, FD attains slightly better outage performance than HD due to its pre-log advantage. A mild performance uptick at higher carrier frequencies stems from the frequency-dependent MT antenna gains assumed (2/3/6/10 dBi), rather than intrinsic frequency effects.

title: Design and Performance Investigation of Noncoupled High-Gain DC-DC Boost Converter With Reduced Stress and Ripple for Renewable Energy Systems
authors: Dinusha Rasanjalee Kariyapperuma Athukoralalage, Vijayakumar Gali, B. Chitti Babu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a novel non-coupled high-gain DC-DC converter design that achieves a high voltage conversion ratio at a moderate duty cycle by integrating a dual boost configuration with a switched inductor structure. This converter is very suitable for renewable energy systems, especially for solar photovoltaic (SPV) systems for efficient grid integration. Conventional boost converters face limitations like high component stress and reduced efficiency at high duty cycles. The proposed converter employs two switches controlled by a single PWM signal, simplifying control while aiming to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and minimize the need for additional filtering components. The proposed topology addresses key limitations of traditional boost converters. Its performance was evaluated through MATLAB/Simulink simulations under both steady and varying weather conditions. Compared to the conventional boost converter, the proposed design demonstrated improved efficiency and reduced voltage stress on switching components, confirming its potential for enhanced performance in SPV applications.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning and Wavelet Scattering for Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring in Smart Farming Energy Systems
authors: Diaa-Eldin A. Mansour, Ahmed S. Abdellah, Zeiad Alshabrawy Mahmoud, Ahmed Mohamed Ali Mousa, Tamer F. Megahed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) is a promising technique for disaggregating aggregated energy consumption data into appliance-level load profiles without the need for intrusive metering systems. This paper presents an advanced NILM framework specifically designed for smart farming energy systems, where cost-effective, scalable, and accurate energy management is essential. The proposed model integrates hybrid deep learning architectures with wavelet scattering transforms for robust feature extraction. Wavelet scattering is employed to generate low-variance, translationinvariant features from time-series power data, enhancing the model's ability to distinguish between appliances with similar energy signatures and reducing the dimensionality of the input data. To perform appliance classification, the study investigates and compares three machine learning models: Subspace kNearest Neighbors (Subspace KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM) Kernel, and Gaussian Naive Bayes. These classifiers are evaluated using MATLAB's Classification Learner. Due to the current lack of publicly available energy datasets specific to agricultural equipment and smart farm loads, the proposed NILM system was validated using home appliance datasets, which are widely accepted benchmarks in NILM research. The results validate the proposed system's capability to perform accurate and scalable energy disaggregation, with significant improvements in classification accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Distance Metric Robustness in RSSI Fingerprinting Under Sparse Access Point Conditions
authors: Uroš Bojanić, Mirjana Simić Pejović, Milan Bjelica
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Wi-Fi fingerprinting is a popular indoor localization method, but its performance often degrades with access point instability. This paper systematically evaluates fourteen distance metrics for RSSI-based fingerprinting using k-nearest neighbors regression under controlled signal dropout scenarios. Results show that classical metrics such as Euclidean and Manhattan are effective in dense network environments, but Mahalanobis and Hamming achieve superior robustness under sparse AP conditions, offering new insights for designing adaptive and resilient localization systems.

title: MAB-Based Dynamic Task Offloading in Heterogeneous Edge Networks
authors: Liqiong Chen, Xianhui Zhang, Shiya Chen, Sun Huaiying
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: In heterogeneous edge computing environments, terminal devices must dynamically select suitable edge servers based on task characteristics and network conditions to perform computation offloading. However, due to significant variations in server performance and load, task latency exhibits high uncertainty, rendering traditional static or globally informationdriven offloading strategies ill-suited for dynamic changes. To address this, this paper proposes a Multi-Armed Bandit-based Dynamic Task Offloading algorithm (MAB_DTO). This method models the offloading process as an Integer Linear Programming (ILP) problem. By obtaining a fractional solution through LP relaxation, it screens candidate server sets and combines dynamic thresholds to complete offloading decisions and state updates. Simulation results demonstrate that MAB_DTO achieves superior delay performance compared to the Greedy algorithm and the Multi-UAV Mobile Edge Computing via Deep Reinforcement Learning(MU_DRL) algorithm under various load conditions.

title: Utensil Classification using Computer Vision: A Feasibility Study on Preventing Kitchen Accidents for Diverse Users
authors: Nma Salam Rakib, Stephen Karungaru, Kenji Terada, Mohammad Mehedi Hasan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Incidents involving kitchen tools often result from improper handling or misuse, particularly among children and individuals with physical disabilities. To address this, we present a feasibility study on a computer vision-based system designed to detect and classify kitchen utensils using deep learning techniques. The proposed system utilizes an object detection algorithm for real-time object detection, distinguishing utensils as either safe or hazardous based on static risk mapping derived from their shape and material characteristics. A custom dataset of various kitchen utensils was used, including both occluded and non-occluded conditions. We achieved an mAP50-95 of 0.72 and 0.80 for the occluded and non-occluded kitchen utensils datasets, respectively. While this initial study does not incorporate context- aware inference or real-time alert mechanisms, it demonstrates the potential of object detection models as a foundational step toward intelligent, safety-enhancing kitchen systems. Although the evaluation was conducted under a controlled environment, future research will focus on validating the system in real kitchens and extending static risk mapping into context-aware safety models.

title: Disposable Inkjet-Printed Flexible Strain Sensors for Respiratory Rate Monitoring
authors: Ishant G. Patil, Ting Yang Ling, Khong Wui Gan, Suan Hui Pu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Inkjet printing has emerged as a promising technology for the digital manufacturing of wearable health monitoring devices. Respiration rate monitoring is a vital parameter for wearable healthcare applications. In addition to offering accurate and non-invasive respiration rate measurements, flexible strain sensors have been extensively tested for their potential to provide reliable long-term performance at low cost without compromising user comfort. In this work, we design and fabricated a disposable paper-based flexible silver/reduced graphene-oxide hybrid printed strain sensor for respiration rate monitoring. The inkjet-printed strain sensors exhibit a stable electromechanical response, validated through statistical analysis. Physiological evaluations were conducted by placing the sensors on chest and abdomen regions under spontaneous, normal and deep breathing conditions. The result revealed that sensors placed near the hypochondriac region provide the highest sensitivity, while challenges such as poor adhesion on chest curvature must also be addressed. To further enhance sensitivity and reliability, additional experiments were conducted on the upper chest and lumbar regions which improved the measurement of respiration rate. Overall, the inkjet-printed sensors achieve high accuracy for respiration rate measurements while maintaining user comfort, highlighting their potential as an affordable and practical wearable respiratory rate monitoring device.

title: Research on Intelligent Control Methods for Wireless Charging Systems of Electric Vehicles
authors: Hao Chenlong, Ma Xianghua
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To address the problems of efficiency degradation and insufficient stability in wireless charging systems for electric vehicles (EVs) under conditions such as dynamic misalignment and variable loads, this study proposes an intelligent control method based on a hierarchical collaborative control architecture. By constructing an electromagnetic-control coupling model and integrating a Multi-Objective Evolutionary Optimization Algorithm (MOEOA) with an Adaptive Fuzzy Neural Network Controller (AFNNC), the system achieves coordinated optimization of charging efficiency, operational stability, and electromagnetic safety. Experimental results show that the proposed method improves the static charging efficiency to 92.1%, and maintains above 88% under dynamic scenarios, providing theoretical and technical support for the engineering application of wireless charging technology.

title: Bayesian Optimization for Tuning Random Forest in SMOTE-Based Cross-Project Software Defect Prediction paper
authors: Jiayu Mao, Liqiong Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Abstract-Cross-project software defect prediction (CPDP) enables early defect identification in new projects by using data from other projects. However, it suffers from class imbalance and poor hyperparameter tuning. This paper proposes a method combining SMOTE with Bayesian Optimization (BO) to improve Random Forest performance in CPDP. SMOTE is first applied to the source project to balance the class distribution; then BO searches for optimal RF hyperparameters by maximizing predictive performance. We evaluate the approach on ReLink and Eclipse datasets using MCC, AUC, precision, and recall. On the Relink dataset, the proposed method achieves a maximum improvement of 29% in Recall compared to the baseline model; on the Eclipse project, the MCC score is improved by $3.2 \%$. Furthermore, the introduction of the SMOTE algorithm results in an additional increase of up to $9.3 \%$ in Recall on the Relink dataset, relative to the baseline without SMOTE. In the Eclipse project, both MCC and AUC metrics show significant improvements, indicating enhanced performance in handling class imbalance and defective module identification.

title: An Improved YOLOv11-Based Intelligent Detection Method for On-Site Operation Safety Protection in Power Construction Environment
authors: Xiaoyang He
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper presents an improved YOLOv11n algorithm integrated with Adaptive Spatial Fusion (ASF) module and the Spatially Enhanced Attention Module (SEAM) to address the critical need for personal protective equipment monitoring of workers in on-site operation power construction environments. By incorporating refined attention mechanisms into both spatial and multi-scale feature fusion processes, the proposed method significantly improves detection performance for hardhats and safety vests under complex scenarios. Through comprehensive ablation studies on a publicly available dataset, we demonstrate the complementary advantages of ASF and SEAM modules in boosting both mAP50 and mAP50:95 metrics. Experimental results show that our approach achieves performance gains of 0.6% improvement in Precision, 0.2% in mAP50 and 0.8% in mAP50:95 compared to the baseline YOLOv11n model, while delivering superior accuracy and robustness in safety equipment detection. The proposed framework provides a reliable technical foundation for intelligent safety supervision in power construction operations.

title: Transfer Learning for Brain Tumor MRI Image Classification: A Comparative Study of Custom Deep Learning Models with K-Fold Cross Validation and Ensemble
authors: Ankon Saha, Sajid Mahmud, Nuzath Tabassum Arthi, Musharrat Khan, Mahmudul Islam Bhuiyan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Manual review of brain MRI image alone struggles for timely and reliable tumor diagnosis. We tested a custom ensemble framework for four-class MRI image classification (glioma, meningioma, pituitary, no tumor). On the BRISC 2025 T1-weighted corpus, we do a uniform preprocessing: grayscale and denoising, ROI cropping with respect to the largest contour, resizing to $224 \times 224 \times 3$ pixels, and normalization. The three networks, DenseNet201, InceptionV3, and Xception, are ImageNetpretrained and are adapted with custom heads. Training is done by 5-fold cross-validation. Meta-learner MLP integration is then done on the networks’ features to boost complementary information present across the networks. Learning curves stabilize fast with high accuracy across folds. The ensemble outperforms single models almost every time. In summary, Custom ensembles with meta-learners were able to achieve almost perfect classification on BRISC data, thus verifying the usefulness of integrating multiple architectures. We finish by pointing out extensions toward large and more diverse datasets, multi-modal inputs, and 3D MRI to improve generalization and clinical applicability.

title: Micro-Mechanical Antennas: Modelling, Estimation, and Performance Evaluation
authors: Anand Mohandas, Ananthapalli Naga Surya Teja, Dilip Krishnaswamy
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper introduces a physics-grounded channel modeling and training framework for a Mechanical Tunable Antenna (MTA) system designed to mitigate fading and enhance reliability in wireless communication. Unlike conventional fixed-element systems, the MTA exploits actuator-driven scanning across discrete orientations to maximize the effective channel response. The channel model is developed by explicitly linking Maxwell’s equations and radiation integrals to antenna translation and rotation, yielding a spatial response coefficient that captures element pattern, polarization alignment, and phase variation due to mechanical displacement. A training-based estimation strategy is then proposed, where pilot symbols guide the selection of the optimal scanning orientation by maximizing received signal power. Both single-input single-output (SISO) and multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) cases are analyzed, with the MIMO system offering faster convergence to the additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) bound by halving the required scanning steps. Simulation results for BPSK modulation under Rayleigh fading demonstrate that increasing the number of scanning orientations significantly improves bit error rate (BER) performance, approaching the AWGN limit. These findings establish MTA as a viable candidate for achieving robust and adaptive communication links in dynamic environments, highlighting its potential role in future wireless networks.

title: Convergence of 6G and ATSC3 Networks via Broadcast to Everything (B2X): Use cases, Solutions and Collaborations
authors: Rashmi Kamran, James Kelso, Pranav Jha, Shwetha Kiran, Leonard J Fabiano, Prasanna Chaporkar, Sangsu Kim, Sesh Simha
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Sixth Generation (6G) networks are expected to support a wide variety of new use cases. The growing demand for Artificial Intelligence (AI) inference and other emerging applications will significantly increase the need for additional bandwidth and resources in mobile networks. Currently, mobile networks mainly rely on unicast delivery to serve users. However, by combining unicast with multicast and broadcast delivery methods, network resources can be used more efficiently. To manage the rising traffic load in future mobile networks, integrating mobile and broadcast networks is a promising approach. Broadcast to Everything (B2X) is an extension of the Advanced Television Systems Committee’s ATSC 3.0 standard that is being designed to enable interoperability between ATSC3 and Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) mobile networks. This convergence can enable more efficient multicast and broadcast delivery while freeing up capacity for unicast traffic. Terrestrial broadcast technologies like ATSC3, which are built for efficient multicast/broadcast and operate on dedicated spectrum, can be effectively combined with mobile networks. This converged setup can improve content delivery and better serve user demand. This paper highlights the importance of converging 3GPP mobile networks and non-3GPP broadcast networks, particularly ATSC3 to enable multicast and broadcast delivery to wireless users efficiently. Emerging use cases for converged networks are reviewed, along with methods for implementing a converged network. Technical aspects, research directions, standardization activities and collaboration opportunities are also included to cover operational dimensions.

title: Constant-Impedance T and $\Pi$ Phase Shifters
authors: Dušan N. Grujić, Nikola Ž. Petrović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Phase shifters are key components in beamforming and electronic beam steering. As the operating frequency increases, shorter wavelength allows the integration of antenna arrays in consumer products, and even into chip package. In this paper we propose a new topology for an integrated, constant-impedance phase shifter, which uses capacitively loaded transformer as a tunable inductor. The proposed phase shifter is suitable for integration in a standard CMOS processes. We have derived the design equations for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Pi$</tex> and T topologies, and provided design examples.

title: Validation and Analysis of Grid-Following Control for Connecting Renewable Energy Sources to the Grid in Hardware-in-the-Loop with Comparison to Simulation
authors: Fatemeh Abedini, Kia Malekian Boroujeni, Jens Teuscher
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The rapid expansion of renewable energy demands advanced power electronic converters, with grid-following control serving as a conventional approach for their operation. However, validating controller performance under real-world conditions remains challenging. This study employs power hardware-in-the loop (PHIL) technology to analyze the difference between simulation and physical testing. A grid-following inverter is initially modelled in MATLAB and subsequently implemented in a PHIL test environment. The system comprises a DC source feeding an 11-level inverter, with its AC side synchronized to the grid. A real-time simulator interfaced with RT-LAB manages the closed loop control and switching of the modular multilevel converter (MMC). To evaluate the control method, various scenarios have been tested, including changes in the phase shifts of the grid voltage to verify phase shift spreading, and harmonic injection. The results of both methodologies are analyzed, including a detailed FFT analysis to assess performance metrics. The findings highlight the accuracy of the PHIL approach, as its real-time results closely align with those obtained from physical testing. Moreover, since PHIL integrates actual hardware into the testing process, it eliminates many uncertainties associated with purely software-based simulations, delivering highly reliable outcomes without significant risks. In addition to its ability to provide realistic and dependable results, HIL testing is also time and cost-efficient and allows for testing under extreme conditions that may be impractical or unsafe in real world scenarios. Consequently, HIL is emerging as a strong alternative to traditional simulations, with anticipated widespread adoption in various industries in the near future.

title: Kernel-Level DDoS Protection Using eBPF in Iot Networks
authors: Kristina Živanović, Pavle Vuletić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents an in-kernel mechanism implemented using the Extended Berkeley Packet Filter for IoT system Denial of Service attack detection and prevention. The proposed mechanism detects attacks that exploit MQTT vulnerabilities and is executed in XDP (eXpress Data Path) of Linux-based kernel before the packet reaches the kernel socket buffers and before it enters the system network stack. Protection mechanisms are implemented on the message broker as the central point for all MQTT traffic, making it the most effective location to detect potential DoS attacks before they affect the connected IoT devices. Experimental results prove that the approach is lightweight and capable of detecting and preventing DoS attacks.

title: Early Attestation of the Confidential Virtual Machine with Full Disk Encryption Support
authors: Ilija Kulic, Pavle Vuletic, Danko Miladinovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The implementation of software solutions in the cloud brings numerous benefits but does not guarantee the security of processed data, which poses an obstacle for companies that handle medical, financial, or other sensitive data. One solution is the use of Confidential Virtual Machines (CVMs) based on Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) technologies combined with Full Disk Encryption (FDE) mechanisms. The SNPGuard tool enables the deployment and attestation of CVMs that utilize AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization-Secure Nested Paging (SEV-SNP) technology to protect data during processing and the Linux unified key setup (LUKS) mechanism to protect data at rest. In this work, an extension of the tool and the CVM attestation protocol was implemented by adding support for a virtual trusted platform module (vTPM) device through a software-emulated TPM device. The extension of the attestation protocol relies on TPM QUOTE attestation in addition to SEV-SNP attestation. By combining these two attestation methods, a more complete picture of the CVM state during startup is achieved, thereby enhancing the level of security.

title: A 200 GHz Bow-Tie Antenna Employing Frequency Selective Surface Integration for On-Chip Systems
authors: Furkan Çiftçi, Yusuf Salih Gurbet, Semih Doğu
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This study presents an on-chip bow-tie antenna miniaturized to approximately 200 GHz with an impedance bandwidth of roughly 20 GHz at -10 dB. The antenna is designed in a standard <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.18 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> CMOS process as a CPS-fed radiator, together with an FSS-inspired element. The bow-tie radiator is realized in the top metal layer, while the bottom metal layer is divided into a grid of sub-wavelength copper cells. Compared to the reference design, the proposed antenna shifts the optimal performance to 200 GHz, achieves a return loss of about 26 dB over a 20 GHz bandwidth, and improves the peak realized gain to nearly 3.0 dBi. The antenna exhibits total and radiation efficiencies of 95 % and 97 %, respectively. Both the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{E}$</tex> - and H- plane patterns are wide and highly symmetric, with low sidelobe levels and reduced back radiation, yielding a directive beam occupying a total area of only <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>.

title: Secure Quantum Federated Learning Framework for URLLC in 6G Smart Healthcare Systems
authors: Annapurna Pradhan, Susmita Das
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The proliferation of future sixth-generation (6G) wireless systems envisions the progressive development of smart healthcare systems enabled by ultra-reliable low latency communication (URLLC). However, the exponential increase in consumer Internet of Things (CIoT) healthcare devices at the mobile edge generates heterogeneous end-user information obtained from monitoring and sensing operations in smart healthcare systems. Thus, preserving the privacy of edge CIoT users and enabling secure URLLC task offloading, we propose a Federated Learning (FL) based distributed computing architecture using Quantum enhanced Federated Learning (QFL). To address the data heterogeneity and secure edge computing, we consider the accurate channel information based on pilot symbol distribution modeled as image data. Then, using QFL, we identify the malicious information and optimize resource allocation through global model aggregated updates to enable secure data transmission. The simulation results validate the superiority of the proposed QFL framework in terms of improved accuracy and sum secrecy rate compared to the classical FL framework.

title: Blockchain-Enabled Federated Learning for Proactive Cyber-Physical Threat Mitigation in AI-Driven Renewable Smart Grids
authors: Muhammad Inam ul Haq, Hussam Al Hamadi, Zeeshan A. Afreen, Zeeshan Rashid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The rapid deployment of distributed renewable energy resources and AI-powered control systems in modern smart grids introduces complex cyber-physical threats and privacy risks. Traditional centralized security architectures suffer from high communication overhead, single points of failure, and vulnerability to sophisticated attacks. As part of this paper, there is an innovative blockchain-manifold federated learning (B-FL) system which optimally coordinates decentralized trust management with privacy-friendly collaborative intelligence to detect anomalies on the fly and forecast threats in the renewable-integrated urban smart flow of smart grids. The suggested framework relies on blockchain to ensure updates to the models and impose data integrity as well as provide federated training of deep temporal data-driven models of heterogeneous IoT sensor data. The system allows providing secure performance even with adversarial or non-IID conditions by employing edge computing and smart contracts; thus minimizing the risks of data leakage or communication time. Wide-scale simulations of the renewable integration based on an IEEE 118-bus system reveal high accuracy of detection (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 97 \%$</tex>) along with a 60 % drop in the cost of communication as well as increased resilience to node compromise in comparison to standard FL schemes. The proposed B-FL paradigm establishes a scalable and transparent security infrastructure for next-generation urban energy systems, empowering sustainable and intelligent grid operations.

title: Pavement Crack Detection on the Basis of a Maximum Eight-Direction Filter and Image Features
authors: Yasheng Chang, Wei Liu, Sitong Yan, Lin Lezhi, Yan Zheng, Haiyan Zhao
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Pavement crack severity is a commonly used indicator for measuring the quality of road structures and is also a main manifestation of pavement diseases. With the rapid development of sensor systems and sensor data analysis, semantic segmentation models that are based on sensor data are playing an increasingly important role in urban pavement crack detection. However, notably, the complexity of pavement cracks presents significant challenges for computer vision-based detection. This paper proposes a pavement crack detection method that is based on a deep-learning approach and image features. First, an algorithm that is based on a maximum eight-direction filter (MEDF) is proposed for enhancing crack features, which have no fixed direction or shape. Second, the loss function of the segmentation model is optimized by combining edge information to effectively capture crack features. Finally, compared with three state-of-the-art models (DeepLabV3, FCN, and U-Net), the method proposed in this paper achieved the highest average recall and mIoU scores, which reached 0.735 and 0.698, respectively. The visualization results for the segmentation also reached the comprehensive optimum.

title: A High Accuracy Modified FDTD(2,4) Scheme with More Relaxed Stability Condition
authors: Pengcheng Ren, Lei Kuang, Jianjun Gao, Qing Huo Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A relaxed modified FDTD (2,4) scheme (RM24) is proposed to alleviate the Courant condition. Extending the Modified FDTD (2,4) (M24) scheme, we incorporate third-degree spatial difference terms with fourth-order accuracy into the time-stepping formulas to relax the constraints of the Courant condition. Through the optimization of both the coefficients of the third-degree terms and the original coefficients in the M24 scheme, the global numerical dispersion error of the RM24 scheme is reduced to the minimum. For wideband applications, by selecting the above coefficients corresponding to an appropriate grid resolution while maintaining the spatial step size constant, the numerical dispersion error of the RM24 scheme can be further reduced within the operational frequency band. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed RM24 scheme with large Courant numbers effectively ensures the numerical stability and low numerical dispersion characteristics, thereby enhancing its capability to efficiently achieve accurate results in long-time simulations and electrically large-scale scenarios.

title: AI-Driven Optimization of THz Vehicular Communication
authors: Enis Körpe, Mustafa Alper Akkaş, Yavuz Öztürk
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) communication (0.1-10 THz) offers ultra-high data rates for future vehicular networks, addressing growing data demands and low-latency requirements. This study models a single-lane THz vehicular scenario, comparing a random topology with AI-driven optimization using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and the Firefly Algorithm (FA) in terms of energy efficiency and the total path loss. Using High-Resolution Transmission Molecular Absorption Database (HITRAN) for atmospheric absorption modeling, results show that AI methods significantly reduce the total path loss and minimum required transmit power, with PSO outperforming FA in computational efficiency. These findings highlight the promise of AI-assisted optimization in enhancing THz vehicular communication.

title: Simple Linear Dc Link Voltage Controller to Improve Transient Response of Pfc Rectifiers Under Stability and Current Quality Constraints
authors: Yoav Aminov, Vladimir Yuhimenko, Marco di Benedetto, Alessandro Lidozzi, Mor M. Peretz, Alon Kuperman
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The trade-off between DC link voltage dynamics and AC-side current quality in power factor correction (PFC) rectifiers is well-studied. It has been shown that applying notch filter in series with a typically employed PI regulator (i.e. forming a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PI}+$</tex> Notch controller) permits DC link voltage dynamics refining without worsening total harmonic distortion (THD) of the grid-side current. This work indicates that dropping the integral term of the PI regulator part (i.e. forming a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P}+$</tex> Notch controller) allows attaining further improvement of PFC rectifiers transient response to step-like load variations without sacrificing the grid-side current THD. On the other hand, it is demonstrated that the system possesses small tolerable average DC link voltage steady-state error (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1 \%$</tex> under full load). Analytical expressions linking the coefficients of the proposed controller with the above-mentioned performance merits for given DC link capacitance value and mains frequency uncertainty range are revealed in the paper. Simulations results validate the proposed design methodology.

title: A Proposed Architecture for C-V2X-Based Mesh Networking in Infrastructure-Less Environments
authors: Nerea Jiménez Zumalde, Aitor Pascual Bouzas, Jasone Astorga Burgo, David Franco Veiga, Jorge Sasiain Garcia, Eduardo Jacob Taquet
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a system for deploying communication networks in areas lacking existing infrastructure by utilizing drones (UAVs) equipped with C-V2X modules. These drones establish a mobile ad hoc mesh network using the B.A.T.M.A.N. protocol, facilitating the transmission of data, including real-time video streams, across multiple hops until reaching a relay node connected to a 5G network. This relay node functions as a gateway to external servers, enabling edge computing capabilities. The system was developed as a prototype and subjected to testing, demonstrating its ability to transmit video with acceptable latency over multiple hops. While the current setup is still under development, the results highlight its potential applicability in emergency situations or environments without existing infrastructure.

title: FL-MultiDDoSNet: A Visual Federated Fusion for Securing Future Networks Against DDoS Attacks
authors: Avinash Awasthi, Suraj Mishra, Pritam Vediya, Hemant Miranka, Ramesh Babu Battula, Dinesh Gopalani
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Intelligent Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks are an emerging threat to future network infrastructures like IoT and 5G, with traditional detection methods can’t keep up with their scale and complexity. Existing intelligent systems often face challenges with data privacy, computational overhead, and performance degradation on heterogeneous, non-identically distributed (non-IID) data. This paper introduces FL-MultiDDoSNet, a novel federated learning framework for detecting intelligent DDoS. Our approach transforms raw network traffic data into 2D image representations, drastically reducing computational and memory overhead during training. The framework operates over a decentralized heterogeneous future network trained on deep learning models individually at the client. These distributed models are then aggregated, and a final prediction is made using a voting-based fusion mechanism at the central server, enhancing detection accuracy and resilience. Experimental results show that FL-MultiDDoSNet achieves a state-of-the-art accuracy of 99.98%, with a minimal communication overhead of 7.3 MB and an ultra-low latency of 30 ms that outperforms existing models.

title: DQN-Based Joint Scheduling of eMBB and Massive URLLC in 5G Networks
authors: Rohan Desai, Indulekha K. P., T. G. Venkatesh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The evolution of 5G New Radio (NR) categorizes users into three primary classes: Enhanced Mobile Broadband (eMBB), Ultra-Reliable Low Latency Communication (URLLC), and Massive Machine-Type Communication (mMTC). While eMBB users demand high data rates and coverage, URLLC devices require strict latency and reliability guarantees. In this paper, we address the joint scheduling challenge of eMBB and massive URLLC traffic in industrial scenarios, formulating it as a resource packing problem under heterogeneous quality-of-service constraints. To address this, we propose a Deep Q-Learning (DQN)-based resource allocation framework that integrates both orthogonal and non-orthogonal access strategies. A portion of Physical Resource Blocks (PRBs) is reserved exclusively for URLLC, while the remaining PRBs—primarily allocated to eMBB—can be dynamically punctured to accommodate bursty URLLC traffic. The proposed model adapts in real time to varying traffic loads, maximizing spectral efficiency while minimizing eMBB degradation and resource underutilization. Simulation results show that our DQN-based approach outperforms traditional static scheduling, achieving a favorable trade-off between throughput and latency in diverse load conditions.

title: Low Latency in Containerized Environments: A Performance Analysis with DPDK and Kubernetes
authors: Ibrahim Mohamed Ramadan, Carlo Centofanti, Andrea Marotta, Fabio Graziosi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Low latency applications are highly sensitive to the overhead introduced by virtualization and container orchestration. This paper evaluates the combined effects of Kubernetes and DPDK on a Layer 2 packet reflector, implemented in both Python and DPDK.Across six deployment scenarios—including bare-metal and containerized setups with and without Multus CNI—we measure the impact on latency and jitter. Results show that Kubernetes introduces significant overhead, while DPDK reduces latency by up to 70% and jitter by 55%, restoring near-native performance even in containerized environments.Our findings demonstrate that DPDK, when paired with direct NIC access through Multus, is an effective solution for deploying real-time services in modern cloud-native infrastructures.

title: Development of an Aerial-Ground Cooperative Robot System for Coastal Litter Collection
authors: Tansuriyavong Suriyon, Maehara Toyo, Domepananakorn Nontacha, Unno Atsuhito
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study develops a cooperative robot system for collecting coastal litter. An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) scans the area to locate trash, while an unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) is navigated to the location for physical collection. The system aims to improve the efficiency of beach cleanup operations.

title: Application of the SAO-Optimized CNN-BiLSTM-AM Hybrid Model in Green Financial Product Price Prediction : A Case Study of the CSI Environmental Protection Industry Index
authors: Meiming Yan, Xiaoxiao Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: At present, green finance in China is showing a rapid development trend. Against this backdrop, predicting the prices of green financial products has become a key point in investment decision-making and risk management processes. This is because the prices of green financial products have high volatility and complex nonlinear characteristics. When traditional statistical models are used for prediction, It is often impossible to achieve satisfactory prediction accuracy. A new hybrid deep learning model, which is based on Snow Ablation Optimizer, it is alled SAO-CNN-BiLSTM-AM. This model integrates the feature extraction ability of convolutional neural networks, the temporal modeling ability of bidirectional long short-term memory networks, and all the global dependency capture capabilities of the attention mechanism. The SAO algorithm is also adopted to automatically optimize the hyperparameters, which enhances the accuracy and robustness of the prediction. In this paper, the daily data of the CSI environmental protection Industry Index from January 1, 2014 to December 31, 2024 is taken as the empirical sample. The prediction performances of the two models, SAO-CNN-BiLSTMAM and CNN-BiLSTM-AM, were compared. It can be seen from the results obtained from the experiment that the SAO-CNN-BiLSTM-AM model is better than the CNN-BiLSTM-AM model in terms of RMSE, MAE and $\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$, and the prediction accuracy has been significantly improved. This study provides an effective method framework for price prediction in the green financial market.

title: Deep Learning based QoT Estimation in Elastic Optical Networks
authors: Nitesh Kumar, Jaisingh Thangaraj
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Estimating the Quality of Transmission (QoT) is crucial for designing an Elastic Optical Networks (EONs). In conventional method, QoT estimation rely on the physical-layer models with conservative margins, which can be computationally expensive along with wastage of bandwidth. In order to identify the QoT in EON faster, we propose the deep learning technique where we use data-driven method. In this method, we generated a dataset of around 2000 simulated lightpaths with 11 features each. We labeled it by providing the criteria that whether the lightpath is within the threshold Bit Error Rate (BER). We then train a Deep Neural Network (DNN) to classify lightpaths that are within the threshold limit and acceptable in terms of QoT or not. By using DNN, we achieve high accuracy (∼98% on test data) despite class imbalance, with strong precision and recall. From our simulation results we found that a DNN can learn the intricate connection between QoT and lightpath parameters, yielding predictions for QoT that are almost instantaneous. This approach enables faster and more efficient network provisioning by obviating the need for time-consuming physics-based QoT calculations.

title: Benchmarking Super-Resolution Models with Tensorflow and JAX on the DermaMNIST Dataset
authors: Medina Kapo, Anel Tanović, Emir Buza
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this paper, a comparison of three super-resolution models based on convolutional neural networks was performed when working with dermatoscopic images. The values of the PSNR and SSIM are above 28 and 70%, respectivelly, which confirms the success of the given models. JAX has proven to be faster than TensorFlow in this paper, especially when running on GPU. JAX proved faster than TensorFlow, with speedups of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1.5} \times \mathbf{- 5} \times$</tex> on GPU and up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4. 2} \times$</tex> on CPU.

title: Camouflaged target detection based on improved deep gradient network model
authors: Zhihao Luo, Wanjun Yu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Aiming at the low detection accuracy of camouflaged target detection at present, as well as the problems of leakage and false detection in complex scenes, an improved camouflaged target detection model based on DGNet is proposed. Firstly, the receptive field convolution block attention module convolution (RFCBAMConv) is used to replace the standard convolution in the original model network to help the model focus on the detailed features of the camouflaged target. Secondly, in order to enable the model to better identify camouflaged targets, the Channel Attention and Spatial Attention Module (CSM) and Distraction Mining Module (DMM) modules are used to reduce the interference of false positives and false negatives, so as to further improve the generalization ability of the model. Experimental results show that the detection accuracy of the improved model on the CAMO-Te, COD10K-Te and NC4K-Te datasets is improved by $3.4 \%, 2.6 \%$ and 2.1% respectively compared with the original model.
