title: Prior-Guided Selective Parameter Fine-Tuning for Source-Free Domain Adaptive Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Fanzhe Yan, Gang Yang, Xun Chen, Yue Yu, Aiping Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) transfers knowledge from pre-trained source models to the un labeled target domain without accessing the private source data. Conventional SFDA methods for medical imageseg mentation typically depend on pseudo-label driven self training with full model fine-tuning. Although these methods have shown decent performance, the underlying principles remain insufficiently explored. In this work, we investigate SFDA through the PAC-Bayesian generalization error bound, demonstrating that its generalization error is jointly constrained by model complexity and pseudo-label noise. Motivated by this, we propose PATH, a selective PArameter fine-tuning framework guided by Topological and Historical priors for SFDA medical image segmentation. Specifically, PATH identifies domain-variant and task-distinctive parameters and sparsely updates them, thereby reducing effective model complexity during adaptation. In addition, PATH estimates pseudo-label reliability by integrating topological structure and historical prediction consistency priors to suppress pseudo-label noise. Extensive experiments on cross-scanner fundus image segmentation and cross modality abdominal multi-organ segmentation benchmarks demonstrate that PATH outperforms competing SFDA methods, achieving state-of-the-art performance. Code will be available at https://github.com/dogeONE-bit/PATH.

title: A Graph Convolution Network Model for Multi Area Distribution System Fast State Estimation
authors: Mohammad Amin Ranjbar, Sasan Azad, Mohammad Taghi Ameli, Hossein Ameli, Goran Strbac
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: State estimation (SE) plays a crucial role in the operation and control of power systems. While traditional approaches are promising, they face challenges such as increased computation time in large networks and reduced efficiency in specific scenarios due to limited knowledge of network topology. The network is divided into areas, and only local measuring devices are used for state estimation within each area. Distance data that may lead to model misinterpretation is not included in this approach. By performing calculations in parallel for different areas, state estimation time is reduced, and the accuracy of the results is improved. This paper also develops a graph convolution network (GCN)-based model to enhance SE accuracy, which considers the topological information of the power system in the form of an adjacency matrix. The model is evaluated on an 118-bus network, with results confirming its effectiveness based on various evaluation metrics.

title: System for Analytical Processing with an Integrated Data Warehouse for Presenting Tourism Trends: (Case study: Sarajevo)
authors: Alen Čelik, Kenan Saračević, Almir Karabegović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents a methodological approach for integrating heterogeneous tourism data into a unified spatiotemporal analytical framework. By combining business intelligence, geospatial processing, and machine learning techniques, the proposed system enables a predictive and spatially aware analysis of tourist behavior. The approach is evaluated through a case study from Sarajevo Canton and demonstrates how fragmented data sources, temporal, spatial, and behavioral, can be semantically aligned to support strategic decision-making in tourism. Although the accuracy of the predictive model is constrained by data limitations, the integrated architecture reveals patterns in tourist flows and spatial clustering that are not captured by traditional methods. The main contribution lies in establishing a generalizable analytical approach to tourism intelligence, bridging data silos, and improving the analytical capabilities of destination management systems.

title: Hybrid System for Macedonian Sign Language Translation and Recognition Using NLP, Computer Vision and 3D Animation
authors: Blagoja Todorovski, Stefan Spasovski, Zoran Ivanovski, Branislav Gerazov, Tomislav Kartalov
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Macedonian Sign Language (MSL) remains underrepresented in digital technologies, creating significant barriers in education and communication. This paper presents a multimodal system that integrates linguistic processing, computer vision, and 3D animation to provide both automatic translation from Macedonian text into sign language and realtime recognition of signs. The pipeline consists of three major modules. The first module is a hybrid text processing system that combines grammatical rules with a fine-tuned multilingual transformer (mBART-50) to convert Macedonian sentences into glosses, achieving a BLEU score of 30.1 and a chrF of 45.0 after hybrid normalization. The second module focuses on visualization, using MediaPipe to extract keypoints from sign videos and Blender to render these into fluid 3D avatar animations. The third module performs recognition of the Macedonian manual alphabet using MobileNetV2 trained on an augmented dataset of over 38,000 images. The system achieves 97.2% validation accuracy and a macro F1-score of 0.936 in recognition tasks. The modular design makes the system suitable for educational platforms, accessibility services, and further research into continuous sign translation.

title: A Rician-Based Physically Motivated Wavelet for Fading Channel Signal Classification
authors: Stefan Panic, Aleksandar Mosic, Vladeta Milenkovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the design and application of a novel mother wavelet inspired by the Rician probability density function (PDF), tailored for classifying Line-of-Sight (LOS) and Non-Line-of-Sight (NLOS) propagation conditions. The proposed Rician wavelet filter is constructed by deriving the corresponding low-pass and high-pass filter coefficients using shifted and normalized Rician PDF samples, ensuring compliance with wavelet admissibility and orthogonality criteria. Using this wavelet, we perform discrete wavelet transform (DWT) decomposition of measured channel impulse responses. Energy features extracted from the first three DWT scales are used to train standard classifiers, including Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Random Forest (RF). Evaluation on a observed dataset demonstrates that the proposed Rician wavelet outperforms traditional wavelet bases in terms of classification accuracy. Experimental results highlight the potential of PDF-driven wavelet design in enhancing the performance of signal classification tasks in wireless channel environments.

title: Guidelines for Selecting Communication Technologies Between Power Electronic Converters and Their Digital Twins in Smart Grid Systems
authors: S. Gajip, P. Njemčević, M. Hamza, M. Dimitrijević, S. Huseinbegović, M. Ćalasan
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Under fluctuating demand and distributed generation, smart-grid (SG) modernization depends on the reliability and efficiency of power electronic converters (PECs). However, PECs face operational stresses and gradual degradation, which compromise their performance. To address these challenges, digital twin (DT) technology is introduced as a virtual counterpart that interacts with the physical PEC, enabling real-time monitoring, predictive maintenance, and performance optimization. Numerous DT implementations for PECs have been reported, yet most focus on modeling/control, leaving communication requirements and technology selection underexplored. To address this gap, in this paper we first review existing DT realizations to identify their key communication requirements. Based on that research, we proposed a classification framework that links DT functionality to appropriate communication solutions and provided practical guidance for selecting the optimal technologies. These guidelines specify which communication technologies are most suitable for each DT category, which makes informed decision-making easier when DT-enabled PECs are used in modern smart grids.

title: Smart Power Transaction of Quaid-e-Azam Solar Park for Grid-Enabled Micro Grid Using PVsyst Software
authors: Umar Mahmood Chohan, Asam ul Haq, Zeeshan Ahmad Arfeen, Zeeshan Rashid, Muhammad Javed, Madia Safdar, Shadi Atalla
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The operational efficiency of a photovoltaic (PV) system is influenced by various factors such as geographical coordinates, site-specific climatic conditions, PV module specifications, solar radiation intensity, module orientation, and inverter efficiency. This paper evaluates the operational performance of an on-grid 100 MWp solar power project located in Bahawalpur, Pakistan. Using the PVsyst software, the performance ratio (PR), system efficiency, and associated losses were simulated and analyzed. The study identifies optimal operating conditions and quantifies how different environmental and system parameters affect overall output. By understanding the real-world behavior of the existing PV system, the findings aim to support the design and deployment of more efficient and cost-effective solar installations in the region. The research underscores the significance of solar irradiance, ambient temperature, and thermal characteristics of the panels in determining system performance.

title: Adaptive Physical Layer Authentication for Underwater Acoustic Sensor Networks with Self-Calibrating Parameters
authors: Bogdan Krivokapic, Slavica Tomovic, Igor Radusinovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a physical layer authentication method for underwater acoustic communication that exploits the channel impulse response (CIR) as a transmitter fingerprint. CIR features extracted from packets are treated as samples from a probability distribution, and authentication is performed by comparing the distribution observed in new packets with the distribution predicted from recent legitimate traffic. To perform these comparisons, distributions are embedded in a Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS), where distances directly capture subtle deviations in channel behavior. To make this computationally feasible on low-resource devices, we approximate the embeddings using Random Fourier Features (RFF), which reduces the complexity of scoring each packet from quadratic to linear time. The scheme adapts to environmental variability through online calibration, deriving acceptance thresholds from the observed dispersion of legitimate packet features. The proposed approach provides both efficiency and robustness, enabling operation without labeled attack data or manual tuning. It delivers high authentication accuracy under static and time-varying sound speed profiles while substantially reducing computational overhead.

title: Lean Transformation in Power Transmission Maintenance
authors: Hussain Essa Lootah, Maryam Ali Abdulqader, Haifa Ismail Mohammad Sharif, Mariam Abdulrahman El Helwe, Damian Joseph Murphy
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Lean principles, though rooted in manufacturing, have shown growing relevance across service and infrastructure sectors, including power transmission. This paper presents Dubai Electricity and Water Authority's (DEWA) experience in adopting Lean methodologies to optimize maintenance processes in its Transmission Power Division. Through a structured transformation program, the division reduced waste, improved asset reliability, and fostered a sustainable culture of continuous improvement. A practical Lean Maintenance Transformation Framework is introduced, demonstrating how Lean can be localized to a utility context. Quantitative results–including streamlining 16 maintenance processes, reduction of 1500 kg of CO2 emissions, and cost savings of 1,437,607 AED–highlight the tangible value achieved.

title: A Framework for Teaching 5G/6G Security with Explainable AI
authors: Evangelia Konstantopoulou, Nicolas Sklavos
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The fifth-generation (5G) and emerging sixthgeneration (6G) networks, are slowly but surely becoming an indispensable part of human life. However, their complexity creates a significant learning challenge when introducing their security concepts into Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) curricula. Thus, there is a need for domain-specific telecommunication security education. In this paper, a concise, modular framework is proposed, utilizing the capabilities of Explainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI). By combining AI-based threat detection examples with XAI visualizations, students learn how intelligent systems identify suspicious activity and understand the reasoning behind these decisions. This curriculum format, which prioritizes conceptual learning, can be easily integrated to interdisciplinary STEM contexts. The pedagogical rationale is presented, following an outline of the main modules of an AI-enabled 5G/6G network security course. Moreover, a prototype scenario simplifying an AI model for educational purposes is provided. Finally, integration possibilities, implementation challenges, and directions for future work are discussed.

title: Binary/Ternary Neural Networks for Gesture and Human Activity Recognition in Ultra Resource-Constrained Sensor Systems
authors: Alberto Rodriguez Arreola, Jose Rodrigo Camacho Perez, Emma Gutierrez Cortes, Theodoros D. Verykios
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Technology plays a vital role in enhancing lives, especially for people with disabilities. Gesture and activity recognition using embedded systems can restore communication, mobility and independence. Yet, enabling such intelligence in ultra resource-constrained sensor systems demands highly efficient, low-power solutions. One promising approach is the use of neural networks with binary or ternary parameters, which significantly reduce memory requirements and computational load. In this paper, we present the training and deployment of binary and ternary neural networks for gesture and human activity recognition on off-the-shelf, ultra resource-constrained sensor systems. The proposed method introduces a fully differentiable, end-to-end framework for training and deploying mixed binary and ternary models directly on the target system. The proposed models offer broad applicability due to their minimal memory requirements and low energy consumption, as validated through experimental evaluation. Experimental results show that the proposed models reduce memory usage by over 80 % and latency by up to 32 %, even when running at a clock speed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 x$</tex> slower than state-of-the-art systems.

title: Optimization of Handover through Knowledge Graph Enabled Coordination between LLM and O-RAN
authors: Alqama Rao, Varun Gowtham, Sindhura Shivaprasad, Florian Schreiner, Marius Corici, Thomas Magedanz
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The evolution of telecommunication networks into 6G has introduced a paradigm shift, aiming to incorporate diverse and heterogeneous technologies along with targeting specialized use-cases tailored to private networks. Furthermore, the increased disaggregation of the network has enabled the ubiquity of Virtualized Network Functions (VNFs) to function on Commercially-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) hardware, opening an ecosystem of open interfaces and open software. Owing to this evolution, the management complexity of the network also grows correspondingly, mandating a shift in approach. In contrast to the static Policy Based Management and Control (PBMC) which requires the management system to be well thought out during the design phase, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is poised to learn and address the requirements during the run-time, introducing flexibility and adaptability, making it easier for the operator to manage and at the same time reducing operations and costs to design the management system. This article presents the incorporation of Large Language Model (LLM) adapted to Knowledge Graph (KG) for the purpose of intelligently triggering and coordinating handover in an Open Radio Access Network (O-RAN) system, thus anchoring KG as the intermediate representation and digital twin of knowledge.

title: AI-driven Programmable Protocols for 6G and Beyond
authors: Pranav Jha, Shwetha Kiran, Rashmi Kamran, Prasanna Chaporkar, Abhay Karandikar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning (AI/ML) technologies have started making a rapid foray into mobile communication networks. It is anticipated that ‘AI for networks’, i.e., incorporation of AI/ML technology into network design, will play a crucial role in future mobile networks. One area that may benefit significantly from the usage of ‘AI for networks’ is the design and optimization of communication protocols in mobile networks. Communication protocols, the building blocks of all communication networks, have traditionally been organized into fixed layered architectures. In addition, they typically possess immutable behaviour with limited user/service specific variations. For example, existing networks, such as the 5th Generation (5G) network, uses the same set of protocols to support all users and services, with limited user/service specific configurations. Considering the requirement to support a vast array of services in future mobile networks, it is time to rethink this traditional ossified layered protocol architecture. In this paper, we propose programmable and adaptive protocols based future mobile network architecture. The proposed architecture can harness AI/ML technology to dynamically design, program and optimize the communication protocols. As discussed in this paper, a mobile network architecture with an AI-driven flexible and customizable communication protocols, is better suited to handle diverse user/service/system requirements, network conditions, and performance requirements of future.

title: A Computationally Efficient & Byzantine-Robust Federated Learning Algorithm for IoT Networks
authors: Ashim Kumar, Nityam Pareek, Vikky Masih, Arghyadip Roy, Prashant W Patil, Ratnajit Bhattacharjee
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a decentralized machine learning paradigm that enables multiple IoT clients to collaboratively train a global model without sharing raw data. However, FL is vulnerable to Byzantine attacks by rogue IoT clients, leading to potential degradation in performance. We propose a novel robust FL aggregation mechanism leveraging ideas from Mutual Information (MI) between clients and Geometric Median (GM) to identify and prune Byzantine updates during the aggregation process. The proposed approach improves robustness by mitigating the impact of Byzantine IoT clients, ensuring a more accurate and efficient learning process. The computational complexity analysis of the proposed technique reveals that robustness is achieved with low computational complexity. The proposed algorithm is evaluated and compared with various state-of-the-art algorithms on various datasets, including real-world datasets for IoT systems.

title: Leakage Rate Analysis for Untrusted RIS Under Non-Orthogonal CCI in 6G Bands
authors: Volkan Özduran
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper investigates the leakage rate (LR) performance of an untrusted reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) in the presence of non-orthogonal co-channel interference (CCI), which arises from nearby randomly deployed non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) transmissions. In addition, to mitigate the information leakage, a limited number of friendly jammers are randomly deployed to interfere with the untrusted RIS. The analysis considers active, passive, and absorptive operating modes of the RIS. Outage probability is employed for the LR analysis, and both analytical and asymptotic expressions are validated through Monte Carlo simulations. The results demonstrate that while non-orthogonal CCI and friendly jammers slightly degrade system performance, this degradation is effectively mitigated by increasing the number of reflecting elements. Moreover, as the RIS becomes larger, the adverse impact of non-orthogonal CCI is significantly reduced.

title: Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS) of LeftHandedness Across Global Populations
authors: Wai Yie Leong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Left-handedness, a prominent phenotype affecting approximately 10% of the global population, has long been hypothesized to possess a polygenic basis influenced by complex gene-environment interactions. Despite previous studies suggesting associations with loci involved in neurodevelopment and brain lateralization, the genetic determinants of handedness remain largely unresolved. This study proposes a comprehensive genome-wide association study (GWAS) across diverse ethnic populations to identify and validate genetic variants correlated with left-handedness. Using high-throughput genotyping data from cohorts in Europe, East Asia, Africa, and the Americas, we applied advanced bioinformatics pipelines-leveraging tools such as PLINK, BOLT-LMM, and FUMA-for quality control, association testing, population stratification correction, and functional annotation. We identified multiple statistically significant single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) ($\mathbf{p}\lt \mathbf{5} \times \mathbf{1 0}^{-\mathbf{8}}$) enriched in genes associated with axonogenesis (e.g., LRRTM1, PCSK6), synaptic plasticity, and corpus callosum development. Pathway enrichment analysis highlighted involvement in leftright asymmetry pathways and Wnt signaling cascades. Polygenic risk scores (PRS) demonstrated moderate predictive power (AUC > 0.68) in distinguishing handedness across populations, with notable variation in allele frequency and effect size due to ancestry-specific genetic backgrounds. Furthermore, functional annotation using GTEx and ENCODE revealed several SNPs acting as expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) in the prefrontal cortex and motor areas of the brain. This research contributes to a deeper understanding of the heritability of handedness and underscores the importance of inclusive, multi-population genetic studies in unraveling complex neurobehavioral traits. The findings hold translational value for neurodevelopmental disorder research, where atypical handedness is often observed as a comorbid phenotype.

title: Evaluating the Performance of Large Language Models on the MCAT
authors: Harrison Chu, Alexis Leo, Arnold Spantzel, Heidi Spantzel, Jessica Tseng, Alyssa Leo, Ashlynn Brar, Gabrielle Dizon, Soroush Seyedhosseini
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The emergence of large language models (LLMs) such as OpenAI’s ChatGPT and Google’s Gemini has opened new possibilities for their use in standardized test preparation. This study evaluates the performance of ChatGPT 4.0 and Gemini (both December 2024 versions) on an official AAMC full-length Medical College Admission Test (MCAT) practice exam. Using a standardized input protocol, we compared the models’ answers and calculated accuracy, MCAT section scores, and percentile rankings. ChatGPT outperformed Gemini, achieving a score of 522 (99th percentile) with an accuracy of 90.87%, compared to Gemini’s 518 (95th percentile) and 84.78% accuracy, with a statistically significant difference $(\mathbf{p}=\mathbf{0. 0 0 5})$. While these results highlight the educational potential of LLMs, they also raise important questions about the relevance of standardized testing in an era of increasingly accessible AI tools. Furthermore, although LLMs perform well on exams, their non-negligible error rates caution against their use in clinical decision-making without human oversight. This study contributes to the growing discussion on how AI may transform medical education, assessment, and the future role of physicians.

title: Case Report of Neurofeedback for a Patient with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
authors: Tomoko Kawatake, Taira Suzuki
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This case report presents a two-month neurofeedback (NF) intervention for a male patient in his 50 s with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and depression. Training at $\mathbf{C z}$ reinforced low-beta $(\mathbf{1 5}-\mathbf{1 8 ~ H z})$ while inhibiting 28 Hz and $22-36 \mathrm{~Hz}$. EEG analysis using the Maximum Entropy Method revealed a transient delta rebound after the sixth session, coinciding with temporary distress but followed by stabilization. Alpha power under eyes-closed conditions showed a sustained increase, associated with the disappearance of trauma-related nightmares and improved sleep. Notably, the rewarded low-beta band itself did not increase, suggesting that clinical improvements stemmed from network-level reorganization rather than isolated reinforcement. Subjective reports indicated reduced irritability, enhanced emotional regulation, and improved self-reflection, corroborated by clinical observation. These findings highlight delta rebound as a potential neurophysiological marker and demonstrate the therapeutic promise of low-beta neurofeedback in PTSD.

title: EEG-based Negative Emotions Detection in a Risk Simulated Autonomous Driving Environments
authors: Nurul Hanis Mohamad Razali, Mohd Shuhanaz Zanar Azalan, Wan Khairunizam, Ekkasit Kumarnsit, Hafiz Halin, Nifareeda Samerphob
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper details an investigation into the detection of fear and focus emotional states using electroencephalography (EEG) signals within risk simulated autonomous driving environments. The study employed a mixed-methods approach, integrating objective EEG data with subjective self-assessment responses from 10 participants exposed to driving in risk simulated environments. A comprehensive methodology for EEG signal acquisition, preprocessing, and feature extraction, including Power Spectral Density (PSD), statistical measures, and Hjorth parameters are implemented. A $\boldsymbol{k}$-Nearest Neighbors ($\boldsymbol{k}$-NN) classifier, enhanced with Principal Component Analysis (PCA), was developed and rigorously evaluated using 10 -fold cross-validation. The results demonstrate the presence of distinguishable EEG patterns between fear and focus, achieving an outstanding overall classification accuracy of 98.76% (using PSD features), with statistical features also performing exceptionally well (97.93%). While self-assessments validated scenario efficacy, detailed perparticipant analysis revealed varying degrees of alignment between physiological and subjective emotional states. This research provides valuable insights into EEG-based emotion recognition in risk simulated environments, laying a foundational groundwork for developing adaptive and usercentered autonomous vehicle systems that enhance safety and trust by monitoring driver emotional states.

title: Enhancing Quantum Key Distribution with Quantum Projective Simulation
authors: Milad Ghadimi, Swaraj Shekhar Nande, Hosein K. Nazari, Riccardo Bassoli, Frank H. P. Fitzek
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper investigates a novel approach to Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) enhanced by Quantum Projective Simulation (QPS), a quantum-inspired reinforcement learning model. By allowing agents to simulate future actions through quantum random walks over a memory network of quantum clips, QPS enables Alice and Bob to dynamically adapt their key distribution strategies based on past experiences. Simulation results show that the QPS-based QKD model achieves faster convergence to optimal strategies, improves resilience against eavesdropping attacks, and maintains a higher success probability compared to traditional QKD methods. These findings suggest that integrating QPS into QKD can significantly enhance the efficiency and security of quantum communication systems in dynamic and adversarial environments, positioning it as a promising candidate for future 6G networks. Index Terms—QKD, QPS, Quantum Random Walk, Artificial Intelligence.

title: Characterizing 5G Core Stability under Dynamic UE Conditions via Outlier Density Analysis
authors: Arun Prakash, Marius Corici, Pragadeeswari Selvakumar, Marcus Purat
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The dynamic nature of User Equipment (UE) life-cycle events, such as registration and de-registration, imposes significant stress on the 5G Core Network (5G CN), potentially leading to performance degradation and failures. While prior work established methods for proactive failure prediction based on control plane metrics, the direct impact of UE churn on system stability requires a deeper investigation. This paper extends previous research by characterizing the correlation between UE registration/de-registration cycles and the density of statistical outliers in network metrics. Through a series of controlled experiments simulating UE churn, we demonstrate that outlier density serves as a sensitive proxy for systemic instability and operational stress. Our findings reveal a strong, predictable pattern of correlation between the number of active UEs and outlier density, allowing us to establish a signature for benign, high-load conditions. As UEs are registered, the outlier density increases in a characteristic way, and as they are de-registered, it returns to a stable baseline. This research validates the utility of outlier density for characterizing the system’s response to dynamic UE activity, which is a critical step in distinguishing normal operational stress from anomalous patterns that precede network failures. This provides a more nuanced understanding of 5G CN behavior and enhances proactive failure prediction mechanisms by offering a simple and direct way to detect the state of the system and adapt to more robust operational configurations without relying on complex prediction algorithms.

title: A Comprehensive Framework for Palm Vein Anti-Spoofing with Preprocessing Pipeline, Dataset and Benchmark
authors: Caiping Yan, Zhi Lan, Hong Li, Yuqi Li, Zonglin Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Non-contact palm-vein recognition has been widely adopted in security-critical applications owing to its contact-free acquisition paradigm and exceptional discriminative power. However, these systems remain susceptible to a spectrum of presentation attacks (PAs), creating significant security risks that require urgent mitigation. Progress on palm-vein anti-spoofing is currently impeded by three fundamental gaps: (i) the absence of an open-source, end-to-end pipeline for preprocessing liveness-detection data; (ii) a lack of publicly available datasets specifically tailored to anti-spoofing evaluation; and (iii) the unavailability of benchmark studies employing standardized protocols and reference implementations. In light of these key issues, we make the following four contributions. Firstly, we propose a new open-source preprocessing pipeline that can significantly improve model performance, reducing errors by up to 53.3%. Secondly, we introduce PVASD, a new largest known dataset comprised of 1,187,519 images belonging to 5,515 subjects, which consists of 880,241 live palm vein images along with 307,278 spoof attack images including 16 different attack types – both 2d (printed stuff) and 3d (gloves and prosthesis models) attacks captured under a variety of environments using off-the-shelf commercial-grade sensors at five resolutions. Lastly, comprehensive benchmarks are also created by evaluating three types of representative methods namely classical image classification models, face anti-spoofing methods adapted from face domain and anomaly-detection-based approaches, while our experimental results reveal unique characteristics intrinsic only to palm vein spoof attacks, which will hopefully provide valuable guidance to researchers for further investigation. Furthermore, we also expanded PVASD by adding 20,000 spoof samples generated by artificial intelligence, and evaluated the vulnerability of the existing models to deepfake attacks. We will release our preprocessing pipeline, dataset, and benchmark codes at https://github.com/valhongli/PVASD to advance future reproducible studies and accelerate palm-vein anti-spoofing algorithmic research.

title: Design of Wideband Co-Linearly-Polarized Magnetoelectric Dipole Antenna With Stable Gain for Vehicular Sensing and Communications
authors: Liangliang Zhao, Aidong Li, Yongmao Wang, Lehu Wen, Hailiang Zhu, Mingxuan Zheng, Huiling Zhao, Chufeng Hu, Mingyue Yang, Steven Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: A novel wideband co-linearly-polarized magnetoelectric (ME) dipole antenna with stable gain has been designed for vehicular sensing and communications applications, which uses folded ME dipole, decoupling plate, irregular metal wall, slots on the bottom of the suspended rectangular tube, and parasitic metal posts. Firstly, by using folded ME dipole, the operating bandwidth can be broadened significantly. Then, a series of technologies for adjusting the transmission zero are introduced to improve the isolation across the whole bandwidth, by using decoupling plate, irregular metal wall, slots on the bottom of the suspended rectangular tube to change the current distribution. Furthermore, several methods modifying the field distribution are employed to realize the stable and high gain covering the working band, by utilizing the additional metal posts combined with the irregular metal wall, slots on the bottom of the suspended rectangular tube for changing the deteriorated field distribution. Finally, the proposed antenna with the above three significant contributions is fabricated and measured to validate the proposed design. The experiment results show that the wide operational bandwidth across 1.75-3.95 GHz (77.2%), good polarization isolation higher than 22 dB, and the peak gain of 9.1 dBi with a stable fluctuation less than 1.5 dBi are obtained. These superiorities demonstrate a very promising candidate for applications in in-band full-duplex fields, which will greatly facilitate the development of vehicular sensing and communications.

title: A Broadband Low-Profile Electronic Beam-Scanning Transmitarray Antenna with Dual Polarization Independent Control Capability
authors: Yong Heng Zhao, Sheng Sun, Changrong Liu, Ping Li
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, a novel broadband low-profile recon figurable transmitarray (RTA) antenna with independent dual polarization (DP) beam-scanning capability is proposed. The enhanced bandwidth is achieved through bow-tie patches incorporating integratedvias in the transmission cell design, while independent control of dual-polarized responses is realized by four strategically placed PIN diodes. To significantly reduce the feed-to-RTA distance, a specifically designed phase-controlled re f lectarray (PCRA) with two-degree-of-freedom cells is employed to generate a virtual focal point, reducing the profile height to one-third of conventional designs. A 16 × 16-cell DP-RTA proto type operating at 11.5 GHz was fabricated to validate the design. Utilizing the designed 1-bit phase distributions optimization method based on the discrete human evolutionary optimization algorithm (DHEOA), the antenna achieves good ±50° 2D beam scanning performance. Measurements demonstrate a 38.3% 3-dB gain bandwidth (9.5-14 GHz) and a peak gain of 21.7 dBi.

title: Market-Driven Optimization of Energy Storage Technologies: A Comparative Study of MISO and NYISO
authors: Mohammadali Norouzi, MD Arafath Uzzaman, Behnam Mohammadi-Ivatloo, Jamshid Aghaei
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of energy storage system (ESS) performance in two major U.S. electricity markets, the Midcontinent independent system operator (MISO) and the New York independent system operator (NYISO). The study evaluates the revenue potential and market participation of five ESS technologies, Li-Ion, Advanced Lead-Acid, Flywheel, Li-Iron Phosphate, and Vanadium Redox Flow, in arbitrage and frequency regulation services using QuEST software. Results show that each market structure and each technology attribute strongly affect profitability. Fast-response storage technologies excel in frequency regulation services, whereas longer-duration systems achieve steadier returns from energy arbitrage. The comparative analysis indicates that MISO generally provides greater revenue opportunities for storage optimized for sustained output and rapid cycling, whereas NYISO market conditions lead to different optimal strategies. In both markets, adding frequency regulation to arbitrage operations (revenue stacking) significantly boosts total revenue for all technologies.

title: GIS-Based Assessment of Adaptive System Restoration for Enhancing Electricity Grid Resilience
authors: Ali Reza Kheirkhah, Jonatas Boas Leite, Jamshid Aghaei, Kianoush Emami, Hassan Baji, Behnam Mohammadi-Ivatloo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a GIS-enabled analytical framework aimed at improving the operational resilience of power distribution networks facing high-impact, low-probability (HILP) events. The approach estimates the total cost of energy not supplied through Monte Carlo simulations (MCSs) and applies risk-based metrics—specifically Value at Risk (VaR)—to quantify system resilience. By integrating Geographic Information Systems (GIS), the framework spatially represents network vulnerabilities and assesses the effects of resilience-enhancing strategies, including Fault Location, Isolation, and Service Restoration (FLISR) and Demand Response Management (DRM). In contrast to traditional models that depend on static input data, the proposed system incorporates real-time sensor feedback and adaptive controls, forming a dynamic decision-support loop. The framework is validated using data from four operational feeders, demonstrating its capability to guide resilience-focused investment and improve system performance under uncertain conditions.

title: A Wavelet Ensemble Approach for Denoising Partial Discharge Signals in Smart Grids
authors: Hassan Ali, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Christian Staubach
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Partial discharge (PD) signals are critical for detecting insulation faults in high-voltage equipment, playing a key role in the condition monitoring of smart grid infrastructure. However, these signals are often obscured by external noise sources, hindering accurate diagnostics. This paper presents a Wavelet Ensemble Denoising approach with Segment-Wise Morphological Alignment (WEMSA) to enhance PD signal clarity in smart grid environments. The method fuses detail coefficients from multiple wavelet bases using energy-based weighting and refines them through local shape-preserving adjustments. Experimental results on synthetic PD signals demonstrate that the proposed method significantly outperforms conventional techniques such as Energy-Based Wavelet Selection (EBWS) and SNR-Based Wavelet Selection (SNRBWS) in terms of Mean Squared Error (MSE), Correlation Coefficient (CC), and output Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR). The WEMSA framework exhibits robust performance under low-SNR conditions and shows strong potential for real-time and embedded diagnostics in smart grid systems.

title: Energy Disaggregation & Appliance Identification in a Smart Home: Transfer Learning Enables Edge Computing
authors: M. Hashim Shahab, Ghulam Amjad Hussain, Hasan Mujtaba Buttar, Ahsan Mehmood, Waqas Aman, M. Mahboob Ur Rahman, M. Wasim Nawaz, Haris Pervaiz
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) or energy disaggregation aims to extract the load profiles of individual consumer electronic appliances, given an aggregate load profile of the mains of a smart home. This work proposes a novel deep-learning and edge computing approach to solve the NILM problem and a few related problems as follows. 1) We build upon the reputed seq2-point convolutional neural network (CNN) model to come up with the proposed seq2-[3] - point CNN model to solve the (home) NILM problem and site-NILM problem (basically, NILM at a smaller scale). 2) We solve the related problem of appliance identification by building upon the pre-trained 2D-CNN models, i.e., AlexNet, ResNet-18, and DenseNet-121, which are fine-tuned on two custom datasets that consist of Wavelets and short-time Fourier transform (STFT)-based 2D electrical signatures of the appliances. Low-frequency REDD dataset is used for all problems, except site-NILM where REFIT dataset is used. As for the results, we achieve a maximum accuracy of 94.6 % for home-NILM, 81 % for site-NILM, and 88.9 % for appliance identification (with ResNet model).

title: Edge-Deployable Multi-Modal CNN for Intelligent Fault Diagnosis in Solar Photovoltaic Arrays
authors: Rekha R Nair, Tina Babu, Alavikunhu Panthakkan, Majida Appathil, Balamurugan Balusamy, Hussain Al-Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The global photovoltaic market has reached 191 GW capacity, yet operational faults cause <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 - 2 5 \%}$</tex> energy losses due to inadequate detection methods. This research presents a novel multi-modal machine learning framework that integrates thermal imaging and electrical signature analysis for intelligent fault detection in photovoltaic systems. The methodology employs a dual-branch convolutional neural network with attention mechanisms to dynamically fuse thermal and electrical features, enabling superior fault classification across eight fault categories including hot spots, partial shading, soiling, and degradation. Evaluated on the IRPV dataset containing 1,247 thermal images with synchronized electrical measurements, the proposed system achieved 94.7 % accuracy and 93.2 % weighted F1-score, outperforming single-modal approaches by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{7. 4 - 1 2. 2 \%}$</tex>. The attention mechanism effectively balanced feature contributions, with real-time inference capability of 15.3 ms on edge devices. This advancement enables automated monitoring systems that can significantly reduce maintenance costs, improve energy yield through early fault detection, and support the sustainable expansion of renewable energy infrastructure globally.

title: Quantum-Resistant Authentication Based on Digital Signatures: An Analysis and Study Case Under a Transition Scenario
authors: Eliú Moreno Ramírez, Miguel Morales-Sandoval, Claudia Feregrino Uribe
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In this paper, we present an analysis and a case study of quantum-resistant message authentication in vehicular communications, where the transition from classic to quantum-resistant cryptography is evident as vehicles have a long life span and must support current standards and future ones in the coming years. Under such a scenario, a partially hybrid scheme with both types of cryptography could be the most suitable solution approach. For the specific case of the vehicular domain, this paper discusses a Hardware/Software (Hw/Sw) co-design that meets application domain constrains, in terms of performance and payload imposed by current standards. This approach could be extended to other domains, such as the military or industrial ones, where the same assumptions could apply.

title: Design of Survivable Fronthaul Networks with Power-over-Fiber
authors: Egemen Erbayat, Gustavo B. Figueiredo, Shih-Chun Lin, Motoharu Matsuura, Hiroshi Hasegawa, Suresh Subramaniam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Modern fronthaul networks require reliable, power-efficient solutions as 5G/6G densification accelerates. Power-over-Fiber (PWoF) addresses power challenges by eliminating electrical grid dependencies, especially crucial during disasters. However, existing optimization approaches ignore fiber cuts and optical splitter failures, which can cause cascading network failures. We formulate the resilient fronthaul network design problem using Integer Linear Programming (ILP) to ensure survivability under single-point failures. Due to computational complexity, we develop a relaxed formulation ensuring splitter-disjoint paths and introduce the Redundant Randomized Successive Splitter Assignment (RRSSA) heuristic algorithm. Numerical evaluation across 100 topologies shows RRSSA achieves near-optimal performance with 35-40% cost savings over baseline methods while maintaining polynomial-time complexity for practical deployment.

title: Uncertainty-Aware MPC Routing for UAV-Assisted VANETs using RNN-GANs
authors: Prangya Priyadarshini, Suchismita Chinara, Arun Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The huge Internet of Things (IoT) that 6G envisions needs transmission systems that are smart, self-sufficient, and long-lasting. It’s hard to meet the strict Quality of Service (QoS) needs of future applications when there is a lot of movement and the network conditions are hard to predict, like Vehicular IoT (V-IoT). This study presents an AI-driven, cross-layer control architecture that uses dynamic aerial edge nodes (UAVs) to provide reliable data distribution. A Recurrent Neural Network-based Generative Adversarial Network (RNN-GAN) is essentially a prediction engine that forecasts the probability distributions of future link quality and network congestion. These observations from different layers are fed into a Model Predictive Control (MPC) agent at the network layer. This agent chooses routes ahead of time while taking risk into account. Preliminary simulation results show that the suggested strategy improves Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) by up to 16%, lowers end-to-end latency by over 30% with high traffic, and up to 65% when employing aerial relays.

title: Q-CryptChain: Next-Generation Quantum Cryptography Blockchain Security Framework for the Metaverse
authors: Sandeep Ravikanti, Jay Dave, Hai Dong, Iqbal Gondal, Nikumani Choudhury, Kaushik Voolapalli
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The Metaverse integrates virtual reality, augmented reality, and decentralized economies, but its security foundations are increasingly threatened by quantum computing. Classical cryptography used in blockchain systems is vulnerable to quantum attacks, while existing blockchain-based frameworks lack quantum resistance. Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) offers provably secure communication, but has not been systematically applied to Metaverse security. To address this gap, we propose Q-CryptChain, a hybrid framework that combines QKD with blockchain to deliver quantum-safe confidentiality, tamper-proof integrity, and continuous authentication. We formalize the system and threat model, define explicit security properties, and present strengthened algorithms for handshake, transaction validation, and session monitoring. Q-CryptChain provides a future-proof security foundation for Metaverse ecosystems, enabling trustworthy interactions against emerging quantum-era threats.

title: Securing O-RAN: A Modular xApp-Based Defense Framework in the Near-RT RIC
authors: Prudhvi Kumar Kakani, Manjunath Reddy Chavva Balannagari, Matthias Tammen, Hans D. Schotten
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The progressive adoption of O-RAN architectures enables greater flexibility and innovation through programmability and modularization but also introduces novel cybersecurity risks due to increased system complexity and exposure. The core innovation of this paper is an embedded security framework operating inside the Near-RT RIC – the real-time "brain" of open cellular networks. Unlike traditional telecom security tools that guard the network perimeter or analyze data offline, this paper proposes developing modular defense mechanisms that run within the RIC itself. It leverages containerized security xApps (extensible applications) inside the RIC to perform real-time anomaly detection and automated threat mitigation. These xApps use hybrid artificial intelligence models to detect both high-volume attacks (e.g. DDoS flooding, jamming) and stealthy adversarial attacks targeting the RAN’s control logic. Upon detection, the framework enforces mitigation actions—such as quarantining rogue xApps, throttling malicious traffic, or detaching compromised user equipment—within the RIC’s control loop. This approach elevates the RIC from a potential weakness to a resilient, autonomous control point—capable of rapid, trustworthy, and intelligent defense against both volumetric and adversarial threats in AI-native O-RAN networks.

title: Dependency-Aware Microservice Placement in Dynamic Vehicular Edge Computing
authors: Surayya A, Md. Muzakkir Hussain, Firoj Gazi, S Hemanth Durga Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Vehicular Edge Computing (VEC) is a promising paradigm to support latency-sensitive and computation-intensive vehicular applications such as object detection, trajectory prediction, and hazard alerts. Microservice architectures enable scalability and modularity, but placing dependent microservices across heterogeneous edge service providers (ESPs) remains a critical challenge. Existing placement strategies often treat services independently, ignoring inter-service dependencies, which leads to increased inter-node communication delays and degraded performance. In this paper, we propose a dependency-aware microservice placement framework for VEC using deep reinforcement learning. Our approach leverages a Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) based actor–critic agent to learn placement decisions that jointly minimize end-to-end service latency and maximize resource utilization while respecting capacity and SLA constraints. Experiments on real vehicular mobility traces from Luxembourg City demonstrate that the proposed method significantly reduces service latency and SLA violations compared to random and greedy baselines, while efficiently utilizing edge resources.

title: Advance Scheduling Algorithm in 5G for Healthcare Robotics
authors: Bikas Kumar Singh, Navin Kumar
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: 5G wireless technology is changing healthcare robotics by enabling remote surgeries, quick diagnostics, and autonomous patient management. These applications require reliable communication networks and appropriate scheduling that meet strict Quality of Service (QoS) standards for safety and responsiveness. However, existing 5G scheduling algorithms like Round Robin and Proportional Fair do not meet the necessary latency and reliability demands of robotic surgeries, often causing delays. To solve this, a new scheduling algorithm is proposed that uses 5G features like network slicing and prioritization to ensure low-latency communication for healthcare robotics. This algorithm assigns network resources based on task urgency and channel conditions, improving the performance of critical medical operations. Testing of the new scheduler on the Open-Air Interface 5G simulation platform shows better throughput and reduced latency for high-priority tasks. Future research will explore using AI-driven methods and hybrid scheduling to enhance network performance further.

title: Enhancing Algebra Learning and Technology Acceptance Through a Gamified Mobile App
authors: Elizabeth Mena-Aviles, Luz Natzin López-Gonzalez, Jose Manuel Medina Pozos, Claudia Hernandez-Mena
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study evaluates the impact of Math Modelation Quest (MMQ), a gamified mobile application designed to enhance algebra learning and promote technology acceptance among high school students. A quasi-experimental design was implemented with 70 participants, combining pre- and post-tests to measure algebra performance and a Technology Acceptance Model (TAM) survey to assess perceptions of the app. After three in-class sessions, results revealed a statistically significant improvement in algebra scores, with the group average increasing by 7 points, benefiting both lower- and higher-achieving students as well as both genders. The overall TAM mean was 3.06 on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-4$</tex> Likert scale, indicating favorable acceptance of the app, with perceived ease of use as the strongest dimension. These findings confirm MMQ's potential as a scalable, student-centered tool that fosters both measurable academic progress and positive attitudes toward digital learning and extend previous pilot results with undergraduate students by demonstrating similar benefits for high school learners.

title: Evaluating the Inherent Cyber Resilience of Inverter-Based Microgrids Against PLL Attacks Under Fault Conditions
authors: Alkistis Kontou, Mazheruddin Syed, Alexandros Paspatis, Zhiwang Feng, Charalambos Konstantinou, Nikos Hatziargyriou
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Recently, the concept of inherent cyber resilience has emerged, advocating the use of passive mitigation strategies that leverage the natural dynamics of microgrid components. Prior work has demonstrated that when the phase-locked-loop (PLL) of a grid-following (GFL) inverter is under attack, reducing the droop gain of the closest located grid forming (GFM) inverter effectively mitigates the exhibited voltage sags due to routine load changes. Building on this foundation, this paper first investigates the impact of PLL attacks under major disturbances, such as electrical faults. Simulation studies reveal that fault-induced effects can be magnified, leading to more severe voltage drops, increasing the risk of generator disconnection or even systemwide blackout. Second, it is shown that reducing the droop gain of the GFM inverter effectively restores fault responses to levels observed in an uncompromised system, enhancing system robustness and demonstrating that the concept of inherent cyber resilience remains effective even under fault scenarios.

title: An Encoder-Decoder Retnet Model for Fmcw Radar Interference Mitigation
authors: Elif Ozturk, Isin Erer
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Interference mitigation is one of the primary challenges in radar technology, particularly for automotive radars that utilize frequency-modulated continuous wave radars, where reliability is crucial. In this study, the RetNet-ED model, an encoder-decoder architecture that adapts the retentive network for the signal-to-signal task of interference mitigation, is proposed. The core innovation is the design of a stable, deep architecture that successfully applies the RetNet mechanism to the complex domain of radar signals. Specifically, a segmented processing pipeline to handle long sequences of signal and gated residual connections are added, a key stabilization technique that enables the deep network to converge effectively. Extensive experiments using the open-source ARIM-v2 dataset demonstrate that RetNet-ED delivers state-of-the-art performance. In particular, it exceeds a robust Transformer baseline in Signal-to-Distortion Ratio (SDR) and sets a new benchmark for both Amplitude and Phase Estimation Error, demonstrating superior reconstruction accuracy across all tested Signal-to-Noise Ratios (SNR). This work demonstrates that the RetNet model, with proper architectural adaptation, is a successor to the transformer model, providing a high-performance alternative for complex signal processing tasks and offering a new, validated approach to developing high-quality interference cancellation models.

title: Federated Execution of Scientific Workflows
authors: Vojdan Kjorveziroski, Sonja Filiposka, Anastas Mishev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Workflow management systems (WfMSs) allow the execution of scientific and general-purpose workflows over multiple compute nodes, dealing with aspects such as scheduling, orchestration, and data management. Existing WfMSs focus on working within a single infrastructure, which limits their scalability, resiliency, and accessibility. We present an architecture for a federated WfMS capable of orchestrating workflows on multiple geographically dispersed infrastructures. This approach allows the pooling of resources, offering theoretically limitless scalability, and makes access to highly performant and specialized hardware more accessible to researchers and end-users alike. We also introduce support for a novel runtime environment in the world of scientific workflows - WebAssembly, suitable for execution of massively parallel workflow tasks. We validate the architecture by extending a real-world WfMS with new federation features, enabling task execution across different infrastructures depending on workflow resource requirements and users' preferences regarding execution location.

title: Advancing Renewable Microgrid Systems in Mosul: Integration Strategies and Management Solutions
authors: Khursheed Sabeel, Maher Al-Greer, Omar Abdulwahid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The global transition toward sustainable energy systems is accelerating, driven by increasing environmental concerns, the volatility of fossil fuel markets, and the need for energy security. In regions like Mosul, Iraq-where infrastructure has faced significant disruption-developing resilient and sustainable energy solutions is particularly urgent. Microgrids, powered by renewable energy sources such as solar and wind, offer a viable path to decentralize electricity supply, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and decrease reliance on costly diesel generators. However, effective integration and management of renewable resources in microgrids remain technically challenging due to their intermittent and unpredictable nature. Conventional control strategies often struggle to maintain system stability, especially when renewable supply exceeds demand or fluctuates rapidly. In this context, intelligent control methods are essential to ensure efficient energy dispatch and storage coordination. This study proposes a fuzzy logic controller (FLC) to enhance power management across four interconnected microgrid zones in Mosul. The controller dynamically balances load demands, optimizes energy storage usage, and reduces diesel dependency, providing a cost-effective and environmentally sustainable solution. Through simulation in MATLAB/Simulink, the system demonstrates its potential to transform microgrid operations, contributing to a smarter, cleaner, and more resilient energy future for regions.

title: Bi-Directional GNN-Based Localization of PD Sources in Distributed Windings of HV Rotating Machines
authors: Hassan Ali, Christian Staubach, Muhammad Sheikh
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Accurate localization of partial discharges (PDs) in spatially distributed windings of high-voltage rotating machines is critical for insulation health monitoring. This paper proposes a novel bi-directional graph neural network (GNN) model to localize PD sources in linear (path-type) winding structures. The model leverages PD signal arrival times in both directions as node features in a graph representation of the winding. A synthetic dataset simulating PD wave propagation with noisy arrival times was used to train and validate the model. The proposed method achieved high classification accuracy and demonstrated strong robustness to noise. The approach is scalable and shows promise for real-world monitoring of rotating machinery.

title: Strategic PMU Deployment for Grid Observability and Stability: First Deployment in Rwanda
authors: Rock Agon, Jasper Kwizera, Dieudonne Iradukunda, Ateny Aguto, Barry Rawn
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Despite increasing instability and recurrent blackouts, advanced monitoring technologies remain underutilized in Rwanda's power grid. This paper presents the first comprehensive study on strategic Phasor Measurement Unit (PMU) deployment in Rwanda, integrating optimal placement, field testing, and stability analysis. The Optimal PMU Placement problem was formulated using a mixed-integer linear programming framework and solved through a customized combinatorial setcover search refined with observability redundancy metrics. A constrained variant of the algorithm was further developed to determine optimal PMU siting under limited deployment budgets, identifying the top five critical substations that maximize network observability. Comparative benchmarking with Depth-First Search and commercial-solver-based MILP approaches verified the method's accuracy, achieving full topological observability with 21 PMUs. A pilot PMU installation provided 50 frames-per-second synchrophasor data, which analyzed, revealed interarea oscillations. These results demonstrate the value of highresolution synchrophasor analytics and establish a scalable, datadriven framework for resilient grid modernization in emerging power systems.

title: A Hermite Transform-Based Watermarking Approach for Robust and Imperceptible Image Protection
authors: Andjela Draganić, Djordje Stanković, Nedjeljko Lekić, Irena Orović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper proposes a digital image watermarking approach in the Hermite transform domain. A two-dimensional Hermite transform is used and the watermark is embedded by avoiding the largest transform coefficients, preserving visual quality while maintaining robustness. Due to the sparsity and localization of the Hermite basis, the method remains resistant to common attacks such as compression and filtering. Experimental results confirm an effective trade-off between imperceptibility and robustness.

title: The Wisdom of the Crowd: High-Fidelity Classification of Cyber-Attacks and Faults in Power Systems Using Ensemble and Machine Learning
authors: Emad Abukhousa, Syed Sohail Feroz Syed Afroz, Fahad Alsaeed, Abdulaziz Qwbaiban, Saman Zonouz, A.P. Sakis Meliopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents a high-fidelity evaluation frame-work for machine learning (ML)-based classification of cyber-attacks and physical faults using electromagnetic transient simulations with digital substation emulation at 4.8 kHz. Twelve ML models, including ensemble algorithms and a multi-layer perceptron (MLP), were trained on labeled time-domain measurements and evaluated in a real-time streaming environment designed for sub-cycle responsiveness. The architecture incorporates a cycle-length smoothing filter and confidence threshold to stabilize decisions. Results show that while several models achieved nearperfect offline accuracies (up to 99.9%), only the MLP sustained robust coverage (98-99%) under streaming, whereas ensembles preserved perfect anomaly precision but abstained frequently (10-49% coverage). These findings demonstrate that offline accuracy alone is an unreliable indicator of field readiness and underscore the need for realistic testing and inference pipelines to ensure dependable classification in inverter-based resources (IBR)-rich networks.

title: Relative Freshness Stochastic Hybrid Systems Markov Chain (RF-SHS-MC) model for the study of Age of Information
authors: Y Arun Kumar Reddy, T. G Venkatesh
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The Age of Information (AoI) quantifies the freshness of status updates in a remote monitoring system. This paper introduces a new technique to calculate the average AoI efficiently using stochastic hybrid systems (SHS) analysis. In this paper, the relative freshness of packets in a queueing system is used to define the discrete states of the SHS Markov chain. We validate the average AoI for M/M/1/1 and M/M/1/2 queuing systems with First Come First Serve (FCFS) queuing discipline using this relative freshness approach. Furthermore, we extend our analysis to dual-queue status update systems.

title: DDPTA: Zero-Shot Learning for Skeleton-Based Action Recognition
authors: Jinjie Wang, Bi Zeng, Shenghong Zhong, Pengfei Wei, Xiaoting Gao
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Traditional skeleton-based action recognition methods rely on large labeled datasets, which are costly to collect and unsuitable for hazardous actions, thereby limiting generalization. To overcome these limitations, recent works adopt zero-shot learning by using rich textual descriptions to guide the alignment and recognition of unlabeled skeleton features. However, these methods still struggle with similar actions (e.g., reading vs. writing), due to ambiguity arising from noise in both modalities. We propose the Discriminative Dual-Prototype TextAlignment (DDPTA) framework. Our framework introduces a novel dual-prototype design with tailored refinement strategies to effectively distill these two complementary prototypes. For the Spatial Prototype, our CycleSpatial module first distills the action's core joint form from noisy spatial features, which is then guided by a Sieve-based Alignment. For the Temporal Prototype, our MambaTempo module leverages the Selective State Space Model to extract representations across distinct temporal stages, enabling fine-grained alignment with descriptions of different time periods. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superior performance of our method, showcasing its effectiveness in advancing the field of zero-shot skeleton-based action recognition.

title: FedPML: Federated Prototype Meta-Learning for Adaptation and Generalization in Distributed Environments
authors: Hunmin Lee, Kehua Wang, Daehee Seo
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Federated learning (FL) holds significant promise for enabling automatic modulation classification (AMC) across distributed wireless Internet-of-Things (IoT) systems while preserving data privacy. Yet, its deployment in real-world scenarios is hindered by two fundamental limitations: the inability to generalize across non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) clients without sacrificing personalization, and the lack of fast, data-efficient local adaptation mechanisms under non-IID, resource-constrained conditions. In this work, we present FedPML, a novel federated prototype-based meta-learning framework that directly addresses these challenges through a unified and scalable approach. FedPML leverages a lightweight Reptile-based meta-optimization strategy and class-level prototypes to jointly optimize for cross-client consistency and local task adaptability. This design enables rapid personalization with minimal data and computation, while preserving global knowledge alignment across heterogeneous clients. Extensive experiments on standard AMC benchmarks under a wide range of IID and non-IID conditions show that FedPML consistently outperforms strong FL baselines, achieving higher accuracy, faster convergence, and reduced communication overhead. The results demonstrate that FedPML is a powerful and practical solution for realizing resilient, low-latency AMC in decentralized IoT networks.

title: An Online Error Estimation Method Based on Two Rotational Inertial Navigation Systems
authors: Lin Yan, Lei Wang, Haorui Du
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Rotation modulation technology significantly enhances the navigation accuracy of inertial navigation systems (INS), thereby facilitating the widespread application of rotational inertial navigation systems (RINS). In marine or airborne applications, it is common to install two or more RINS units on the same carrier. By employing information fusion techniques, the navigation performance can be significantly enhanced. This paper proposes an online error estimation method for two RINSs. This method is based on the information fusion of two systems. It employs two RINSs with rotation strategies around different axes and utilizes rotation modulation technology to improve the observability of inertial sensor errors. Through Kalman filtering, the online optimal estimation of the gyro drift, accelerometer bias, scale factors and installation misalignment angles of two systems can be achieved. The simulation and experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in performing online estimation of inertial sensors errors for the two RINSs. Specifically, the estimation accuracy reaches about 0.001°/h for gyroscope drift, about 2μg for accelerometer bias, about 2″for misalignment angles, and about 2 ppm for scale factors in both static and dynamic conditions. Through error compensation and information fusion, the navigation accuracy has increased by 62% in a static state and by 57% in a dynamic condition, thereby validating the efficacy of the proposed methodology.

title: GrowSP++: Growing Superpoints and Primitives for Unsupervised 3D Semantic Segmentation
authors: Zihui Zhang, Weisheng Dai, Bing Wang, Bo Li, Bo Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: We study the problem of 3D semantic segmentation from raw point clouds. Unlike existing methods which primarily rely on a large amount of human annotations for training neural networks, we proposes GrowSP++, an unsupervised method to successfully identify complex semantic classes for every point in 3D scenes, without needing any type of human labels. Our method is composed of three major components: 1) a feature extractor incorporating 2D-3D feature distillation, 2) a superpoint constructor featuring progressively growing superpoints, and 3) a semantic primitive constructor with an additional growing strategy. The key to our method is the superpoint constructor together with the progressive growing strategy on both super points and semantic primitives, driving the feature extractor to progressively learn similar features for 3D points belonging to the same semantic class. We extensively evaluate our method on five challenging indoor and outdoor datasets, demonstrating state of-the-art performance over all unsupervised baselines. We hope our work could inspire more advanced methods for unsupervised 3D semantic learning.

title: MorphoCopter: Design, Modeling, and Control of a New Transformable Quad–Bi Copter_supp1-3643609.mp4
authors: Minghui Zheng
publish: N/A
abstract: This article presents a novel morphing quadrotor, named MorphoCopter, covering its design, modeling, control, and experimental tests. It features a unique single rotary joint that enables rapid transformation into an ultranarrow profile. Although quadrotors have seen widespread adoption in applications, such as cinematography, agriculture, and disaster management, with increasingly sophisticated control systems, their hardware configurations have remained largely unchanged, limiting their capabilities in certain environments. Our design addresses this by enabling the hardware configuration to change on the fly when required. In standard flight mode, the MorphoCopter adopts an X configuration, functioning as a traditional quadcopter, but can quickly fold into a stacked bicopters arrangement or any configuration in between. Existing morphing designs often sacrifice controllability in compact configurations or rely on complex multijoint systems. Moreover, our design achieves a greater width reduction than any existing solution. We develop a new inertia and control-action aware adaptive control system that maintains robust performance across all rotary-joint configurations. The prototype can reduce its width from 447 to 138 mm (nearly 70% reduction) in just a few seconds. We validated the MorphoCopter through rigorous simulations and a comprehensive series of flight experiments, including robustness tests, trajectory tracking, and narrow-gap passing tests.
