title: Comparison of Clustering Algorithms on Facial Image Embeddings: K-Means vs. Fuzzy C-Means
authors: Ángel García-Báez, Héctor-Gabriel Acosta-Mesa, Sergio Hernández-Méndez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study investigates the ability of unsupervised clustering algorithms to identify latent structures in the FairFace image dataset. To do this, high-dimensional feature vectors are extracted from each image using the AlexNet convolutional neural network. The K-means and Fuzzy C-means algorithms are applied, and the optimal number of clusters is determined to be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{k}=2$</tex>. However, external validation, by comparing the groups formed with the seven racial labels, reveals a low correspondence, showing an almost equal distribution of classes in both clusters. It is concluded that, although the algorithms identify a consistent bipartite structure in the data, this does not correspond to the predefined racial categories. This suggests that the features extracted by AlexNet are dominated by other visual attributes, such as gender, lighting, or pose, and are not sufficient on their own to separate the data according to the underlying racial classification.

title: Educational Integration of ESP32 Project-Based Learning with Generative AI: Design, Implementation, and Evaluation in Two Engineering Cohorts
authors: Jose Manuel Medina Pozos, Jose M. Nieto-Jalil
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Microcontroller education is shifting from syntaxfocused programming to engineering reasoning under real constraints. We report a five-week, project-based and cooperative learning module using ESP32 with Arduino, where generative <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{A I}$</tex> is allowed as guided scaffolding under mandatory traceability and individual oral verification. Two independent cohorts (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=14$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=15; N=29$</tex>) worked in triads with rotating roles and evidence boards. Summative assessment combined public prototype demonstration (50 percent) and individual viva (50 percent), while structured peer assessment supported accountability. The overall mean grade was 75.54 (SD 14.61); cohort means were 77.45 and 73.75, with a small between-cohort difference (Cohen d about 0.25). The approval rate was 72.4 percent. Peer assessment averaged 0.917 and correlated strongly with grades (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r$</tex> about 0.78 overall; 0.85 and 0.69 by cohort), indicating alignment between recognized contributions and summative performance. Student perception was high and homogeneous across teaching, guidance, environment, expertise, and challenge. We conclude that integrating traceable generative AI with product-viva-peer assessment can accelerate learning in short blocks without compromising validity, offering a replicable design for instrumentation and control courses. The study provides pedagogical insights into how GenAI-supported PBL can enhance engineering reasoning and accountability. It contributes an evidence-based design model that integrates authentic assessment, cooperative learning, and AI literacy for modern engineering education.

title: Large-Scale Validation and Analysis of the Rejection Capacity in Entropic Associative Memory
authors: Ángel Fernando Bórquez, Rafael Morales, Luis A. Pineda
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The Entropic Associative Memory (EAM) is a cognitively inspired computational model that combines probabilistic recognition with an efficient pattern storage and retrieval architecture. Previous evaluations, limited to small domains of about ten classes and a few thousand instances per class, showed promising results in classification and reconstruction. This work extends those studies in two ways. First, we assess scalability using Googles Quick, Draw! dataset, which includes over 300 classes and 100,000 instances per class. Second, we test EAMs rejection capability by storing only half of the classes and evaluating performance on the full dataset. Results confirm EAMs adaptability to large-scale scenarios and its effective rejection of novel stimuli, underscoring its potential as a robust and explainable AI model.

title: An Analysis of Indexes to Forecast the Achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations: A Case Study Mexico
authors: Gerardo M. Ortigoza, William A. Castillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Data analysis of a group of different indexes and machine learning methods are used to obtain current progress and projections of the future achievements of the UN sustainable development goals. These projections can be a valuable tool to make educated decisions that improve a country's performance in seeking to meet the UN sustainable developments goals. This work explores the Sustainable Development Goals Index (SDGI) and its correlations with another seven important indexes: Urban Competence Index (UCI), Fragile States Index (FSI), Human Development Index (HDI), Global Competitiveness Index (GCI), Global Innovation Index (GII), Environmental Performance Index (EPI) and Social Progress Index (SPI). Machine learning projections are obtained for the time evolution of the indexes with the purpose of knowing in what percentage the sustainability objectives set by the 2030 United Nations agenda will be achieved by our study case Mexico. Using Pearson correlations, multiple linear approximations of the SGD index are proposed based on indexes that have a statistically significant correlation with it. Our findings suggest that indexes correlated with de SDGI can be used as predictors, thus a close monitoring of these predictor variables can give us valuable information on how the SDGI will change. Machine learning projections show us the future behavior not only of the SDGI but also of the predictor indexes that are correlated with it. Currently to evaluate progress in achieving the goals, the United Nations periodically reports the measurement of the distance to the SDG targets for various countries. However, oftentimes not enough data is provided for the indicators, which makes it difficult to establish progress towards a certain SDG. Therefore, understanding the multiple linear relationship between the SDGI and other predictive indexes might help gauge the SDGI's advancement.

title: An ML-Enabled Low-Latency Transmission Scheme for Next-Generation Wireless Systems
authors: Puja Dube, Brijesh Pandey, Monika Aggarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Hybrid Automatic Repeat Request (HARQ) ensures reliability in LTE and 5G but faces challenges in low-latency scenarios like URLLC, including feedback delays, signaling errors, retransmission overhead, and performance issues in high-mobility environments. Moreover, lost or misdecoded HARQ feedback at gNBs can cause unnecessary retransmissions, exacerbating these issues. In this paper, to address the limitations of the current HARQ feedback method, we introduced an ML-based HARQ bit predictor to reduce latency, enhance data transmission reliability and throughput in 5G and emerging 6G networks. By predicting HARQ bits, the system initiates immediate retransmissions, minimizing delays associated with traditional feedback mechanisms. The proposed method is a generalized approach that benefits 5G systems using the OFDM waveform and can also be applied to technologies like OTFS, which may be used in 6G and future communications. The Machine Learning-based HARQ bit predictor is a binary classification model utilizing advanced feature selection and an optimized neural network. It exhibits near-perfect performance with rapid convergence of accuracy and loss curves, minimal misclassifications in the confusion matrix, and an almost ideal precision-recall curve. The close alignment of training and validation curves indicates no overfitting. This model’s outstanding performance in HARQ bit prediction suggests significant potential for future wireless communication systems.

title: Live Football Statistics Aggregator
authors: S. Vasilova, L. Saragjinov, V. Zdraveski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We present a Live Football Statistics Aggregator that combines Python multiprocessing with Apache Kafka to deliver real-time analytics. The pipeline ingests heterogeneous football APIs, normalizes events in parallel, and streams results to a FastAPI backend and React UI. In experiments, multi-process execution substantially reduced latency versus a sequential baseline. Kafka adds durability, backpressure, and horizontal scalability, making the system practical for production environments.

title: Transformation of Petrol Stations into Battery Stations and Application of Electronic and Information Technologies as a Way for Electric Vehicles Energy Supply
authors: Dusanka Bundalo, Zlatko Bundalo, Mirko Sajic, Igor Dugonjic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The biggest problem for owners of fully electric vehicles is charging of the vehicle battery with electric energy. This paper proposes and describes one method that reduces and generally solves such problems. It is proposed to gradually transform existing traditional petrol stations into battery stations and to apply modern electronic and information technologies in their design. Also, it is proposed that instead of electric vehicles with built-in fixed batteries, electric vehicles with replaceable batteries be used. In such vehicles, when the battery is discharged, it is replaced with a previously charged battery of the same type. So, the petrol stations are transformed into battery stations for charging or for replacing electric vehicles batteries. Also, electronic and information technologies should be used for efficient control and monitoring of battery charging, for managing and monitoring status of the entire system and for informing users about battery charging locations and available charging points at those locations. It is also proposed to maximally use solar and wind energy in such systems. The paper considers and describes the proposed method in more detail, way of implementation and application.

title: SurgAR: A Prototype of the Augmented Reality-Enhanced Endoscopic Surgery Assistant System
authors: Xiaofei Wang, Xin Tang, Qiuhui Wang, Yun Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology into the analysis of endoscopic surgery videos brings substantial benefits to surgical training and Intraoperative Navigation (IN). Existing AI-based surgical image segmentation and annotation are insufficient and complicated to meet the requirement of surgeons: What’s next? In this article, by collaborating computer researchers and surgeons, we designed and implemented a new system named SurgAR. The system transfers surgical image segmentation and annotation results into IN information to identify the subsequent step in the surgery, socalled “snipe point”. The decision-making process for determining the “snipe point” is grounded in the expert knowledge accumulated by highly experienced senior surgeons. This system combined three importance dimensions of endoscopic surgery: time information of the surgical procedures, space information of the anatomical landmarks from surgical images segmentation, and 3D reconstruction registration based on the experience. SurgAR can overlay “snipe point” on the real surgical video stream and through head-mounted Augmented Reality (AR) device to assist surgeons.

title: A Low-Cost Non-Mydriatic Fundus Imaging System with a Three Stage Deep Learning Pipeline for Automatic Diagnosis of Diabetic Retinopathy
authors: Paarth Nawani
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Diabetic Retinopathy affects 103.12 million people annually, with the number expected to climb to 191.0 million by 2030. Unfortunately, this issue disproportionately impacts those in low-resource regions, where 90% of all blindness occurs due to minimal basic eye care systems. Here, we propose an all-in-one non-mydriatic fundus camera integrated with a three-step machine learning pipeline designed for automatic diagnosis. The fundus capture system is powered by a Raspberry Pi connected to a camera module, 2 LEDs for fundus illumination, and an ophthalmic lens for magnification. We solely utilized off-the-shelf components to ensure that our device remained low-cost and accessible to all. Our machine learning pipeline consists of three key components. First, a Super-Resolution Generative Adversarial Network was fine-tuned for retinal images to enhance image quality. Second, an ensemble model was developed by combining DenseNet121, InceptionV3, and MobileNetV2 models, rigorously testing and fine-tuning these pre-trained models to achieve optimal performance. Finally, we implemented a YOLOv8 Object Detection model to identify and draw bounding boxes around potential lesions in the fundus, improving AI explainability. Ultimately, our ensemble model achieved an impressive accuracy of 95.2%, surpassing many current benchmarks. This system, costing under ${\$} 100$, has the potential to bridge the gap in global eye care inequality, offering a cost-effective and accessible solution for early detection and diagnosis of diabetic retinopathy in underserved regions.

title: Car Body Defect Detection Algorithm Based on Improved YOLOv11s
authors: Tingfeng Ye, Xuedong Jing
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: To address the body defect issues existing in the automobile factory assembly process, current detection technologies still suffer from limitations such as restricted detection accuracy, high false detection rates in defect classification, great difficulties in small defect recognition, and low detection efficiency. This paper proposes an improved automobile body defect detection algorithm based on the YOLOv11s architecture, named EDD4-YOLOv11.On the basis of the original YOLOv11s model, firstly, the C3K2 modules in the backbone and neck parts are replaced with C3K2-EIEM modules. By virtue of the dynamic attention and cross-scale interaction capabilities of C3K2-EIEM, the characterization of defect features is enhanced. Secondly, in the detection head part, the original detection head is replaced with the high-performance Dyhead detection head. The ability of Dyhead to dynamically adapt to multi-scale targets complements that of EIEM, jointly improving the accuracy of capturing multi-scale defects. Finally, to achieve lightweight design, the standard convolutions inside Dyhead are replaced with DCNv4 (Deformable Convolutional Network v4). This modification reduces computational complexity and parameter scale while ensuring detection accuracy, facilitating edge deployment on embedded devices.Experimental results show that compared with the original YOLOv11s algorithm, the improved EDD4-YOLOv11 algorithm increases precision, recall, and mean average precision (mAP) by 1.7%, 2.4%, and 3.9% respectively, further enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of automobile body defect detection.

title: Pilot-Assisted Receiver Design for Non-Coherent Distributed Transmission in 5G-NR
authors: Abhratanu Karmakar, Arhum Ahmad, Satyam Agarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a receiver design for non-coherent distributed transmission (NCDT) in 5G NR systems that eliminates the need for feedback or strict transmitter coordination. Unlike conventional coherent approaches that rely on precise synchronization and continuous feedback to emulate MISO systems, our method leverages standardized 5G NR pilot symbols and statistical detection to enable reliable distributed transmission. The receiver estimates channel magnitude, as well as phase and frequency offsets, using maximum likelihood estimation, and performs symbol detection through a likelihood ratio test framework. Simulation results under 5G channel conditions show that the proposed receiver design remains effective under offset-induced interference and achieves reliable performance in an NCDT system without feedback and synchronization.

title: Novel Method for Transmission Line Fault Detection Using Adaptive Boosting
authors: Nandana Rajesh, Preetha Sreekumar
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid machine learning framework based on Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost) and Support Vector Machines (SVM) for accurate real-time fault detection, classification, and localization in transmission systems. Voltage and current magnitudes are used as features, avoiding the need for complex signal transformations. The proposed ensemble architecture includes an AdaBoost classifier for fault detection and type classification, followed by an SVM regressor for fault localization. Experimental results demonstrate 100 % fault detection accuracy, 98.39% line classification accuracy, and a mean absolute error (MAE) of 1.12 km in fault localization, with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{R}^{2}$</tex> score of 0.997. This emphasizes the effectiveness of proposed model in providing low-latency, high-accuracy fault detection, making it a compelling solution for deployment in smart grid monitoring and protection systems.

title: Lean-Agile Transformation for HV Cable Projects
authors: Saadat Ali, Abdulla Ali, Zayed Ahmed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper presents the application of Lean-Agile methodologies to high-voltage cable commissioning projects, aiming to enhance efficiency, quality, and collaboration. Key tools such as 5 S, Kaizen, and Value Stream Mapping were integrated with Agile sprint planning throughout installation, testing, and commissioning stages. This approach resulted in a 40 % reduction in outage lead times, a 20 % improvement in quality compliance, and a significant decrease in project delays. Resource optimization and digitalization of checklists further contributed to measurable time and cost savings. The findings demonstrate that Lean-Agile principles can be successfully adapted to utility infrastructure projects, providing a scalable model for timely, high-quality, and cost-effective delivery.

title: Learning Binary Autoencoder-Based Codes with Progressive Training
authors: Vukan Ninkovic, Dejan Vukobratovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Error-correcting codes play a central role in digital communication, ensuring that transmitted information can be accurately reconstructed despite channel impairments. Recently, autoencoder (AE)-based approaches have gained attention for the end-to-end design of communication systems, offering a datadriven alternative to conventional coding schemes. However, enforcing binary codewords within differentiable AE architectures remains difficult, as discretization breaks gradient flow and often leads to unstable convergence. To overcome this limitation, a simplified two-stage training procedure is proposed, consisting of a continuous pretraining phase followed by direct binarization and fine-tuning without gradient approximation techniques. For the (7,4) block configuration over a binary symmetric channel (BSC), the learned encoder-decoder pair learns a rotated version (coset code) of the optimal Hamming code, naturally recovering its linear and distance properties and thereby achieving the same block error rate (BLER) with maximum-likelihood (ML) decoding. These results indicate that compact AE architectures can effectively learn structured, algebraically optimal binary codes through stable and straightforward training.

title: Optimal Sizing and Economic Analysis of Solar Home Systems: A Swarm Electrification Approach
authors: Abuzar Sani Jakhro, Nayyar Hussain Mirjat, Abdullah Sani Jakhro, Muhammad Sami Memon, Raja Haresh Kumar, Zubair Ahmed Memon
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: In the pursuit of universal electricity access by 2030, this paper proposes the optimal sizing of Solar Home Systems (SHSs) by enabling Swarm Electrification. However, the objective of study is to minimize Net Present Cost (NPC) while optimizing the sizes of PV and Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) through Mixed-Integer Linear Programming (MILP). The results demonstrate that energy sharing through interconnected approach can maximize energy utilization up to 97.3 % of SHS. Furthermore, results indicate that the optimal sizing of 0.81 kW and 0.88 kW of PV, and 2.81 kWh and 2.72 kWh of BESS collectively can significantly generate overall revenue of $ 945 and provide energy access up to 97 % to tier 1 and 94% to tier 2 household consumers without any upfront cost incurring, providing cost-effective and sustainable energy solution for rural electrification.

title: A Novel Hybrid Hyperbolic Tangent Function-Based Supertwisting and Integral Backstepping Control for HESS in DC Microgrid
authors: Hafiz Mian Muhammad Adil, Hassan A. Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The seamless integration of renewable energy resources in DC microgrids (DCMGs) is crucial for enabling green and sustainable energy production. However, to address the intermittent nature of these renewable resources, efficient and robust control is required for the hybrid energy storage system (HESS) in DCMGs. In this paper, a novel hybrid nonlinear control scheme, combining a hyperbolic tangent function-based supertwisting and integral backstepping (HTSTIBS), is proposed for a battery-ultracapacitor-based HESS in a solar photovoltaic (PV)-based DCMG. The performance of the proposed controller is examined using MATLAB simulations, ensuring power balance in the system and tight regulation of the DC bus voltage amid solar intermittency and load demand variations. The superiority of the proposed controller is established through comparison with Lyapunov function control (LFC) and integral backstepping sliding mode control (IBSSMC), demonstrating an enhanced dynamic response with the fastest settling time of 7 ms (LFC: 120 ms, IBS-SMC: 20 ms), the lowest root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.0029 V (LFC: 1.138 V, IBS-SMC: 0.0034 V), and the absence of chattering.

title: Applied Granger Causality in Electricity Market Analysis: A Case Study on Data Transformations and Structural Insights
authors: Dubravko Sabolić, Igor Ivanković, Renata Rubeša, Filip Grebenar
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper investigates the applicability and limitations of Granger causality testing in electricity market analysis. Using selected hourly and daily time series from the Croatian power system and European energy markets as illustrative examples, we estimate a set of four-variable VAR models under multiple data transformations: raw, first-differenced, and filtered differences. The models include load, production, wholesale electricity prices, and fuel-related prices. We report Granger test results, full regression coefficient matrices, and significance flags to examine the sensitivity of inference to model specification. The findings generally align with expectations-such as strong bidirectional causality among regional market prices-but also reveal anomalies, including the apparent lack of windprice causality and somewhat counterintuitive firm <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex>-to-gas causal links. These results highlight the importance of careful model interpretation and the value of testing multiple structural assumptions in data-driven policy analysis.

title: Optimal Placement of dSTATCOM and Energy Storage to Regulate Voltage for Supporting High PV Penetration
authors: Umme Mumtahina, Sanath Alahakoon, Peter Wolfs
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Energy production enhances daily life but poses environmental challenges. Transitioning from fossil fuels to renewables is essential to mitigate climate change. The Australian Federal Government supports this shift by aiming for stable electricity prices, supply security, and a cleaner energy sector. However, renewable energy integration complicates voltage control in distribution networks. Maintaining voltage within limits is a key responsibility of utilities, influenced by system design, operational methods, loads, and now decentralized sources like solar PV. This paper explores the use of distributed static synchronous compensators (dSTATCOM) and battery energy storage (BES) to manage voltage and reduce peak demand. A voltage regulation strategy using both technologies is developed, with optimal placement determined by a differential evolution algorithm. Simulations are performed on a low-voltage rural distribution feeder in Central Queensland, Australia. These solutions support the reliable integration of renewables and promote sustainable energy growth.

title: Forecast-Based Maximum Energy Utilization in a Decentralized Solar-Powered Microgrid
authors: Fayaz Ahmed, Uzair Ahmed, Sajid Hussain, Hassan Abbas Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Solar home systems and centralised solar microgrids have traditionally been utilised to electrify offgrid communities. However, in these systems, maximum energy utilization is a challenge due to (a) limited storage (due to cost constraints) and (b) mismatch between energy production and usage. Decentralized solar-powered microgrids (DSMGs) with household generation and storage offer a clean and reliable solution to deliver electricity in off-grid areas. This paper evaluates DSMGs and presents a forecast-based energy management strategy for a DSMG consisting of interconnected houses with individual solar generation and storage. Each house can act as a prosumer (ability to share power with others) in the grid. Using Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) models, day-ahead forecasts of solar generation and load demand along with battery energy storage system (BESS) parameters are fed into an optimization framework that manages how energy is stored, consumed, or shared. The goal is to maximize the use of solar energy while keeping BESS usage within allowable limits. The developed framework is tested using practical data from an off-grid deployment with four interconnected houses. The results show that the proposed approach increases overall <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P V}$</tex> utilization by 9.47 %, with individual houses achieving improvements of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3. 0 4 \%}$</tex>. The framework reduces energy waste and enhances energy utilization through optimized sharing within a DSMG.

title: Using Deep Learning Approach to Detect Mixed-Rate Data Spoofing in PMUs
authors: Alvin Huseinovic, Halil Bisgin, Yusuf Korkmaz, Suleyman Uludag
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Wide-area monitoring systems in the smart grid rely on Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs) and Phasor Data Concentrators (PDCs) to provide high-resolution situational awareness. However, legacy protocols such as IEEE C37.1182 lack built-in security, leaving PMU streams vulnerable to spoofing. In this paper, we study two canonical data injection strategies—Repeat Last Value (RLV) and Mirroring (MA)—and examine detector robustness when the volume of injected attacks scales well beyond prior work. Using a 24 h dataset from EPFL, we train on six hours and test on the remaining eighteen under both matched and mismatched attack densities (low → high and high → low). Results show that the proposed CNNs achieve high sensitivity and specificity across diverse scenarios

title: Advancements in Non-Invasive Blood Pressure Measurement: A Comprehensive Review of Cuffed, Cuffless, and Contactless Methods
authors: Terezie Kauzlaricova, Martin Augustynek, Jan Kubicek
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Recent advances in non-invasive blood pressure (BP) monitoring are transforming the field, offering alternatives to traditional cuff-based methods that are often limited by discomfort and intermittent measurement. Following PRISMA guidelines, this review systematically analyses studies published between 2020 and 2024, categorizing current BP measurement techniques into cuff-based, cuffless, and contactless methods. Special attention is given to emerging technologies such as photoplethysmography (PPG), electrocardiography (ECG), bioimpedance, radar sensing, and remote PPG (rPPG), as well as the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) for signal processing and BP estimation. The review evaluates the comparative performance, clinical relevance, and readiness for real-world application across modalities. While cuffless and contactless approaches show significant promise for continuous and user-friendly monitoring, their accuracy often depends on calibration, multimodal data fusion, and robust algorithm design. Ethical considerations related to unobtrusive monitoring are also discussed. This work highlights current limitations, identifies future research opportunities, and supports the development of next-generation, AI-driven BP monitoring systems suitable for both clinical and consumer use.

title: Improvement of Fourier Domain-Based Fractional Anisotropic Diffusion for Image Denoising Using Deep Learning
authors: Milorad P. Paskaš
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper explores the application of a convolutional neural network (CNN) for enhancing image quality following the removal of additive Gaussian noise. In the first stage, image denoising is performed using fractional-order anisotropic diffusion with a resolution parameter. Fractional differentiation is applied in the Fourier domain, as is standard in the literature. However, this initial denoising stage requires empirical tuning of several parameters. To address this challenge and further improve denoising performance, an additional deep learning-based stage is introduced. The combination of these two consecutive denoising stages results in both visual and numerical improvements. Quality metrics such as PSNR and SSIM confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach, with notable enhancements particularly at higher noise levels.

title: Optimizing Solar Energy Harvest Through Intelligent Self-Cleaning System
authors: M. Ahsan Khalid, Beenish Hassan, G. Amjad Hussain, Amjad Gawanmeh, Zeeshan A. Arfeen, Zeeshan Rashid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Dust accumulation on solar panels dramatically reduces their energy output, especially in remote and dry areas where water-based cleaning is not feasible. This article presents the design and execution of an intelligent, waterless self-cleaning system controlled by Arduino. A DC gear motor powers the system's revolving brushes, which are managed by a motor driver. Light, dust, rain, and ultrasonic sensors allow the system to operate independently relying completely on its surroundings. The system is powered by 12 V DC battery, which guarantees economical and environmentally friendly operation, appropriate for off-grid locations. According to experimental data, the prototype enhances captured energy by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-30 {\%}$</tex> and restores up to 97% of the panel's rated output when compared to grimy panels. The suggested method provides a workable and expandable way to preserve solar panel performance in areas that are prone to dust.

title: Entropy-Based Multilevel Thresholding of Transmission Line Insulator Images Using Pso and Acor Algorithms
authors: Nermin Komar, Mirza Batalovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Timely detection of damaged transmission line insulators enables preventive prevention of costly interruptions. Manual inspections are time-consuming and error-prone, while automated approaches enable faster and more reliable damage detection. This paper presents the application of multilevel thresholding for the segmentation of power line insulator images using two metaheuristic optimization methods: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Ant Colony Optimization for Continuous Domains (ACOR). By comparing these methods, their basic differences and effectiveness are analyzed. Two entropy-based objective functions are used to optimize thresholding: Kapur's and Otsu's criteria. On the proposed data set, the segmentation was evaluated according to the accuracy and execution time of the algorithms. The results show that the combination of PSO and Kapur's entropy criterion provides a good trade-off between accuracy and time required, which makes this method particularly suitable for high-volume inspection tasks.

title: The Impact of an Open-Circuit Fault on QoS Parameters for IPTV Over VDSL
authors: Namir Škaljo, Alen Begović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper continues with the analysis of the impact of some frequently occurring and very intense galvanic faults on IPTV QoS parameters on VDSL lines in FTTB networks. In addition to the previously presented results for certain types of very intense faults, this paper will show the results of research into the impact of another significantly pronounced fault that can occur in drop wires, but also in other segments of access networks.

title: Economic Dispatch in Grids with Solar Power Plants and Energy Storage Systems
authors: Lidija M. Korunović, Teodora D. Denić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper addresses the economic dispatch problem in grids with thermal, hydro and solar power plants, and energy storage systems (ESSs). Mathematical model of dynamic combined economic emission dispatch (DCEED) problem is given, and optimization results are discussed emphasizing the efficiency of applied software. The results encompass total operating cost and greenhouse gas emission in a grid without and with ESSs, for actual load and prospective load growth. The effects of energy storage systems have been quantified, demonstrating both the economic and environmental positive impacts of their implementation in modern power grids.

title: Lwe-Based Single Noisy Linear Equations for Public Key Over Integer Encryption
authors: Mostefa Kara, Ahcene Bounceur, Abdelkader Laouid, Khaled Chait, Yassine Himeur, Konstantinos Karampidis
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: In this work, we introduce a novel post-quantum public key encryption scheme over integers, leveraging a hybrid approach that combines large random numbers with the Learning With Errors (LWE) system. The scheme addresses the security challenges posed by quantum computing advancements, aiming to provide a robust solution resistant to quantum-based attacks. By using the unknown random number hardness assumption with enhancements to the traditional LWE framework and operating directly on integers, this approach ensures a high level of cryptographic security while maintaining computational efficiency. Extensive theoretical and experimental analyses demonstrate that the proposed encryption system achieves state-of-the-art performance: encryption execution time as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.45 \times 10^{-5}$</tex> seconds, decryption time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.47 \times 10^{-5}$</tex> seconds, and an integrity check time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.30 \times 10^{-5}$</tex> seconds. Moreover, the ciphertext size is reduced to only 1330 bits while maintaining a 256 -bit security level, representing a significant reduction in storage requirements compared to conventional lattice-based approaches. These results confirm that our scheme not only provides strong quantum-resistant security guarantees but also delivers excellent efficiency and scalability, making it a viable candidate for secure communications in bandwidth-limited and resource-constrained environments in the quantum era.

title: Feasibility of EV Adoption as Distributed Solar Energy Storage: A Logistic Forecast of the UAE's Viability Timeline
authors: Srinjay Shrinivas Shankar, Yousef Saleh, Abdulhayee Yamin, Jameel Ahmed, Zain Ali AlNaser
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The United Arab Emirates is well-endowed with superior solar energy resources and vehicular market strength. Combining them, however, raises a key question: Might a national fleet of electric vehicles (EVs), in tandem with widescale deployment of photovoltaic (PVs) and vehicle-to-grid (V2G) systems (which currently experiences an increase in market size) [11], offer sufficient nocturnal storage to offset daily renewable generation? To answer it, the study adopts a tripartite forecasting framework: (i) a logistic model of EV adoption from Norway's experience; (ii) forecasts of electricity demand from a combination of historical growth and global benchmarks; and (iii) a regression forecasting of the trends of the costs of solar PVs. The study reveals that, on current trajectories, the cumulative storage of the EVs alone will be insufficient to cover prospective loads at night even in the face of rapidly decreasing solar prices. Nonetheless, this study identifies a plethora of methods that are capable of shrinking the deficit. These range from utility-scale batteries and boosting of purchase of EVs to stimulation of demand and diversified renewable power penetration and cross-border energy collaborations. The overarching conclusion is that the conquest of renewable self-sufficiency is not a passive corollary of existing trends but a task that necessitates a combination of coordinated effort at the technological, legislative, and behavioural levels.

title: Revolutionizing Air Mobility: Cutting-Edge Infrastructure for Safe Air Corridor Navigation
authors: Nishant Gupta, Arhum Ahmad, Dhawal Salwan, Satyam Agarwal, Kamesh Namuduri
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The development in the automation sector and aircraft design has enabled significant innovations in the urban aviation sector, particularly in advanced air mobility (AAM). AAM includes on-demand air transportation services for both cargo and passengers by utilizing unmanned aerial system (UAS) or other small aircraft like electric vertical takeoff and landing (eV-TOL) vehicles. These vehicles operate within designated pathways known as "Air Corridors." Air corridors are performance-based controlled airspaces where UASs adhere to specific protocols, including skylane assignment, route availability, traffic control, collision avoidance, etc. In this paper, we explore the urban air mobility (UAM) ecosystem, with an emphasis on the air corridors. We propose a novel design concept for building the infrastructure to support safe operations in the air corridors. Specifically, our proposed design entails utilizing a multi-beam subarray antenna system that can keep the UAS within the air corridor and detect malicious objects within the air corridor to avoid collision. Moreover, we present a case study to demonstrate the operation of an air corridor. Finally, we highlight the challenges involved in implementing the proposed air corridor concept.

title: IntelliTest: An Intelligent Framework for Agentic Functional Test Generation Using Multimodal Data and Domain Knowledge
authors: Akshat Sukhdeo Tiwari, Satya Ganesh Nutan Dev C, Pratik Madhukar Patole, Goutham Ponnamreddy, Srinivas Chinthalapudi, Durga Prasad Kattamanchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: IntelliTest is an end-to-end, locally deployable framework that automates functional test generation and selection for complex embedded systems from two input modes: Software Change Artifacts (SCAs)—multimodal changelist data combining code diffs with textual metadata—and Natural-Language Queries (NLQs) for direct test requests. It employs a domainagnostic ontology defining procedural semantics, compiled into a structured procedural database and a specification knowledge graph for retrieval-augmented reasoning. The dual-agent architecture—Context-Analysis-and-Scoping Agent (CASA) and Constrained-Testcase-Synthesis Agent (CTSA)—interprets SCAs or NLQs, validates functionalities through ontology-grounded databases, and synthesizes constraint-compliant sequences. Dynamic coverage databases use greedy set-cover selection and cross-impact expansion to expose cousin bugs in adjacent modules. Human-in-the-loop feedback refines ontology instantiations. Deployed locally for data-security compliance, IntelliTest was validated on commercial modem firmware (>50,000 files, >250,000 functions), achieving 95% functionality identification, 92% code-change coverage, 90% constraint satisfaction, and a five-fold reduction in generation time, shrinking regression suites by 40–60% while maintaining comprehensive coverage

title: Reinforcement Learning Based C-DRX Configuration Selection for UE Power Saving in 6G
authors: Sayan Rudra Pal, Abhijeet Abhimanyu Masal, Radhakrishna Ganti, J. Klutto Milleth
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Discontinuous reception (DRX) is one of the important power-saving mechanisms introduced in the 5G new radio (NR) technology. It enables a user equipment to enter into a low-power state when no downlink data is to be received. The 5G advanced and 6G networks are expected to support diverse applications with varying traffic patterns and require dynamic adaptation of DRX parameters based on specific traffic characteristics. This necessitates different approaches to DRX configuration optimization. 3GPP is studying artificial intelligence-based machine learning (AI-ML) techniques to address the above issue and has recently shown robustness and efficiency compared to classical approaches. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning-based framework to optimize the DRX configuration. The proposed method determines the optimal DRX configuration for different types of network traffic while meeting the key performance objectives.

title: DenseLoc: A Benchmark Dataset for Ultra-Precise Indoor Localization Using Deep MLP Model
authors: Pritam Vediya, Avinash Awasthi, Hemant Miranka, Ramesh Babu Battula, Dinesh Gopalani
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Accurate indoor localization is prominent in enabling seamless connectivity and context-aware applications across smart buildings, healthcare, robotics, and industrial IoT environments. However, the traditional methods and datasets, such as RSSI datasets, struggle in complex indoor environments where SNR, doppler effects, and non-line of sight (NLoS) conditions dominate. Further, CSI datasets for indoor localization methods captured important features but did not consider required environment-aware characteristics and lacked ultra-precise localization. We proposed a novel CSI dataset DenseLoc, captured at the 3.5 GHz mid-band frequency to address complex indoor localization challenges in a 2.5D space where the z axis was kept constant. The dataset was developed across five realistic scenarios designed to be environment-aware, spanning line of sight (LoS), NLoS, and mixed visibility conditions. A customized GNU Radio with USRP 2953R’s based framework extracts rich signal features, focusing on spectral correlation function (SCF)-based cyclostationary sensing, which robustly distinguishes LoS/NLoS environments. Moreover, we introduce the k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN)-based data augmentation technique that enhances the dataset’s diversity while preserving spatial continuity. The dataset was tested on our Deep MLP model, in which we achieved millimeter-level 2.5D localization accuracy, demonstrating the effectiveness of our approach and establishing a new benchmark for precise indoor localization.

title: Seeing More With Less: Leveraging Positional Telemetry for V2X Cooperative Perception
authors: Shenghua Chen, Ilya Sabnani, Ilija Hadzic, Manzoor A. Khan, Anton Dahbura, Krishan Sabnani
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: We present a novel fusion algorithm that enhances vehicular perception in Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) networks. Traditional fusion methods face significant implementation challenges since these networks have limited available bandwidth for data transmission. Although intermediate-layer processing reduces overall message size, compatibility is often limited to vehicles operating under application-or platform-specific standardization. Due to these transmission and implementation issues, we have developed a novel system that uses raw-level positional telemetry data to generate global perception maps. We combine data pipelines and transformation matrices with Kalman Filtering techniques to generate a dynamic, unified representation of a multi-vehicle environment. Our algorithm increases detection precision by over 21 percent for the overall perception system and by over 59 percent when measured on a median-per-grid basis across various detection scenes and network delays for different sample sizes. This mechanism permits the efficient transmission of essential information while maintaining the integrity of perception and tracking processes. We improve upon existing methodologies in multi-vehicle environments and complex traffic scenarios by enhancing performance under challenging network conditions. Our work provides foundational support for systems related to cooperative perception, autonomous driving, and safety-critical maneuvering by enabling robust data fusion. This is essential for developing vehicular autonomy at scale and supporting network operations for ground-level V2X infrastructure.

title: CSI Prediction for 5G and B5G in mMIMO System using Deep Learning Approach
authors: Priya Barman, Vasudev Dehalwar, R. K. Pateriya
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The subject of mMIMO has gained considerable importance because of its capability to enhance the system’s performance while minimizing the need for transmission power. In 5G frequency division duplex (FDD) systems, the feedback from the downlink channel state information (CSI) is sent by user equipment (UE) to the base station (BS), significantly increasing network throughput. However, in massive MIMO systems, CSI feedback is required by all BSs, which increases transmission overhead and latency. This paper presents deep learning-based techniques for CSI prediction in the uplink, offering a thorough evaluation of these techniques in the massive MIMO architecture that can be implemented in 5G and beyond-5G networks. It also outlines notable research gaps, persistent challenges, and potential research areas, highlighting the critical urgency for further advanced deep learning patterns and new technologies to support the effectiveness of Channel State Information forecasting. This study 21.8% increase in inference rate along with a 43% decrease in memory consumption, while a 63% rise in Normalized Mean Squared Error (NMSE) shows the trade-off in balancing accuracy and efficiency.

title: Expanding Front-Haul Networks’ Capacity and Flexibility by Spatial Parallelism
authors: Dan M. Marom, Christos Christofidis, Alberto Otero-Casado, Pablo Torres-Ferrera, Antonio Napoli, Ioannis Tomkos
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Point-to-multipoint front-haul networks provide shared access to edge sites, with capacity and routing constraints. The front-haul capacity can be multiplied by introducing several spatial feeds and means for associating input feed to specific remote units at the edge via switching/routing. The front-haul is empowered using our spatially-diverse point-to-multipoint architecture, and we compare several technologies for its implementation. We introduce subcarrier-level rapid networking and spatial-feeder enhancements with an innovative four-port optical interlacer, increasing capacity and networking flexibility.

title: Real-Time Software Architecture for Pid Angle Control in Experimental Pvtol Platforms
authors: Anai Camacho Luna, David Lara Alabazares, Abdelhamid RABHI, Jesus Namigtle Jimenez, Jair Galicia Santiago, Irahan Otoniel José Guzmán
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a software platform developed in LabVIEW, based on a state machine model, for controlling the positioning and angular trajectory of a PVTOL (Planar Vertical Take-Off and Landing) system. Communication with the experimental platform was implemented using Arduino UNO R4 microcontrollers, integrating low-cost distance sensors and a 3DM-GX1 IMU. The data was acquired at 60 Hz via I2C and USB protocols. The software includes signal logging and controller response features for subsequent analysis. Experimental validation, using a classic PID control, demonstrated stable performance of the PVTOL, with no significant oscillations and robustness against external disturbances.

title: Towards Design and Implementation of an Interactive System for Real-Time Monitoring of Domestic Energy Consumption
authors: Jerry-Israel Romero-Villalobos, José-Guillermo Hernández-Calderón, Lorena Alonso-Ramírez, L. Gerardo Montané-Jiménez, Valeria Soto-Mendoza
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In domestic environments, most users lack access to detailed, real-time data on their electricity consumption. This limitation hinders their ability to make informed decisions that promote energy efficiency and cost savings. Existing utility tools typically present historical consumption data in static formats, making identifying specific usage patterns or high-consumption devices challenging. Furthermore, the lack of visual and accessible digital interfaces in this area prevents users, especially those without technical knowledge, from understanding their energy consumption. To address this problem, we present Power Track, an interactive, user-centric system designed to monitor, control, and visualize real-time domestic energy consumption. The platform integrates sensors, ESP32 microcontrollers, and Wi-Fi communication via the MQTT protocol to collect data stored in a cloud-based relational database. The system features a responsive web interface, developed with React and Node.js, that graphically displays historical and current consumption. This design fosters energy awareness and facilitates informed decision-making, encouraging sustainable consumption habits. Development followed a User-Centered Design (UCD) methodology, which included requirements specification, prototyping, and user validation to ensure usability and relevance. Power Track represents a scalable and user-friendly tool that aligns with the principles of smart cities and energy efficiency.

title: A Low-Cost Low-Power Radiation-Reflection-Integrated Programmable Metasurface Antenna for Dynamic Beam Scanning and Multiharmonic Independent Beam Control
authors: Chao Song, Han Wei Tian, Qian Zhu, Zheng Zhang, Ya Li Zhao, Tie Jun Cui, Wei Xiang Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A low-cost and low-power radiation-reflection-integrated programmable metasurface antenna (RRIPMA) is proposed, designed and demonstrated. Each meta-element of RRIPMA can be digitally programmed to operate in either the radiation mode or the reflection mode; moreover, it can achieve 2-bit radiation phase modulation and 1-bit reflection phase modulation from 9.6 to 10.6 GHz. By applying the space-time coding method based on particle swarm optimization algorithm, RRIPMA enables flexible control of radiated and reflected waves in both space and frequency domains. A prototype of RRIPMA array was fabricated and experimentally validated, demonstrating capabilities including low-sidelobe radiated beam scanning and wide-angle reflected beam scanning. In addition, its ability to simultaneously and independently control the radiated and reflected waves at multiple harmonic frequencies has been demonstrated. It is notable that the total power consumption of the entire RRIPMA system (including its control module) is only 188 mW, showing excellent low-power feature. The RRIPMA architecture offers a promising alternative to the conventional phased arrays, enabling highly integrated, low-cost, and low-power multi-tasking systems for applications such as wireless communications and sensing.

title: Towards a Multi-Layer Defence Framework for Securing Near-Real-Time Operations in Open RAN
authors: Hamed Alimohammadi, Samara Mayhoub, Sotiris Chatzimiltis, Mohammad Shojafar, Muhammad Nasir Mumtaz Bhutta
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Securing the near-real-time (near-RT) control operations in Open Radio Access Networks (Open RAN) is increasingly critical, yet remains insufficiently addressed, as new runtime threats target the control loop while the system is operational. In this paper, we propose a multi-layer defence framework designed to enhance the security of near-RT RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) operations. We classify operational-time threats into three categories—message-level, data-level, and control logic-level—and design and implement a dedicated detection and mitigation component for each: a signature-based E2 message inspection module performing structural and semantic validation of signalling exchanges, a telemetry poisoning detector based on temporal anomaly scoring using an LSTM network, and a runtime xApp attestation mechanism based on an execution-time hash challenge–response. The framework is evaluated on an Open RAN testbed comprising FlexRIC and a commercial RAN emulator, demonstrating effective detection rates, low latency overheads, and practical integration feasibility. Results indicate that the proposed safeguards can operate within near-RT time constraints while significantly improving protection against runtime attacks, introducing less than 80 ms overhead for a network with 500 User Equipment (UEs). Overall, this work lays the foundation for deployable, layered, and policy-driven runtime security architectures for the near-RT RIC control loop in Open RAN, and provides an extensible framework into which future mitigation policies and threat-specific modules can be integrated.

title: Institutional Approaches to Post-Quantum Cryptography: A Comparative Analysis of Migration Frameworks
authors: Mustafa El Bizri, Ahmad M. El-Hajj, Layth Sliman, Ali M. Haidar
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The advancement of quantum computing is increasingly recognized as a significant threat to classical public-key cryptographic systems, triggering a global shift toward Post-Quantum Cryptography (PQC). This article presents a topical survey and comparative analysis of the transition strategies adopted by leading cybersecurity agencies—including National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Agence Nationale de la Sécurité des Systèmes d’Information (ANSSI), Bundesamt für Sicherheit in der Informationstechnik (BSI), Cryptography Research and Evaluation Committees (CRYPTREC), and European Union Agency for Cybersecurity (ENISA). The technical foundations of standardized PQC algorithms (Module Lattice–Key Encapsulation Mechanism (ML-KEM), Module Lattice–Digital Signature Algorithm (ML-DSA), Fast-Fourier Lattice-based Compact Signatures over NTRU (FALCON), and Stateless Hash-based–Digital Signature Algorithm (SLH-DSA)) are reviewed, alongside a critical examination of hybrid cryptography, crypto-agility, and strategic alignment on standards and migration principles, despite jurisdictional differences in policy enforcement. The survey highlights shared priorities, such as phased implementation, backward compatibility, and risk mitigation via hybrid adoption. To enhance analytical depth, the study introduces the Institutional–Sectoral PQC Migration Convergence Framework, linking institutional pillars to sectoral readiness for reproducible comparative assessment. National strategies are shown to serve as potential roadmaps for global institutions, underscoring the importance of international coordination and adaptability. These insights support the development of secure, interoperable, and future-proof cryptographic infrastructures in the quantum era, operationalized via the proposed 10-step migration playbook.
