title: Modeling of Visual Cortex Responses to Retinal Neuromorphic Spike-Timing-Based Microstimulation in Mouse Brain Slices
authors: Yuina Terakura, Keisuke Yamada, Santa Fukuda, Yuki Hayashida
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Previous clinical studies have shown that electrical pulse trains delivered into the visual cortex can evoke artificial visual sensations in individuals with acquired blindness, demonstrating the feasibility of intracortical visual prostheses. Our previous physiological experiments in mouse brain slices revealed that a single microstimulation pulse can drive synchronized neuronal action potentials in the vicinity of stimulating microelectrode tip, enabling temporal control of cortical activity using retinal spike-timing-based pulse sequences. In this study, we developed a linear-nonlinear cascade model to predict cortical responses to such neuromorphic stimulation, and confirmed its ability to reproduce key features of the observed neural dynamics.

title: Pelvic Tumor Segmentation in Magnetic Resonance Images By U-Net
authors: Noppanon Nobnop, Piya Kiatisevi, Chamaiporn Sukjamsri, Theekapun Charoenpong
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) is widely used for diagnosing pelvic tumors. Tumor segmentation is an essential step in surgical planning; however, it typically requires specialized experts to manually segment tumors in MRI scans. This research presents a method for segmenting pelvic tumors from MRI images using deep learning technique. A U-Net framework and a U-Net with Batch Normalization architecture for pelvic tumor segmentation are used. To test the performance of the proposed method, we use 24 T2-weighted (T2W) MRI images. The Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC) and Intersection Over Union (IoU) of the U-Net are 71.99% and 56.24%, respectively, while the DSC and IoU of the U-Net with batch normalization layer are 88.68% and 79.66%, respectively. The U-Net with batch normalization layer shows satisfactory results.

title: Securing IEC 61850 with Ascon Lightweight Authenticated Encryption: A Case Study
authors: Aniket Banerjee, Utsav Banerjee
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Modern power grids use GOOSE and SV protocols for reliable high-speed communications between intelligent electronic devices following the IEC 61850 standard. Their stringent timing requirements make it prohibitively expensive to deploy cryptographic mechanisms to ensure confidentiality and integrity of the messages exchanged. Considering the security implications of breaches in such critical infrastructure, this work analyses the benefits of using the upcoming NIST lightweight cryptography standard Ascon to perform integrity protection and authenticated encryption in the context of IEC 61850 GOOSE and SV protocols. Profiling experiments on a Raspberry Pi 5 edge computing device demonstrate that an Ascon-based implementation achieves a two-fold speed-up compared to a traditional AES-based implementation. Our study shows that Ascon can be considered as a viable option for fast lightweight cryptography to secure latency-critical message payloads communicated in substation networks.

title: Traffic Monitoring of 5G RAN using Cloud Computing
authors: Navin Kumar, DS Yadav, VKVV Satyanarayana, Satyakumar V, Sandesh Komarala, Seungil Yoon
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The proliferation of data generated by 5G networks driven by high-density user populations and massive machine-type connection, necessitates robust network traffic monitoring. With diverse users accessing various services, effective traffic management becomes critical. This paper introduces a cloud-based monitoring system leveraging distributed processing and machine learning to enable real-time traffic monitoring, anomaly detection, and network resource optimization. The system efficiently identifies traffic patterns, congestion, and abnormalities, ensuring low latency and network stability. By employing artificial neural networks trained on historical traffic data, the system distinguishes between normal and suspicious traffic, promptly alerting operators to congestion or excessive traffic. Extensive testing and validation in a cloud environment demonstrate the system’s capability and reliability, achieving faster anomaly detection, higher accuracy and, improved resource utilization. This solution benefits network operators, service providers, and end-users by enhancing network dependability and laying the foundation for adaptive control in 5G networks. It represents a significant step toward intelligent, scalable, and efficient network management, paving the way for future advancements in 5G infrastructure.

title: Monitoring of Vital Signs in Anesthetized Rats via Harmonic-based Algorithms with 24 GHz Doppler Radar
authors: Yoshiki Ninomiya, Masaki Kurosawa, Nguyen Huu Son, Kohei Baba, Yutaka Kano, Guanghao Sun
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This study explores the measurement of respiratory rate (RR) and heart rate (HR) in anesthetized rats using a 24 GHz continuous wave (CW) Doppler radar. Noncontact vital sign monitoring methods are increasingly needed to reduce stress in laboratory animals, yet application to small animals remains challenging. We developed a simple algorithm to estimate RR and HR without complex signal processing. Experiments on three healthy rats under isoflurane anesthesia demonstrated high accuracy, with RR showing Root mean squared error (RMSE) of 3.6 bpm and mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) of $3.2 \%$, and HR showing RMSE of 1.4 bpm and MAPE of $\mathbf{0. 1 6 \%}$. This approach enables stress-free monitoring and holds promise for health management of laboratory animals as well as broader biomedical applications. Future work will focus on improving accuracy and developing real-time systems.

title: Photon Blockade in a Two-Cavity System with Two-Photon Dissipation
authors: Hongming Tao
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: The photon blockade is a key quantum-nonlinear effect in which the admission of a second photon to a resonator is inhibited, enabling on-demand single-photon emission. Its practical use is limited by the weak intrinsic nonlinearity of most optical platforms. We address this limitation in a coupled-cavity architecture by engineering two-photon dissipation as a control resource rather than a detrimental loss. Within a quantum-master-equation framework, we model single-photon loss, engineered two-photon decay, and pure dephasing, and analyze their joint impact on the steady-state statistics of the driven cavities. We track the zero-delay correlation, photon populations, and detuning/drive dependences under distinct driving schemes (both cavities driven vs. single-cavity drive with. The results show that adding two-photon dissipation (i) suppresses multiphoton occupation and strengthens antibunching, (ii) broadens the operating window in detuning and drive amplitude, and (iii) improves robustness against moderate dephasing and device imperfections. A mechanism analysis attributes these gains to interference between coherent second-order processes and dissipative selection that stabilizes the odd-photon manifold. The study yields design guidelines for realizing stable, cavity-based single-photon sources using dissipation engineering.

title: Preference-Aware Data Segmentation and Scheduling for Efficient Task Downloading in Smart Community Networks
authors: Liqiong Chen, Rongfa Wu, Huaiying Sun, Kaiwen Zhi
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: With the rapid development of smart community systems, optimizing data transmission has become essential for improving community management and overall system efficiency. Static associations between devices and community access points often result in excessive workloads, low resource utilization, and uneven data distribution, especially during peak usage periods. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Preference-aware Data Segmentation and Scheduling method for community networks. The method includes three stages. First, a segmentation strategy divides large data packets into smaller parallel units for efficient allocation. Second, a preference list-based scheduling mechanism evaluates access points according to transmission speed, latency, and available capacity. Third, a preference-driven matching process assigns data units to the most suitable access points. Extensive simulations were performed under varying user loads and device densities. The results show that the proposed method reduces data transmission latency compared with traditional static strategies and baseline approaches. Resource utilization of community access points is improved, and load distribution across access points is more balanced. These findings indicate that the method effectively enhances efficiency, resource utilization, and load distribution, providing a practical solution for data transmission optimization in smart community networks.

title: Wideband Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface Unit Cell Utilizing Asymmetric Resonator Geometry for mmWave Communications
authors: Bhishm Tripathi, Shailesh Mani, KA Nethravathi, Sandeep Kumar, Geetha K. S
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The commercial rollout of 5th generation (5G) mobile networks has intensified research into the forthcoming 6th generation (6G) mobile networks and the advancement of technologies such as reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) for 5G New Radio (NR) bands. In this work, we propose a novel linearly polarized unit cell featuring a Single-Ring Resonator (SRR) with asymmetric arms, achieving 180°± +30° phase shift and <−1.8 dB reflection loss across 24.5 GHz to 28 GHz. It ensures full 360° phase coverage with an achieved bandwidth of 2.4 GHz centered at 26.25 GHz (corresponding to 9.16% fractional bandwidth), with stable ON/OFF switching in 5G n257/n258 bands. A 0.5 dB to 1.0 dB switching margin and minimal ripple (≤0.2 dB) enable efficient binary modulation. The unit cell demonstrates angular stability, maintaining stable reflection magnitude and phase response for incidence angles up to 40°. Simulation results validate RIS reconfigurability with low-power passive components and angular stability, highlighting its potential to maximize mmWave network sum rate via adaptive beamforming.

title: Leveraging Artificial Intelligence for Optimal RAN Functional Split Decisions in 6G Space-Air-Ground Integrated Networks
authors: Shama Noreen, Hans D. Schotten
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As non-terrestrial platforms expand 6G coverage, dynamically orchestrating radio access network (RAN) functional splits (FS) within disaggregated RAN architectures becomes critical for meeting stringent latency and reliability requirements. Conventional optimization methods fall short in addressing the uncertainty and heterogeneity of space–air–ground integrated networks (SAGIN), making artificial intelligence (AI) particularly well-suited to this orchestration problem. This paper provides a comprehensive roadmap for AI-driven decision-making of RAN FS in 6G SAGIN. It identifies architectural enablers specific to FS in SAGIN, formalizes key design objectives, and introduces a novel state-feature taxonomy. Leveraging federated learning (FL), it introduces a distributed, open RAN (O-RAN) compatible framework that supports real-time and resilient orchestration across satellites, aerial, and terrestrial nodes, while addressing key challenges in client scheduling, resource optimization, and the mitigation of stale updates.

title: Digital Twin Assisted Proactive Management in Zero Touch Networks
authors: Tamizhelakkiya K, Dibakar Das, Komal Sharma, Jyotsna Bapat, Debabrata Das
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The rapid expansion of cellular networks and the rising demand for high-quality services require efficient and autonomous network management solutions. Zero Touch Network (ZTN) management has emerged as a key approach to automating network operations, minimizing manual intervention, and improving service reliability. Digital Twin (DT) creates a virtual representation of the physical network in real-time, allowing continuous monitoring, predictive analytics, and intelligent decision-making by simulating what-if scenarios. This paper integrates DT with ZTN proactive bandwidth management in end-to-end (E2E) next-generation networks. The integrated architecture applies Few-Shot Learning (FSL) to a memory-augmented Bidirectional Long Short Term Memory (BiLSTM) model to predict a new network state to augment the known and trained states. Using Q-learning, it determines the optimal action (e.g. traffic shaping) under varying network conditions such that user Quality of Service (QoS) requirements are met. Three scenarios have been considered: 1) normal ZTN operation with closed-loop control, 2) a what-if scenario of DT, and 3) network state unknown to DT. The simulation results show that the network can adapt to underlying changing conditions. The ZTN assisted by DT achieves only 0. 18% deviation from the no bandwidth variation scenario.

title: Balancing Robot Control via State-Space Approach with Evolutionary Dynamic Parameter Identification
authors: Leslie N. Monroy-Bautista, José R. Rivera-Ruiz, Edson E. Cruz-Miguel, Jose G. Pérez-Juárez, José R. García-Martínez, César García-Arellano
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the design and implementation of a state-space controller for a balancing robot, modeled as an inverted cart-pendulum system. Due to the inherently unstable and nonlinear dynamics of such systems, an evolutionary optimization method-specifically Differential Evolution (DE)-was employed to estimate the model parameters from experimental data, thereby achieving an accurate representation of the real dynamics. Based on this identified model, the controller was developed to stabilize the robot by regulating both the pendulum angle and the chassis displacement. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed control strategy successfully maintains the robot in balance with minimal oscillations, restricting the deviation from the 90 -degree upright reference to within <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.5-1$</tex> degree and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.4990. These findings confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach and highlight its potential for application in self-balancing robotic platforms.

title: Design and Implementation of a Hybrid System Integrating Wireless Sensors with an Optical Link with Potential Application in Precision Agriculture
authors: Eloy Mejía-Yautentzi, Josefina Castañeda-Camacho, Mario Alberto Castillo-Rosete, Juan Carlos Colín-Ortega, Ignacio Enrique Zaldívar-Huerta
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This work presents the design and implementation of a hybrid prototype that integrates a Wireless Sensor Network (WSN) with an optical link using direct optical modulation. The WSN emulates nodes across crop field areas to monitor parameters such as humidity and temperature. The optical communication system permits real-time transmission of this data over long distances. Precisely, this is the main contribution of this work, as the distance limitation by the use of wireless devices is overcome. The results demonstrate the robustness of the link, bandwidth optimization, and efficiency of centralized data analysis. The proposed solution is scalable and adaptable to remote agricultural environments, contributing to sustainable resource management.

title: ESP-NOW Based Automatic Gate Control System
authors: Uroš Joković
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of an automatic gate control system based on ESP32 microcontrollers and the ESP-NOW communication protocol. Vehicle proximity is estimated using the Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI), enabling the gate to open automatically without user interaction. The proposed solution ensures high reliability through multiple receivers at the gate, low power consumption, and enhanced security using AES encryption and ECDH key exchange embedded in the ESP-NOW protocol. Experimental results confirm that the system is a simple, cost-effective, and efficient alternative to existing gate access solutions.

title: A Review of Power System Challenges Stemming from Large AI Data Center Loads
authors: Venkateswara R. Seshmasetti, Abdulla Ismail, Haris M. Khalid
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The deployment of Artificial Intelligence (AI) data centers presents significant challenges for electrical power systems. This proposed paper reviews the impacts of AI data center loads on power system operation by systematically analyzing technical documents, utility reports, and regulatory frameworks. Unlike traditional loads, AI data centers exhibit distinct power dynamics, independent protection philosophies, and geographic concentration, which can destabilize both local and system levels. Notable incidents, such as sharp power fluctuations and load disconnections, raise concerns about system stability. This proposed review aims to synthesize knowledge on this emerging topic by developing a multitimescale framework, validating theoretical predictions, classifying AI-induced oscillatory modes (0.5-23 Hz), examining stability effects in Inverter-Based Resources (IBR) systems, and proposing hierarchical mitigation strategies. These insights provide vital guidance for operators and researchers on the impacts of AI data centers on the grid.

title: Planar PCB Antenna Array with DT Distribution and Increased Efficiency for Surveillance Radar Application
authors: Boro Reljic, Slobodan M. Simic, Zoran Golubicic, Aleksa Zejak
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents a report about advances in development of planar printed antenna array for surveillance radar application. The paper presents a novel development of planar PCB antenna array with 256 antenna elements and Dolph-Tschebyscheff (DT) current distribution. This antenna system is developed for direct application in PR-15 radar equipment and to meet all required environmental specifications. Achieved results show good performances of the PCB antenna system: high gain and efficiency, narrow beam width, low side lobe levels, low profile and size smaller than parabolic reflector antenna. Also novel antenna satisfies all rigorous environmental conditions.

title: Energy-Efficient Zonal HVAC Control using Iot, CCTV Occupancy Analytics and MPC
authors: Michael Short, Sean Williams, Nashwan Dawood, Malek Qalit Alrashidi, Sami Mnasri, Mansoor Alghamdi, Maha Alqabli
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Buildings account for a substantial share of global energy demand and greenhouse-gas emissions, with HVAC systems often the largest loads in operation. At the same time, indoor air quality (IAQ) influences cognition, comfort, and health - typically managed by limiting CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentrations below regulatory or de-facto thresholds. Traditional timetable-based or rule-based ventilation struggles to track rapidly varying occupancy, causing IAQ excursions and energy waste. Leveraging IoT sensors and CCTV analytics to obtain real-time occupancy signals to correlate with indoor environment variables, together with predictive control, enables proactive ventilation that better balances IAQ and energy. This paper presents a novel occupancy-aware predictive HVAC framework that fuses real-time occupant estimates from CCTV analytics with a disturbance-aware ARX model for CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> concentration (recursively identified from measured data), along with a real-time, energy-aware MPC scheme. The MPC includes a cubic-law fan power model and a dynamic minimum-ventilation constraint derived from static designed occupancy (per-area and per-person outdoor-air requirements) and zonal airflow characteristics. Using measured hourly occupancy estimates and CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> data from the Net Zero Industry Innovation Centre (NZIIC) in Middlesbrough, UK, we identify an accurate ARX(2,2) model and use it in Hardware-in-the-Loop (HIL) experiments to validate the approach. Results demonstrate that the controller varies airflow predictively and in step with occupancy, maintaining optimal Indoor Air Quality (IAQ) well under a 1000 ppm limit, while substantially reducing fan energy requirement by 85% versus a static preprogrammed ventilation strategy designed for average designed daytime occupancy with night setback as a comparative baseline.

title: RO-MIL: A Ground-View Military Object Detection Dataset
authors: Andrada Petrescu, Mihaela Gordan, Şerban-Nicolae Meza, Andrei-Gheorghe Corcheş
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Military object detection in real-world environments remains challenging due to camouflage, partial occlusions, and variable lighting conditions. Learning efficient detection models is limited by the small number of available image datasets from real military scenarios. To address this issue, we present a novel annotated dataset, tailored for YOLObased training, collected during CADET field exercises near Sibiu, Romania. The dataset consists of 786 RGB images, covering three classes: personnel, vehicles, and aircraft. Manual annotations were added in Label Studio at the original resolution and exported in YOLO format. The dataset was split into train/validation/test subsets and used to train YOLOv6-n, YOLOv8-n, and YOLOv11-n models, confirming its suitability for realistic tactical scenarios. As future work, we aim to extend the dataset with polarimetric channels (DoLP/AoLP) to reveal material and texture cues not visible in the standard RGB representation.

title: Iot-Based Adaptive Street Lighting: Scalable Solutions for High-Density Large-Scale Smart City Networks
authors: Alexandru Lavric, Gutu Alexandrin, Adrian-Ioan Petrariu, Partemie-Marian Mutescu
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Street lighting is a critical component of urban infrastructure with a direct impact on public safety, quality of life and energy efficiency. This paper presents the design, development, and testing of an adaptive street lighting control system based on modern IoT technologies specific to the Smart City concept, focusing on scalability and interoperability for largescale deployments in heterogeneous environments. The lighting control system integrates motion sensors to detect the presence of vehicles and pedestrians adjusting light levels accordingly. The collected information is centralized in a cloud-based platform, where it is stored and processed. Based on the information collected by the sensors, light intensity is dynamically adjusted to increase pedestrian and driver safety, optimize energy consumption, and reduce light pollution. The experimental results obtained show a high level of performance, providing an integrated IoT solution for the sustainable development of smart cities.

title: Central Dogma of Biology: Inclusion, Educational Game, and AI Technology in the University Classroom
authors: Julián Alejandro Yunes-Rojas, José M. Nieto-Jalil, Hera Andrade Zaldivar, Irma Cruz Solís, Jorge Lozano-Aponte
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: We present a low-cost, UDL-grounded instructional approach to teaching the central dogma of molecular biology in an undergraduate course. The design integrates a kinesthetic MDF jigsaw with PLA 3D-printed molecular models, multimodal accessibility assets (Braille process cards, captioned/narrated micro-lectures, QR-linked resources), and an educational chatbot that delivers formative, rationale-seeking feedback on student-generated case studies. In a pilot cohort (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=18$</tex>; matched <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=10$</tex>), learning scores increased from 8.2 (pre) to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.6 / 10$</tex> (post) on a paired test, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{t}(9)=2.91$</tex>, two-tailed p <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.017,95 \% \text{CI}$</tex> for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta \mathrm{M}=1.4:[0.31,2.49]$</tex>; variance decreased from 3.07 to 0.27, indicating greater response consistency. Standardized effects were large (paired <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{d}_{(\mathbf{z})}=0.92$</tex>; Hedges' <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{g} \approx$</tex> 0.98). Perception data showed impact/usefulness <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=69.7 / 100$</tex> (collaborative work <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=94$</tex>) and engagement <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=75.5 / 100$</tex> (self-regulation/strategic thinking <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=89$</tex>). Grounded in Universal Design for Learning and research on serious games and chatbots in education, the approach is scalable and transferable to related life-science topics, providing a transferable framework for inclusive STEM education. We outline threats to validity (sample size, instrumentation) and a replication plan with pre-registered analyses and component ablation to benchmark the relative contribution of the tactile kit, multimodal media, and chatbot.

title: Energy Efficiency Testing and Power Modeling of O-RAN Radio Units
authors: Zhuohuan Li, Prasanthi Maddala, N. K. Shankaranarayanan, Ivan Seskar, Sarat Puthenpura, Alexandru Stancu, Christian Nunez Alvarez, Gregg Albrecht
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The power consumption of O-RAN Radio Units (O-RUs) is a dominant factor in the overall energy efficiency and sustainability of O-RAN networks. To develop effective energy management solutions, detailed O-RU energy tests and accurate power consumption models are essential. This paper presents a comprehensive study on multi-vendor O-RU energy efficiency, making two key contributions: (a) we introduce a versatile O-RU energy testing platform and present a comprehensive set of power measurements from multiple O-RUs across various operational parameters, including MIMO configurations and traffic loads; (b) we leverage this empirical data to parameterize and validate a component-based power model. Our findings provide critical insights into O-RU power dynamics, enabling the refinement of energy-saving algorithms and supporting the sustainable evolution of O-RAN deployments.

title: Throughput Prediction in Dense WLANs Using TabTransformer Models Trained on Simulated Scenarios
authors: Sapna V M, Achyuth S S, Prasad H.B
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In today’s data-driven wireless landscape, ensuring reliable throughput in WLANs is critical—especially in dense environments where multiple devices compete for limited spectrum. This paper introduces a machine learning-based approach, leveraging the TabTransformer model, to accurately forecast the throughput of a Basic Service Set (BSS) in IEEE 802.11 networks. Instead of relying on time-consuming field measurements, we use Komondor—a robust network simulator—to generate diverse deployment scenarios, enabling efficient training of our predictive model. Our results demonstrate that TabTransformers can capture complex feature interactions in tabular WLAN data and offer strong predictive performance across varying conditions. This proactive prediction capability can significantly enhance real-time network design and resource allocation.

title: Reduced harmonic errors by geometrically modulating the demagnetizing fields in wave-type anisotropic magnetoresistance angle sensors
authors: Qihang Xu, Jiaming Liu, Mengmeng Guan, Wei Su, Zhiguang Wang, Zhongqiang Hu, Ming Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Anisotropic Magnetoresistance (AMR) angle sensors are widely utilized in industrial applications owing to their non-contact operation, cost efficiency, and miniaturization potential. However, harmonic distortion inherent in AMR measurements fundamentally limits angle encoder accuracy. This work introduces a high-precision AMR sensor employing a wave-type topology that suppresses harmonic errors through geometric innovation, demonstrating significant performance enhancements versus conventional strip-type sensors: 64.3% reduction in maximum angular error (0.50° vs. 1.4°), 65.3% lower worst-case nonlinearity (0.2% vs. 0.576%), and minimal change in repeatability (0.14° vs. 0.137°). Systematic evaluation of dynamic responses under variable field angles through Stoner–Wohlfarth modeling and experimental validation exhibits excellent agreement, confirming curvature optimization effectively minimizes angular errors. Mechanistic analysis identifies demagnetizing fields and induced anisotropy as dominant error sources. Crucially, this architecture maintains fabrication simplicity, demonstrating exceptional cost-performance synergy for automotive, robotics, and industrial automation applications requiring sub-0.5° accuracy.

title: Radar-Centric AFDM Waveform With Chirp-Domain Index Modulation for ISAC
authors: Muneeb Ahmad, Sobia Baig, Nawaf A. Alqwaifly
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: This paper presents a radar-centric framework for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) that utilizes affine frequency-division multiplexing (AFDM). We propose chirp-domain index modulation (CDIM) as a method to embed data without compromising radar performance. In this method, each AFDM block is assembled using a pair of predetermined chirp coefficients chosen from a radar-compliant lookup table. These chirp pairs are equivalent in terms of ambiguity, meaning that the embedded communication symbols preserve the radar’s correlation properties and compactness of ambiguity. The suggested AFDM-IM waveform maintains a constant signal envelope and performs matched filtering for high-resolution range-Doppler estimation. Chirp selection embeds communication data structurally, rather than using traditional amplitude or phase modulation. This enables the receiver to detect the index with low complexity. Simulation results demonstrate that AFDM-IM can estimate radar signals even when transmitted over doubly dispersive channels and can also efficiently send modest amounts of data. The proposed framework strikes a good balance between sensing fidelity and communication throughput, making it a viable choice for next-generation ISAC systems.

title: A Cryo-CMOS Smart Temperature Sensor for the Ultrawide Temperature Range From 5 K to 296 K
authors: D. Cerviño Fungueiriño, L.A. Enthoven, J. van Staveren, M. Babaie, F. Sebastiano
publish: IEEE Solid-State Circuits Letters
abstract: This work presents a cryo-CMOS smart temperature sensor operating from room temperature down to 5K. By adopting sensing elements (CMOS bulk diodes, PMOS/DTMOS in weak inversion) that circumvent the poor cryogenic performance of Si BJTs, a robust switched-capacitor second-order Sigma-Delta readout and cryogenic-aware design techniques, the sensor achieves a maximum error of ±0.73K (4 samples, 2-point trim), a resolution below 0.05K for a 102.4ms readout duration, and a power consumption of 15.5μW (93.5μW) at 5K (296K).

title: Microwave Resonator Orientation-Based Dual-Principle Linear Displacement Sensor
authors: Premsai Regalla, A. V. Praveen Kumar, Amir Ebrahimi, Kamran Ghorbani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper reports the first dual-principle microwave displacement sensor, capable of operating in either frequency-shift or single-frequency amplitude-variation mode, thereby offering unprecedented flexibility for displacement measurement. The sensor consists of a metallic strip printed on a high-permittivity circular dielectric slab, forming a cylindrical dielectric resonator (CDR) positioned between two parallel microstrip transmission lines. A key feature is that the operating mode is selected simply by changing the orientation of the resonator relative to the feedlines, enabling effortless reconfiguration. In the frequency-shift mode (strip perpendicular to the feed lines), displacement is detected through variations in open-stub lengths on the feedlines, achieving 40 MHz/mm sensitivity over a 0–40 mm range. In the amplitude-variation mode (strip parallel to the feedlines), two resonances- strip and dielectric-resonator modes- are exploited, yielding sensitivities of 2 dB/mm (0–12 mm) and 1 dB/mm (0–17 mm), respectively. The sensor further exhibits a wide dynamic range in swept-frequency operation and simultaneous multi-resonance detection in fixed-frequency mode, with high agreement between simulations and measurements. The proposed design introduces a new class of reconfigurable resonator-based displacement sensors with strong potential for robotics, industrial automation, structural health monitoring, and aerospace vibration detection.

title: Classification of Non-Functional Requirements Using Neuroevolution of Convolutional Neural Networks
authors: María-Saarayim González-Hernández, Efrén Mezura-Montes, Ángel-J. Sánchez-García
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Software requirements classification is an activity typically performed by humans, which increases the effort involved and is also prone to errors. Given this, the usage of machine learning has become popular, including artificial neural networks and also convolutional neural networks. However, such models are usually handcrafted and not optimized. Therefore, this paper proposes to perform software requirements classification using a neuroevolved convolutional neural network using an adapted version of the genetic algorithm named DeepGA. A sevenclass software requirements dataset is used in the experiments. The results suggest that the neuroevolutionary process improves the classification capabilities of the deep neural networks even in unbalanced scenarios.

title: Study on Student Satisfaction with a Learning Management System in a Hybrid Learning Modality
authors: Luis Alejandro Gazca Herrera, Karina Culebro Castillo, Jessica Garizurieta Bernabe, Ximena Montserrat Zarate Hernández, Akemi Sánchez Molgado
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, education institutions were compelled to transform their educational modalities in order to address potential future health contingencies. In 2021, the Universidad Veracruzana implemented a hybrid learning model as a strategy for the safe return to both face-to-face and virtual class, utilizing hybrid classrooms and its learning management system (LMS) known as EMINUS. The objective of the study was to analyze students' satisfaction with the LMS in the hybrid context, assessing its usefulness in the teaching-learning process. The study employed a quantitative approach, with a descriptive and longitudinal design, using a properly validated instrument divided into dimensions related to the LMS, the hybrid modality, communication, and technological infrastructure. Students expressed a favorable perception regarding the functionality, accessibility, and ease of use of the LMS, as well the instructional design and communication with the hybrid modality. However, areas for improvement were identified in aspects such as training in the use of the platform and the performance of hybrid classroom. It is concluded that the LMS is valued as a key resource for hybrid learning. Student satisfaction is influenced by instructional planning and teacher support, although technical and training challenges persist. The research provides empirical evidence on the student experience with an LMS in a hybrid modality, offering a reference point for the design of educational improvement strategies in similar contexts.

title: Development of AI-Based Microdrone Capabilities for Multifunctional Aerial Applications
authors: Valentin-Dimitrie Popescu, Mircea Giurgiu, Marton Cserei
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and experimental evaluation of a new concept for a multi-drone system capable of executing complex aerial missions in both indoor and outdoor environments. The novelty of the proposed architecture consists in integrating ultra-wideband communication, onboard Artificial Intelligence (AI) for object detection, and a web-based control interface to coordinate multiple microdrones of the type Crazyflie 2.1. Key functionalities include real-time video surveillance, autonomous navigation to predefined coordinates, precise indoor positioning using Time Difference of Arrival (TDoA), optical flow-based stability, and onboard object detection. Experimental results demonstrate the system's robustness, adaptability, and potential for real-world applications such as security monitoring, industrial inspection, and intelligent autonomous operations in GPS-denied environments.

title: Charge Carrier Recombination Study of Perovskite $\text{MAPbI}_{3-\mathrm{x}} \text{Cl}_{\mathrm{x}}$ Solar Cell
authors: E.J. Morales-Flores, M.A. Millán-Franco, Hailin Hu, A.G. Vázquez, L. Martínez-García, J. Martínez-Castillo, E. A. Morales González, J.C. Nolasco-Montaño
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Perovskite solar cells have proven to be an alternative as a low-cost device. However, there is still room for improvement in its efficiency. In this work, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{T i O}_{\mathbf{2}} / \mathbf{M A P b I}_{\mathbf{3}}$</tex> <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{x} \text{Cl}_{x} /$</tex> Spiro-OMeTAD solar cells are investigated to identify the recombination pathway of charge carriers. Specifically, numerical simulations were conducted to model the experimental currentvoltage characteristics. Afterward, the band diagram of the device and the interfacial barriers were calculated. We demonstrate that the barrier at the MAPbI3-xCIx/Spiro-OMeTAD junction is the lowest, indicating that charge carrier recombination is predominant at this interface.

title: Comparative Analysis of Natural Frequency in Mechanical Materials using Adaptive Photodetection with Speckle Patterns
authors: Darwin Mayorga Cruz
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Due to their continuous use in industrial environments, machines experience several problems caused by resonant mechanical vibrations. Their analysis and control can prevent considerable damage, such as accelerated wear and serious failures in materials and machinery. Implementation of methods based on well-known systems such as accelerometers or proximeters for estimating resonant natural frequencies has certain disadvantages, as they are contact procedures. On the other hand, optical and optoelectronic methods are non-contact and telemetric, making them attractive alternatives under specific conditions. In this research, the adaptive photodetection method, based on the non-stationary photoelectromotive force (P-EMF) effect with optical speckle patterns was performed on three metallic materials, for mechanical vibrations detection and natural frequency characterization. Experimental results obtained with speckle P-EMF tests were compared and discussed with contact methods.

title: Highlights in Electrical Substations Technologies for Connection to TSO's
authors: Luis Ivan Ruiz Flores, Esmeralda Plancarte, Brenda Campos Castillo
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: In this paper, the comparisons of the insulation systems for electrical substations are presented, focused on the gas-insulated technologies (GIS) used by Transmission System Operators (TSO's), as well as the typical control scheme that is currently being used. recommend monitoring the electrical system with this type of technology. Currently there are various brands and recognized companies that manufacture this type of primary electrical equipment integrating control and protection elements with state-of-the-art technology; However, the need to place substations in the industry to supply its auxiliary services requires comparing factors such as cost and long-term maintenance; as well as the size or space for its installation. The above, since the rise of electrical systems globally, is underpinning the safety of personnel and electrical installations in electrical systems. In this article, we present the most important manufacturing characteristics, used by manufacturing companies of Electrical Substations, although they are not the only ones worldwide; Parameters and factors are weighted in a table that would contribute to the technical knowledge of the high voltage issue, as well as contribute to the electrical community that makes decisions in design and implementation within its facilities. The foregoing, to contribute to the engineering community who need to install TSO's substations in an electrical reconfiguration or an expansion of the electrical system.

title: Robustness and Explainability of Machine-Learning-Based Medium Voltage Circuit Breaker Condition Assessment Method
authors: Kerim Obarcanin, Emir Sokic, Samim Konjicija, Amer Smajkic, Tatjana Konjic, Bakir Lacevic
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This article explores the robustness and explainability of a convolutional neural network-based fault detection method for medium-voltage circuit breakers. The robustness is analysed by evaluating the method's performance under the presence of stationary and non-stationary disturbances in the vibration signature. Additionally, the impact of sensor ageing on performance indices is investigated to assess long-term reliability. Since the condition assessment method is focused on binary classification, the detection outcome interpretation aspect is addressed by providing recommendations for operator or autonomous system actions. Both aspects are demonstrated using datasets collected from real-world medium-voltage circuit breakers.

title: Characterization of physical properties of a microactuator based on a Yoshida-type chemomechanical gel
authors: Alexander V. Sychev, Ilya L. Mallphanov, Anastasia S. Vanina, Anastasia I. Lavrova, Eugene B. Postnikov
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Chemomechanical gels, which exhibit self-sustained volume oscillations driven by the Belousov-Zhabotinsky reaction, are promising soft materials for the creation of pumps and actuators for microfluidic applications and microrobotics. In this work, we report mechanical characteristics of a microdevice containing a driving part based on a novel self-oscillating gel based on complexes of iron with tridentate $1^{2}, 2^{2}: 2^{6}, 3^{2}$-terpyridine and its derivatives, as well as structural and rheological properties of the latter. The appropriate methods of experimental investigation and data processing are discussed as well.

title: Composite Filtering Methods for Millimeter-Wave Radar-Based Heart Rate Monitoring
authors: Chi-Hung Wang, Chia-Hsien Lin, Chih-Wei Chen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Due to the fragile and limited skin of newborns and premature babies, traditional electrocardiograms require longterm skin contact. At the same time, photovolume change technology is susceptible to sweating and interference from ambient light, which is not conducive to long-term monitoring. Although millimeter-wave radar (mmWave Radar) offers the advantage of non-contact measurement, most studies employ single-layer filtering, which does not fully align with the characteristics of ECG PQRST waves, thereby limiting its clinical applications. In this study, an improved composite filtering method is proposed to align the mmWave Radar heart rhythm waveform more closely with the ECG RR interval graph, thereby enhancing the accuracy of heart rhythm calculation. The system collected data from 20 test subjects. It used three methods: bandpass filtering (BPF), wavelet noise reduction (WD), and matching filtering (MF) to combine them into seven filtering schemes for comparison IWR6843AOPEVM. Through multidimensional similarity index (MSRI) analysis, combined with dynamic time warping (DTW) distance, spectral coherence, and sample entropy similarity, the results showed that the BPF+WD combination had the best effect. After recalculating the $\mathbf{R R}$ interval, the difference between the mmWave radar heart rate and the ECG was approximately one beat per minute (BPM), with an accuracy rate of 98.57%. These findings provide a reference for improving non-contact heart rhythm monitoring and may support the future clinical adoption of mmWave Radar.

title: TASC : Tactical Assessment-based SD-WAN Control For Mainstream Traffic Management
authors: Pavan Iddalagi, Amrita Mishra
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In modern SD-WAN architectures, maintaining the health of transport tunnels is essential for supporting high quality audio and video streams. Most SD-WAN solutions require customers to manually configure the tunnel health probing protocol (THPP) probe frequency, yet offer no clear guidance for determining an optimal value. Motivated by this research gap we propose a novel framework called tactical assessment-based SD-WAN control (TASC). TASC dynamically adjusts THPP probe frequency based on a real time assessment of network conditions using topology-agnostic parameters, including the mainstream traffic’s effective available bandwidth (EABW), bandwidth utilization (BWU), queue service rate (QSR), THPP’s one-way delay (OWD), CPU utilization, and operational status. Further, these parameters have been used to compute a novel Mainstream Traffic Health (MTH) score. Unlike static approaches, TASC applies positive weights to reinforce factors that promote tunnel stability and negative weights to those that indicate degradation. Experimental results demonstrate that TASC significantly outperforms traditional SD-WAN.

title: Scalable Marine AIS Architecture with FedMicro for Distributed Vessel Tracking
authors: Amballa Venkata Sriram, Sathwik Narkedimilli, Sujith Makam, Sai Prashanth Mallellu, MSVPJ Sathvik, R. Venkatesha Prasad
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Maritime domain awareness increasingly relies on Automatic Identification System (AIS) data. Yet, traditional monolithic backends struggle to scale with rising message volumes and offer limited resilience, data sovereignty, or rapid deployability. This study addresses the challenges by introducing a novel federated learning and microservices architecture for distributed vessel tracking. Each end node trains local models on a proprietary AIS Maritime environment via Dockerized microservices: Data Pre-Processor, Client Trainer, Aggregator, Global Model Updater, and XAI Service, enabling independent scaling, fault isolation, and federated governance without exposing raw feeds. A global model is aggregated using FedAvg and served with a sub-second latency of 10 ms of aggregation and 406 ms of inference. Experimental evaluation on four benchmark AIS snapshots yields strong predictive performance (MAE = 0.31, RMSE = 0.39, R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.78) and demonstrates transparent feature attribution via SHAP. These results validate the proposed architecture’s capability to deliver accurate, low-latency energy predictions while preserving data sovereignty and cross-node consistency. This study lays the foundation for robust, interoperable maritime analytics by bridging microservice agility with federated intelligence and XAI.

title: Towards Efficient IoUT Vision: Simulated Compressed Image Transmission and Detection
authors: Jahnava Sai Garikapati, Ch Madhu Bhushan, Firoj Gazi, Md Muzakkir Hussain
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Underwater communication is constrained by limited bandwidth, high latency, and signal attenuation, particularly in acoustic transmission scenarios. To address these challenges, this paper investigates a simulation-based framework for underwater image transmission using discrete cosine transform (DCT) and quantization-based compression. Grayscale images are compressed at varying quantization levels (3-bit to 8-bit) and transmitted over a simulated underwater acoustic channel with relay-based attenuation and noise. The impact of compression on image fidelity is evaluated using Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio and Structural Similarity Index (PSNR, SSIM), while object detection robustness is assessed via classification accuracy using a MobileNetV2 model. Experimental results demonstrate a clear trade-off between compression efficiency and detection accuracy, offering insights into optimal quantization strategies for bandwidth-limited underwater environments. This simulation framework, developed entirely in MATLAB, provides a scalable testbed for evaluating vision-centric Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT) applications prior to real-world deployment on resource-constrained devices.

title: A Novel Integrated Architecture for Intent Based Approach and Zero Touch Networks
authors: Neelam Gupta, Dibakar Das, Tamizhelakkiya K, Uma Maheswari Natarajan, Sharvari Ravindran, Komal Sharma, Jyotsna Bapat, Debabrata Das
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Sixth Generation (6G) and beyond networks present challenges in managing quality of service (QoS) of diverse applications and meeting Service Level Agreements (SLAs) under varying network conditions. Hence, network management needs automation using machine Learning (ML) and artificial Intelligence (AI) to meet real-time requirements. Zero touch network (ZTN) is one of the frameworks to automate network management with mechanisms, such as, closed loop control to ensure that the goals are met perpetually. Intent-Based Networking (IBN) specifies the user intents with diverse network requirements which are then translated into specific network configurations and actions. This paper presents a novel architecture for integrating IBN and ZTN to serve the intent goals. Users provide the intent in natural language, e.g., English, which is then translated using natural language processing (NLP) techniques (e.g., retrieval augmented generation (RAG)) into Network Intent LanguagE (Nile). The Nile intent is passed to the BiLSTM and Q-learning based ZTN closed loop as a goal which maintains the intent under varying network conditions. The integrated architecture is also implemented on a testbed using OpenAirInterface (OAI). Additionally, to evaluate the architecture, an optimization problem is formulated which evaluated with Monte Carlo simulations. Results demonstrate how ZTN achieves goals set by user intent 98% of the duration. Simulation and testbed results are compared which show similar trend. Mean Opinion Score (MOS) for Quality of Experience (QoE) is also measured to indicate satisfaction of user intent.

title: Improving DNS Exfiltration Detection via Transformer Pretraining
authors: Miloš Tomić, Aleksa Cvetanović, Predrag Tadić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: We study whether in-domain pretraining of Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformer (BERT) model improves subdomain-level detection of exfiltration at ultra-low false positive rates. Previous work mostly examined fine-tuned generic Transformers, but did not aim to isolate the effect of pretraining on the downstream task of classification. We therefore address this gap by developing a controlled pipeline where we freeze operating points on validation and apply them unchanged to the test set in order to measure the impact of pretraining. Our results show significant improvements in the left tail of the Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) against randomly initialized baseline. Additionally, within pretrained model variants, increase in the number of pretraining steps had the most impact when more labeled data were available for fine-tuning.

title: Integration of Business Intelligence Systems with Spatial Components for the Presentation of Tourist Movement
authors: Kenan Saračević, Alen Čelik, Almir Karabegović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: In Bosnia and Herzegovina, there is a significant lack of research combining Artificial Intelligence (AI), Business Intelligence (BI), and geospatial analysis in tourism planning. This paper aims to fill that gap by demonstrating the integration of these technologies applied to spatial data in order to analyze tourist movement patterns. Spatial data processing was performed using QGIS (Quantum Geographic Information System), an open-source Geographic Information System (GIS), while Python was used to apply clustering algorithms on the data points. The resulting insights are visualized clearly through Power BI dashboards for better interpretability. This approach allows for understanding the relationship between tourists' routes and the proximity of hotels and museums. By combining AI, BI, and spatial data, more effective tourism planning can be achieved, helping to maintain well-organized and sustainable destinations.

title: User-Defined Memory Sharing and Execution for Edge-Based Collaborative Applications
authors: Katarina-Glorija Grujić, Miloš Simić
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Emerging edge computing environments demand lightweight, scalable orchestration frameworks that enable modular execution and efficient memory sharing across distributed nodes. This paper proposes a data sharing and processing platform where users define a graph between specified kernels. We survey existing modular orchestration solutions (Node-RED, Apache NiFi, AWS Step Functions) and large-scale data processing frameworks (Google Dremel, Apache Spark, Apache Hadoop) to position our solution. Our approach bridges the gap between modular orchestration and distributed memory sharing for edge computing applications.

title: Integrating Digital Twins and Machine Learning in Industry 4.0: State of the Art and Research Perspectives
authors: Mare Srbinovska, Zivko Kokolanski, Vladimir Dimcev, Dimitar Taskovski, Marija Markovska Dimitrovska, Maja Celeska Krstevska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Digital Twin (DT) technology is a key enabler of Industry 4.0, combining sensor data and simulations for monitoring, optimization, and decision-making. Physics-based DTs offer interpretability but are computationally intensive, while machine learning (ML) adds adaptability yet often lacks transparency and generalization. Their convergence, especially via hybrid or physics-informed frameworks, enables accurate and efficient digital representations of industrial processes. Applications already include predictive maintenance, energy optimization, and fault detection, though challenges in data scarcity, real-time performance, interpretability, and standardization persist. This paper reviews the state of the art in ML-enhanced DTs, highlights research gaps, and outlines directions for robust, explainable, and sustainable solutions.

title: Efficient Scheduling of RAN Workloads in Multi-Core Architectures
authors: Pramit Biswas, Makarand Kulkarni, Parag Naik, Anindya Saha
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As radio access networks (RAN) are being deployed over cloud-based platforms for several benefits, it is essential to understand the difference between the execution of the RAN software workloads when presented to these platforms built around general-purpose processors (GPP) and those built using specialized DSP architectures. Hard real-time guarantees, which the RAN software demands, are different from traditional applications that are hosted on public and on-premise cloud platforms. To meet these requirements, several techniques are employed, ranging from manipulation of cache lines to restricting the processor performance states, which try to asymptotically meet the real-time requirements. While there are enough studies on processor scheduling, the aspect of scheduling RAN software on a multicore GPP platform is limited. Hence, providing limits on guarantees of performance has been overlooked. This paper describes the specific characteristics of the RAN software and formulates the scheduling problem. Heuristic solutions to the scheduling problem are presented, given different requirements for RAN workloads. The shortcomings of deploying these real-time workloads on GPP are illustrated, and conclusions about further possibilities are presented.

title: Connectivity-Aware VNF Placement in Space-Air-Ground Integrated Networks
authors: Kanimozhi C, Chaitanya Mabbu, Venkatarami Reddy Chintapalli, Subashini R
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: The Space-Air-Ground Integrated Network (SAGIN) has emerged as a promising solution to bridge the digital divide by extending connectivity to users in remote and underserved regions. Within SAGIN, Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites play a pivotal role in providing global coverage and reduced latency. However, the limited resources of LEO satellites make the deployment of hardware-based network functions impractical. This challenge can be addressed by Network Function Virtualization (NFV) and efficient Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) placement. However, due to the dynamic nature of satellite networks, VNF placement remains a significant challenge. Previous studies often overlook the temporal stability of satellite connectivity and lead to frequent VNF migrations and degraded service performance. To address this gap, we propose an heuristic algorithm with two phases: the Long Connectivity-Based Path Selection (LCBPS) phase to identify paths with longer satellite connectivity durations and the Long Connectivity-Based VNF Placement with VNF Sharing (LCBVPVS) phase that leverages both long-connectivity-based VNF placement and VNF sharing to reduce deployment time and cost. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art approach in terms of longer connectivity duration, more than 35% of service acceptance rate and less than 50% to 60% of end-to-end delay in dynamic satellite networks.

title: Delay Outage Probability in IoT Networks with IRS-Aided NOMA-MEC: Performance Evaluation and Enhancement
authors: M Arulvizhi, KC Sriharipriya, Michael Kuhn
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Internet of Things (IoT) products are now extensively deployed and play a significant role in the daily lives of individuals. The increasing adoption of IoT applications generates numerous computationally intensive tasks. However, they are unable to perform these tasks locally due to their limited battery life, storage capacity, and processing power. To solve this, multi access edge computing (MEC) servers are required to handle computationally intensive tasks. In addition, non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) approaches are suggested as a solution to the issue caused by the constraints of wireless transmission resources. However, when the direct connections between the base station and the IoT devices are obstructed, intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) are introduced to offload the tasks. This study examines the performance of an IRS assisted NOMA-MEC for IoT networks under Rayleigh fading. To assess the performance of the proposed system, the closed form formula for delay outage probability (DOP) is derived. According to simulation data, the proposed design minimizes DOP by ≈0.5309 compared to NOMA-MEC at SNR =14dB.

title: Composite Planar In Situ Antenna Measurements Using a Robotic Arm System
authors: Celia Fontá Romero, Ana Arboleya, Fernando Rodríguez Varela, Eduardo Martinez-de-Rioja, Manuel Sierra Castañer
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern antenna systems demands flexible measurement solutions that overcome the limitations of conventional setups, particularly regarding advanced sampling schemes and portability. Robotic arm-based systems have emerged as a key option for implementing advanced antenna measurement techniques due to their flexibility. However, these systems face challenges such as positioning errors and restricted range of motion, which limit the size of the acquisition surfaces. This work presents a portable antenna measurement system that integrates a collaborative robot (cobot) mounted on a mobile platform with an Optical Tracking System (OTS) for in situ antenna characterization. To address the range of motion limitations, a composite plane technique is introduced, enabling the combination of individual measurement surfaces into a larger composite surface. These individual surfaces are acquired after manually repositioning the mobile platform, relying on the OTS data for precise alignment and compensation for probe displacements. The proposed system features a simple calibration procedure and post-processing techniques to correct positioning errors without requiring complex robot calibrations or additional hardware. The system has been experimentally validated through measurements in the X- and V-bands, demonstrating good results and highlighting its effectiveness, accuracy, and adaptability for advanced in situ antenna measurements.

title: Toward State Estimation Algorithms in Cooperative Positioning: A Comprehensive Framework Design and Its Realization_supp5-3645051.mp4
authors: Ruichen Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: Cooperative positioning enhances localization accuracy in intelligent artifact swarms through shared measurements, especially in environments such as urban canyons or disaster zones. Dynamic topologies, heterogeneous measurements, and scalability demands create complex challenges for state estimation. This paper introduces MRCA, the first comprehensive framework unifying heterogeneous measurements, reasoning processes, environment cognition, and scenario-based applications for cooperative positioning. The four-layer architecture comprises: i) the Measurement block converts signals into measurement parameters in a standard format independent of sensor types and measurement methods; ii) the Reasoning block uncovers the underlying principles of state transition using a four reasoning elements; iii) the Cognition block underscores the importance of node-environment interactions by identifying new valid radiation sources and verifying the ongoing validity of existing ones; iv) the Application block offers users task-driven cooperative positioning services, like execute potential navigation actions. Our proposed framework demonstrates performance improvements in various key metrics compared to legacy swarm positioning algorithms. Focusing on the framework itself, we employ the most basic algorithms within each block, and the experimental results are as follows: In scenarios featuring static unknown anchors, sparse perception, and collision interference, MRCA reduces cumulative positioning error by over 51% for dead-reckoning and 39% for traditional distributed cooperative positioning, while reducing average orientation error by over 31% and 27%, respectively. Running on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> consumer-grade IMUs, MRCA achieves a final RMSE of 10.27 m, outperforming even a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${\$}1~500$</tex-math> </inline-formula> industrial-grade IMU in dead-reckoning mode (11.99 m). Through the validation of real - scene datasets, the paper illustrates how this framework integrates into system-level solutions for real-world implementation, further advancing the theoretical understanding of state estimation in cooperative positioning systems.
