title: Deep Learning Image Embeddings for Ventricular Beat Classification
authors: Stojancho Tudjarski, Nikola Petrovski, Marjan Gusev, Nevena Ackovska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Ventricular arrhythmias pose significant risks to cardiovascular health, necessitating accurate detection from electrocardiogram signals. This study investigates the effectiveness of vector embeddings derived from various convolutional neural networks and contrastive language-image pretraining-based models for classifying ventricular heartbeats presented as images. A comparative analysis revealed that the combination of the ResNet50 model and support vector machines achieved the top F1 score of 79.30%. The results provide insights into how deep neural network models can produce effective vector embeddings of heartbeats to train heartbeat classification models.

title: From Front-End to Perception: A Chisel Generator for Low-Latency FMCW Radar Signal Processing
authors: Nikola Ž. Petrović, Marija Petrović, Vladimir Milovanović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: A Chisel-based, highly configurable hardware generator for FMCW radar signal processing that emits synthesizable range-Doppler FFT pipelines tailored to front-end parameters and inter-ramp timing is presented. The generator parameters that include FFT size, pipeline depth, butterfly type, fixed-point word lengths, and rounding/saturation modes, make the latency/throughput/area trade-offs explicit, enabling rapid designspace exploration across operating regimes. Generated instances can be tailored to the specific radar front-end in use and integrate cleanly with higher-level perception stacks. In addition, a dedicated low-latency path for target range detection reduces end-to-end detection latency for near-field targets.

title: Hybrid Reduced Rating DVR for Fault Ride-Through in Wind Turbine Generators
authors: Mohammad Hushki, Bashar Zahawi
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid dynamic voltage restorer topology aimed to reduce the power rating requirements for a DVR used as a fault ride-through support for a wind turbine generator. An auxiliary dissipation resistor is employed during fault conditions to absorb some of the power generated by the turbine and reduce the DVR power evacuation burden. The design reduces the required power rating of all the DVR's components significantly. A stator voltage control scheme is proposed to ensure voltage support under symmetrical fault conditions. The performance of the proposed topology was evaluated using PSCAD/EMTDC and compared with the conventional DVR voltage restoration circuit. The results confirm that the proposed scheme successfully maintains the stator voltage at pre-fault levels while utilizing a substantially lower-rated DVR.

title: Channel Modeling for UAV-Based Air-to-Ground Communications in Post-Disaster Environments Using Sionna RT
authors: Batuhan Bertan Karagoz, Serdar Inal, Erdal Panayirci, Ertugrul Basar
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Post-earthquake traffic surges pose significant challenges to terrestrial cellular infrastructure in developing regions, where 4G/5G coverage remains sparse. Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) carrying lightweight base stations have emerged as a remedy, yet their propagation characteristics in such harsh environments remain insufficiently understood. This study establishes a comprehensive channel modeling framework tailored to postdisaster scenarios. Computer simulation results gathered from a representative disaster area are assessed through the extraction of path-loss and shadowing parameters.

title: Time Synchronization in OFDM-Based Secure Data Transmission Schemes Over Voice Channels
authors: Zvezdana Kuzmanović, Sara Čubrilović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper proposes reliable time-synchronization sequence for secure data transmission over voice channels. We propose and evaluate a compact synchronization preamble derived from the eCall emergency standard, specifically optimized for OFDM-based speech-like signals transmitted through nonlinear voice channel processing. The preamble employs overlapping pseudo-noise sequences with intentional polarity changes to maintain detection robustness while minimizing overhead. Through extensive testing across diverse real-world environ-ments-including 3G networks, all AMR codec compression modes, and VoIP platforms (Signal, Telegram)-our detection algorithm demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving 100% synchronization success in most scenarios, despite significant signal degradation. The detection maintains reliability even under substantial amplitude attenuation and partial signal loss, while automatically detecting and compensating for channel-induced polarity inversion. This work provides a practical synchronization framework that enables robust real-time communication while preserving the speech-like characteristics necessary for seamless transmission through voice channels.

title: Service Restoration Using Aphid-Ant Mutualism Algorithm in Resilient Distribution Networks
authors: Muhammad Khizer, Raheel Zafar
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Service restoration is crucial for the operation of smart distribution grids during emergency conditions. Self-healing capable microgrids, employing remotely controlled switches and distributed generation, make distribution networks resilient against extreme events by restoring the out-of-service loads. This paper proposes the first application of a recent aphid-ant mutualism (AAM) algorithm with an adaptive exploration-exploitation balance. The AAM algorithm efficiently navigates the highly combinatorial nonconvex solution space to maximize the service restoration of out-of-service loads while satisfying operational constraints. To tackle the key challenge of maintaining a radial topology in subsequent microgrids, this paper proposes a novel graph theory-based heuristic involving a concept of connected components and subgraphs to produce radial configurations. The proposed heuristic repairs the non-radial topologies during the position update process of metaheuristics without limiting the solution space. Case studies on an IEEE 33-bus system under multiple faults indicate that the load restored with switches on all lines is 33 % more than with switches on selected lines.

title: Opportunities of Smart Polymeric Materials for Autonomous Marine Energy and Sensor Systems
authors: Maximo A. Figueroa-Navarro, Ma. A. Martinez-Cosio, G. Gonzalez-Chavez, L.H. Porragas-Beltran, Marcela G. Téllez-Martinez, Gustavo M. Rodriguez-Linan, Jesus Delgado-Maciel, Huber Giron-Nieto, Mario Antonio Peña Meza, Agustín L. Herrera-May, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The ocean provides a vast and sustainable energy reserve capable of powering autonomous networks and distributed sensors in marine environments. Efficient exploitation of this resource is crucial to reduce carbon emissions, enhance scientific exploration, and support coastal surveillance operations. Hybrid nanogenerators—combining triboelectric, piezoelectric, electromagnetic, and thermoelectric mechanisms—have emerged as promising technologies for harvesting wave and current energy while simultaneously functioning as self-powered sensors. Their versatility and cost-effectiveness make them attractive for large-scale deployment, although challenges such as corrosion, biofouling, dielectric degradation, and mechanical fatigue must be addressed to ensure long-term performance. In this review, we present a comprehensive overview of recent progress in the structural design, material engineering, and hybrid configurations of triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) for marine energy harvesting. Special emphasis is placed on the integration of smart polymeric materials and device architectures optimized for harsh oceanic environments. Finally, we provide a forward-looking perspective on the opportunities of TENG-based self-powered sensors within marine IoT frameworks, highlighting their strategic role in advancing blue energy technologies and enabling autonomous monitoring systems.

title: Research on the Influencing Factors and Configuration Paths of the Construction of China’s Innovation Consortium
authors: Guohua Xiao, Huiyue Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Amid the new round of technological revolution and industrial chain restructuring, innovation consortia have become China’s pivotal institutional arrangement for resolving“choke-point” bottlenecks and fostering new-quality productive forces. Yet their performance varies markedly across provinces, industries and years, and single-factor explanations fail to capture the complex causal recipes. Integrating the Strategy Tripod Perspective with configuration theory, this study pioneers the use of dynamic Qualitative Comparative Analysis (QCA) to examine panel data (2021-2024) of 356 innovation consortia that include listed firms, thereby capturing the temporal evolution of causal configurations. Drawing on multi-source databases, we test the configurational effects of three-dimensional antecedents-resources, industry and institutions. Four equifinal pathways to high-performing consortia are identified: (1) institutional synergy and innovation-resource integration, (2)industry-transition orientation, (3)high-level talent traction, and(4)multi-dimensional resource endowment. No single condition is necessary; instead, high performance requires multifactor alignment. Intellectual-property protection and scientific human capital constitute core conditions, while the importance of industrial-cluster advantages increases with policies such as the“chain-master” system. By overcoming the“net-effect” limitation of traditional regressions, the study offers theoretical insights and policy tools for governments to design differentiated and precision support schemes.

title: Effects of Introducing Synaptic Scaling on Spiking Neural Network Learning
authors: Shinnosuke Touda, Hirotsugu Okuno
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) employing unsupervised learning methods inspired by neural plasticity are expected to be a new framework for artificial intelligence. In this study, we investigated the effect of multiple types of neural plasticity, such as spike-time-dependent plasticity (STDP) and synaptic scaling, on the learning in a winner-take-all (WTA) network composed of spiking neurons. We implemented a WTA network with multiple types of neural plasticity using Python. The MNIST and the Fashion-MNIST datasets were used for training and testing. We varied the number of neurons, the time constant of STDP, and the normalization method used in synaptic scaling to compare classification accuracy. The results demonstrated that synaptic scaling based on the $\mathbf{L 2}$ norm was the most effective in improving classification performance. By implementing L2-normbased synaptic scaling and setting the number of neurons in both excitatory and inhibitory layers to 400, the network achieved classification accuracies of 88.84% on the MNIST dataset and 68.01% on the Fashion-MNIST dataset after one epoch of training.

title: Type-1 Fuzzy Logic Systems For Modelling The Mechanical Properties Of Gamma Irradiated 3D Printed Specimens
authors: Wafa’ H. AlAlaween, Abdallah H. AlAlawin, Anas Alwaheba, Moh’d Etoom
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Gamma irradiation has been utilized in many applications. Therefore, its effects on mechanical and chemical properties should be analysed and modelled specifically for 3D printed parts. Therefore, this article investigates and models the effects of Gamma irradiation parameters on the mechanical properties of 3D printed parts produced using the 3D fused deposition printing process. In addition, the interactions and relationships among the 3D printing and Gamma irradiation parameters are also examined and modelled. For this purpose, type-1 fuzzy logic systems (T1FLSs) are established to extract and linguistically represent these relationships before and after irradiation. Such systems allow users to predict the mechanical properties of 3D printed parts before and after irradiation Validated on a real set of experimental data conducted according to the Taguchi L9 orthogonal array, the T1FLSs can successfully predict the mechanical properties with significant performance measures.

title: Correction of Field Amplitudes and Resonance Frequency Levels in FDTD Solutions for Uniform and Nonuniform Grids
authors: Osman Said Bişkin, Talha Saydam, Serkan Aksoy
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Accurate Finite Difference Time Domain (FDTD) simulations are essential for electromagnetic applications such as electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) testing and radar crosssection (RCS) reduction, where incorrect field values can result in failure to meet compliance standards. In this study, an analytical normalization factor is proposed to correct the inaccurate field values (amplitudes and magnitudes) at resonance frequencies caused by the FDTD spatial discretization. This factor is derived from the identity of the Dirac delta function. The correction is applied using uniform, Type I, II, III, and Chebyshev-Gauss-Lobatto (CGL) grids for a three-dimensional (3D) rectangular resonator problem. The numerical results are validated against an exact analytical time domain solution. The proposed correction operation is found to be effective across various grid types.

title: Transient Model of Grounding System Considering Soil Ionization and Frequency-Dependent Electrical Parameters
authors: Tianqi Song, Chun Li, Lei Lan, Shangmao Hu, Lu Qu, Hansheng Cai, Gang Liu, Hailiang Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Lightning strikes are a leading cause of power outages in transmission systems. Evaluating the transient response of grounding systems is critical for effective lightning protection. This response is governed by both soil ionization and frequency-dependent properties. Previous studies often faced challenges in accurately modeling soil ionization and validations limited to experimental currents featuring either short wavefronts or high amplitudes. This paper proposes a transient model for a grid-type grounding system that accounts for both soil ionization and frequency-dependent effects, solved using a Fourier transform-based time-frequency domain transformation method. By integrating layered soil modeling with an electric field-dependent soil ionization model, the approach significantly enhances computational accuracy. The model is validated under triggered lightning conditions considering a soil resistivity of 230 Ω·m, and effectively addresses both short wavefronts and high-amplitude currents, with model predictions deviating from measurements by only 3.5%.

title: RFI-Aware Downlink Spatial Filtering in Terrestrial Networks for Passive Satellite Coexistence
authors: Md Toufiqur Rahman, Hariharan Venkat, Chung-Tse Michael Wu, Narayan B. Mandayam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: We investigate optimal resource allocation techniques for enabling coexistence between filtenna (filter with antenna) equipped multi-user MIMO (MU-MIMO) terrestrial networks (TNs) and passive satellite (SAT) services. We design a digital beamforming strategy that minimizes total transmit power while satisfying user-specific Quality of Service (QoS) constraints and minimizing out-of-band (OOB) interference to passive satellite receivers. By jointly optimizing the digital precoding matrix and the filtenna parameters—especially the number of varactor stages—we achieve significant suppression of Radio Frequency Interference (RFI) to satellite systems. We present two case studies of RFI mitigation in the context of terrestrial base stations operating in: (i) the FR2 n258 band (24.25–27.5 GHz mmWave), focusing on protecting passive weather satellites operating at 23.8 GHz; and (ii) the proposed FR3 band (10–10.5 GHz), focusing on protecting passive Earth Exploration Satellite Service (EESS) operating at 10.6–10.7 GHz. Simulation results show that the joint precoder–filtenna design enables effective mitigation of RFI from TNs to passive SAT services, including designing for trade-offs between TNs’ QoS and RFI levels. Specifically, our results reveal that tightening the RFI-to-SAT suppression by 2 dB at 10.6–10.7 GHz and 23.8 GHz, results in an average rate loss of approximately 45 Mbps and 95 Mbps, respectively.

title: Timing and Frequency Offset Estimation Using NPSS in NB-IoT based NTN
authors: Shreya Arvind, Siva Rama Krishna M., Naveen Mysore Balasubramanya
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: In this paper, a non-terrestrial network (NTN) using low earth orbit (LEO) satellite as the base station and the narrowband internet of things (NB-IoT) as the wireless communication standard is considered. The user equipment (UE) in this NTN is intended to operate without the global navigation satellite system (GNSS), which in turn presents the challenge of accurately estimating the propagation delay and Doppler shift for reliable communication with the LEO satellite. A non-coherent, frequency domain synchronization method is proposed to estimate the delay (timing offset) and Doppler (frequency offset) using the downlink synchronization signal of NB-IoT, i.e., the narrowband primary synchronization signal (NPSS). It is found that the accuracy of estimation obtained by adopting the proposed algorithm meets the benchmark set by the third-generation partnership project (3GPP)s. For subsequent uplink transmissions, first for random access and then for data transmission, it is proposed that the UE pre-compensates for these offsets. It is shown that the precompensation not only helps in UE detection being successful at the random access stage using conventional algorithms used for terrestrial networks, but also results in acceptable data decoding performance.

title: Enhancing Call Center Support for Child Care: Retrieval-Augmented Generation in Serbian
authors: Siniša Suzić, Vuk Stanojev, Milan Sečujski, Nikola Simić, Tijana Nosek, Dragana Bajović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper introduces an enhanced conceptual design of a Serbian-language call center system for assisting parents of young children, based on a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework that relies on a verified external medical knowledge source. The system takes dialogue summaries as input and retrieves contextually relevant text passages from a curated dataset as responses. Human evaluation of the top five generated outputs revealed that the system cannot rely solely on RAG similarity scores and that an additional rescoring mechanism is required to improve output relevance. Two automatic approaches were tested. The performance of the first one, based on atomic fact extraction combined with LLM-based scoring, did not achieve a sufficient level of accuracy. However, the second automatic approach, using a general-purpose large language model (LLM), demonstrated a strong correlation with both expert and non-expert human assessments, confirming its potential as a reliable surrogate for human evaluation.

title: Driving Fatigue Detection Based on Behavioral with Cognitive Task Scenario
authors: Faisal Hadi, Jin Yien Lee, Wen Liang Yeoh, Nan Bu, Osamu Fukuda
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Fatigue is a major contributing factor to traffic accidents worldwide. Research on driver fatigue detection using various methods continues to be developed. Ease of implementation, low cost and more realistic are key challenges in any research study. This study aims to measure fatigue levels using driver behavioral measurement methods with the addition of cognitive load, similar to real-world driver tasks. This study uses cameras to measure driver behavior. The parameters used are body and head posture, gaze, and changes in driver expression. While driving, the driver is given cognitive tasks with certain scenarios. By implementing a one-class support vector machine (OCSVM), it was found that, in general, although each parameter tends to vary between individuals, there are significant anomalies in facial position and rotation along with driving duration, indicating driver fatigue. Meanwhile, there was a slight anomaly in body position, although subjective measurements indicated that all participants felt a higher workload after using the driving simulator.

title: SmartRehab: A Novel Current-Controlled Rehabilitation System with EMG-Driven Functional Electrical Stimulation for Stroke Recovery
authors: Muhammad Ahmed Khan, Hoda Fares, Hemant Ghayvat, Cihan Uyanik, Sadasivan Puthusserypady, Ada Poon, Babak Razavi, Maarten Lansberg, Kimford J. Meador
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: This paper introduces SmartRehab, a novel current-controlled rehabilitation system that integrates an electromyography (EMG)-driven functional electrical stimulation (FES) system for upper limb stroke rehabilitation. The system combines real-time EMG biofeedback, precise current-controlled FES stimulation, and comprehensive performance analysis software to deliver personalized and adaptive therapy. SmartRehab features a dual-microcontroller architecture, enabling uniform coordination between EMG signal processing, high-voltage stimulation control, and wireless communication. The system employs an EMG biofeedback-based stimulation modulation algorithm that dynamically adjusts the current output in response to voluntary muscle activity. This promotes active patient engagement while minimizing the risk of muscle spasms. The SmartRehab Controlling and Analysis Software (CAS) provides an interactive platform for device calibration, therapy execution, real-time monitoring, and structured data management and analysis. A pilot validation study with a single healthy subject demonstrated the system’s capability for smooth, proportional stimulation control based on voluntary EMG activity. The processed EMG envelope triggered FES activation when exceeding a maximum voluntary contraction (MVC) threshold, with stimulation current amplitude modulated proportionally to the EMG signal. The system maintained stable closed-loop control during sustained contractions and ensured smooth termination of stimulation during relaxation. SmartRehab’s integrated approach enables personalized, adaptive therapy and quantitative assessment of functional recovery, paving the way for more targeted and effective stroke rehabilitation protocols.

title: A Web-Based Geospatial Platform for Mapping Public Higher Education Graduates
authors: Diego Briscón-de-la-Torre, Rafael Rivera-López, Daniela Hernández-Barrios, Martin Hernández-Ordoñez, Marco Antonio Cruz-Chávez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This paper presents a web-based geospatial portal for visualizing worldwide locations of university graduates. This system uses an interactive map front-end with a lightweight API and a relational database to deliver searchable and filterable views of graduate data. The system is developed using open source libraries (OpenStreetMap, Leaflet, PHP, and MariaDB). It implements marker clustering, responsive layouts, and simple queries to retrieve results by country and cohort. A component and data-flow design enables straightforward deployment in common web environments and facilitates maintainability. The reported results show that interactive geovisualization complements conventional tracer studies by transforming static reports into an exploratory interface for prospective students, graduates, and administrators. The paper contributes (i) a practical integration of graduate-tracking workflows with interactive web mapping, (ii) an API and schema design that favors portability and low-cost operation, and (iii) implementation guidelines that foreground consent, minimal data exposure, and secure handling of personal information.

title: Implementation of DICOM Security Profiles
authors: Goran Kovačević, Ana Gavrovska
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Information Security has become an increasingly important factor when considering processing of personal or sensitive data. This is especially true in case of medical information, where patient privacy is of utmost importance. The need for data confidentiality, integrity, and availability is addressed by the international telemedicine standard called DICOM (Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine). This work primarily focuses on DICOM Part 15: Security and System Management Profiles, demonstrating implementation possibilities for its security and verification mechanisms. The results obtained will illustrate practical concepts for establishing a more secure and trusted environment for telemedicine purposes.

title: Functional Principal Component Analysis for Classification of Standing Long Jump Stability
authors: Selena Bogojević, Sanja Vujnović, Olivera Knežević, Vladislava Krsmanović
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The standing long jump (SLJ) is a test used to evaluate lower limb strength and function. In addition to jump distance, evaluating stability during the jump is also important. This study investigates stability classification in SLJ by analysing the rotational movements of the lower limbs. Inertial sensors were used to collect kinematic data from 10 healthy subjects. Segment and joint angles were derived based on angular velocities in the sagittal plane. Functional principal component analysis (fPCA) was performed on two datasets: joint angles (MfPCAjoint) and segment angles (MfPCAsegment). The resulting fPCA scores were used as inputs for support vector machine classifiers. The classification accuracy was 86% for MfPCAjoint and 85% for MfPCAsegment, with MfPCAjoint also showing more consistent performance metrics. These results suggest that fPCA scores can effectively describe stability, although a larger dataset is necessary for further validation.

title: Scalable Construction of a Lung Cancer Knowledge Base: Profiling Semantic Reasoning in LLMs
authors: Cesar Felipe Martínez Cisneros, Jesús Ulises Quiroz Bautista, Claudia Anahí Guzmán Solano, Bogdan Kaleb García Rivera, Iván García Pacheco, Yalbi Itzel Balderas Martínez, Kolawole John Adebayo, Ignacio Arroyo Fernández
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: The integration of Large Language Models (LLMs) into biomedical research offers new opportunities for domain-specific reasoning and knowledge representation. However, their performance depends heavily on the semantic quality of training data. In oncology, where precision and interpretability are vital, scalable methods for constructing structured knowledge bases are essential for effective fine-tuning. This study presents a pipeline for developing a lung cancer knowledge base using Open Information Extraction (OpenIE). The process includes: (1) identifying medical concepts with the MeSH thesaurus; (2) filtering open-access PubMed literature with permissive licenses (CC0); (3) extracting (subject, relation, object) triplets using OpenIE method; and (4) enriching triplet sets with Named Entity Recognition (NER) to ensure biomedical relevance. The resulting triplet sets provide a domain-specific, large-scale, and noise-aware resource for fine-tuning LLMs. We evaluated T5 models fine-tuned on this dataset through Supervised Semantic Fine-Tuning. Comparative assessments with ROUGE and BERTScore show significantly improved performance and semantic coherence, demonstrating the potential of OpenIE-derived resources as scalable, low-cost solutions for enhancing biomedical NLP.

title: Deep Learning-Based Intrusion Detection for Automotive Can Networks Using Cnn and Ensemble Models
authors: Salem Titouni, Idris Messaoudene, Yassine Himeur, Diana W. Dawoud, Shadi Atalla, Wathiq Mansoor
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The increasing sophistication of in-vehicle communication systems in the Internet of Vehicles (IoV) era presents new challenges in ensuring secure and reliable data exchange. In this study, we introduce an innovative hybrid classification framework that leverages Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for automated deep feature extraction, coupled with a diverse ensemble of machine learning models-namely XGBoost, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Random Forest (RF). These classifiers independently process the learned features, and their outputs are integrated through a meta-classifier, enabling robust decision fusion. The framework is thoroughly evaluated on the CICIoV2024 dataset, which captures real vehicular telemetry under multiple cybersecurity threat scenarios, such as spoofing and DoS attacks. The proposed method achieves an outstanding accuracy of 99.60 %, a precision of 95.77 %, a recall of 97.22 %, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score of 96.37 %, significantly outperforming traditional machine learning baselines. These results highlight its strong potential for practical deployment in intelligent vehicular cybersecurity systems.

title:
Small Prompts, Big Energy and CO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Impact: Benchmarking Ollama LLMs on CPU and GPU
authors: Ana Kolovska, Marjan Gusev, Dimitar Mileski
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Energy efficiency is a crucial challenge when deploying Large Language Models (LLMs). Electricity usage and related <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CO}_{2}$</tex> emissions can differ greatly depending on model architecture, parameter size, prompt length, and inference hardware. In this study, we evaluate 31 popular Ollama models across CPU and GPU inference, resulting in 60 testing scenarios. Energy and carbon metrics were gathered using the NVML and CodeCarbon libraries, providing insights into the environmental impact of LLM inference in data center settings.

title: Integrating Big Data Analytics with the Aura Blockchain for Supply Chain Insights
authors: Haris Hanjalic, Samed Jukic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: This paper examines the integration of Big Data analytics with the Aura Blockchain platform to enhance supply chain management in the luxury goods industry. The Aura Blockchain Consortium, established in 2019-2021 by leading luxury brands including LVMH, Prada, and Cartier, provides a permissioned blockchain infrastructure for product traceability and authenticity verification. By 2025, the consortium has grown to 50+ member brands with over 50 million luxury products registered on its blockchain. This study explores how combining blockchain's immutable ledger capabilities with big data analytics techniques can yield valuable insights including end-to-end traceability, anti-counterfeiting measures, supply chain optimization, quality control, and enhanced customer engagement. The paper presents a technical architecture for integration, discusses real-world implementations such as digital product passports, and addresses challenges including data privacy, scalability, interoperability, and organizational adoption. The findings suggest that this technological convergence enables luxury brands to transition from reactive to proactive supply chain management, meeting both regulatory requirements like the EU's Digital Product Passport initiative and evolving consumer expectations for transparency and sustainability.

title: Monte Carlo Assessment of Reliability and Connectivity in Coordinated Flights of a Swarm of Small UAVs
authors: Dzhihan Menseidov, Slav Mitev
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Coordinated flight of multiple small unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) is a key enabler for mapping, inspection, disaster response, and ad-hoc wireless networking. However, the robustness of such swarms is strongly affected by limited communication range and stochastic wind disturbances. This paper presents a lightweight Monte-Carlo simulation framework to quantify mission-level reliability for small quadcopter teams, using a four-vehicle DJI-class swarm as a reference. Each UAV is modeled as a discrete-time self-driven particle with Reynolds-style alignment and separation terms, a virtual-structure term for formation keeping, and smooth collision avoidance. Communication links follow a random geometric graph; connectivity is checked via breadth-first search. Wind is modeled as an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process fitted to low-altitude gust statistics. For each operating point (communication radius, wind level) hundreds of randomized trials are run to estimate success probability (no collisions, maintained connectivity) and its confidence interval. Results for light wind show a clear connectivity-driven S-transition in success rate as the communication radius increases, with a practical operating knee around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100-120 ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>. The framework runs efficiently in Octave and can be used to tune controller parameters and communication range before field tests, providing a practical entry point for research and teaching on small UAV swarms.

title: Dualmamba: Joint Classification of Hyperspectral and Lidar Data Using State Space Models
authors: Yiyan Zhang, Hongmin Gao, Zhonghao Chen, Shuyu Fei, Shufang Xu, Jun Zhou
publish: IGARSS 2025 - 2025 IEEE International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium
abstract: Models based on CNNs and Transformers have advanced the joint classification of hyperspectral image (HSI) and LiDAR data, but both have limitations. CNNs struggle with long-range dependencies, while Transformers face scalability issues due to quadratic complexity. The recently introduced Mamba, a State Space Model (SSM), offers high efficiency and retains the capabilities of Transformers. In this work, we apply Mamba for joint classification using a dual-branch Siamese Visual State Space Block. Our model, DualMamba, integrates a Modality-Guided Fusion Block and achieves competitive performance on the Houston2013, Trento, and MUUFL datasets, outperforming several CNNs and Transformers-based models.

title: Fine-Grained Contactless Human Respiratory Measurement Using Millimeter-wave Radar
authors: Yong Wang, Chendong Xu, Bao Zhang, Zijun Huang, Dongyu Liu, Shuai Yao, Kuiying Yin, Qisong Wu, Chaochao Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Respiration is a critical vital sign, and its continuous, fine-grained monitoring provides essential insights for clinical assessment and daily health management. Millimeter-wave radar offers a promising contactless and privacy-preserving solution for respiratory monitoring. However, accurately reconstructing respiratory waveforms from radar echoes remains challenging due to the distributed scattering of the human thorax resulting in the respiratory signals across multiple range bins, especially in a high range-resolution radar system, as well as interferences from the body micro-motions such as random body movements (RBMs). In this paper, we propose mmBreath, a fine-grained respiration monitoring system based on a 60 GHz frequency-modulated continuous wave (FMCW) radar. mmBreath adaptively integrates phase signals from multiple range bins to capture comprehensive respiratory dynamics, and employs an attention-enhanced variational autoencoder (VAE) to reconstruct high-fidelity respiratory waveforms. Furthermore, we introduce a respiratory spectrogram reconstruction task as an auxiliary objective to incorporate time-frequency features, which effectively suppresses interference from RBMs, thus further improving reconstruction accuracy. Extensive experiments on 17 hours of data from 12 human subjects demonstrate that mmBreath achieves superior accuracy and robustness, highlighting its potential for practical, contactless respiratory monitoring in real-world scenarios.

title: A Review of Blockchain Consensus Algorithm Research
authors: Qingshui Xue, Bin Li, Shurui Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Blockchain is a decentralized distributed ledger technology in which consensus algorithms ensure data consistency and system security among mutually untrusted nodes. The choice of a consensus algorithm significantly affects key performance indicators of a blockchain system, such as transaction throughput and energy consumption. This paper presents a systematic review of blockchain consensus algorithms. Based on their underlying principles, mainstream consensus algorithms are categorized into two major types: proof-based and voting-based mechanisms. Proof-based algorithms, such as Proof of Work (PoW) and Proof of Stake (PoS), rely on resource investment to obtain the right to produce blocks; voting-based algorithms, including Raft and Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT), achieve consensus through node collaboration and voting. This paper provides an in-depth analysis of nine representative consensus algorithms and compares them in terms of efficiency, scalability, fault tolerance, and complexity. Finally, the paper summarizes the current challenges and potential research directions in the field, offering theoretical support and reference for the design of future blockchain systems.

title: Hybrid Reinforcement Learning-based Path Planner for Narrow Vertical Parking Scenarios
authors: Yunxiang Liu, Daizheng Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Autonomous parking technology faces significant challenges in narrow environments, primarily due to the complexity of path planning caused by space constraints. In tight spaces, feasible parking paths are limited by environmental constraints, and the vehicle must perform complex maneuvers and adjustments within a confined area. Tight spaces refer to parking slots where the clearance between the vehicle width(Wv) and the surrounding obstacles is less than 0.85 meters on either side, complex maneuvers denotes multi-stage re-orientation movements (one-, two- or three-maneuver strategies) required when the available corridor width H falls below $5 m$, necessitating additional backup or forward arcs to reach the target pose, based on Case B and Case C in Section IV.A. This not only increases the difficulty of path planning but also demands higher precision in the path’s execution. Previous research on path planning has mainly been categorized into two types: learning-based methods and non-learning-based methods. The former excels in exploring feasible paths through environmental learning but suffers from reduced path planning capability when the actual environment differs significantly from the learned one. The latter relies on predefined constraints to plan paths, but these constraints are often stringent in narrow environments, reducing path feasibility. To address these limitations, the proposed hybrid planner (1) maps reinforcement-learning agent actions to Reeds-Shepp (RS) curves, constraining the search space and thereby preserving planning capability in previously unseen layouts; and (2) introduces an environment partitioning mechanism that divides the parking zone into subregions, enabling the agent to focus exploration where constraints are tightest and thus substantially improving overall path feasibility in constrained scenarios. We trained and validated the model in a simulated environment. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach achieves a high planning success rate in progressively narrower parking scenarios, with a success rate of over 83.6% across all tested cases.

title: Weakly Supervised Crack Extraction via Score-CAM with Multi-Scale Patch Fusion and False-Positive Filtering
authors: Tatsuma Okada, Yusuke Fujita
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Intelligent Informatics and Biomedical Sciences (ICIIBMS)
abstract: Concrete crack detection is essential for maintaining aging infrastructure. However, conventional deep learning methods rely heavily on pixel-level annotations, which are costly and time-consuming to obtain. To overcome this limitation, we propose a weakly supervised crack extraction framework that eliminates the need for pixel-level labels. A ResNet- $\mathbf{5 0}$ model with a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) is trained using image-level or patch-level annotations, and Score-CAM is employed to visualize crack regions. To enhance detection accuracy, a Multi-Scale Patch Fusion (MSPF) module is introduced, which processes subdivided image patches and fuses their outputs, thereby emphasizing local features and improving the detection of fine cracks. Although MSPF enhances crack detection, it can occasionally generate false positives due to background textures. To further address this issue, we introduce a False-Positive Patch Filtering (FPPF) module, an auxiliary CNN that automatically suppresses erroneous detections. Experiments on a benchmark dataset show that the combination of MSPF and FPPF achieves higher recall and IoU than the baseline, enabling robust crack detection without pixel-level annotations. Overall, the proposed framework substantially reduces annotation costs while maintaining high extraction accuracy, providing a scalable and practical solution for automated infrastructure inspection.

title: Automation and Correlation of Audio and Video Recordings
authors: Jovan Zlatanovic
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: Artificial intelligence today represents the main theme, whether it improves our environment and our lives. This paper will explain the idea of how video signals can be influenced based on different frequencies, i.e., audio signals. Audio and video signals create dependence and autonomy in work, as well as the necessary automation using artificial intelligence (AI) tools. Quick decisions, analysis, and accuracy are enabled by AI tools. Besides broadcasts, this concept could be applied to festivals, concerts, and large events. The entire broadcasting system in this way would give a new dimension to the development of a spectacle and would present every part of participant to the viewers. Safety and accuracy contribute to the quality of the event.

title: Sustainable Energy Management via Integrating Model Context Protocol with Home Assistant
authors: Adel Oulefki, Amine Bechar, Abbes Amira, Fatih Kurugollu, Ahcene Bounceur, Yassine Himeur
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of IoT devices in smart environments necessitates scalable, user-friendly management systems. However, current platforms often lack integration between conversational agents and realtime Digital Twin (DT) supervision. This paper proposes a novel architecture that integrates the Model Context Protocol (MCP) with Home Assistant (HA) to manage a 3D DT dashboard for a smart campus for better energy consumption using a natural language interface powered by Cursor. The system employs an intermediary component, “mcp-proxy”, which bridges the MCP client (Cursor) and the HA MCP server, allowing bidirectional communication over standard input/output and SSE protocols. Through natural language queries, users can monitor and control IoT devices represented within a 3D DT model. The deployment includes smart equipment in the lab, kitchen and mailroom, demonstrating the complete data flow from user interaction to structured response. A case study on energy consumption monitoring illustrates how the proposed system can be used in practical applications. Experimental evaluations with various LLMs confirm the feasibility, responsiveness, and contextual accuracy of the proposed solution. This work highlights the potential of agentic LLMs and open protocols in enabling intuitive and intelligent management of smart sustainable environments.

title: Evaluation of Machine Learning Algorithms for Indoor Localization of NB-IoT Module Based on Radio Channel Quality
authors: Dusan Bortnik, Vladimir Nikic, Milan Lukic, Ivan Mezei
publish: 2025 33rd Telecommunications Forum (TELFOR)
abstract: The number of Internet of Things edge devices in indoor environments has experienced exponential growth in recent years. Under these circumstances, the maintenance of deployed equipment has become increasingly critical, particularly with respect to determining device positions. Traditional methods that rely on GNSS often yield suboptimal results in indoor environments, both in terms of accuracy and energy efficiency. In this paper, we present a novel machine learning (ML)–based approach for indoor localization of NB-IoT devices using a custom-built dataset comprising various radio channel quality parameters. Multiple models were evaluated, with the Histogram-based Gradient Boosting classifier achieving the highest localization accuracy of 95.3%, while RLC and MAC throughput parameters had the highest impact on the results.

title: Evaluation of NY State Decarbonization Policies and Goals Through the Lens of Grid Infrastructure Constraints
authors: Yusef Esa, Kirn Zafar, Ahmed Ali A. Mohamed
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Driven by the urgent need to address climate change and achieve significant reductions in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, energy systems worldwide are undergoing transformative changes. In New York State, the Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act (CLCPA) has set ambitious decarbonization targets. Meeting these goals necessitates the large-scale integration of distributed energy resources (DERs), such as solar photovoltaic (PV) panels, electric vehicles (EVs), and battery energy storage systems (BESS), into the electrical distribution network (EDN). However, a critical question arises: can the existing distribution infrastructure handle this transition without requiring costly or prohibitive upgrades? This study examines New York State's decarbonization policies through the lens of distribution grid constraints, leveraging available tools to analyze the interplay between policy goals and infrastructure capabilities. A central aspect of this research involves leveraging an actual distribution network model from a dense urban region in New York City. The study evaluates scenarios of load growth, driven by electrification—and the intermittency of renewable energy. Projections for 2025, 2030, 2035, and 2045 form the basis for these analyses. Preliminary results reveal critical insights into the challenges and opportunities of grid modernization. High penetration of DERs and electrification can lead to an increase in undervoltage issues, network transformer and feeder loading up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70 \%, 40 \%$</tex> and 19 % respectively, till 2045 as compared to the base case. This necessitates the infrastructure upgrades unless batteries are strategically sited and controlled. Additionally, coordinated charging of EVs and batteries is essential to prevent new peak loads during off-peak hours.

title: Retrieval-Augmented Generation for Maternal Healthcare: Design and Evaluation of a Clinical Question-Answering System in Spanish
authors: Adriana Noguera, Andrés L. Mogollón-Benavides, Santiago Rua, Daniel Sanin-Villa, Juan C. Tejada
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is emerging as a key tool to strengthen maternal health through predictive models, remote monitoring, and decision-support systems. This work presents the design and evaluation of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)-based Question Answering (QA) pipeline applied to clinical content on pregnancy. The system integrates preprocessing, semantic segmentation, and embedding generation using biomedical RoBERTa and multilingual SBERT models, with vector indexing in ChromaDB for efficient retrieval. A Colombian official guideline on maternal health served as the knowledge base, processed into semantically coherent fragments to enhance contextual retrieval. Experimental evaluation with hybrid strategies-combining semantic and keyword-based search with Cross-Encoder reranking-achieved a hit@5 accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{9 0 \%}$</tex>, demonstrating the pipeline's capacity to deliver clinically grounded answers. Results highlight the relevance of adapting AI systems to Spanish-language and low-resource contexts, addressing challenges such as algorithmic transparency, data representativeness, and clinical validation. The proposed approach contributes to more equitable, accurate, and explainable maternal healthcare support systems.

title: Perspectives of Triboelectric–Electromagnetic Hybrid Nanogenerators for Smart Agriculture Monitoring
authors: Antia Ivett Álvarez-Bernabé, Ernesto A. Elvira-Hernández, Víctor Augusto Jarvio-Córdova, Gerardo Mora-Aquino, María Cristina López-Méndez, Pedro Javier García-Ramírez, Enrique Delgado-Alvarado, Agustín L. Herrera-May
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: Smart agriculture can contribute to ensuring food security and a sustainable society. However, many rural areas lack access to Internet of Things (IoT) sensor networks and low-cost renewable energy sources, which can decrease their food productivity. To address these challenges, triboelectric-electromagnetic hybrid nanogenerators offer a technological solution for harvesting wind, water flow, and raindrop energy, converting it into electrical energy to power IoT sensors or serve as self-powered devices. Herein, we report recent advances in the development of triboelectric-electromagnetic hybrid nanogenerators for smart agriculture sensing. In addition, the performance and applications of these hybrid nanogenerators in smart agriculture are discussed. Finally, perspectives on the design, materials, and reliability of these nanogenerators are presented. The use of artificial intelligence and digital twins can help to improve the performance and reliability of hybrid nanogenerators for applications in agriculture 4.0.

title: A Lightweight DL Model for Smart Grid Power Forecasting with Feature and Resolution Mismatch
authors: Sarah Al-Shareeda, Gulcihan Ozdemir, Heung Seok Jeon, Khaleel Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: How can short-term energy consumption be accurately forecasted when sensor data is noisy, incomplete, and lacks contextual richness? This question guided our participation in the 2025 Competition on Electric Energy Consumption Forecast Adopting Multi-criteria Performance Metrics, which challenged teams to predict next-day power demand using real-world high-frequency data. We proposed a robust yet lightweight Deep Learning (DL) pipeline combining hourly downsizing, dual-mode imputation (mean and polynomial regression), and comprehensive normalization, ultimately selecting Standard Scaling for optimal balance. The lightweight GRU-LSTM sequence-to-one model achieves an average RMSE of 601.9 W, MAE of 468.9 W, and 84.36 % accuracy. Despite asymmetric inputs and imputed gaps, it generalized well, captured nonlinear demand patterns, and maintained low inference latency. Notably, spatiotemporal heatmap analysis reveals a strong alignment between temperature trends and predicted consumption, further reinforcing the model's reliability. These results demonstrate that targeted pre-processing paired with compact recurrent architectures can still enable fast, accurate, and deployment-ready energy forecasting in real-world conditions.

title: Enhancing Lightning Protection for Distribution Transformers in High Risk Grid Regions
authors: Murad Anwer, Hadi E. Al-Almaei, Joseph Potvin, Ibrahim A. AlMohaisin, Ali F. Ali Assiri, Tom A. Short
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: Distribution transformers in medium-voltage over-head networks are particularly susceptible to lightning-induced failures, especially in regions with challenging terrain and frequent storms. A study was conducted by Saudi Electricity Company in collaboration with the Electric Power Research Institute that investigated effective lightning protection strategies for transformers through field assessments, forensic transformer analysis, and laboratory tests simulating highly affected regions of Saudi Arabia. The research evaluated the limitations of existing protection schemes, particularly poor grounding and excessive ground lead lengths, and proposes enhancements such as low-voltage surge arresters and riser pole arresters. Recommendations on optimal arrester ratings, installation practices, and grounding improvements to enhance system resilience were provided. The results show improved protection performance and serve as a basis for future field implementation and standard revisions.

title: Robots on the Edge: Latency-Critical and Sensitive Applications on 6G-Enabled Infrastructure
authors: Manuel Patchou, Ching-Chi Lin, Niklas A. Wagner, Tim Gebauer, Kevin-Ismet Šabanović, Jannik Malcher, Stefan Böcker, Jian-Jia Chen, Christian Wietfeld
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Disaster relief missions are often time-sensitive, making network latency a critical factor for robotic operations. While robot applications designed for these missions must be robust in challenging conditions, the underlying networks must also support latency-critical operations. In this work, we formulate two rescue robotics scenarios with differentiated latency criticality. The first scenario, Chemical Hazard Control, focuses on immersive user experience, while the second, Catching the Falling Rod, is a latency-critical mission. We benchmark both scenarios with emulated network latency to assess their performance. The second scenario is further deployed on an Open RAN 6G research infrastructure, where ROS 2 node deployment strategies are investigated for meeting strict latency requirements. The results show that a 100ms latency increase can significantly impact mission outcomes in the first scenario, increasing completion time by 50% and quadrupling the failure rate. In the second scenario, proactive resource scheduling is essential for meeting real-time requirements. These findings validate 6G’s hyper-reliable low-latency goals as essential for real time robotic controlDemo video available online at: https://tiny.cc/6GRealtimeRobotics.

title: A Novel NaaS API Framework for L4S Enforcement: Enhancing Traffic Management Through NEF, PCC, and AI-Driven UPF in 5G Networks
authors: Ameer Shohail L, Ashish Goswami, Mohammed Rashid
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper presents a novel Low Latency, Low Loss, Scalable Throughput (L4S)-enabled NaaS API framework for dynamic QoS (Quality of Service) enforcement and congestion-aware traffic management in 5G Core networks. By integrating the Network Exposure Function (NEF), Policy and Charging Control (PCC), and AI-driven User Plane Function (UPF), the framework enables Explicit Congestion Notification (ECN)-based congestion signaling, dual-queue architectures, and predictive policy adjustments for latency-sensitive applications such as AR/VR, cloud gaming, and industrial automation. Modeled congestion scenarios show significant improvements over static QoD (Quality on Demand) approaches, with average end-to-end latency reduced by over 80% and SLA violations decreased by nearly 80%. The proposed design also supports monetization through intent-based QoS provisioning and premium service tiers, offering CSPs a scalable, programmable alternative to static resource allocation.

title: Accurate Estimation of the Duration of Network Interruption Caused by the User Equipment Mobility in the Real-World Cellular Networks
authors: Marika Kulmar, Muhammad Mahtab Alam
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Connected and automated mobility applications need a short delay, while procedures related to user equipment mobility can cause an interruption of the network service. In this paper, we study how to accurately estimate the duration of network interruption time caused by user mobility in cellular network. We generate a data traffic, collect timestamps of packets and information about the serving cell delivering the packet, and calculate packet inter-arrival times during the cell change. The results show that using the user datagram protocol traffic, the network interruption time had the least variance.

title: Analysis of an Architecture for Integrated Sensing and Communication in 5G OpenRAN
authors: Daniel Lindenschmitt, Tobias Jung, Prudhvi Kumar Kakani, Torsten Reissland, Norman Franchi, Hans D. Schotten
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: This paper analyzes the functional requirements and architectural considerations for Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) in a 5G Open Radio Access Network (OpenRAN) environment, with emphasis on secure and modular deployment. Focusing on a mono-static, half-duplex sensing approach, it evaluates radar setup options, signal types, and processing placement within the Radio Access Network (RAN), considering performance and security implications. The proposed architecture minimizes hardware modifications by leveraging sniffer Radio Units (RUs) and existing OpenRAN fronthaul interfaces, while protecting sensitive In-phase and Quadrature (I/Q) data and control traffic against potential attacks. Security threats, such as passive sensing, spoofing, and privacy violations, are mapped to mitigation strategies within the OpenRAN framework. The result is a deployment blueprint applicable to both Public Land Mobile Networks (PLMNs) and Non-Public Networks (NPNs), supporting future 6G ISAC capabilities in a standards-compliant manner.

title: Enhancing Electromagnetic Conceptualization Through AI-Driven Simulation in First-Year Bioengineering Education
authors: Andrei Solorzano Perez, Jose Manuel Nieto-Jalil, Adrián Isrrael Tec Chim, David I. Ibarra-Zarate, Claudia Hernandez Mena, Jorge Alvarez
publish: 2025 Mexican International Conference on Computer Science (ENC)
abstract: This study examines integrating generative AI-combining ChatGPT with Wolfram Language-to support simulation of electric and magnetic fields in first-year engineering at Tecnológico de Monterrey. Grounded in constructivism and project-/challenge-based learning, the intervention situates vector-field modeling in authentic contexts, using Coulomb's law for electric fields and Biot-Savart/Ampère's laws for magnetic fields across common geometries. In a quasi-experimental, non-equivalent groups design (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=44$</tex>; six weeks; same instructor), the experimental group used AI-assisted modeling while the comparison group relied on traditional resources. Outcomes included conceptual understanding (pre/post concept test), quality of simulations (programming rubric; inter-rater ICC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.82$</tex>), and perceived usefulness of AI (Likert survey). Analysis showed an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 7.3$</tex>-point post-test advantage for the AI group (95 % CI 3.5-11.1), a large standardized effect (Hedges' g <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\approx 0.90$</tex>), and a positive perception- performance association (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\beta} \approx \mathbf{0. 7 8}$</tex>; 95% CI 0.52-1.04). Students using AI produced more accurate, interpretable simulations and improved spatial reasoning. Findings support careful integration of generative AI to strengthen conceptual reasoning and modeling in early electromagnetism. Limitations include the quasi-experimental design and single-context implementation; future work will test longitudinal retention and transferability.

title: Economic Analysis of A Rule-Based PV-BESS-H2 Hybrid System
authors: Rajitha Wattegama, Michael Short, Geetika Aggarwal, Raj Naidoo
publish: 2025 IEEE PES Conference on Innovative Smart Grid Technologies - Middle East (ISGT Middle East)
abstract: This study evaluates the techno-economic performance of a rule-based grid-interactive hybrid system combining solar photovoltaic (PV), battery energy storage (BESS), and proton exchange membrane (PEM) electrolysis for green hydrogen production. The proposed model uses real hourly PV generation data for Middlesbrough, UK (2024) and day-ahead market price signals to drive a rule-based dispatch. The novelty lies in the analysis of the prioritized control sequence serving a fixed 1 MW load, charging the BESS, conditionally running the electrolyser, and exporting to the grid optimised to capture value from both price-responsive arbitrage and hydrogen sales. Simulations for PV capacities from 1.0-3.0 MW with a 0.5 MW/2 MWh BESS and a 250 kW electrolyser show that PV oversizing strongly improves utilisation of surplus energy. The 3.0 MW scenario achieved the highest annual combined revenue <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\pounds 22,410)$</tex> and reduced grid import costs by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 21 \%$</tex>, with a payback of 13.4 years at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pounds 5 / \text{kg}$</tex> hydrogen. The findings confirm that coupling BESS and hydrogen pathways with simple price-driven operational strategies can enhance revenue diversity and cost savings, providing a scalable strategy for distributed renewable energy systems.

title: No-Op and Obfuscation of Network Operations Data for Network Security and Privacy
authors: Baw Chng
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: As communication networks collect ever more detailed operational data, fueled by advancements in big data analytics and AI — and with quantum computing on the horizon to enable quick data analytics at very large scales — the risk of malicious actors exploiting these data using side-channel attack techniques to reveal sensitive operational details that network operators wish to keep confidential also increases significantly. To address this emerging threat, the author proposes a proactive and preemptive defense: deliberately injecting noise and uncertainty into network operations data by integrating "no-op" (no operation) primitives into protocol designs and normal network traffic. By obfuscating network behavior through these benign operations, the approach aims to undermine the efficacy of side-channel analytics, protect network privacy, and complicate reconnaissance efforts by adversaries. The discussion also takes into consideration the complexity of modern network deployments, emphasizing the myriad intermediaries and operators that handle traffic and data, and highlights the growing potential for exploitation as data collection proliferates. The proposed method provides a defense mechanism against the evolving landscape of network-based side-channel attacks.

title: The Selection of Relevance: Content-Selection Strategies in Semantic and Task-Oriented V2X Communications
authors: Luca Lusvarghi, Javier Gozalvez
publish: 2025 IEEE Future Networks World Forum (FNWF)
abstract: Semantic and task-oriented Vehicle-to-Everything (V2X) communications have been recently proposed to address the scalability challenges of future V2X networks by focusing on the relevance of the exchanged information. Relevance captures the impact of the transmitted information meaning on the intended receiver’s task by taking into account the intended receiver’s context, e.g., its position, speed, and planned driving intentions. Due to its context-dependent nature, relevance can greatly vary across different driving scenarios and different intended receivers, as each vehicle experiences unique context conditions. Hence, selecting the content of the transmitted messages to provide all intended receivers with the required relevant information can be a challenging task, especially in the broadcast V2X communication domain where each transmitting vehicle has multiple intended receivers. This work analyses the impact of different content-selection strategies on the performance of semantic and task-oriented V2X communications. The obtained results show that contentselection strategies play a critical role, particularly under constrained communication scenarios, and that their impact can significantly vary under different driving scenarios. Our analysis highlights key tradeoffs in the content-selection task and offers valuable insights for the design of effective contentselection strategies able to maximize the performance of semantic and task-oriented V2X communications.
